title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: The Android Sign Step is not required if signing is configured in your project’s build.gradle file. If so, running the Android Build Step (or the Gradle Runner Step) signs the output (APK or AAB) automatically. Nevertheless, we recommend that you use the Android Sign Step to sign your project in an easy and secure way.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: jarsign and apksigner

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: APKs can be signed with either jarsigner or apksigner. For APKs, if you wish to use apksigner to sign your project, then in the Android Sign Step you have to first set the Enables apksigner input to true and leave the APK Signature Scheme input on automatic. This way apksigner checks your APK’s minimum and target SDK versions and chooses the required schemes. It signs your project with V1 scheme if your minimum supported version is low and it also signs with other schemes for newer systems.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Please note that AAB files can only be signed with jarsigner. The Step uses jarsigner if it detects a file ending with .aab

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Upload your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow after the Step that builds your APK or AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Bitrise uses the above Environment Variables and sets them as inputs into the respective fields of the Android Sign Step. Once the Step runs, it produces either a signed APK or an AAB. The signed APK or AAB is used in deploy Steps, for example, the Google Play Deploy Step or the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The latter deploys the APK/AAB on the Artifacts tab. You can also use Release Management to deploy your app once you built an installable artifact.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Downloading your keystore file

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can download your keystore file to the project directory using the File Downloader Step:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body:
- file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - destination: "$HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks" #native android#

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: If a Step requires the keystore file, make sure to include that Step AFTER the File Downloader Step.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: After this Step, my_keystore.jks will be available at $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: To build and deploy an Ionic or Cordova app on Bitrise, you need to digitally sign both the Android and iOS project (if you're building both) and then use the Cordova Archive or the Ionic Archive Step to build the app before deploying it.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: You can deploy the successfully built app to:

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Online stores, such as the Google Play Store or Apple's App Store.

title: Deploying Ionic/Cordova apps
body: Bitrise.io: the generated binaries will be available on the Artifacts tab of the build's page. You can download them from there or share them with others via the public install page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to bitrise.io Step uploads all the artifacts related to your build into the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: You can share the generated binary file (APK for Android or an IPA file for iOS) with your team members using the public install page. The public install page is a URL you can share with others who can install the generated app binary on their device. You can also notify user groups or individual users that your APK or IPA file has been built.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: In the Notify: User Roles, add the role so that only those get notified who have been granted with this role. Or fill out the Notify: Emails field with email addresses of the users you want to notify.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure you set those email addresses as Secrets! These details can be also modified under Notifications if you click the eye icon next to your generated binary in the Artifacts tab.

title: Deploying a cross-platform app to bitrise.io
body: If you want the Step to generate a public install page for you, set the Enable public page for the App? input to true.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You can use the Deploy to Google Play Step in your Workflow to upload your digitally signed AAB/APK to the Google Play Store.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Note that if you’re building for both iOS and Android in one project, and either of your apps fails, the whole Cordova archive/Ionic archive Step will fail.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The Platform input needs to be set to device.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: The archive Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure code signing for your app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Configure Google Play access.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: You only need to do this for your very first Google Play deployment of the app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Google Play Step after the Cordova Archive or Ionic Archive Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Fill out the required input fields as follows:

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Service Account JSON key file path: This field can accept a remote URL so you have to provide the Env Var which contains your uploaded service account JSON key. For example: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Package name: The package name of your Android app.

title: Deploying your Android project to Google Play
body: Track: The track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Note that if you’re building for both iOS and Android in one project, and either of your apps fails, the whole Cordova archive/Ionic archive Step will fail.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Platform input needs to be set to device.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The archive Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Configure iOS code signing for your iOS project.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step to your Workflow, after the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Password or, if you use two-factor authentication on App Store Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed.

title: Deploying your iOS project to the App Store

title: Getting started with Expo projects
body: Get started on Bitrise by signing up via email or a Git provider, connecting a repository, and running the first build for your Expo app.

title: Getting started with Expo projects
body: You can generate React Native projects with the React Native CLI or with the Expo CLI. Expo is a toolchain that allows you to quickly get a React Native app up and running without having to use native code in Xcode or Android Studio.

title: Getting started with Expo projects
body: In this guide we discuss how to set up, test, code sign and deploy your React Native project built with the Expo CLI.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: First, let’s see how to add a React Native Expo project to bitrise.io.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Log in to Bitrise and go to the Dashboard.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Click the New CI project button.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Under Project access, select the Workspace that will own the project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Set the privacy of the project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Privacy is final

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You cannot change this setting later! If you realize you've accidentally added your project as a public project even though you need it to be private, you'll have to delete the project and add it again.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Private projects are only accessible to you, your Workspace members and those who are invited to work on a project. They require authentication to access the repository of the project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Public projects expose their bitrise.yml and their build logs to everyone. If you have a public project’s build URL, you can view its build log, to help with troubleshooting, for example. Public projects do not require authentication and they cannot have SSH keys.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Select one of two options to set your repository URL:

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: With the Select remote repository option, you can select a repository from a list of repos from a connected Git provider account. Choose the Git provider from the dropdown menu, then click Select a repository... and select the repository from the list.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: The Enter URL manually option does not require a connected Git provider account: you can simply enter the URL and proceed to the authentication phase. We strongly recommend using an SSH URL, unless you are setting up a public project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Repository URL

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You will be able to change your project's repository URL later. You can also connect or disconnect your account to Git provider services at any time.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: If you signed up for Bitrise using a Git provider account, that one is already connected and you can select any of your repositories from it.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: If you use an OAuth connection, you need to add an SSH key in the Authorize Bitrise section.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You don't need SSH keys if:

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Your project is a public project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You connect to your Git repository via a GitHub project installation.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Auto-add a generated SSH key to your repository: We recommend using this option. We automatically generate an SSH key pair and register the public key to your repository. Requires your connected Git provider account to have admin rights to the repository.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Copy a generated SSH key to your Git provider manually: We generate an SSH key pair for you and you can copy the public key and register it manually to your Git provider. It is useful if, for example, you need to access multiple repositories with the same SSH key.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Add your own SSH key to Bitrise: You can generate your own SSH key and paste the private key here after choosing this option. You also need to add the public key to the repository manually. To generate your SSH key pair: Generating your own SSH keypair.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Configure SSH keys at any time

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: If you can't set up a valid, working SSH key connection at this time, don't worry: proceed with adding your project. You can set up the SSH connection afterwards: Configuring SSH keys.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Select the default branch of your repository. This branch should contain the configuration of your project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: If you successfully configured SSH access in the previous step or if you're adding a public project, Bitrise will parse your repository and allow you to select a branch from a dropdown menu.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: If you didn't configure repository access, you need to type the branch name manually.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You can change the default branch of the project later.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: In the next step, choose Yes, auto-detect configuration. Bitrise will scan your repository and attempt to set up a stack and default Workflows based on the results of the scan. In most cases, we recommend choosing this option.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Project type

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Detecting a project type serves to assist in the initial configuration of your project. But don't worry, you can change every setting, including the project type, at any time after you added the project.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Wait while Bitrise is validating your project. If automatic validation fails, you can set the project up manually.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Register a webhook when prompted so that Bitrise can start a build automatically when code is pushed to your repository, or a pull request is created.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: Once you are done, click View Project Page to go to the newly added project's home page. From there, you can start editing your Workflows and run builds.

title: Adding an Expo project to Bitrise
body: You have successfully set up your React Native project on bitrise.io! Your first build gets kicked off automatically using the primary workflow. You can check the generated reports of the first build on the Artifacts tab on your Build’s page.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: If the Bitrise project scanner has successfully scanned your project, Run npm command or Run yarn command Steps will be included in your default Workflows. These Steps can install the missing Javascript dependencies for your app.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: For native Android dependencies, you can use the Install missing Android SDK components Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: For native iOS dependencies, you can use, among others, the Brew install Step or the Run CocoaPods install Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: To install Javascript dependencies with npm:

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: Using Yarn instead of npm

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: In this guide, we're using npm to install Javascript dependencies. However, you can use the Run yarn command Step: it can install missing JS dependencies without any additional configuration required.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: Make sure your Workflow includes the Run npm command Step.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: In The 'npm' command with arguments to run input variable, type install.

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: Using the npm ci command instead of npm install

title: Installing dependencies for Expo apps
body: If you already have an up to date package-lock.json file in your project, we recommend using the ci command in The 'npm' command with arguments to run input. Using npm ci can not only result in much faster build times compared to npm install but more reliable builds as well.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: You can use React Native’s built in testing method, called jest to perform unit tests.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: Add the run npm command Step to your Workflow.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: In the npm command with arguments to run input field, type test.

title: Testing your React Native app
body: For more detailed guides on React Native testing, check out Testing React Native apps.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: Bitrise's Test reports add-on allows you to view and analyze your test results in one convenient place. By default, these tests won't show up in Test reports. However, you can export the results: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step. The basic process is as follows:

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: Generate a junit.xml file during the build.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: For example, you can use jest-junit to prepare a report.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: Add the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step to your Workflow.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: In the Path where custom test results reside input, add the folder in which your junit.xml file and other test results are located.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: In the Test result search pattern input, set *.xml.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: In the The name of the test input, set the name of the test run.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: The test results will be under this name in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Adding React Native test results to Test reports
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Deploying your Expo project
body: Bitrise supports Expo Application Services (EAS) for Expo projects, and the default deploy Bitrise Workflow uses the Run Expo Application Services (EAS) build Step to trigger a build on EAS.

title: Deploying your Expo project
body: In case you don’t want to use EAS, you can use Turtle CLI for your Bitrise Workflows. See this Workflow Recipe for details.

title: Getting started with macOS projects

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Once you created your app, the first build will run based on the automatically created primary workflow. You can check it out in the app’s Workflow Editor: click the app’s name on your Dashboard then click the Workflow tab

title: Testing your macOS app
body: If your app does not have test targets defined, the primary workflow will NOT include the Xcode Test for Mac Step.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: If you have test targets defined, the primary Workflow of a macOS app includes the two Steps you need to run your Xcode tests, and view their results on bitrise.io:

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Xcode Test for Mac

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Code signing files

title: Testing your macOS app
body: Running Xcode tests and deploying their results to Bitrise do not require any code signing files. So don’t worry about them just yet!

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Xcode Test for Mac Step runs the pre-defined Xcode tests. It has a default configuration that does not need to be modified: if the tests are written correctly, they will work. You can find the same configuration options in Xcode, too.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io will deploy the following to the Logs and Artifacts tab of the build:

title: Testing your macOS app
body: your Xcode test results.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: your raw xcodebuildoutput log.

title: Testing your macOS app
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step also exports the results of the Xcode Test for Mac Step to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: To install and test the app on other physical devices, you will need to create and export an .app or .pkg file. This requires setting up code signing. In the example, we’ll be exporting an app with the development export method: you cannot upload such an app to Testflight but you can test it, for example, on the devices of your internal testers.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Automatic Provisioining

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: The example procedure described here uses manual provisioning, with the Certificate and profile installer Step. However, Bitrise also supports automatic provisioning but it is not in the scope of this guide.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: You will need:

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: the automatically created deploy workflow.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: a Development certificate (a .p12 certificate file).

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: a Development type Provisioning Profile. For a macOS project, the file extension of the provisioning profile is .provisionprofile.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Set the code signing type of your project in Xcode to either manual or automatic (Xcode managed), and generate the package file locally.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Collect and upload the code signing files.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: The tool can also upload your code signing files to Bitrise - we recommend doing so! Otherwise, upload them manually: enter the Workflow Editor and select the Code signing tab, then upload the files in their respective fields.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Go to your app’s Workflow Editor, and select the deploy workflow in the WORKFLOW dropdown menu in the top left corner.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Check that you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow. It must be before the Xcode Archive for Mac Step (you can have other Steps between the two, like Xcode Test for Mac).

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Check the Export method input under the app/pkg export configs input group of the Xcode Archive for Mac Step.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: If you selected development when you added the app to Bitrise, you don’t need to change the input. Otherwise, manually set it to development.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: Start a build.

title: Code signing and exporting a macOS app
body: If you uploaded the correct code signing files, the Certificate and profile installer Step should install your code signing files and the Xcode Archive for Mac Step should export an .app or .pkg file with the development export method. If you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your workflow, you can find the binary package file on the Artifacts tab of the build page.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: If you set up your code signing files and created an .app or .pkg file for your internal testers, it is time to involve external testers and then to publish your macOS app to the App Store. Let’s see how!

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Developer ID

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: If you want to distribute your app outside the App Store, you can sign it with a Developer ID. This method is not in the scope of this guide but on Bitrise, it works the same way: you just need to upload the appropriate code signing files.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: To deploy to the App Store, you will need these code signing files:

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: a Mac App Distribution certificate.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: a Mac Installer Distribution certificate.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: On your local machine, set up App Store code signing for your project in Xcode, and export an .app or .pkg file. If this fails locally, it will definitely fail on Bitrise, too!

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Collect and upload the code signing files.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Go to the app’s Workflow Editor and create a new Workflow: click the + button next to the Workflow dropdown menu, enter the name of your new Workflow and in the BASED ON dropdown menu, select deploy. This way the new Workflow will be a copy of the basic deploy Workflow.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Click on the the app/pkg export methods , and set the Export Method input of the Xcode Archive for Mac Step to app-store.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: You can export multiple binaries with different export methods: use the Export macOS Xcode archive Step in your Workflow, to do so.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Add the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step to your workflow, after the Xcode Archive for Mac Step but preferably before the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Provide your Apple credentials in the Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader (formerly iTunes Connect) Step.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: The Step will need your:

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Apple ID.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: password or, if you use two-factor authentication on iTunes Connect, your application password.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: Don’t worry, the password will not be visible in the logs or exposed - that’s why it is marked SENSITIVE.

title: Deploying the app to the App Store Connect
body: And that’s it! Start a build - if everything went well, you should see your app on Testflight. From there, you can distribute it to external testers or release it to the App Store.

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: Bitrise offers full support for using Unity software on our build machines: convenient license management, up to 40 GB of disk space, and a mobile-focused build environment that allows users to easily create both iOS- and Android versions of their Unity projects.

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: To be able to build a Unity app on Bitrise, you need to:

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: Add your project as a Bitrise app.

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: Download and install Unity on the virtual machine running your build.

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: Add your licenses to Bitrise and activate it during the build.

title: Unity software integration on Bitrise
body: Build your project.

title: Adding a Unity project as a Bitrise app
body: Add your Unity project as a new app. The project scanner doesn't support Unity software so it won't detect your project as a Unity project so you can skip automatic configuration and register the project as Other.

title: Adding a Unity project as a Bitrise app
body: We recommend using an Xcode stack: these contain the most important Android tools, too. You can build both iOS and Android versions of your Unity apps on our Xcode stacks.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: To be able to build a Unity project on Bitrise, you'll need to install Unity software on the virtual machine at the start of your build. This is the standard practice of running Unity software in the cloud and it only takes a few minutes.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: To be able to build a Unity project on Bitrise, you'll need to install Unity software on the virtual machine at the start of your build. This is the standard practice of running Unity software in the cloud and it only takes a few minutes.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Xcode stacks

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Make sure you use an Xcode stack to run Unity builds: the instructions on this page are valid for installing Unity on our Xcode stacks.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Look up the Unity software version you want to download on the Unity download archive.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Find the Unity Editor of the version you need, and copy its download link.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: The link will look something like this: https://download.unity3d.com/download_unity/b16b3b16c7a0/MacEditorInstallerArm64/Unity.pkg.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: You will also need the download links for the two platform support packages (iOS and Android). You can find these on the LTS Releases page.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Add a Script Step to the start of your Workflow.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: In the Content input, add the curl commands to download the necessary Unity packages. For example:

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body:
#workaround for .NET issue https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/64103
export COMPlus_ReadyToRun=0
envman add --key COMPlus_ReadyToRun --value 0

#download unity pkg for Apple Silicon
curl -o ./unity.pkg http://download.unity3d.com/download_unity/8af3c3e441b1/MacEditorInstallerArm64/Unity-2021.3.12f1.pkg

#download android support platform
curl -o ./android.pkg http://download.unity3d.com/download_unity/8af3c3e441b1/MacEditorTargetInstaller/UnitySetup-Android-Support-for-Editor-2021.3.12f1.pkg

#download iOS support platform
curl -o ./ios.pkg http://download.unity3d.com/download_unity/8af3c3e441b1/MacEditorTargetInstaller/UnitySetup-iOS-Support-for-Editor-2021.3.12f1.pkg

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Replace the download links with the links for the versions you need.

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: Optionally, you can install a Unity software version for Apple silicon that supports Rosetta:

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body:
#download unity pkg for Apple Silicon with Rosetta support
curl -o ./unity.pkg http://download.unity3d.com/download_unity/8af3c3e441b1/MacEditorInstaller/Unity-2021.3.12f1.pkg

title: Downloading and installing Unity software on Bitrise
body: If successful, you should be able to find Unity software at /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity.

title: Setting up Unity licenses on Bitrise
body: In alignment with Unity's policy, only paid plans are supporting command line… which means you need to add Unity license pools on Bitrise to be able to build a Unity project. Our build machines will be able to find the licence for your Workflow but you need to activate it by providing your Unity email address and password.

title: Setting up Unity licenses on Bitrise
body: Multiple licenses required

title: Setting up Unity licenses on Bitrise
body: To run multiple builds concurrently, you need separate license keys for each build. For example, if you want to run three builds of a Unity app at the same time, you need at least three separate Unity licenses.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Log in to Bitrise and hover over the left navigation bar.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Make sure you have the right workspace selected in the Workspace menu.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Select Settings.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: On the left, select Integrations.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Select the License pools tab.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Click Add license pool.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Fill out the fields.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: You must set:

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: A name: that's how you can find your pool in the Workflow Editor.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: An Environment Variable key: this is how you can use the license in a build script.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: The license keys themselves. A license key can't have a space or any special character other than underscore in it.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Click Save.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Open the Workflow Editor for the app you need and go to the Licenses tab.

title: Adding Unity license pools
body: Select a license pool for each Workflow where you need them.

title: Activating a Unity license
body: When trying to run a build, you need to activate your Unity license first. This requires providing your Unity email address and password. We recommend using Secrets to store these.

title: Activating a Unity license
body: Deactivating a license

title: Activating a Unity license
body: Once your build is finished, we strongly recommend deactivating the Unity license so you can reuse it:

title: Activating a Unity license
body: /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity -quit -batchmode -logFile -returnlicense

title: Activating a Unity license
body: Create two Secrets to store your email address and password. We recommend using the following keys:

title: Activating a Unity license
body: UNITY_EMAIL, with your email address as the value.

title: Activating a Unity license
body: UNITY_PW, with your Unity password as a value.

title: Activating a Unity license
body: Add the following code to a Script Step that comes after the Step installing Unity software in the Workflow:

title: Activating a Unity license
body: /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity -quit -batchmode -serial "$UNITY_SERIAL" -username "$UNITY_EMAIL" -password "$UNITY_PW" -logfile

title: Activating a Unity license
body: Use a Utility Workflow

title: Activating a Unity license
body: A best practice is to create a utility Workflow that contains this Step, and run it before each Workflow that requires Unity.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: Once everything is set up, you can run a build using Unity software on Bitrise. You can build both an Android and an iOS version of your app, even in the same Workflow.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: To run a build using Unity software on Bitrise:

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: Add Unity license pools to Bitrise.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: Activate your Unity license in the build.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: Download and install Unity on the virtual machine.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: To build the Android version of your app, add a Script Step and in the Content input, add the following:

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity -nographics -quit -batchmode -logFile -projectPath "$BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR" -executeMethod BitriseUnity.Build -androidSdkPath "$ANDROID_HOME" -buildOutput "$BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/mygame.apk" -buildPlatform android

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: To create an Xcode project for the iOS version of your app, add the following to the Script Step:

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity -nographics -quit -batchmode -logFile -projectPath "$BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR" -executeMethod BitriseUnity.Build -buildOutput "$BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/xcodebuild" -buildPlatform ios

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: Create and export an IPA from the Xcode project.

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: When you are done, deactivate your license:

title: Running a build using Unity software
body: /Applications/Unity/Unity.app/Contents/MacOS/Unity -quit -batchmode -logFile -returnlicense

title: Infrastructure
body: Bitrise is a platform, above all: you do not have to download anything to use it, you do not have to run it on your own computer or servers - we take care of all of that.

title: Infrastructure
body: That also means you do not have to worry about infrastructure, either: maintenance, tools, virtualization are all our job and our concern.

title: Infrastructure
body: On Bitrise, we use virtual machines (VM) to run your builds: every build runs in a new VM, and each VM is discarded immediately after the build has finished.

title: Infrastructure
body: A stack is the type of virtual machine we can use to run your build. For example, for a native iOS app, the best stack is one of our Xcode stacks. Stacks come with all of the necessary tools pre-installed, and are regularly updated to make sure they will serve all of your needs.

title: Build machines
body: Bitrise offers Xcode and Linux stacks. Each stack has a large number of pre-installed tools.

title: Build machines
body: Both Linux and Xcode stacks are available on several different build machine types. Each machine type offers several options with varying computing power, depending on your subscription plan. You can configure a default machine type for each of your app and you can also set Workflow-specific machine types. You can do this when selecting stacks for your app: Setting the stack for your builds.

title: Build machines
body: Changing machine types using the API

title: Build machines
body: You can also change build machine types for all apps owned by a single user or Workspace using the API: Changing machine types in all apps at the same time.

title: Build machines
body: Each Bitrise build machine has its own IP address range: you can allowlist these IP addresses to be able to access our build machines from, for example, a private cloud: Configuring network access with IP allowlists

title: Build machines
body: For more information about build and code security, see Code security.

title: Configuring network access with IP allowlists
body: You can access Bitrise virtual machines from behind a private network or a firewall. To do so, allowlist our build machine IP addresses in your network.

title: Configuring network access with IP allowlists
body: Our datacenters are behind a set of public static IP addresses, with the virtual machines having their own internal subnets behind these addresses. Depending on your company security policy, you may need to allowlist the public IP addresses to be able to access the build machine: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines.

title: Configuring network access with IP allowlists
body: Similarly, the Bitrise background workers powering app.bitrise.io UI and related control plane, configuration management, signaling to your services are accessible at a set of static IP addresses. Allowlisting these addresses can ensure you can still receive build status updates or that Bitrise can access the bitrise.yml file: IP address ranges for Bitrise backend workers of your app.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: For most users, who host their repositories on cloud-based service providers, there is no need for any network configuration to be able to use Bitrise. All we need is permission to access the repository and for that, an SSH key or an access token is enough.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: However, your company security policy might not allow unknown and unauthorized IP addresses to communicate with the servers where your code is being stored - either on your own datacenter or in a private cloud. In that case, Bitrise won’t work unless the relevant IP addresses are added to your allow list.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: You will see IP addresses from the following ranges as source when your Bitrise build machines reach out to your services like Git to download your source code, or call into your test backend services, or any other services you run outside Bitrise that are required to be reached as part of your CI workflow.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Allowlist the entire subnet

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: If the provided public IP address is a subnet, you need to allow the entire subnet on your network! For example, 208.52.166.128/28 means all IP addresses between 208.52.166.128 and 208.52.166.143 (208.52.166.128, 208.52.166.129, 208.52.166.130, and so on, all the way to and including 208.52.166.143) have to be allowlisted.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Multi-tenant vs Single-tenant

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: The build machine IP ranges listed below are for the Bitrise multi-tenant environment. Depending on your organization's security requirements, it may not be advisable to allow access to your network from the Bitrise multi-tenant IP range. For organizations with enhanced security requirements, you can:

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Connect by VPN.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Select a single-tenant environment.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Deploy runners to your own AWS account.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: Feel free to contact us if you have questions.

title: IP address ranges for the Bitrise build machines
body: External and internal IP address ranges for the build machines

title: IP address ranges for Bitrise backend workers
body: Bitrise backend workers are operating behind firewalls and NAT gateways. There are some use cases when our backend workers need to reach your services.

title: IP address ranges for Bitrise backend workers
body: These addresses may be relevant if you use self-hosted Git services or store your bitrise.yml file in the repository. In this way Bitrise can, for example, access the bitrise.yml file, or send build status updates on commits and pull requests in a self-hosted repository.

title: IP address ranges for Bitrise backend workers

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: To free up additional disk space on Bitrise build machines, delete unneeded tools and resources by using a Script Step in your build.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: If you need additional disk space on Bitrise build machines, you can always delete tools and resources that you do not use. You just need to use a Script Step at the start of your build.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: java.io.IOException: No space left on device

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: If you get the java.io.IOException: No space left on device error during a build, you can try to free up additional space with the below method - the error indicates there's no more space available on the build machine.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Check your stack's System Report on GitHub.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: The System Report includes the list of pre-installed tools and their version on the stack.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Find the tools you don't need in your build.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Add a Script Step to the beginning of your Workflow.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: In the Script content input of the Step, add the necessary commands to uninstall the tools.

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: Uninstalling unneeded tools

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: If your app doesn't need Android SDK tools, you can remove them with the following commands in your Script Step:

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body:
sudo rm -rf /usr/local/share/android-sdk 
sudo rm -rf /opt/android-ndk

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: You can delete iOS simulators that you don't use:

title: Freeing up storage space on build machines
body: sudo rm -rf ~/Library/Developer/CoreSimulator/Profiles/Runtimes/iOS\\ 10.3.simruntime/

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise offers multiple build machines with different specifications and credit costs. You can choose between them based on your needs.

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise offers multiple build machines with different specifications and credit costs. You can choose between them based on your needs.

title: Build machine types
body: You can track how much time you spent building your apps on each machine type with Insights: Utilization metrics.

title: Build machine types
body: Machine availability by subscription plan

title: Build machine types
body: Not all machines are available on all subscription plans. Visit the pricing page to find out which machines are available on your plan!

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise build machine types

title: Build stacks
body: The Bitrise build stack defines the virtual machine version used to run your builds. The main types are macOS stacks and Android & Docker stacks.

title: Build stacks
body: The build stack indicates the virtual machine version that we will use to run your build. The main stack types are:

title: Build stacks
body: macOS stacks: These stacks run on a macOS operating system and each one includes multiple Xcode versions. Ideal for building iOS apps. They also have Android tools installed if you want to use them to build a cross-platform app.

title: Build stacks
body: The Android & Docker stack: These stacks run on Linux operating system in a Docker environment. They have all Android tools installed and they are ideal for building native Android apps.

title: Build stacks
body: Free disk space

title: Build stacks
body: Each stack has at least 100 GB of free disk space. You can check each stack's exact available disk space on the relevant stack report page: Bitrise stack reports.

title: Build stacks
body: Each build runs in its own virtual machine and the virtual machine is rolled back to a saved state, the “base box” state, after the build is finished. This way your builds are always protected by changes made by others and by your previous builds and you can use a stable environment to define your build workflow, since no state persists between builds.

title: Build stacks
body: Passwordless sudo enabled

title: Build stacks
body: The user account that is used for the builds is configured to have passwordless sudo enabled. This way you are able to install all the extra things you need for your builds and for other automation. If a tool is not preinstalled on your stack of choice, you can install it yourself - see the guide.

title: Build stacks
body: After adding your app to Bitrise we will select an appropriate stack for it. You can change the stack at any time on the Stacks & Machines tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Build stacks
body: After selecting the stack you want to use, you’ll see a short description of the stack with an additional link to learn more about that specific one (for example, to see what tools are preinstalled, and which versions, on the selected stack).

title: Build stacks
body: Stack status types

title: Build stacks
body: Stack prepare types

title: Stack update policy
body: Bitrise stacks are updated every week: some stacks are completely rebuilt while on others only certain cache archives are updated.

title: Stack update policy
body: Bitrise stacks include the most important tools for mobile development pre-installed and ready for use. Our goal is to make Workflows simple and make your builds fast and efficient. These tools change continuously: old versions become deprecated and unsupported while new versions are released with new features and breaking changes.

title: Stack update policy
body: Stacks on bitrise.io are updated regularly. The updates contain one or more of the following kinds of changes:

title: Stack update policy
body: Tool upgrade: An already installed tool is upgraded to the latest version (for example, the git CLI is upgraded from 2.9.1 to 2.9.5).

title: Stack update policy
body: Tool addition: A new tool is added (for example, the latest Android emulator system image becomes preinstalled when a new Android version is released).

title: Stack update policy
body: Tool removal: A tool version is removed if it reaches end-of-life and poses a security risk, making another version of the tool the default (for example, Ruby 2.7 is removed, making Ruby 3.0 the new default).

title: Stack update policy
body: Platform changes: Changes to major components, like Xcode on macOS stacks, OS versions, Android SDK.

title: Stack update policy
body: Using the previous version of a stack

title: Stack update policy
body: Updating a stack to a new version might cause problems with some builds. To help ease the transition, you can use the previous version of a stack for 2-3 days after an update: Using the previous version of a stack.

title: Stack update policy
body: For more information on what tools are available on the different stacks, check out our relevant guide: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: You can select macOS stacks based on the Xcode version you need. Under the hood, one VM image contains multiple Xcode versions installed and your requested Xcode version is activated at runtime before your Workflow starts.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: As a rule of thumb, Xcode minor versions of the same major version share the same VM image, but there might be exceptions based on compatibility issues and other considerations.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Versioning

title: Xcode stack updates
body: When talking about versions, we use semver terminology, regardless of how the various tools define their versions.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Stacks have a lifecycle and have four different states: Edge, Stable, Frozen and Removed.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Edge: These stacks are for previewing upcoming versions and changes. They are updated in-place regularly, and they include the latest stable release of Xcode, the latest beta release of Xcode (if available) and the latest stable version of pre-installed tools. Regular weekly updates could add or remove tools, as well as upgrade the OS. Backwards compatibility for weekly updates is not guaranteed on an Edge stack. Run builds on Edge stacks to preview upcoming tool version changes (such as Ruby 3.2 becoming the default) and get access to the latest pre-release Xcode (such as Xcode 15 Beta).

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Stable: These stacks are only updated with Xcode patch versions, and with critical security fixes. For maximum reliability and reproducible builds, we recommend pinning exact tool versions in Workflows instead of relying on the stack defaults (for example, pinning a Ruby version).

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Frozen: These stacks are no longer updated and flagged for removal in accordance with the Stack deprecation and removal policy. The stack is still available for yourbuilds but you will see the final removal date on the UI. Preinstalled tools are not updated, so it’s your responsibility to keep up with bugfixes and security patches.

title: Xcode stack updates
body: Removed: These stacks are no longer available to use.

title: State transitions for Xcode stacks
body: During the lifecycle of a stack it will transition between states when triggered by new Xcode and macOS releases. Stacks transition as follows:

title: State transitions for Xcode stacks
body: Edge to Stable.

title: State transitions for Xcode stacks
body: Stable to Frozen.

title: State transitions for Xcode stacks
body: Frozen to Removed.

title: Edge stack updates
body: Edge stacks provide a way to preview and test upcoming changes. Xcode Beta versions become available as Edge stacks while final Xcode releases become available as new Stable stacks. Xcode Edge stacks change when:

title: Edge stack updates
body: The first Beta version of a new major Xcode version is released.

title: Edge stack updates
body: The first Beta version of a new minor Xcode version is released.

title: Edge stack updates
body: A new version of an Xcode Beta version is released.

title: Edge stack updates
body: When an Xcode minor version is released as a beta, it becomes available as an Edge stack. Other Edge stacks do not transition to Stable until the beta version in question is released as a GA version.

title: Edge stack updates

title: Stable stack updates

title: macOS releases
body: The exact macOS version is always highlighted on the stack report pages.

title: macOS releases
body: When a new major macOS version is released, we upgrade the Edge stacks to the new OS after an internal testing period.

title: macOS releases
body: As a general rule, we don’t upgrade macOS on Stable stacks to avoid unexpected build failures. We wait until a future Xcode release starts requiring the new OS version (for example, Xcode 15.0, 15.1 and 15.2 are compatible with macOS Ventura, but 15.3 requires Sonoma). Once this happens, the Stable stack variant of this Xcode version is based on the new major OS version, while older Stable Xcode stacks remain on the older OS version.

title: macOS releases
body: While the new major OS is not available as a Stable stack, we recommend testing it on one of the Edge stacks. We are looking for your feedback, including edge cases and performance regressions.

title: Events not triggering a state transition
body: Not all Xcode releases trigger a transition. For example, Xcode beta minor version releases do not trigger an Edge to Stable stack transition: the new beta version simply replaces the old one. Xcode patch releases do not trigger an Edge to Stable stack transition. Instead, the Stable stacks will be updated in place with the new patch version.

title: Linux stack updates
body: Linux stacks on Bitrise are based on Ubuntu LTS releases. Each Bitrise stack is based on one Ubuntu LTS version and never gets upgraded to another. Instead, we release new stacks and sunset older ones over time.

title: Using the previous version of a stack
body: We regularly update the Bitrise stacks based on user requests and external tooling changes. These updates can potentially introduce breaking changes, despite our efforts to avoid those.

title: Using the previous version of a stack
body: For those cases, we provide a temporary option to use the previous version of a given stack for a few days after the release of a new version.

title: Using the previous version of a stack
body: This is meant to be a temporary mechanism only. Because of infrastructure reasons, we can't keep the previous release available forever. Usually, the previous version is removed a few days after a successful release.

title: Using the previous version of a stack
body: Once the previous version becomes unavailable, new builds run on the latest version even if this feature is enabled.

title: Using the previous version of a stack
body: If a previous version is not available for a given stack at a given time, the switch is inactive and the feature can't be turned on. Any build triggered will run on the current version of the stack.

title: July 2024
body: Mentions of dependency manager cache updates. Both Cocoapods and Homebrew have better mechanisms now than cloning the entire registry git repo, and these newer mechanisms (Cocoapods CDN, Homebrew API) are enabled on stacks now. When stacks are updated, you can expect the on-disk repos to be up-to-date, but Stable stacks are no longer strictly updated weekly if there are no other changes to release.

body: The breaking changes to stable macOS stacks (once a year when a new Xcode major version is released) no longer apply to older, existing stable stacks, only the newly released stable stack. For example, when Xcode 16.0 is released, the planned breaking changes only apply to the Xcode 16.0 stable stack. Xcode 14.x and 15.x stable stacks won’t receive breaking changes.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: On Bitrise, Android stacks are supported for around two years; Xcode stacks are deprecated gradually as new Xcode versions are released.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: We don't keep all stacks around forever: our aim is to provide you with the latest tools to help you build the best app you can. However, we don't expect you to rework your build configuration every time a stack update comes out: you can keep using your reliable older stacks for a long time.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: Some older stacks are frozen when a new major version of Xcode is released. When a stack is frozen, you can still keep using it, but the stack will no longer get any updates, and at that point, we strongly recommend switching to a newer, active stack.

title: Stack deprecation and removal policy
body: After stacks have been frozen for a year, they are removed when the next major version of Xcode is released.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: We offer a wide variety of Xcode stacks in order to make sure you do not need to immediately switch when a new version comes out. Our policy is as follows:

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: Keep the three most recent major versions of Xcode.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: Keep the two most recent minor versions for each major version of Xcode.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: We base our policy on Apple's current release cadence: first beta in June, general availability in September.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: The life cycle of a major Xcode version on our stacks is 36 months.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: For 24 months, the stack is active and maintained according to our stack update policy.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: After 24 months, the stack becomes frozen for 12 months and it will no longer receive updates. At this point, we strongly recommend migrating to an active stack.

title: Maintaining Xcode stacks
body: After the end of the 36th month, the stacks of the major Xcode version are removed.

title: Deprecating Linux stacks
body: A Linux stack is supported for about two years, roughly in sync with Ubuntu LTS (long term support) releases.

title: Deprecating Linux stacks
body: When a previous Linux stack reaches end of maintenance, we deprecate the stack and earmark it for removal. At that point you can no longer select the stack for your apps. But the apps that are already using those stacks can keep using them until removal.

title: Deprecating Linux stacks
body: In all cases, there will be a minimum of four weeks' notice provided for the removal of these stacks. You can see all upcoming stack deprecations on this page. We also recommend subscribing to RSS updates of important announcements about stacks.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Bitrise's Android stacks run on Linux-based virtual machines that are created from Docker images. You can find all the image files on GitHub.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: For our Linux-based stacks, we use standard Docker images, hosted on Docker Hub. You can find the available stacks, called Ubuntu for Android & Docker, in our stack reports.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Pre-installed tools

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: All stacks have a large number of pre-installed tools available: Preinstalled tools on Bitrise stacks

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Every build runs in a new VM, not just in a new container. The VM is destroyed right after the build. This allows us to grant you full control over Docker and the whole environment.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: When your build starts on a Docker-based stack, we volume mount the /var/run/docker.sock socket into your container (similar to calling docker run -v /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock .... You can find a description about this access granting method here).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: The docker binary has to be installed inside the base Docker image because docker started to migrate from a single-binary solution to dynamically loaded components, and simply sharing the docker binary is not sufficient anymore.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: We install Docker in every one of our Docker images so that you don’t have to do anything if you use our image, or you base your own image on our Docker images.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: This means that you have access to docker in your container, and can use other tools which use docker, like docker-compose. You can, for example, configure and run tests and other automations on website projects using docker-compose.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: You can call docker info, docker build, docker run, docker login, docker push exactly how you would on your own machine.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: Shared volumes

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: If you want to run docker in your build and share volumes, please note that only those volumes can be shared that are shared with the base docker container (the one your build is running in). This is due to how docker handles volume sharing. Everything under /bitrise can be mounted as a volume, but no other path is guaranteed to work with --volume mapping.

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: It means that if you use the standard paths and you use relative paths to mount volumes, it’ll work as expected, as the default source code directory is located inside /bitrise (by default it’s /bitrise/src in our Docker images).

title: The Android/Linux/Docker environment
body: What WON’T WORK, however, is if you change the source code directory to be located outside of /bitrise, or you want to mount a folder with an absolute path outside of /bitrise.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: If you need a Java or JDK version which is not installed on our Android stacks, follow this guide. The example below will install Java/JDK 1.14 with a Script Step. You can adapt it to the version of your choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Add the Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: In the Script content input of the Step, add your script:

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: The example below installs Java 14 but feel free to replace the openjdk-14-jdk and java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64 parts with your version of choice.

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
 
add-apt-repository -y ppa:openjdk-r/ppa
apt-get update -qq
apt-get install -y openjdk-14-jdk
update-java-alternatives -s /usr/lib/jvm/java-1.14.0-openjdk-amd64
echo "done"

title: Installing a Java version on an Android stack
body: Start a new build. This Script Step can be the very first Step in the Workflow, as it does not depend on anything else.
