title: Ruby versions on Bitrise
body: Ruby is pre-installed on all our stacks. You can view the actual versions in the system reports. However, you can use a different Ruby version if that's what your app needs.

title: Managing Ruby versions in your builds
body: If you need a specific Ruby version, there are two main ways to make sure it will be installed on the virtual machine.

title: Managing Ruby versions in your builds
body: You can use a .ruby-version file. We recommend this method.

title: Managing Ruby versions in your builds
body: You can use a Script Step to override the Ruby version.

title: Using a .ruby-version file
body: The best way is to simply include the .ruby-version file in the root of your repository. The file should specify the version you need.

title: Using a .ruby-version file
body: The Run CocoaPods Install Step looks for the .ruby-version file in the root of your repo. When you run the Step, it will install and activate the specified version. We plan to implement this feature for all Bitrise Steps that need Ruby.

title: Using a .ruby-version file
body: Common version manager tools such as Ruby Version Manager, rbenv, or asdf can read the file and automatically activate the specified version.

title: Using a .ruby-version file
body: Setting up a version manager locally

title: Using a .ruby-version file
body: If you set up one of the version manager tools locally, you can have a consistent setup between your local environment and the CI environment.

title: Using a Script Step
body: An alternative solution is to add a Script Step to your Workflow to override the default Ruby version. You can declare the version you want in the RUBY_VERSION Environment Variable and then use that Env Var with either rbenv or asdf.

title: Using a Script Step
body: Best practice: using asdf

title: Using a Script Step
body: Using asdf commands is the recommended way to manually switch Ruby versions in a Script Step.

title: Using a Script Step
body:
- script:
 title: Activate correct Ruby version
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 set -ex
 RUBY_VERSION=3.2.2
 asdf install ruby $RUBY_VERSION
 asdf global ruby $RUBY_VERSION

title: Supported Ruby versions
body: Before changing the Ruby version, make sure that the necessary tools support the version you need.

title: Supported Ruby versions
body: Fastlane supports Ruby 3 which means the Deploy to App Store Connect with Deliver and the fastlane Steps definitely support Ruby 3.

title: Supported Ruby versions
body: The recent versions of CocoaPods support Ruby 3. However, older legacy gems in your Gemfile or pods in your Podfile might not be compatible. Generally, we recommend always updating gems and pods to the latest version, and testing a Ruby version change in a local environment first.

title: Code security
body: Every Bitrise build runs in a new virtual machine that has no access to previous builds. We do not store your source code and you can set up how it is accessed.

title: Code security
body: To guarantee the security of your code, every Bitrise build runs in its own, clean virtual machine and we discard the whole virtual machine after the build finishes, erasing every file your build uses and every change you make during your build.

title: Code security
body: This is also true for the Android & Docker stacks, which use Docker containers to run the build. The build itself still gets a full virtual machine where no other Docker container is started, only the one used as the environment of the build. In short, we only use Docker containers to manage the environment, not for build environment isolation - that’s ensured by using full virtual machines for every build.

title: Code security
body: This way your builds are always protected from changes made by others and from your previous builds, no one else can access your code and you can use a stable environment to define your build Workflow. Every build is completed in an isolated environment, unrelated to any previous or parallelly running builds.

title: Source code
body: We don’t store your source code. The source code is only accessed on the build machines (virtual machines) the way you define it in your Bitrise configuration. If you don’t have a Git Clone Step or some other Step that accesses your Git repository in your configuration, then the source code won’t be touched at all. At the end of the build the whole virtual machine is destroyed. As such, any change you made to your source code on the virtual machine will be lost unless you commit your changes and push them to a remote repository.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The files you upload in the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor are stored on Amazon S3 in a way that it’s only accessible for the web servers.

title: Code signing and other files
body: The required credentials are not stored in any database, it is only available in the web servers’ environment. Build servers can’t access the files directly either. When a build starts, the web server generates a read-only, time limited access URL for these files, using Amazon S3 pre-signed URLs.

title: Passwords
body: Passwords are stored in a hashed, encrypted form. We are encrypting the passwords with bcrypt algorithm, using multiple stretches.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Bitrise offers two types of custom build platforms for enterprises: dedicated build platforms behind the Bitrise firewall and private build platforms on the user's own environment.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Using a custom enterprise build platform means running your Bitrise builds on virtual machines (VM) dedicated and specifically configured to your needs. With a private cloud, you have complete control over how and when your builds run.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Bitrise offers two types of custom build platforms for enterprises:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated build platform: a set of dedicated machines behind the Bitrise firewall. These machines will have the same public IP address as any Bitrise build machine but they are reserved for your exclusive use.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Private build platform: this solution includes your own firewall, storage capacity, and computing environment. This allows you to create a custom virtualization configuration, as well as a site-to-site VPN. With the latter, data will never leave your network and you do not have to separately connect to a VPN with each build.

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: The private build platform is an advanced set-up with plenty of configuration options. To learn more about the details, contact us!

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Check out the most important differences between the dedicated and the private build platforms:

title: Customizable enterprise build platforms
body: Dedicated vs private build platform

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: Customers using the Bitrise-managed Linux machines can take advantage of advanced capabilities with Docker containers.

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: Beta feature

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: This feature is in beta and we do not recommend using it with production applications. Register here for the beta.

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: Customers using the Bitrise-managed Linux machines can take advantage of advanced capabilities with Docker containers:

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: We deliver our Linux build environment with all Android-related tools and technologies preinstalled so native and cross-platform Android Workflows can be run efficiently. With the new Services feature, Android mobile apps can be end-to-end tested by running the emulator and the required back-end Service on the same machine.

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: Our customers can start up Bitrise-managed builds using their own Docker image stored in their private repository to ensure all third-party and in-house custom tools are present at runtime. Using the same local and CI Docker image for development becomes easy, reducing complexity and the chance of issues due to different environments.

title: Docker containers on Bitrise
body: With the Container feature, customers can use any Docker image stored in a public or private repository, powering all web development CI/CD builds.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Container support enables the use of any Docker container image as an execution environment for a group of Steps within a Workflow. It also enables running background services : this can be used, for example, to run advanced testing scenarios.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Beta feature

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: This feature is in beta and we do not recommend using it with production applications. Register here for the beta.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Container support enables the use of any Docker container image as an execution environment for a group of Steps. It also enables running background services: this can be used, for example, to run advanced testing scenarios.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Using containers comes with several potential benefits:

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Full control over your build environment.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: No need to install dependencies during the build itself. This reduces build times and complexity.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: You can use the same environment that you use on your local development environment to test and build the app.

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: Linux only

title: Using containers in Bitrise Workflows
body: This is a Linux only feature. macOS-based environments are not supported.

title: Step execution containers
body: Docker containers can be defined for any Bitrise app in the bitrise.yml configuration file. You define the container in the top level of the configuration file and then refer to it in a with group in the Workflow configuration.

title: Step execution containers
body: To do so, you need to add a containers property to your bitrise.yml file. Under this property, you need to define:

title: Step execution containers
body: The ID of the containers. It will be used to reference this container.

title: Step execution containers
body: The name of the Docker image you want to use.

title: Step execution containers
body: The version of the image.

title: Step execution containers
body:
containers:
 node-21:
 image: node:21.6
 node-18: 
 image: node:18.19

title: Step execution containers
body: Once the containers are defined, you can refer to them in a with group within the Workflow. Steps within the same with group will run in the same container. You can define multiple with groups within the same Workflow.

title: Step execution containers
body:
containers:
 node_22:
 image: node:22
 python:
 image: python:3.12

workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - with:
 container: python
 steps:
 - script:
 title: Validate our changes using a custom python script
 inputs:
 - content: python3 validate.py
 - with:
 container: node_22
 steps:
 - script:
 title: NPM install

title: Step execution containers
body: Getting images

title: Step execution containers
body: You can use any public Docker image from Docker Hub.

title: Step execution containers
body: For detailed configuration options, check out Container API reference.

title: Step execution containers
body: Testing an app with Node.js

title: Step execution containers
body: This example shows a simple use of the container property to enable Steps or groups of Steps to use different execution environments.

title: Step execution containers
body: We test our application using two different versions of Node.js, using the public node images from Docker Hub. We also run a custom Python script to validate our changes before testing them.

title: Step execution containers
body:
containers:
 node_22:
 image: node:22
 node_20:
 image: node:20
 python:
 image: python:3.12

workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - git-clone@8: {}
 - with:
 container: python
 steps:
 - script:
 title: Validate our changes using a custom python script
 inputs:
 - content: python3 validate.py
 - with:
 container: node_22
 steps:
 - script:
 title: NPM install
 inputs:
 - content: npm ci
 - script:
 title: NPM test
 inputs:
 - content: npm test
 - with:
 container: node_20
 steps:
 - script:
 title: NPM install
 inputs:
 - content: npm ci
 - script:
 title: NPM test
 inputs:
 - content: npm test

title: Step execution containers
body: When the ci Workflow is running:

title: Step execution containers
body: The git-clone Step will run on the default Bitrise environment.

title: Step execution containers
body: The first script Step is wrapped in a with group and it has a container image defined, so a new container is created from the image: python:3.12. The host will share the necessary working directories with the container so the cloned repository will be available inside the container.

title: Step execution containers
body: The Step that executes the Python script will be executed inside this newly created Python container.

title: Step execution containers
body: -The ci Workflow has two more with groups, these will run after each other, both configured with a different container image for node. Each with group can be configured with different images which are not shared across the groups, but they all use the same volume mounts in case there is a need for file sharing.

title: Step execution containers
body: Both groups install the npm packages and run the tests respectively in their own environment using different Node.js versions.

title: Step execution containers
body: Use debian/ubuntu images

title: Step execution containers
body: Our Script Steps use bash and therefore they might fail with alpine based images as they usually do not come with that installed. We recommend using debian/ubuntu based images.

title: File sharing across containers
body: To enable file sharing across different containers and the host Bitrise environment, the following folders are shared each time you run a Docker container on Bitrise:

title: File sharing across containers
body: /bitrise

title: File sharing across containers
body: /root/.bitrise:/root/.bitrise/

title: File sharing across containers
body: tmp:/tmp

title: File sharing across containers
body: By default, Bitrise will use /bitrise/src as its working directory, and everything created in either of these folders will be available across all Step execution containers.

title: File sharing across containers
body: Step execution containers only

title: File sharing across containers
body: This only applies to Step execution containers. Volumes and sharing files with service containers are not supported.

title: Service containers
body: One or more service can be configured for a group of Steps, allowing running Docker containers as services for advanced integration testing. These are tied to the lifecycle of a with group and will run alongside it in the background. Once all Steps within the groups finish, they are cleaned up.

title: Service containers
body: To do so, you need to add the services property to the top level in the bitrise.yml file of your app. You need to define:

title: Service containers
body: The ID of the service which is used to refer to the service in a with group.

title: Service containers
body: The image name of the service.

title: Service containers
body: The image version of the service.

title: Service containers
body: You can then refer to the ID of the service in a Workflow’s with group . The Steps in the group will have access to the referred service.

title: Service containers
body: Service containers for advanced integration test

title: Service containers
body:
containers:
 node-21:
 image: node:21.6

services:
 postgres:
 image: postgres:16
 envs:
 - POSTGRES_USER: postgres
 - POSTGRES_DB: bitrise
 # You can reference Bitrise secrets here, e.g: $POSTGRES_PASSWORD
 - POSTGRES_PASSWORD: password
 ports:
 - 5432:5432
 options: >-
 --health-cmd pg_isready
 --health-interval 10s
 --health-timeout 5s
 --health-retries 5
 redis:
 image: redis:7
 ports:
 - 6379:6379
 options: >-
 --health-cmd "redis-cli ping"
 --health-interval 10s
 --health-timeout 5s
 --health-retries 5

workflows:
 e2e-tests:
 envs:
 - POSTGRES_DSN: "postgres://postgres:password@postgres:5432/bitrise"
 - REDIS_DSN: "redis://redis:6379/1"
 steps:
 - with:
 container: node-21
 services:
 - postgres
 - redis
 steps:
 - script:
 title: e2e tests
 inputs:
 - content: npm run e2e-tests

title: Service containers
body: The example configuration defines a Workflow called e2e-tests.

title: Service containers
body: This Workflow's with group uses service containers to enable a more advanced integration test scenario using postgres and redis. It also utilizes a container to run the tests in a Node environment.

title: Service containers
body: There are two services defined: postgres and redis. Each service is configured to have healthchecks using the options parameter. The CLI will respect those options and only start the execution of the Steps once every service reports healthy.

title: Service containers
body: Each service is exposed on a port, but as we are utilizing containers, they will be accessible using their name postgres:5432 and redis:6379, respectively.

title: Service containers
body: If we were to omit the container configuration (not using a Step execution container) we would be able to access the services on the following addresses

title: Service containers
body: :postgres: localhost:5432

title: Service containers
body: redis: localhost:6379

title: Service containers
body: Once the services are ready, the Step will execute the npm run e2e-tests command, which can utilize the environment variables POSTGRES_DSN and REDIS_DSN defined by the Workflow to connect to services.

title: Service containers
body: For detailed configuration options, check out Container API reference.

title: Network access for service containers
body: Service containers are all joined to the same docker network called bitrise. This ensures that all of them are accessible from any other service container and Step execution container.

title: Network access for service containers
body: Running your own background workers

title: Network access for service containers
body: You can run your own background workers by executing the Docker commands yourself or by using something like docker-compose but make sure you use the same network.

title: Debugging containers
body: Once the build has finished, the logs will be converted into a structured view. This removes all logs that were created between Steps. As the container feature works on the Workflow level, its logs will be shown just before the first Step of the respective Workflow.

title: Debugging containers
body: To see the container logs, make sure to download the full logs from the build page: Downloading a build log.

title: Container API reference
body: The container configuration for both Step execution containers and service containers allows multiple options in addition to the image name and version.

title: Container API reference
body: Beta feature

title: Container API reference
body: This feature is in beta and we do not recommend using it with production applications. Register here for the beta.

title: Container API reference
body: You can define a Step execution container and a service container for a group of Steps. For a Step execution container, each Step within a with group will be running in the defined container.

title: Container API reference
body: The container configuration for both Step execution containers and service containers allows multiple options in addition to the image name and version.

title: Container API reference
body: Accessing services

title: Container API reference
body: Service containers can be used even when the Step group is not using a Step execution container. The only difference is how to access the services.

title: Container API reference
body: Use the <service_id> (name of the service) to access it when you are using Step execution container. For example, http://postgres:5432.

title: Container API reference
body: Use localhost to access your service if you are not using a Step execution container. For example, http://localhost:5432.

title: Container API reference
body: Step execution container and service API reference

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: You can create your own Docker image and push it to a container registry during a Bitrise build with the Docker Build & Push Step.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: You can create your own Docker image and push it to a container registry during a Bitrise build with the Docker Build & Push Step.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: The Step uses the docker build command: it requires a Dockerfile that contains the build instructions and a build context. Build context means the set of files located at the specified path. The Step allows you to pass options and build arguments to the build.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: To speed up your builds, the Step also supports key-based caching.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: To build the image with build options, build arguments and caching used:

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Workflow Editor

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: bitrise.yml

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add the Docker Build & Push Step to your Workflow.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Configure the required inputs for the Step:

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Image tags: A list of tags to be applied to the name of the built image. You can add one tag per line. For more information about image tags, their function, and their required format, check out the Docker documentation.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Build context path: The path to the files that constitute your build context. It should be relative to your Bitrise working directory.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Dockerfile path: The path to the Dockerfile you wish to use. It should be relative to your Bitrise working directory.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: If you want to push the built image to a container registry, set the Push docker image input to true.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: To cache the image, set the Use Bitrise key-value cache input to true.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: The input uses the following cache keys:

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}-{{ .Branch }}-{{ .CommitHash }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}-{{ .Branch }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Alternative caching method

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: The Step also supports caching using the --cache-from and the --cache-to options of the docker build command. The Cache from arguments and Cache to arguments inputs provide this function.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: If using key-based caching, do NOT use these inputs! Leave them empty.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Optionally, customize the build command with build arguments and options.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add build arguments in the Build arguments input: one argument per line in a MY_ARG=my_value format.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add options in the Extra options input: one extra option per line in the format of --option value or --option=value.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Values with quotes

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: When using values with quotes in them (for example, when the value contains spaces) do not use the equal sign. Separate it with spaces instead: --option "value with spaces".

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add the docker-build-push Step to your Workflow.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Configure the required inputs for the Step:

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: tags: A list of tags to be applied to the name of the built image. You can add one tag per line. For more information about image tags, their function, and their required format, check out the Docker documentation.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: context: The path to the files that constitute your build context. It should be relative to your Bitrise working directory.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: file: The path to the Dockerfile you wish to use. It should be relative to your Bitrise working directory.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body:
workflow:
 steps:
 - docker-build-push:
 inputs:
 - tags: myregistry.com/myimage:latest
 - context: "./path"
 - file: "./Dockerfile"

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: If you want to push the built image to a container registry, set the push input to true.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body:
workflow:
 steps:
 - docker-build-push:
 inputs:
 - tags: myregistry.com/myimage:latest
 - context: "./path"
 - file: "./Dockerfile"
 - push: "true"

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: To cache the image, set the use_bitrise_cache input to true.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: The input uses the following cache keys:

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}-{{ .Branch }}-{{ .CommitHash }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}-{{ .Branch }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: docker-imagename-{{ .OS }}-{{ .Arch }}

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Alternative caching method

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: The Step also supports caching using the --cache-from and the --cache-to options of the docker build command. The cache_from and cache_to inputs provide this function.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: If using key-based caching, do NOT use these inputs! Leave them empty.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body:
workflow:
 steps:
 - docker-build-push:
 inputs:
 - tags: myregistry.com/myimage:latest
 - context: "./path"
 - file: "./Dockerfile"
 - push: "true"
 - use_bitrise_cache: "true"

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Optionally, customize the build command with build arguments and options.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add build arguments in the build_arg input: one argument per line in a MY_ARG=my_value format.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Add options in the extra_options input: one extra option per line in the format of --option value or --option=value.

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: Values with quotes

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body: When using values with quotes in them (for example, when the value contains spaces) do not use the equal sign. Separate it with spaces instead: --option "value with spaces".

title: Building your own Docker image on Bitrise
body:
workflow:
 steps:
 - docker-build-push:
 inputs:
 - tags: myregistry.com/myimage:latest
 - context: "./path"
 - file: "./Dockerfile"
 - push: "true"
 - use_bitrise_cache: "true"
 - build_arg: BUILD_ARG=my_value
 - extra_options: "--option value"

title: Using your own Docker image
body: You can use your own Docker image on Bitrise, as well as run custom Docker commands in your Workflow. Use either a custom image from Docker Hub or your own Dockerfile.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Docker Hub rate limits

title: Using your own Docker image
body: From July 15, 2024, rate limiting will apply on downloads from Docker Hub. If you pull a Docker image from Docker Hub without authentication during a Bitrise build on our Linux machines, you may run into issues because of rate limiting.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Bitrise is mirroring some of the popular public docker images, but to avoid these potential issues with rate limiting, you can either:

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Authenticate your Docker image pulling requests towards Docker Hub. For the details and Docker's full policy, refer to Docker Hub rate limit.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Switch to another Docker registry to store your images.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: On Bitrise, every single build runs in its own, separate virtual machine that is destroyed at the end of the build. On our Android stacks, we use Docker for this purpose. Our stacks have pre-installed Docker images but you can use your own custom image, and run custom Docker commands in your Workflow. There are two ways to use your own Docker configuration on Bitrise:

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Run docker commands yourself during your build. To do so, use one or more Script Step.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Set a custom image in the Workflow Editor.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: No Docker on macOS stacks

title: Using your own Docker image
body: Docker isn't installed on any of our macOS-based stacks; our guides related to Docker only apply to Linux-based stacks.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: We recommend that you run docker commands with a Script Step as you should NOT CHANGE the base environment Docker image on the Stack tab unless you really have to! Running the docker commands yourself during the build is more flexible and provides an overall higher level of control.

title: Using your own Docker image
body: GitHub sample repository

title: Using your own Docker image
body: You can find a sample repository on GitHub, which is configured to run on your Mac/Linux using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: The recommended way of using a custom Docker configuration both locally and on bitrise.io, is to add a Script Step to your Workflow to run Docker commands. You can use the same Step to authenticate yourself to a service such as Docker Hub and to run your selected image.

title: Running docker commands with a Script Step
body: We provide three examples on how to run Docker commands using our Script Step:

title: Running docker hello-world
body: The official hello-world Docker image is hosted on Docker Hub. If you wish to use any of the images from Docker Hub, you must authenticate first.

title: Running docker hello-world
body: In this example, we’re following the official getting started guide to run the hello-world Docker image. In our example bitrise.yml file, you can see a simple build configuration that can run the image:

title: Running docker hello-world
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run hello-world
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN
 docker run hello-world

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: You can use your own Dockerfile on Bitrise in your repository to define the Docker environment:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
---
format_version: 11
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
trigger_map:
- push_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
- pull_request_source_branch: "*"
 workflow: primary
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: ''
 - git-clone@3.4.1: {}
 - script@1:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample .
 docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: This Workflow will:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Git clone your repository.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: Run docker build -t bitrise-minimal-sample . and docker run --rm bitrise-minimal-sample in the repository’s root.

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body: If you have a Dockerfile like this in the root of the repository:

title: Building and running a Dockerfile
body:
FROM alpine:3.3

CMD cat /etc/alpine-release
