title: Using docker-compose
body: You can also run a Docker image from your own Docker file using the docker-compose command. With compose, you can configure your application’s services and then you can start all services with a single command.

title: Using docker-compose
body: For example, set up a docker-compose.yml like this in your repository root (where the Dockerfile is):

title: Using docker-compose
body:
version: '2'
services:
 sample-app:
 build: .

title: Using docker-compose
body: Now you can run your services with a single docker-compose call in your Script Step:

title: Using docker-compose
body:
- script@1.1.3:
 title: docker run
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x
 docker-compose run --rm sample-app

title: Using docker-compose
body: Docker compose will build and run the image automatically. You don’t have to specify a -t tag since the services name will be used by docker-compose to tag the image automatically.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: You can use Bitrise with a Docker image pulled from Docker Hub, as you can see in our Running docker hello-world example. However, on a free plan for anonymous users, Docker Hub only allows a limited number of image pulls. If you set the image in the Workflow Editor, no authentication will be performed: your pull will be a pull by an anonymous user from a Bitrise public IP address. With many of our users going for this option, the Docker Hub rate limit would mean some users wouldn’t be able to start builds.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: The workaround is simple: you need to use a Script Step to authenticate yourself with your own Docker Hub account, and use the Step to pull the image from Docker Hub. To do so:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Create a personal access token on Docker Hub.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: This will be used to authenticate you instead of your password.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: On Bitrise, create two Secret Environment Variables: one for your Docker Hub username and another for the personal access token.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: In our examples, we’ll use DOCKERHUB_USER for the Docker Hub username and DOCKERHUB_TOKEN.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Use the docker login command in a Script Step to authenticate, with the Secret Env Vars as arguments:

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body:
- script@1.1.3: 
 inputs: 
 - content: | 
 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: Use the docker run command in the Script Step to run your chosen Docker image.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body: In our example, it’s Docker’s official hello-world image. You can just replace hello-world with any image you want to use from Docker Hub.

title: Using a custom Docker image from Docker Hub
body:
- script@1.1.3: 
 inputs: 
 - content: | 
 docker login -u $DOCKERHUB_USER -p $DOCKERHUB_TOKEN
 docker run hello-world

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: In the Workflow Editor on bitrise.io, you have the option to set a path to a custom Docker image.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you want to run your build in a custom Docker environment, we strongly recommend basing your own Docker image on one of our base Docker images. Our images have every base tool pre-installed, the standard Bitrise directories created, the environments (such as $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR) set, and are pre-cached on the build virtual machines.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: However, if you decide to create your own Docker image please read this guide, from start to finish.

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Custom Android docker image

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Creating and maintaining your own Android Docker image can be quite time consuming! If you only need to install a couple of additional tools, you should do that, for example, with a Script Step instead! For more information, see our Install Any Additional Tool guide. You should only use your own Android docker image if you really have to!

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Setting a custom Docker image in the Workflow Editor
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path in the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: We have four different Docker image types available. You can base your own image on any of these, depending on your needs.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path in the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Bitrise Docker image types

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: To base your own image on one of our available images, specify your base image at the very top of your Dockerfile with a FROM instruction and the quay.io ID of the image. In our example, we’ll use the latest version of the Bitrise base image:

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: FROM quay.io/bitriseio/docker-bitrise-base:latest

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: You have to use the quay.io ID of the image you want to use as the base image. For example, quay.io/bitriseio/android, quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk, quay.io/bitriseio/android-ndk-lts, or quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base.

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: Don’t use the alpha images for your builds

title: Creating your own image from a Bitrise image
body: For every Docker image we have on quay.io, we have an alpha tagged version too. The alpha ones are frequently rebuilt and are NOT PRECACHED ON bitrise.io, so you should avoid those.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: You can set your own Docker image in the Workflow Editor if the image can be pulled with the docker pull command and you use the Ubuntu 20.04 stack.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Using an image hosted on Docker Hub

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: If you wish to use an image hosted on Docker Hub, do not set the image path in the Workflow Editor! Use a Script Step instead to authenticate your Docker Hub account and run the selected image.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Open the Workflow Editor.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Select Stacks & Machines.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Copy and paste the ID of your app. For example, quay.io/bitriseio/bitrise-base.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: This option is not available on Ubuntu 22.04.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Save your changes.

title: Using your created Docker image in a build
body: Now you should be able to use your own image to run your builds on bitrise.io.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: You can run a Bitrise build in Docker on your own machines: you need Docker, the Bitrise CLI, and a Bitrise Docker image.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Docker Hub rate limit

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: From July 15, 2024, rate limiting will apply on downloads from Docker Hub. If you pull a Docker image from Docker Hub without authentication during a Bitrise build on our Linux machines, you may run into issues because of rate limiting.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Bitrise is mirroring some of the popular public docker images, but to avoid these potential issues with rate limiting, you can either:

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Authenticate your Docker image pulling requests towards Docker Hub. For the details and Docker's full policy, refer to Docker Hub rate limit.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Switch to another Docker registry to store your images.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: To be able to run your Linux stack builds locally, you’ll need docker:

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: For Linux, just follow the official install instructions.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: For Mac, you can use Docker for Mac, which is the easiest way to get started.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: In this guide, we’ll use this Bitrise Android sample project.

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: Large images ahead

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: The official Bitrise Docker images are quite large because they include a wide variety of preinstalled tools. You’ll need at least 20-25 GB FREE DISC SPACE!

title: Running your build locally in Docker
body: If you’re not familiar with the Bitrise CLI, you should try that first. You don’t have to master the CLI, if you know what bitrise run WORKFLOW does, that should be enough for this tutorial.

title: Downloading docker images
body: Install docker.

title: Downloading docker images
body: Make sure you have your bitrise.yml in your repository.

title: Downloading docker images
body: You don’t have to commit it, but the file must exist in your repository’s root directory.

title: Downloading docker images
body: cd into your repository’s directory on your Mac/Linux.

title: Downloading docker images
body: Pull the image from its registry:

title: Downloading docker images
body: docker pull bitriseio/android-20.04:latest

title: Downloading docker images
body: Run the following command:

title: Downloading docker images
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android-20.04:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW`

title: Downloading docker images
body: If you want to just jump into the container and experiment inside, you can replace --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android-20.04:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW with -it quay.io/bitriseio/android-20.04:latest bash to start an interactive bash shell inside the container. For example:

title: Downloading docker images
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" -it quay.io/bitriseio/android-20.04:latest bash

title: Downloading docker images
body: In general, if your project is an Android project but you don’t use Android NDK, to preserve precious disk space, you should use the quay.io/bitriseio/android docker image. You can find other official Bitrise docker images on our Quay page. In this example, we’re using the quay.io/bitriseio/android one.

title: Downloading docker images
body: Download docker images from the Quay:

title: Downloading docker images
body: docker pull bitriseio/android-20.04:latest`

title: Downloading docker images
body: Be aware that this can take quite a bit of time, as this image is over 10 GB. If the download fails or hangs, you can restart it any time by running the same command again.

title: Downloading docker images
body: Download your Bitrise build configuration (bitrise.yml) to the root directory of your repository.

title: Downloading docker images
body: You can download your project’s bitrise.yml from the bitrise.yml tab of your Workflow Editor on bitrise.io.

title: Downloading docker images
body: In your Terminal / Command Line go to (cd) the root directory of your repository. Check if your bitrise.yml is at this location.

title: Downloading docker images
body: If you try to reproduce an issue, you should git clone your repository into a NEW DIRECTORY, so that the directory will only contain the files which are committed into the repository! It’s a frequent reproducibility issue that you try to run the commands in your normal working directory, where you most likely have files which are not committed into your repository, for example, files which are in .gitignore.

title: Running the build
body: Run your build with the following command:

title: Running the build
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW

title: Running the build
body: --rm quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bitrise run WORKFLOW

title: Running the build
body: with -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash to start an interactive bash shell inside the container.

title: Running the build
body: For example:

title: Running the build
body: docker run --privileged --env CI=false --volume "$(pwd):/bitrise/src" --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" -it quay.io/bitriseio/android:latest bash`.

title: Running the build
body: This command will share the current directory (the directory of your repository) as a shared volume with the docker container, and will make it available inside the container at the path /bitrise/src.

title: Running the build
body: After this, you can run bitrise run WORKFLOW, which will run the workflow inside the container. To exit from the container, just run exit.

title: Running the build
body: Don’t forget to replace WORKFLOW with the actual ID of your workflow in your bitrise.yml, with something like primary!

title: Running the build
body: The --env CI=false flag sets the environment variable CI to false - this will make Bitrise CLI skip certain steps that only make sense to run in a CI environment. For example, our Git Clone Step - you already have your code, so there’s no need to git clone it again inside the docker container (that’s why we shared the code directory as a --volume).

title: Running the build
body: The --rm flag tells docker to discard the container after the docker run command finishes. This means that if you run the command again, the only thing which will persist between the docker run .. commands are the files stored at the shared --volume (in your repository’s directory). Every other file that is generated into a temp or any other location will be discarded / won’t be kept.

title: Running the build
body: If you want to debug the container after a failed build, feel free to remove the --rm flag, and check out a Docker tutorial about how you can connect to an existing docker container. Please note that simply running the command again will not use the same container, but will create a new one!

title: Running the build
body: The --privileged flag allows access control of the host from the docker container, so you should never use this flag unless you trust the docker image you will use! This flag is required for allowing VPNs to work (to change network configs of the host), for example.

title: Running the build
body: The --volume "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock" flag exposes the docker socket from the host for the container - this is required if you want to run other docker containers from within the container, or if you want to run any docker command during your build / inside the container.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Running Bitrise on self-hosted infrastructure requires setting up agent pools in your Bitrise Workspace. This reserves build agents for use in your self-hosted builds, and provides a token to authenticate the agent to Bitrise.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: You can run Bitrise builds on hardware you control. We offer two different options:

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Running builds on AWS EC2 instances.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Using our on-premise runner to run builds on your own machines, or at other cloud providers.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Both options require setting up runner pools in your Bitrise Workspace. This reserves build runners for use in your self-hosted builds. Each reserved pool comes with a unique token: this token is required for both an AWS EC2 instance and the on-premise runner to be able to connect to your Bitrise Workspace and run builds of the apps owned by the Workspace. You can configure and run these builds from the Workflow Editor, as any other build.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: To do so:

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Log in to Bitrise and hover over the left navigation bar.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Make sure you have the right workspace selected in the Workspace menu.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Select Settings.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: On the left, select Self-hosted infrastructure.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: In the Runner pools section, click Add new.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Type a name into the Name field then click Next.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: You will receive a token. Copy this token: you will need it for authentication.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Open the app you need on Bitrise and click Workflows.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Click Edit bitrise.yml to go the Workflow Editor, and select Stacks & Machines on the left navigation menu.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Find your own stack in the stack selection dropdown menus: it will be called Self-hosted Runner: <Pool name>.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: For example, if you named your pool my-pool, the stack will be called Self-hosted Runner: my-pool.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds
body: Now your builds will run using the reserved runner pools. You can run builds either on your own hardware or on AWS EC2 instances.

title: Running Bitrise builds on-premise
body: You can run Bitrise builds on your own hardware or virtual environment by installing the Bitrise agent and connect it to your Bitrise Workspace. You can install the agent on both macOS and Linux.

title: Running Bitrise builds on-premise
body: You can run Bitrise builds on self-hosted infrastructure - that is, that hardware or virtualized environments that you control - while taking advantage of every feature the Bitrise website offers. To do so, you just need to install the Bitrise agent on your own infrastructure and connect it to your Workspace. Once that is done, you can run builds from your Bitrise account, using the Bitrise UI as usual.

title: When to use the on-premise runner
body: If you need to run Bitrise builds on infrastructure that you control, Bitrise offers two options: using AWS EC2 instances, or the on-premise runner option.

title: When to use the on-premise runner
body: We only recommend using the on-premise runner if you have the necessary machines or use a cloud provider other than AWS for your infrastructure needs. The on-premise runner is NOT plug and play: you need to make sure all necessary tools and services are installed on your machines.

title: When to use the on-premise runner
body: If you do have an AWS account for managing your infrastructure, we recommend checking our AWS offering.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: To be able to run Bitrise builds on your own infrastructure, you need to get the Bitrise runner from Homebrew and then configure your network to be able to access two Bitrise service endpoints.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: To be able to run Bitrise builds on your own infrastructure, you need to get the Bitrise runner from Homebrew and then configure your network to be able to access two Bitrise service endpoints.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Tools and services

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Please note that when using the Bitrise runner this way, you have to make sure you have all the tools you need installed on the machine. For now, we don't provide preinstalled tools for this on-premise solution.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: macOS

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Linux

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Configure Bitrise runner pools in your Workspace settings page on bitrise.io: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Make sure to get the token from the process.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Fetch the bitrise-den-agent formula from Homebrew.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: brew tap bitrise-io/den-agent

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Install the latest version.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: brew install bitrise-den-agent

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Installing a specific version

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: You can also install a specific version by amending the version number to the command:

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: brew install bitrise-den-agent@2.1.26

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Install the Bitrise CLI. The CLI runs the builds based on YAML configurations.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: brew install bitrise

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Configure your network to be able to access the following two services:

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: https://den.services.bitrise.io

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: https://build-log.services.bitrise.io

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: The agent needs to be able to access both of these to run your builds and communicate with the Bitrise website.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Generate a service daemon template.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: You need the runner pool token to finish the process.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: brew create-daemon --bitrise-agent-intro-secret=YOUR_AGENT_POOL_TOKEN

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Connect the runner on your machine to your Bitrise workspace.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body:
sudo mkdir -p ~/Library/LaunchDaemons 
sudo chown root:wheel ~/Library/LaunchDaemons 
sudo cp /opt/homebrew/io.bitrise.self-hosted-agent.plist ~/Library/LaunchDaemons 
sudo chown root:wheel ~/Library/LaunchDaemons/io.bitrise.self-hosted-agent.plist 
sudo launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchDaemons/io.bitrise.self-hosted-agent.plist

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: We provide the Linux Bitrise Runner binary with x86_64 architecture only since Google isn’t supporting arm64 with Android tools yet. You can vote in this Google issue to change this.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: On your Apple Silicon machine, you can run the Linux Bitrise Runner with docker using the correct flags: --platform linux/x86_64.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: If you require an arm64 Linux Bitrise Runner binary, please visit the Bitrise Roadmap and cast your vote.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Download the Bitrise CLI binary with curl and make it executable.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body:
curl -fL https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise/releases/latest/download/bitrise-$(uname -s)-$(uname -m) > /usr/local/bin/bitrise

chmod +x /usr/local/bin/bitrise

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Configure Bitrise runner pools in your Workspace settings page on bitrise.io: Configuring runner pools for self-hosted builds.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Make sure to get the token from the process.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Add a GPG public key.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body:
curl -fsSL https://bitrise-den-agent-deb.s3.amazonaws.com/DEB-GPG-KEY-bitrise.pub | 
sudo gpg --dearmor -o /usr/share/keyrings/DEB-GPG-KEY-bitrise.gpg

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Add the Bitrise DEN agent deb package repository.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body:
echo 'deb [arch=amd64 signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/DEB-GPG-KEY-bitrise.gpg] https://bitrise-den-agent-deb.s3.amazonaws.com stable main' | 
sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/den-agent-deb.list

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: Install the runner and connect it on your machine to your Bitrise workspace.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body: You need the runner pool token to finish the process.

title: Setting up Bitrise on-premise
body:
sudo apt update
sudo apt install bitrise-den-agent
/usr/bin/bitrise-den-agent-configure.sh YOUR_AGENT_POOL_TOKEN

title: Bitrise on AWS: Cloud Controller
body: The Cloud Controller enables you to enjoy the benefits of a Bitrise-managed infrastructure on your AWS environment. With the Cloud Controller, you can manage your build infrastructure even without deep knowledge about AWS.

title: AWS offering types
body: There are two basic types of Bitrise on AWS AMIs:

title: AWS offering types
body: Bare metal: Your builds run directly on an AWS machine. This means that the build environment is persistent, the same way it would be on your own computer. Artifacts or cache items from a build can have an effect on subsequent builds, unless you clean up the environment.

title: AWS offering types
body: Virtualized/VM-based: Just like on Bitrise, every build runs in its own virtual machine that is destroyed once the build is finished. It is powered by Bitrise’s virtualization solution that has run millions of builds on the Bitrise-managed machines built on top of Apple’s virtualization framework. Our macOS offerings, including the virtualized solution, are only available on Apple silicon machines.

title: AWS offering types
body: Updating the AMIs

title: AWS offering types
body: The Bitrise AMIs are constantly updated with the latest versions of the pre-installed tools. However, providing the latest Xcode and Android Studio versions in the form of AMIs are slower than on the Bitrise-managed machines, because of the AWS AMI review process. You can check out the currently available versions on the AWS stack reports.

title: AWS offering types
body: AWS pricing for Mac dedicated hosts

title: AWS offering types
body: For macOS instances, a dedicated host must be allocated. On-Demand EC2 Mac Dedicated Hosts have a minimum host allocation and billing duration of 24 hours. For more details, check out the official AWS documentation: Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts Pricing.

title: Bare metal macOS
body: The bare metal macOS AMI is only available on Apple silicon machines, on the following instance types:

title: Bare metal macOS
body: mac2.metal

title: Bare metal macOS
body: mac2-m2.metal

title: Bare metal macOS
body: mac2-m2pro.metal

title: Bare metal macOS
body: Android emulators are supported on all the instance types above.

title: Virtualized macOS
body: The virtualized macOS AMI is only available on Apple silicon machines, on the following instance types:

title: Virtualized macOS
body: mac2.metal

title: Virtualized macOS
body: mac2-m2.metal

title: Virtualized macOS
body: mac2-m2pro.metal

title: Virtualized macOS
body: Virtualization offers an ephemeral build environment: the virtual machine is destroyed at the end of every build. This means that all builds run in a completely clean environment, and previous builds have no effect on them.

title: Virtualized macOS
body: You have the option of running either one or two VMs per build. Depending on how resource intensive a build is, running two VMs can mean significant savings in hardware costs.

title: Virtualized macOS
body: No Android emulation

title: Virtualized macOS
body: Android emulation is not available as the Apple silicon architecture doesn't support nested virtualization.

title: Bare metal Linux
body: The bare metal Linux AMI is available on the following AWS instance types:

title: Bare metal Linux
body: t2.2xlarge

title: Bare metal Linux
body: t2.xlarge

title: Bare metal Linux
body: c5n.metal

title: Bare metal Linux
body: c5.xlarge

title: Bare metal Linux
body: c5.metal

title: Bare metal Linux
body: c5.4xlarge

title: Bare metal Linux
body: c5.2xlarge

title: Bare metal Linux
body: Different instance types suit different computing needs. To find out more about the functions and capabilities of the different instance types, check out the official AWS documentation.

title: Bare metal Linux
body: You can run Android emulators on the metal instance types only. The other instance types don't support the use of emulators.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: If you need to run Bitrise builds on infrastructure that you control, we offer two options: using AWS EC2 instances or our on-premise option.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: We recommend using AWS instances to run Bitrise builds if you or your company already has an AWS account to operate important infrastructure. Using an AWS instance comes with several advantages:

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: Plug and play: we provide the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) as a mobile-specific build environment, with all required tools preinstalled. No specific setup needed: you only need to configure the EC2 instance.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: Control your environment: you can configure network and storage settings during the launch of the instance (for example, you can configure a separate subnet for your Bitrise builds) to make sure all build machines run in their own AWS environment and operate according to company security policies.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: Security: your code base will remain entirely in your control.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: Information leaving the AWS environment

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: Using certain features means leaving the AWS environment: for example, using the build cache, generating build artifacts or test results.

title: When to choose the AWS option
body: If you don't have an AWS account, use some other cloud provider, or already manage your own machines, we recommend checking out our on-premise runner offering.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: The Cloud Controller enables you to enjoy the benefits of a Bitrise-managed infrastructure on your AWS environment. With the Cloud Controller, you can manage your build infrastructure even without deep knowledge about AWS.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: The Cloud Controller enables Bitrise on AWS users to operate EC2 infrastructure at scale:

title: Cloud controller overview
body: The automation supports both the bare metal and the VM-based macOS offerings, providing complete automation on reserving macOS dedicated hosts, starting the instances with the chosen AMI, and connecting to the Bitrise pool.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: Controller's automation saves your mobile DevOps team time and removes an error-prone manual process that doesn't scale above a certain number of instances.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: Changing the number of instances in the Agent Pool definition enables EC2 cost savings. Scaling down even a bigger macOS machine pool for the weekend will be as easy as changing a single number in the configuration.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: Updating the machines to a newer build environment - provided in the form of an AMI by Bitrise - will be seamless and won't disturb the mobile developers. The configuration can define the percentage of machines affected by the update at any given time.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: You can monitor the instances in each Bitrise pool, see their state, and the builds they are currently running.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: No inbound traffic required

title: Cloud controller overview
body: We’ve created the Bitrise on AWS offering with the highest security standards in mind, to match even the most strict company policy requirements. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, so no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Cloud controller overview
body: Manual setup

title: Cloud controller overview
body: We recommend using the Cloud Controller to run Bitrise builds on AWS. However, if you want full control and customization options, you can choose the manual setup.

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: In order to provide the core functionalities of Bitrise in AWS environment both the controller and the build machines need to access the Bitrise Control Plane on three addresses:

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: https://cloud-controller-aws-internal.services.bitrise.io

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: https://exec.bitrise.io

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: https://build-log.services.bitrise.io

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: Some additional quality-of-life features (like the build machine self-update or the external IP collection) require further communication with additional resources on different addresses. To achieve the maximum security in AWS, you can disable these extra functionalities by enabling the Air-gapped network mode during controller creation.

title: Air-gapped mode for the controller
body: Please note that this setting doesn't affect your AWS configuration. You need to ensure that the network you use is configured securely.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Bitrise on AWS is sold via AWS Private Offer and a Bitrise account is required before you can use Bitrise-provided AMIs. Please don't purchase the offerings via the public AWS Marketplace.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: The Bitrise on AWS AMI is now available for both Linux and macOS. It enables running Bitrise builds on AWS EC2 instances.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Bitrise on AWS is sold via AWS Private Offer and a Bitrise account is required before you can use Bitrise-provided AMIs. Please don't purchase the offerings via the public AWS Marketplace.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: You can get a private offer of the Bitrise on AWS listings:

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: After contacting Bitrise, we will send the order in a pdf format. This document contains all the details of our Bitrise on AWS offering, including the relevant customer data, the service provided, and the price of the service.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Once satisfied with the terms, contact Bitrise again to give up permission to create the AWS private offer. The offer will be visible on the AWS marketplace.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Next you will receive a link to an AWS private offer which will also contain the order form attached. The link should take you to the AWS Marketplace.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Optionally, you can enter a purchase order ID for invoicing purposes here: click Add a purchase order.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: To learn more about purchase orders, check out the official AWS documentation: Managing your purchase orders.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Review the terms of the agreement. The pdf document will be available under the End User License Agreement link below the Create Contract button.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Note that on the bottom right, you might see other available offers, including the Bitrise public offer. These are not relevant: the link you received took you straight to your private offer.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: If everything is in order, click Create Contract on the right. After this point, the contract can’t be modified on the AWS page.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Once the contract is ready, AWS should display a message about receiving a license. At this point you can proceed to configure your AMI by clicking Continue to Configuration.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Choose a fulfillment option, a version and your region before launching. You can read more about launching software from the AWS Marketplace in the official AWS documentation: Launching container software from AWS Marketplace.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: Once ready, click Continue to Launch to launch the software.

title: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs
body: To read more about configuring your AWS EC2 instance and running builds there: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI.

title: Creating and configuring a controller
body: To create and configure an AWS Cloud Controller to run Bitrise builds, you need to configure it on Bitrise first and then set up an instance running the controller agent on AWS.

title: Creating and configuring a controller
body: You must create and connect a Cloud Controller to take advantage of our Controller-managed AWS offering. The process has two stages:

title: Creating and configuring a controller
body: Configuring the Controller on Bitrise.

title: Creating and configuring a controller
body: Setting up an instance running the controller agent on AWS.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Get access to the AWS controller feature from the Bitrise team.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Log in to your Bitrise Workspace as a Workspace owner.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Only Workspace owners can access and configure this feature.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Open the Workspace settings page of the Workspace.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Select Self-hosted infrastructure and go to the Bitrise on AWS tab.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Click Connect with AWS. This should bring up a dialog box.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Set a name for your controller and specify if you want to use the controller in an air-gapped network.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: For more information on air-gapped mode, see Air-gapped mode for the controller.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Copy and save your token.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: Save the token

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: This token is only accessible only right after creation. If the token is lost, you need to delete the controller and create a new one which would generate a new token.

title: Configuring the controller on Bitrise
body: After successful creation, the Bitrise on AWS screen should indicate that the controller on the Bitrise side is prepared, and it’s waiting for an AWS connection. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: After a successful controller creation on Bitrise, go to AWS and create an instance running the Controller Agent.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: New or existing VPC

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: The configuration will need a Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). Every AWS region contains a default VPC but if necessary, you can create your own VPC within each region. If you wish to share your VPC between Bitrise-specific resources and your other resources you can reuse the already existing and configured VPC. If you prefer to separate resources, you can create a new VPC with the provided template.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: For more information, read the official AWS documentation on VPCs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Setup with an existing VPC

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Setup with a new VPC

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Log in to your AWS account.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Select the template option you need and you'll get the HTTP link to your template. You can read more about templates on the AWS CloudFormation templates page.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Link to the base template.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Link to the airgapped template. Use this if the Bitrise Controller is expected to run in airgapped mode.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Additional manual configuration

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: The airgapped support requires some manual configuration in AWS that is not automated via CloudFormation. For details, please check the AWS CloudFormation templates page.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Navigate to CloudFormation and select Create stack with new resources (standard).

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Create a stack using the Template is ready and Amazon S3 URL options.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: In the Amazon S3 URL field, provide the URL gathered in the previous step and click Next.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: On the following prompt, specify the following fields:

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Stack name: Any value works here. This helps to identify the stack if you have multiple stacks.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Latest AMI ID: This AMI ID is used as a base AMI to run the Cloud Controller on.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Bitrise Controller Token: The token is generated as part of controller creation on Bitrise: Configuring the controller on Bitrise.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Bitrise Workspace ID: Identifying Workspaces and projects with their slugs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller Log Group Class : The Cloud Controller generates logs that are accessible to the customers in AWS. This configuration specifies what features the customer wants to use during log analysis. The default is Infrequent access, which provides a limited log analyzing capability at a lower cost.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller Log Retention In Days : Determines how long AWS stores the Cloud Controller logs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller SSH Key : Select one previously configured SSH key. With this key, you can log into the created instance and, if needed, investigate.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Subnet IDs : Choose at least two subnets in two different Availability Zones from the previously configured subnets, but make sure not to select more than one subnet from the same Availability Zone. The selected subnets should belong to the selected VPC. The subnets should have a route table configuration enabling the created instances to communicate to the Bitrise Services. There is no incoming communication required for the Controller.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: VPC CIDR Block : Default value is provided. Make sure you select a CIDR Block matching the VPC’s CIDR Block. For more info, see the official AWS docs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: VPC ID : Select from the previously configured VPCs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Only one controller per VPC/region

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: We do not recommend running more than one Controller in one VPC/one region. These Controllers could start more resources than necessary which can cost money.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: The other stack option configurations are optional. For details, check AWS’s official documentation.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Review your previous settings on the Review screen. If everything looks correct, acknowledge your CloudFormation capabilities at the bottom and then submit your request.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Once the AWS CloudFormation successfully creates the instance running the Controller (this process can take 5-7 minutes), go back to your Workspace page on Bitrise to confirm the connectivity between the instance and AWS. If the Controller’s status is Connected, the connection works correctly.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Log in to your AWS account.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Select the template option you need and you'll get the HTTP link to your template. You can read more about templates on the AWS CloudFormation templates page.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Link to the base template.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Link to the airgapped template. Use this if the Bitrise Controller is expected to run in airgapped mode.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Additional manual configuration

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: The airgapped support requires some manual configuration in AWS that is not automated via CloudFormation. For details, please check the AWS CloudFormation templates page.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Navigate to CloudFormation and select Create stack with new resources (standard).

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Create a stack using the Template is ready and Amazon S3 URL options.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: In the Amazon S3 URL field, provide the URL gathered in the previous step and click Next.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: On the following prompt, specify the following fields (all mentioned fields are required unless specified otherwise):

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Stack name: Any value works here. This helps to identify the stack if you have multiple stacks.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Latest AMI ID: This AMI ID is used as a base AMI to run the Cloud Controller on.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Bitrise Controller Token: The token is generated as part of controller creation on Bitrise: Configuring the controller on Bitrise.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Bitrise Workspace ID: Identifying Workspaces and projects with their slugs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller Log Group Class : The Cloud Controller generates logs that are accessible to the customers in AWS. This configuration specifies what features the customer wants to use during log analysis. The default is Infrequent access, which provides a limited log analyzing capability at a lower cost.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller Log Retention In Days : Determines how long AWS stores the Cloud Controller logs.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Controller SSH Key : Select one previously configured SSH key. With this key, you can log into the created instance and, if needed, investigate.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Environment Name: Optional. The provided value will appear in the names of the created VPC, subnets, and route tables.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Private Subnet 1 CIDR: Default value is provided. IP range (CIDR notation) for the private subnet of the new VPC in the first Availability Zone. The value must be between a /28 netmask and /16 netmask.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Private Subnet 2 CIDR: Default value is provided. IP range (CIDR notation) for the private subnet of the new VPC in the second Availability Zone. The value must be between a /28 netmask and /16 netmask.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Public Subnet 1 CIDR: Default value is provided. IP range (CIDR notation) for the public subnet of the new VPC in the first Availability Zone. The value must be between a /28 netmask and /16 netmask.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Public Subnet 2 CIDR: Default value is provided. IP range (CIDR notation) for the public subnet of the new VPC in the second Availability Zone. The value must be between a /28 netmask and /16 netmask.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: VPC CIDR: Default value is provided. Select the Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) for the new VPC.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: The other stack option configurations are optional. For details, check AWS’s official documentation.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Review your previous settings on the Review screen. If everything looks correct, acknowledge your CloudFormation capabilities at the bottom and then submit your request.

title: Setting up the controller instance on AWS
body: Once the AWS CloudFormation successfully creates the instance running the Controller (this process can take 5-7 minutes), go back to your Workspace page on Bitrise to confirm the connectivity between the instance and AWS. If the Controller’s status is Connected, the connection works correctly.

title: Enabling CloudWatch Bitrise Agent logging
body: Setting up CloudWatch is optional, but we recommend doing so: it enables better build troubleshooting capabilities. Bitrise can provide you with faster support in case of an issue if you share the Bitrise Agent logs from your CloudWatch setup.

title: Enabling CloudWatch Bitrise Agent logging
body: To enable your AWS resources, such as EC2 instances, to send logs to CloudWatch, you must configure it in AWS CloudFormation. You need the following settings:

title: Enabling CloudWatch Bitrise Agent logging
body: CreatedBitriseAgentLogs: When enabled, this setting initiates the creation of a CloudWatch log group for the log stream, along with the required role and an instance profile named bitrise-agent-log-instance-profile.

title: Enabling CloudWatch Bitrise Agent logging
body: Bitrise Agent Logs Group Class: The Bitrise Agent generates logs that are accessible to the customers in AWS. This configuration specifies what features the customer wants to use during log analysis. The default is Infrequent access, which provides a limited log analyzing capability at a lower cost.

title: Enabling CloudWatch Bitrise Agent logging
body: Bitrise Agent Logs Retention In Days (required): The days until AWS stores the Bitrise Agent logs.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: AWS CloudFormation simplifies the one-click provisioning and management of the Bitrise Cloud Controller on AWS. When the CloudFormation template is deployed into a customer VPC, it creates the Bitrise Cloud Controller and the accompanying infrastructure.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: AWS CloudFormation simplifies the one-click provisioning and management of the Bitrise Cloud Controller on AWS. When the CloudFormation template is deployed into a customer VPC, it creates the Bitrise Cloud Controller and the accompanying infrastructure.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: Bitrise maintains CloudFormation templates for different use cases:

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: Deploy Cloud Controller to an existing VPC: Choose this template if the user has an established AWS presence with already built-out networking.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: Deploy Cloud Controller into a brand new VPC: Choose this template if the user is new to AWS or doesn’t have an already built-out networking. This template creates a new VPC first (based on customer preferences) and then deploys the controller into it.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to an existing VPC: Choose this template if the user has an established AWS presence with already built-out networking and would like to run the controller in a strictly airgapped environment. This is not fully automated: some manual configuration is needed.

title: AWS CloudFormation templates
body: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller into a brand new VPC: Choose this template if the user is new to AWS or doesn’t have an already built-out networking and would like to run the controller in a strictly airgapped environment. This template creates a new VPC first with the correct airgapped configuration and then deploys the controller into it.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: Template parameters:

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: Stack Name (required): Identifies the Bitrise Cloud Controller parent stack within the AWS Account.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: Latest AMI ID: This AMI ID is used as a base AMI to run the Cloud Controller on.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: BitriseControllerToken (required): The controller token the user receives when creating a controller on the Bitrise Website.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: BitriseWorkspaceID (required): The workspace ID belonging to the customer’s Bitrise account.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: ControllerLogGroupClass (required): The controller saves error logs to a CloudWatch log group within the customer AWS Account. The customer controls which Log Group Class fits their budget the most. The default value should be suitable for most of the cases. Default: INFREQUENT_ACCESS.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: ControllerLogRetentionInDays (required): The number of days Cloud Watch should retain the Controller error logs. Default: 7 (days).

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: ControllerSshKey (required): Provides SSH access for the Cloud Controller instance.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: SubnetIds (required): At least two subnets within the same region but in different AZs. We recommend using private subnets, but public subnets work as well.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: VpcId (required): The VPC where the controller will be deployed.

title: Deploy CloudController to an existing VPC
body: VpcCidrBlock (required): The CIDR block of the selected VPC.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Internal Application Load Balancer: Servers have no traffic and only perform periodic health checks on the Cloud Controller instance. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Autoscaling Group: Makes sure that a healthy Cloud Controller instance is running at a time.Instance: a t2.small instance on which the Cloud Controller runs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: LaunchTemplate: Cloud Controller instance configuration. Also needed for the controller self-update feature.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: IAM role, instance profile, and policy: Certain permissions are necessary for the controller to query the build node states.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Secret Manager: The template creates two secrets, respectively, for storing the WorkspaceID and the Controller Token.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Cloud Watch log group: The template creates a Cloud Watch log group for storing Controller error logs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Security groups: The template creates two security groups: one for the LoadBalancer and one for the instance.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: Template parameters:

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: Stack Name (required): Identifies the Bitrise Cloud Controller parent stack within the AWS Account.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: Latest AMI ID: This AMI ID is used as a base AMI to run the Cloud Controller on.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: BitriseControllerToken (required): The controller token the user receives when creating a controller on the Bitrise Website.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: BitriseWorkspaceID (required): The workspace ID belonging to the customer’s Bitrise account.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerLogGroupClass (required): The controller saves error logs to a CloudWatch log group within the customer AWS Account. The customer controls which Log Group Class fits their budget the most. The default value should be suitable for most of the cases. Default: INFREQUENT_ACCESS.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerLogRetentionInDays (required): The number of days Cloud Watch should retain the Controller error logs. Default: 7 (days).

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerSshKey (required): Provides SSH access for the Cloud Controller instance.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: EnvironmentName (optional): Adds a prefix to each piece of Bitrise-related infrastructure with the Environment Name. In case the customer has a vast number of resources, it might come in handy to be able to distinguish Bitrise-related resources from the rest.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PrivateSubnet1CIDR (required): CIDR range of the first private subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.32.0/20.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PrivateSubnet2CIDR (required): CIDR range of the second private subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.64.0/20.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PublicSubnet1CIDR (required): CIDR range of the first public subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.0.0/20.

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PublicSubnet2CIDR (required): CIDR range of the second public subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.16.0/20

title: Deploy Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: VpcCidrBlock (required): The CIDR block of the selected VPC.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Internal Application Load Balancer: Servers have no traffic and only perform periodic health checks on the Cloud Controller instance. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Autoscaling Group: Makes sure that a healthy Cloud Controller instance is running at a time.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Instance: a t2.small instance on which the Cloud Controller runs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: LaunchTemplate: Cloud Controller instance configuration. Also needed for the controller self-update feature.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: IAM role, instance profile, and policy: Certain permissions are necessary for the controller to query the build node states.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Secret Manager: The template creates two secrets, respectively, for storing the WorkspaceID and the Controller Token.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Cloud Watch log group: The template creates a Cloud Watch log group for storing Controller error logs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Security groups: The template creates two security groups: one for the LoadBalancer and one for the instance.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: VPC: A standard, general-purpose VPC based on best practices. Choosing the default CIDR block results in subnets with 4096 available IP addresses. The list of VPC-related resources the template creates:

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One VPC.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Two public subnets.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Two private subnets.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One NAT Gateway + one Elastic IP.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One Internet Gateway + one Elastic IP.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Routing tables.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Bitrise Agent Logs: This functionality allows for seamless sending of Bitrise Agent build logs to AWS CloudWatch. It leverages CloudFormation to automatically set up the necessary IAM roles and policies, ensuring the Bitrise Agent has appropriate permissions. Moreover, it creates a specific log group in CloudWatch named bitrise-agent-log, facilitating organized log management and real-time analysis within the AWS environment.

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template
body: Create the following interface-type VPC endpoints using the configured subnet:

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template

body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.autoscaling: Used for controller self-update.

body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ec2: Used for EC2 instance and dedicated host management.

body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ecr.api: Used for downloading controller binary from Bitrise private ECR.

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ecr.dkr: Used for downloading controller binary from Bitrise private ECR.

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.logs: Used for sending controller logs to CloudWatch.

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.secretsmanager: Used for accessing secrets.

title: Manual configuration for the airgapped template
body: Apply the created endpoints to the Instance Security group.
