body: Latest AMI ID: This AMI ID is used as a base AMI to run the Cloud Controller on.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: BitriseControllerToken (required): The controller token the user receives when creating a controller on the Bitrise Website.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: BitriseWorkspaceID (required): The workspace ID belonging to the customer’s Bitrise account.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerLogGroupClass (required): The controller saves error logs to a CloudWatch log group within the customer AWS Account. The customer controls which Log Group Class fits their budget the most. The default value should be suitable for most of the cases. Default: INFREQUENT_ACCESS.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerLogRetentionInDays (required): The number of days Cloud Watch should retain the Controller error logs. Default: 7 (days).

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: ControllerSshKey (required): Provides SSH access for the Cloud Controller instance.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: EnvironmentName (optional): Adds a prefix to each piece of Bitrise-related infrastructure with the Environment Name. In case the customer has a vast number of resources, it might come in handy to be able to distinguish Bitrise-related resources from the rest.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PrivateSubnet1CIDR (required): CIDR range of the first private subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.32.0/20.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PrivateSubnet2CIDR (required): CIDR range of the second private subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.64.0/20.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PublicSubnet1CIDR (required): CIDR range of the first public subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.0.0/20.

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: PublicSubnet2CIDR (required): CIDR range of the second public subnet of the new VPC. Default: 10.192.16.0/20

title: Deploy Airgapped Cloud Controller to a new VPC
body: VpcCidrBlock (required): The CIDR block of the selected VPC.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Internal Application Load Balancer: Servers have no traffic and only perform periodic health checks on the Cloud Controller instance. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Autoscaling Group: Makes sure that a healthy Cloud Controller instance is running at a time.Instance: a t2.small instance on which the Cloud Controller runs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Instance: a t2.small instance on which the Cloud Controller runs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Airgapped LaunchTemplate: Cloud Controller instance configuration. Also needed for the controller self-update feature.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: IAM role, instance profile, and policy: Certain permissions are necessary for the controller to query the build node states.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Secret Manager: The template creates two secrets, respectively, for storing the WorkspaceID and the Controller Token.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Cloud Watch log group: The template creates a Cloud Watch log group for storing Controller error logs.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Airgapped security groups: The template creates two security groups: one for the LoadBalancer and one for the instance.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: VPC: A standard, general-purpose VPC based on best practices. Choosing the default CIDR block results in subnets with 4096 available IP addresses. The list of VPC-related resources the template creates:

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One VPC.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Two public subnets.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Two private subnets.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One NAT Gateway + one Elastic IP.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: One Internet Gateway + one Elastic IP.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Routing tables.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: VPC Endpoints: The template creates 6 interface type endpoints and connects them to the instance security group to enable controller access to AWS resources:

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.autoscaling: Used for controller self-update.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ec2: Used for EC2 instance and dedicated host management.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ecr.api: Used for downloading controller binary from Bitrise private ECR.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.ecr.dkr: Used for downloading controller binary from Bitrise private ECR.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.logs: Used for sending controller logs to CloudWatch.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: com.amazonaws.${AWS::Region}.secretsmanager: Used for accessing secrets.

title: Infrastructure provisioned by the template
body: Bitrise Agent Logs: This functionality allows for seamless sending of Bitrise Agent build logs to AWS CloudWatch. It leverages CloudFormation to automatically set up the necessary IAM roles and policies, ensuring the Bitrise Agent has appropriate permissions. Moreover, it creates a specific log group in CloudWatch named bitrise-agent-log, facilitating organized log management and real-time analysis within the AWS environment.

title: Necessary AWS permissions and connectivity
body: The controller needs certain AWS permissions to perform actions on the build nodes. We did our best to limit the required permissions to a minimal scope. We even made our CloudFormation template repository public to build trust. Please see the entire list of (up-to-date) required permissions in the repository.

title: Necessary AWS permissions and connectivity
body: The controller requires connectivity to certain Bitrise endpoints. See more in the controller documentation.

title: Configuring a machine pool
body: After you created an AWS controller, you can configure a machine pool. The pool is a group of instances that share the same configuration and can run Bitrise builds. The Controller ensures that the necessary amounts of matching resources are started on AWS.

title: Configuring a machine pool
body: After you created an AWS controller, you can configure a machine pool. The pool is a group of instances that share the same configuration and can run Bitrise builds. The Controller ensures that the necessary amounts of matching resources are started on AWS.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Creating a new pool is happening through a multi-stage wizard, where you need to provide details about the pool:

title: Creating a new pool
body: Open your Workspace settings page.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Select Self-hosted infrastructure and go to the Bitrise on AWS tab, then click Create pool.

title: Creating a new pool
body: On the first screen, configure your agent pool settings:

title: Creating a new pool
body: Pool name (required): The pool name will appear on the Stacks & Machines tab of the Workflow Editor to allow you to select the pool to run builds. The name must be unique within the Workspace, across other pools and Bitrise agent pools. If the name is not unique, the pool cannot be created.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Number of machines (required): The number of machines created. The higher the number, the more builds can run parallel within the available concurrency.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Rolling update percentage (required): Rolling update percentage configures the expected system availability during machine restarts. The lower the number, the more machines will be available during a change rollout, but the overall time required for the rollout could be significantly higher. The provided values should be between 1% and 100% inclusive. The system rounds up the percentage-based values. If you have five machines with a 95% rolling update percentage, all five machines will be attempted to restart simultaneously. We recommend keeping this number high in case a breaking or blocking change is released (like SSH key rotation) and could be lower for smaller changes (like decreased disk size).

title: Creating a new pool
body: After clicking Next, provide the machine parameters on the next screen:

title: Creating a new pool
body: Amazon Machine Image (AMI) ID (required): AMI is the Bitrise-built environment with all required tools preinstalled to run mobile builds. The provided ID of the AMI you subscribed to must be configured here. Only the Bitrise-managed AMIs are accepted in the current version.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Stack (required for VM-based AMIs): Stack selector becomes available only if the selected AMI is a VM-based MacOS AMI. In this case, the user must select one stack from the dropdown.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Number of virtual machines: Number of VM selector becomes available only if the selected AMI is a VM-based MacOS AMI. In this case, the user must select how many VM should run on the build machines (1 or 2).

title: Creating a new pool
body: Availability zone (required): The availability zone will define where the resources will be reserved. The Controller is going to start resources with the mac2 or mac2-m2 instance families, which are not available in every AWS availability zone. Make sure to select a valid availability zone from the list.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Machine type (required): Machine type selector becomes available only after the Availability zone is provided. The Controller will start the build machines according to the selected machine type.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Select the right region

title: Creating a new pool
body: The Controller is able to start resources only in the same region where it is located. If the selected availability zone is not in the same region, the machines are not going to start.

title: Creating a new pool
body: On the next screen, under Network & security settings, you can specify further details about the machines:

title: Creating a new pool
body: Subnet ID (required): Specify the subnet ID you want to use for your machines from the availability zone configured before. All created machines will run under the same subnet. The machines must be able to reach Bitrise services from the subnet, but it doesn’t need to be a public subnet as Bitrise is not going to initiate communication. Make sure that your instance can access the following endpoints:

title: Creating a new pool
body: https://exec.bitrise.io

title: Creating a new pool
body: https://build-log.services.bitrise.io

title: Creating a new pool
body: Without accessing these endpoints, you won't be able to run builds even after connecting the instance. This means the subnet must be able to access the internet, either via a NAT Gateway or an Internet Gateway. For more details about subnets, check the official AWS documentation.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Auto-assign public IP address: Enabling the this field will ensure that a public IPv4 address is created for the EC2 instances. Enable it only when the configured subnet is public: that is, it has an internet gateway to directly communicate to the internet. If the subnet can't access the internet, disable this option.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Security groups (required): You can specify one or more security group IDs. With the security groups, you can control traffic to your AWS resources.

title: Creating a new pool
body: At a minimum, an empty-default security group is required, which is empty from the incoming side and allows 0.0.0.0/0 for the outgoing side. If you want to use SSH to access your instances, the security groups must have an incoming port 22 open. If SSH access capability is not required, we recommend removing the related security group.

title: Creating a new pool
body: For more details about security groups, check the official AWS documentation.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Network configuration

title: Creating a new pool
body: Make sure that the selected subnet and security group belongs to the same network, otherwise the machines will not start.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Instance profile (optional): You can configure extra IAM roles for your machines with the instance profile. This is necessary if you wish to access any other resources in AWS. For example, if you want to use your S3 bucket as an artifact store. If such capabilities are not needed, leave the profile empty.

title: Creating a new pool
body: This option can be used to include permissions for streaming Bitrise agent logs directly to CloudWatch, offering a centralized solution for log management and monitoring. If the AWS CloudFormation parameters have been set correctly, an instance profile called bitrise-agent-log-instance-profile has been generated. On AWS, you can get the generated ARN of that profile to use here.

title: Creating a new pool
body: SSH key (optional): Facilitates debugging of the instances. You can access the created instances via SSH if an SSH key is provided and the correct security group settings are configured. If debugging is not required, we recommend leaving this field empty.

title: Creating a new pool
body: After clicking Next, configure storage requirements:

title: Creating a new pool
body: Disk type (required): You can select from different root volume types. We recommend going with at least the gp3 setting. For details, check out the AWS documentation.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Storage size (required): Specify the root volume size in GB. Different images are created with different disk sizes that are the required minimum disk size. We recommend setting the disk size at least 50GB more than the minimum.

title: Creating a new pool
body: Prewarming the disk: Disk prewarming is suggested for every EBS device in order to work reliably. This prewarming could take significant time, up to multiple hours in the case of a bigger storage size configuration. The prewarming can be disabled but then the first few builds running on the build machine will fail.

title: Creating a new pool
body: When done, click Create pool

title: Creating a new pool
body: Once a pool is created, the pool details appear on the screen:

title: Creating a new pool
body: In the header, you can see the name of the pool and its state. If the desired state of the pool has not been reached yet, then the state is Updating. A fully working pool’s status is Up-to-date.

title: Creating a new pool
body: You can also see a section about the pool configuration, followed by the individual machines. Each machine also has a state, indicating if and what build is running on it.

title: Reconfiguring a pool
body: If the pool configuration is incorrect (for example, you need to investigate something that needs a different SSH key and a different subnet), hit the Edit button for any configured pools and reconfigure the pool.

title: Reconfiguring a pool
body: When a reconfiguration is requested, the Controller will terminate some running and incorrectly configured resources. When such termination is completed, a new resource will be created instead. This approach aims to reduce your costs as much as possible.

title: Reconfiguring a pool
body: We recommend reviewing the Rolling update percentage setting during the configuration, as it can create reduced availability if the setting is high. However, it can also slow rollout if the setting is low.

title: Reconfiguring a pool
body: When a reconfiguration starts, the pool status becomes Updating, which stays in this status until all the resources are running according to the new configuration. At that time, the pool status becomes Up-to-date again.

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: You can use our proxy for AWS role-based authentication from a VM. The proxy runs on the host and forwards AWS CLI queries to the AWS metadata server, enabling seamless use of role-based authentication.

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: Set up the HTTP_PROXY environment variable specifically for the AWS CLI command you wish to execute. This ensures that only the AWS CLI uses the proxy, preventing other applications from inadvertently using it.

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: For example, this is how you can copy a file from an S3 bucket to your VM:

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: HTTP_PROXY=<http://192.168.64.1:42769> aws s3 cp s3://test-bucket/test_file.txt /tmp/test_file.txt

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: Variable scope

title: Using AWS AMI role-based authentication from the VM
body: Use the HTTP_PROXY variable within the scope of your command to avoid affecting other applications. Setting it globally might cause other applications to use the proxy unintentionally.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: We've listed some of the potential issues you might run into when attempting to use a cloud controller to run Bitrise builds on AWS. If you're experiencing problems, check this page for your issue.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Can't see the Bitrise on AWS screen

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Make sure you’re looking at the correct place on the Workspace settings page.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the page is not there, contact Bitrise. You might need additional access rights.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I see the Bitrise on AWS screen, but I cannot create a new controller

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Only Workspace Owners can create a new controller. Please make sure you have the correct access rights.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The CloudFormation fails to create the stack when setting up the instance on AWS

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Please open a support ticket!

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The controller instance cannot connect to Bitrise

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Confirm that your configuration is correct:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Check the CloudWatch logs for any errors. If the controller starts working but fails to execute anything, you will find the related logs there.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Under AWS Secret Manager & Secrets, validate that both the workspace ID and the controller token are provided correctly.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If any of the above is not configured correctly, destroy the CloudFormation stack and recreate it with the correct settings.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the instance started but cannot connect to Bitrise:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Check the System Logs of the instance:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If you see an Error response from daemon: Get "https://public.ecr.aws/v2/": context deadline exceeded message, you probably don’t have internet access on your instance. Double-check your route table configuration and make sure the configured subnets are able to access the internet.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Ensure that egress communication to the Bitrise URLs works. You can validate it in the following way:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: SSH into the created instance. In the terminal, use telnet, curl, or wget to access cloud-controller-aws-internal.services.bitrise.io:443.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the request runs to timeout, collect the evidence and notify our support.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If you get 404, the egress communication is good.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If none of the above works, get in touch with Bitrise.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The controller instance is randomly recreating

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: This could be part of the normal workflow. A built-in functionality keeps the registered controllers in a fresh version to ensure the controller is compatible with the constantly evolving Bitrise.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The controller also has a built-in health check functionality, which ensures that the instance is always working and working correctly. As part of that, to solve intermittent issues, the instances can occasionally restart. This is not going to prevent the controller from working correctly.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the controller is still restarting frequently or the user suspects issues with the controller’s behavior, please get in touch with Bitrise.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I forgot the controller’s Secret before creating the controller in AWS

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: You can read the token from the AWS Secrets.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I cannot delete the controller from Bitrise

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: You can delete the controller by clicking the Remove button next to the controller on the Workspace settings page. Only Owners of the Workspace can delete a controller.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Removing the controller from AWS

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Deleting the controller from Bitrise does not remove the controller from AWS. That needs to happen separately. After deleting a connected controller from Bitrise, the controller running in AWS will no longer be able to operate.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I cannot create a new machine pool

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Only Workspace Owners can create machine pools. Please make sure you have the correct access rights.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I created a pool, but nothing happens

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Make sure the controller is in a Connected state:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the Controller is in a Connected state, please check the CloudWatch logs for any errors. The CloudWatch logs could hold information about the misconfigured settings. For example:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Image availability and access.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Disk size requirement.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Security group and subnet configuration issues.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I have configured the pool and see a machine, but its status has been Starting for over 3 minutes now

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: When a new MacOS instance starts in AWS, it could take 5-10 minutes to start the underlying infrastructure.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Open the instance details and check the Created at field under Machine details:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If you see that the host details are filled after minutes, but the instance details are empty, that probably means the pool configuration was incorrect. That could be confirmed under AWS CloudWatch logs. Possible issues include a non-existent SSH key, an incorrect subnet or security group, and an unavailable AMI ID configured. Based on the findings, update the machine pool configuration.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The instance has started on the AWS infrastructure if the machine details are filled in. If you see that the machine was created more than 8-9 minutes ago and the machine’s status is still Starting, start investigating:

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Ensure all the configurations and the AWS resources are correctly provided.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Ensure the created instance can reach out to Bitrise: log in to the instance via the provided SSH key and ping exec.bitrise.io.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I have created a pool, and machines are in the Running state, but I can't start builds on them

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Make sure that your builds are targeting the correct pool. In the Workflow Editor, every pool is selectable; make sure the correct agent-pool-*** is selected for the builds.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I have manually added a security group to one of the Bitrise-managed instances, but in a few seconds, the instance status becomes shutting-down

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The controller is responsible for achieving a state of machines configured on the Bitrise page. If any instances deviate from the required configuration, the controller identifies that and restarts the misconfigured resource.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Please reconfigure the pool if you want to change such a configuration.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I would like to reconfigure the pool to have fewer/more instances, but I don’t see the Edit button

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Only Workspace Owners can edit the pool configuration. Please make sure you have the correct access rights.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I requested fewer machines, but in AWS, I still see Bitrise-managed dedicated hosts in pending/available status

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: When a dedicated host is reserved, it cannot be released until 24 hours. The controller tries to free up the oldest dedicated hosts, but the dedicated host cannot be released if the 24-hour window has not passed.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The controller is going to make sure to release the unneeded resources.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I requested fewer machines 5 minutes ago, but there are still as many machines as I had before in the Running state

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Make sure that the controller is still in the Connected state.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: If the controller is connected, the system might prevent machine termination if builds are still running on the machines. If all the machines are running builds, the system marks the machine with the oldest dedicated host to be terminated. The machine termination will also start as soon as the running build finishes.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: The above logic does not target the build expected to finish first. Instead, it targets the dedicated host that could be released soonest to save you extra costs.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I cannot delete the machine pool I have created

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: Only Workspace Owners can delete a machine pool. Workspace Owners can also reconfigure the pools if any of the settings are incorrect, like the desired number of replicas.

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: I need to access Bitrise Agent logs

title: Troubleshooting the cloud controller
body: To obtain Bitrise Agent logs, configure Cloudwatch Bitrise Agent logging. This is an optional feature but we highly recommend using it for better troubleshooting capabilities.

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: Bitrise is available as an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) in the AWS Marketplace. With the Bitrise AMI, you can run Bitrise builds using your own AWS resources on AWS EC2 instances connected to a Bitrise Workspace.

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: Bitrise is available as an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) in the AWS Marketplace. With the Bitrise AMI, you can run Bitrise builds using your own AWS resources on AWS EC2 instances connected to a Bitrise Workspace. This section focuses on how to manually set up a fully customized AWS configuration for Bitrise builds.

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: No inbound traffic required

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: We’ve created the Bitrise on AWS offering with the highest security standards in mind, to match even the most strict company policy requirements. In all cases the Controller and the build machines will initiate network calls toward the Bitrise control plane, so no external inbound traffic is required.

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: The manual setup also requires an active subscription to a Bitrise AMI: Subscribing to the Bitrise on AWS AMIs.

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: Cloud Controller

title: Bitrise on AWS: manual setup
body: Instead of the manual setup, we strongly recommend using the Cloud Controller to set up AWS for Bitrise builds: Bitrise on AWS: Cloud Controller.

title: Setting up the EC2 instance
body: To run Bitrise builds on an AWS EC2 instance, you need to:

title: Setting up the EC2 instance
body: Configure runner pools on Bitrise: Set up a runner pool for your builds and get the token required to connect your Bitrise Workspace to your AWS EC2 instance.

title: Setting up the EC2 instance
body: Subscribe to the Bitrise AMI and launch an AWS EC2 instance. You can launch either a Mac or a Linux instance. For a Mac instance, you'll need to allocate a dedicated host before launching the instance.

title: Setting up the EC2 instance
body: Use the token to connect the instance to your Bitrise Workspace. This will allow the Bitrise agent to run your builds on your EC2 instances.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Every AWS EC2 Mac instance needs to run on a dedicated host. To be able to run the Bitrise AMI on an EC2 instance, you'll need to allocate a dedicated host and launch the EC2 instance on that host. Doing that requires knowing the host ID which AWS automatically generates when you allocate a host.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: AWS pricing for Mac dedicated hosts

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: For macOS instances, a dedicated host must be allocated. On-Demand EC2 Mac Dedicated Hosts have a minimum host allocation and billing duration of 24 hours. For more details, check out the official AWS documentation: Amazon EC2 Dedicated Hosts Pricing.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Service quotas

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Make sure you have enough service quotas in your selected region to be able to launch a dedicated host.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Viewing current quotas.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Request an increase.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: On the EC2 Dashboard, find the Instances menu on the left navigation bar.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Select Dedicated Hosts.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Click Allocate dedicated host.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Fill out the required fields:

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Name tag: This will be the name of your host.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Host ID

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: The name is not the same as the host ID which you need to launch an EC2 instance on the dedicated host. The host ID is automatically generated by AWS.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Instance family: mac2

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Instance type: mac2.metal

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Availability Zone: It depends on the subnets you plan to use. AWS will tell you if there is no node capacity in your chosen zone.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Quantity: The number of hosts you want to create.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Host maintenance: Disabled. The mac2 instance family does not support host maintenance

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: When you're ready, click Allocate.

title: Allocating a dedicated host for EC2 Mac instances
body: Once the host is ready, you can proceed to launch an EC2 Mac instance.

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: We offer a dedicated Bitrise Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to run the Bitrise agent on your own Amazon EC2 instance.

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: This document guides you through launching an instance on the AWS EC2 console UI. The process has three main phases but you can complete it in one sitting:

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: Preparing your EC2 instance.

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: Configuring the instance on AWS.

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: Connecting the instance to your Bitrise workspace.

title: Launching an EC2 instance for the Bitrise AMI
body: You can also launch instances via the AWS CLI.

title: Preparing your EC2 instance
body: Mac instance

title: Preparing your EC2 instance
body: Linux instance

body: Modify the User data of the instance: add the command to launch the Bitrise runner, using the Secret you created in the AWS Secret Manager:

title: Connecting the instance to your Bitrise Workspace
body: When modifying the user data scripts for a macOS instance, make sure that there is no empty space before the start of the script. The first line should always be #!/bin/bash. If there is empty space before this line, the instance won't work.

title: Connecting the instance to your Bitrise Workspace
body:
TOKEN=$(aws --region ${Region} secretsmanager get-secret-value --secret-id MY_SECRET | jq -r '.SecretString')

sudo sed -i '' “s/BITRISE_AGENT_TOKEN/$TOKEN/” /Users/ec2-user/Library/LaunchDaemons/io.bitrise.self-hosted-agent.plist
sudo launchctl load -w /Users/ec2-user/Library/LaunchDaemons/io.bitrise.self-hosted-agent.plist

title: Advanced options for AWS EC2 instances
body: For optimal use of the EC2 instances, we recommend additional configuration that is not strictly required for the instances to run Bitrise builds. Some of these configuration options are best set during instance creation.

title: Connectivity and security of your EC2 instance
body: Once your EC2 instance is ready, make sure you can connect to the instance and that it can connect to the relevant Bitrise services. You can connect to the instance using SSH or in the case of Mac instances, VNC.

title: Connectivity and security of your EC2 instance
body: You can also set a password for your instance.

title: Instance passwords
body: User data

title: Instance passwords
body: To make sure instance behavior is consistent across all instances, we recommend configuring this as part of user data during instance creation.

title: Instance passwords
body: User data is provided either in plain text or in base64 encoded format.

title: Instance passwords
body: By default, the Bitrise AMI doesn't have user passwords. It is the subscriber's responsibility to set the desired password.

title: Instance passwords
body: For a Mac instance, you need to set a user password and the default login.keychain password:

title: Instance passwords
body:
sudo /usr/bin/dscl . -passwd /Users/ec2-user
security set-keychain-password -o "" -p "<new password>" ~/Library/Keychains/login.keychain-db

title: Instance passwords
body: For a Linux instance:

title: Instance passwords
body: sudo passwd

body: User data is provided either in plain text or in base64 encoded format.

title: Increasing disk size on a Mac instance
body: If you have configured a bigger EBS storage for your EC2 Mac instance than the default (400 GB), resize the partition so macOS can use all available disk space:

title: Increasing disk size on a Mac instance
body:
PDISK=$(diskutil list physical external | head -n1 | cut -d" " -f1)
APFSCONT=$(diskutil list physical external | grep "Apple_APFS" | tr -s " " | cut -d" " -f8)
yes | sudo diskutil repairDisk $PDISK

sudo diskutil apfs resizeContainer $APFSCONT 0

title: Increasing disk size on a Mac instance
body: For more information, please refer to the AWS macOS EC2 documentation.

title: Cleaning up your AWS build environment
body: When running a self-hosted agent, one agent executes multiple builds (one after the other). This allows sharing of data between builds on the local filesystem, but it also requires some care in order to avoid one build affecting another.

title: Cleaning up your AWS build environment
body: To avoid this problem, you can clean up your build environment in between builds. To do so, you need to run the Bitrise CLI on the self-hosted machines in agent mode: Cleaning up a persistent build environment

title: Cleaning up a persistent build environment
body: You can configure the Bitrise CLI to run in agent mode: this allows cleaning up persistent build environments when running builds on self-hosted agents.

title: Cleaning up a persistent build environment
body: On Bitrise, a new virtual machine is created every time a build starts and it is destroyed when the build is finished. You can, however run Bitrise builds in a persistent build environment: for example, you can use our on-premise runner or run builds on an AWS EC2 instance. In such an environment, the products of one build might affect subsequent builds.

title: Cleaning up a persistent build environment
body: On self-hosted infrastructure, one Bitrise runner executes multiple builds. This allows sharing data between builds on the local filesystem, but it also requires care in order to avoid one build affecting another.

title: Cleaning up a persistent build environment
body: To avoid the problem, you can configure the Bitrise CLI to run in agent mode. Agent mode requires placing an agent-config.yml in the host machine's ~/.bitrise/ directory. In the file, you can specify which directories to clean up when starting a new build or at the end of a build. It also allows you to run your own custom scripts if you have a more advanced use case than a simple cleanup.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Linux

title: Configuring agent mode
body: macOS

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Add the agent-config.yml file to your ~/.bitrise/ directory.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: If you wish to configure the exact folders in which you want to do cleanup operations, define a bitrise_dirs property.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: The property overrides the default settings: for example, you can set a different path for the BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR environment variable than the default.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Under bitrise_dirs, define the directories that you wish to perform some action on at the start or at the end of builds in a KEY: path format.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: For example, you can define separate directories for all source code checkout, deployable artifacts, and deployable test result artifacts.

title: Configuring agent mode
body:
# Customize the common Bitrise directories
bitrise_dirs:
 # Root directory for all Bitrise data produced at runtime
 BITRISE_DATA_HOME_DIR: /opt/bitrise
 
 # Directory for source code checkout.
 BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /opt/bitrise/workspace/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG
 
 # Directory for deployable artifacts.
 BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/artifacts
 
 # Directory for deployable test result artifacts.
 BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/test_results
 
 # Directory for the html reports
 BITRISE_HTML_REPORT_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/html_reports

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Multiple projects of the same Workspace

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Don’t forget that multiple projects of the same Workspace could run on the same agent. Make sure to always include $BITRISE_APP_SLUG in the directory hierarchy to separate projects and their source code checkouts.

title: Configuring agent mode
body:
# wrong:
BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /opt/bitrise/workspace
# correct:
BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /opt/bitrise/workspace/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Add a hooks property to the agent-config.yml file. This property will define the actions to perform at the start or end of builds. It has four different parameters:

title: Configuring agent mode
body: cleanup_on_build_start: Defines a directory that is cleaned up when a new build is started.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: cleanup_on_build_end: Defines a directory that is cleaned up whenever a build is finished. Not guaranteed to run in the case of build failure.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: do_on_build_start: Defines a custom script that runs when a new build is started.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: do_on_build_end: Defines a custom script that runs when a build is finished. Not guaranteed to run in the case of build failure.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: Nested Workflows

title: Configuring agent mode
body: A Script Step in a Workflow can execute bitrise run nested_workflow and trigger a nested workflow. This nested Workflow inherits all the envs and parameters of the parent Workflow, and the parent Workflow waits for the completion of the nested Workflow. When the nested Workflow is launched this way, hooks and directory cleanups are not executed in this process to avoid unexpected behavior.

title: Configuring agent mode
body: To test the agent mode, start a build. The log should show the following message at the top:

title: Configuring agent mode
body:
Running in agent mode
Config file: .bitrise/agent-config.yml

title: Common configuration examples
body: Fully isolated builds

title: Common configuration examples
body: To minimize state and maximize reliability, each build is assigned unique directories. Source code is checked out from scratch in each build.

title: Common configuration examples
body:
bitrise_dirs:
 BITRISE_DATA_HOME_DIR: /opt/bitrise
 BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/workspace
 BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/artifacts
 BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/test_results

hooks:
 # Since dirs are unique to each build, there is nothing to clean up here:
 cleanup_on_build_start: []
 
 # Clean up everything after the build ends:
 cleanup_on_build_end:
 - $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR
 - $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR
 - $BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR

title: Common configuration examples
body: Shared source code directory for warm checkouts

title: Common configuration examples
body: For faster source code checkouts, it’s possible to reuse a previous build’s source code directory.

title: Common configuration examples
body:
bitrise_dirs:
 BITRISE_DATA_HOME_DIR: /opt/bitrise
 # Use a warm clone of the repo for all builds:
 BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/workspace
 # For artifacts and test results, it's still a good idea to place them into unique dirs
 BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/artifacts
 BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR: /opt/bitrise/$BITRISE_APP_SLUG/$BITRISE_BUILD_SLUG/test_results

hooks:
 # Since dirs are unique to each build, there is nothing to clean up here:
 cleanup_on_build_start: []
 
 # Optional: clean up artifacts and test results.
 # Note that $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR is NOT clean up here!
 cleanup_on_build_end:
 - $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR
 - $BITRISE_TEST_DEPLOY_DIR

title: Accounts
body: When you sign up for Bitrise, you create your own individual user account. By itself, having a user account isn’t enough to add apps and run builds. For that, you must be part of a Workspace.

title: Accounts
