title: Assigning a group from the Project settings page
body: Click on Grant access for group.

title: Assigning a group from the Project settings page
body: Find the group you wish to add and select the role for the group using the dropdown menus.

title: Assigning a group from the Project settings page
body: Click Save.

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: From the menu on the left, select Collaboration.

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: Go to the Group tab.

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: Search for the group you would like to remove and click "".

title: Revoking access to a project from a group
body: Click Remove in the dialog to revoke the group's access from the project.

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: From the menu on the left, select Collaboration.

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: Go to the People tab.

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: Find the user you would like to remove and click "".

title: Revoking access to a project from a single user
body: Click Remove in the dialog.

title: User roles on project teams
body: Bitrise apps have user roles defined on their team. They limit what you can and cannot do with an application. The same user can have different roles on different projects.

title: User roles on project teams
body: Roles provide access control on Bitrise: they limit what actions a user can and cannot perform on a Bitrise project.

title: User roles on project teams
body: Roles work on an project basis: the same user can have different roles on different applications.

title: User roles on project teams
body: Workspace members - both viewers and managers - can be assigned to a project’s team either individually or in a Workspace group.

title: User roles on project teams
body: There are four types of roles that you can assign to a user on a project's team:

title: User roles on project teams
body: Admin

title: User roles on project teams
body: Platform Engineer

title: User roles on project teams
body: Developer

title: User roles on project teams
body: Tester/QA

title: User roles on project teams
body: In addition, each project has Owners.

title: Owners
body: Bitrise projects are owned by Workspaces. On the project's team, users who are owners in the Workspace have the owner access right to the project.

title: Owners
body: Owners have unlimited access to projects. Only owners can destroy projects or transfer the ownership of projects, and only they have access to payment information.

title: Admins
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for admins of a project's team:

title: Admins
body: An admin cannot delete a project but can invite other members to work on the project. The admin can also give admin rights to other users. However, they cannot transfer ownership of the project: only Owners can do that.

title: Admins
body: Release manager role

title: Admins
body: Admins are also granted the Release manager role by default. They can also grant Release manager acccess to other users: Granting Release manager rights.

title: Developers
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for developers:

title: Developers
body: Developers cannot change team member roles, add new team members, remove existing team members or create, edit or delete Workflows. They can, however, run builds and view build logs.

title: Developers
body: They have no access to sensitive data such as payment information, access tokens or even webhooks.

title: Platform Engineers
body: Here's the role cheatsheet for Platform Engineers:

title: Platform Engineers
body: Platform Engineers can do everything that Developers can, and in addition to that, they can also edit Workflows. They can't access the project settings, manage team members or billing, and they can't delete the project.

title: Testers/QA
body: Here’s the role cheatsheet for testers/QA:

title: Testers/QA
body: Testers can only view builds. They cannot access build logs and they cannot modify the project in any way or form.

title: Testers/QA
body: They have no access to sensitive data such as payment information, access tokens or even webhooks.

title: Changing the owner of a project
body: You can change the owner of a project from the Workspace profile page or from the project's project settings page.

title: Changing the owner of a project
body: Workspaces own projects. When you add a project to Bitrise, you select the Workspace that will act as the owner of the project. From that point, only the owners of the Workspace can change the ownership of the project.

title: Changing the owner of a project
body: It can happen that you need to transfer a project on Bitrise to another Workspace. This can be done in two ways:

title: Changing the owner of a project
body: You can select the projects you want to transfer from the Workspace profile page's Projects tab.

title: Changing the owner of a project
body: Any given project can be transferred from the project's Project settings page.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Owners only

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: You must be an owner of the Workspace to transfer its projects to another Workspace.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Log in to Bitrise and hover over the left navigation bar.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Make sure you have the right workspace selected in the Workspace menu.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Select Settings.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: On the left, select Projects from the menu options.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Click the Move project (↔) button next to the project's name to select a project.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Projects with outside contributors

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: When transferring projects with outside contributors to a Workspace that doesn't allow outside contributors, the existing contributors are automatically removed from the project's team.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Select a user or Workspace to transfer the project to them.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Click Move project to finalize.

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Transferring ownership is permanent

title: Transferring projects on the Workspace profile page
body: Only the new owner can change the project's ownership after the transfer has been completed!

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Log in with an account that is an owner of the project.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Open the Project settings page.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Select Basic settings on the left and find the Danger Zone label.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Click the Move project button.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Select a Workspace to transfer the project to it.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Click Move project to finalize.

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Transferring ownership is permanent!

title: Transferring a project on the Project settings page
body: Only the new owner can change the project's ownership after the transfer has been completed!

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: You can enable the Bitrise Support Access from the Project settings page. This way, our support team can have access to your project, specifically your Workflow, build log, project settings, and your bitrise.yml.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: In this article we describe how you can enable the Bitrise Support Access so that our Support team can have access to your project, specifically your Workflow, build log, project settings or your bitrise.yml file. With the toggle function, you can easily turn the Bitrise Support Access on and off. No need to add us as a user to your project's Team.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: The Bitrise Support user, when enabled, has Admin access to your project. That means it can do anything that a regular user with Admin access rights on a project can do: it has access to your builds and Workflows, to all the settings in the Workflow Editor and to the Project settings page.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: No access to billing information

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: The Bitrise Support user can’t see your Account information or any Billing information. Only the owner of the account has access to this information and has the right to modify any account-related records.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: The Support user can’t see your other projects where the Support user is not enabled. For details, see What the Bitrise Support user can/can't do?

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: How long does the Bitrise Support Access remain active?

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: Due to security reasons once you toggle the Bitrise Support Access on, it will remain active for two weeks after which it automatically gets revoked.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: Let’s see how to set it up!

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: On the left, select General from the menu options.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: Scroll down to the Support Access and toggle the switch to the right to enable it. It might take a couple of seconds to work and you might need to refresh your page to see the enabled status.

title: Enabling the Bitrise Support Access for your project
body: In case of a failing Workflow, our best practice is to create a new and correct version of the failing Workflow called support-testing. You can compare our support-testing with your own and update yours or keep the support-testing Workflow, rename it as you wish, and develop it further.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: You can embed a Bitrise status badge on your site and show visitors the state of your latest build. You can choose to display the status of any build, regardless of the repository branch it was built from, or you can select a specific branch.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: You can get the embed code from the Project settings page of the app, using a status image API token.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Scroll down to the Build status badge section and click Get code.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Optionally, type a branch name in the Branch field.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: If you type a valid branch name, the status of builds from this branch will be shown. If you leave the field empty, the status of any build of the project will be shown.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Choose the format of the embed code in the Format menu: you can choose between a simple HTTPS URL or you can get the code in Markdown.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Copy the embed code from the Embed section.

title: Embedding a build status badge to your site
body: Paste the code to your website.

title: The status image API token
body: The status image API token is a special token which can only be used for the status badge update. No other information can be retrieved with this token. It returns a simple JSON object. For example, if the latest build is successful:

title: The status image API token
body: { "status": "success" }

title: The status image API token
body: The possible status responses are:

title: The status image API token
body: success: If the last finished build was successful.

title: The status image API token
body: error: If the last finished build failed or was aborted.

title: The status image API token
body: unknown: In any other case, for example, if there was no finished build.

title: Public projects
body: To create a public project, simply add a new project to Bitrise and at the start of the process, set the privacy of the project to Public. If your Bitrise project is public, anyone who has the build URL can see the build logs.

title: Public projects
body: Open source projects are great - we all love them! They can be a pain to maintain, however, especially with CI/CD in the picture. That’s why we have introduced the Public projects feature for Bitrise: to make everyone’s life a lot easier!

title: Public projects
body: If your Bitrise project is public, anyone who has the build URL can see the build logs. For example, if the CI status check on GitHub fails on a pull request, anyone can click on the build URL and view the build logs.

title: Public projects
body: To create a public project, simply add a new project to Bitrise and at the start of the process, set the privacy of the project to Public.

title: Public projects
body: Can't modify privacy later

title: Public projects
body: You can't change this setting later! Once you've added an project as a public project, you can't set it back to private. You would have to add the project again.

title: Public projects
body: When you have a public project, outside contributors can troubleshoot issues easier, find out why, for example, a pull request of theirs resulted in a failed build. They do not have to be invited to a Bitrise team to be able to view Bitrise logs and they do not need the help of a Bitrise team member, either.

title: Public projects
body: Of course, this does not mean anyone can do anything with your public project on Bitrise. If the user viewing the logs is not invited to work on the project in some role, they will only be able to:

title: Public projects
body: View the build logs.

title: Public projects
body: Download the build logs.

title: Public projects
body: View the build’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Public projects
body: Public project’s build logs are available for anyone

title: Public projects
body: Remember: a public project’s build logs and bitrise.yml file can be seen by anyone - make sure these files do not expose anything you do not want to be seen!

title: Creating white label app versions
body: You can create different versions of your white label project and build all or just one version by chaining Workflows and setting differences in Environment Variables.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: This guide explains how to create different versions of your white label project and build all or just one version by chaining Workflows and setting differences in Environment Variables.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: In this article, we’re building three individual versions (red, green, white) of our white label project.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: What you’ll need for this setup:

title: Creating white label app versions
body: A main Workflow that launches each version-specific Workflow.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: One or more version-specific Workflow(s) where you can set all the parameters that distinguish your versions from each other.

title: Creating white label app versions
body: A utility Workflow which describes your build logic, and refers to the version-specific options as parameters. Utility Workflows are Workflows that have an underscore before their Workflow ID. Utility Workflows cannot be executed with the bitrise_run command: you need to reference them with the before_run or after_run properties. You can chain utility Workflows with your regular Workflows in the Workflow Editor.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add your project to Bitrise in the usual way.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Select your project on the Bitrise CI page and click Workflows.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Open the dropdown menu of available Workflows and click Create Workflow to create your main Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add a new Workflow based on an Empty Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: In this example, our main Workflow is called allcolor. This Workflow will start running your version-specific Workflows in the chain.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Click + again to create your version-specific Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Keep adding as many Workflows as many different versions you wish to create.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Select Env Vars on the left navigation menu and add your version-specific parameters to each Workflow you’ve just created.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: In this example we’re adding Workflow Environment Variables to our green, red and white Workflows but leaving allcolor intact.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Go back to Workflows and create a utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Make sure you give a name that starts with an underscore, for example, _runner, otherwise Bitrise CLI will not treat it as a utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: Add Steps to your utility Workflow.

title: Prepping Workflows of a white label app
body: In this example, we’re adding a Script Step which will inherit the Environment Variable from the Workflows and print out the value in the build log.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Now that we have a bunch of Workflows ready, it’s time to chain them together in the right order.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Select your main Workflow (allcolor in this example). This is the Workflow that should be triggered by your build triggers.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Click the vertical ellipsis next to the Workflow's name and select Chain Workflows. Select a version Workflow (for example, white) and click Add after.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Add each version-specific Workflow the same way (such as white, green, and red in our example) and add your utility Workflow after each of them, as seen in this image:

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: Go back to your Build’s page and click Start build.

title: Chaining Workflows for a white label app
body: In the Build configuration dialog, select your main Workflow under Workflow. This will kickstart your chained Workflows and build the app versions of your white label app.

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: Steps, Workflows, and Pipelines are the heart of how Bitrise works. A Bitrise build is simply a series of Steps, defined in a Workflow, executed by the Bitrise CLI on our virtual machines (or your own). A Pipeline is a collection of Workflows, organised in Stages.

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: Steps and Workflows are the heart of how Bitrise works. A Bitrise build is simply a series of Steps, defined in a Workflow, executed by the Bitrise CLI on our virtual machines (or your own).

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates.

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: When a build of an app is running, the Steps will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: You can easily move Steps around in a Workflow, you can chain different Workflows together, and you can configure your app so that different branches or code events trigger builds with different Workflows.

title: Workflows and Pipelines
body: You can execute multiple Workflows in parallel in a Pipeline. Pipelines are the highest level of the Bitrise CI/CD configuration. It consists of Stages: each Stage can contain multiple Workflows that are executed in parallel.

title: Workflows
body: A Bitrise Workflow is a collection of Steps. When a build of an app is running, each Step will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Workflows
body: A Bitrise Workflow is a collection of Steps. When a build of an app is running, each Step will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow. Workflows can be created, defined and modified in two ways:

title: Workflows
body: Using the graphical Workflow Editor on bitrise.io, or the offline version on your own device.

title: Workflows
body: Directly editing the bitrise.yml file of your project.

title: Workflows
body: Ultimately, both methods modify the bitrise.yml file - the Workflow Editor is simply a friendlier way of doing so!

title: Workflows
body: By default, a single build is a single Workflow. But you can also chain Workflows together so they run in succession, as well as to trigger multiple Workflow to run simultaneously.

title: Workflows
body: Workflows can also be arranged into Pipelines. A Pipeline consists of multiple Stages and each Stage consists of one or more Workflows which run in parallel.

title: Default Workflows
body: When you add a new app on bitrise.io, one or two Workflows are created automatically, depending on your app.

title: Default Workflows
body: When you add a new app on bitrise.io, we create your initial Workflows for you. These are your default Workflows. You can use these to run your tests or create installable app packages such as IPAs or APKs. Feel free to modify the default Workflows to suit your needs.

title: Default Workflows for an iOS app
body: For a new iOS app, Bitrise automatically generates two Workflows. The Steps of these default Workflows depend on whether you have tests configured on your Xcode project. These Workflows are basic iOS Workflows that allow you to discover how Bitrise works. You can customize these Workflows or create new ones based on them.

title: Default Workflows for an iOS app
body: Default iOS Workflows

title: Default Workflows for an Android app
body: For a new Android app, Bitrise automatically generates two Workflows: run_tests and build_apk. These are basic Android Workflows that allow you to discover how Bitrise works. You can customize these Workflows or create new ones based on them.

title: Default Workflows for an Android app
body: Default Android Workflows

title: Default Workflows for multiplatform apps
body: For multiplatform apps - apps that aren't native iOS or Android apps but created with some mobile development framework, such as React Native, Flutter, Ionic or Cordova -, Bitrise creates two default Workflows: primary and deploy.

title: Default Workflows for multiplatform apps
body: The exact Steps included in these default Workflows depend on the project type. However, the main goals of the two Workflows are the same, regardless of project type:

title: Default Workflows for multiplatform apps
body: The primary Workflow clones your app, installs and caches your dependencies, and runs any tests configured in the project.

title: Default Workflows for multiplatform apps
body: The deploy Workflow, in addition to installing and caching dependencies and running tests, also builds your project: it tries to generate an APK or IPA file.

title: Default Workflows for multiplatform apps
body: For more details about what the default Workflows include for different project types, try out our demo apps!

title: Creating a Workflow
body: You can create new Bitrise Workflows based on any of the existing ones, or you can simply create an empty Workflow and add the Steps yourself.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Workflows in YAML

title: Creating a Workflow
body: This guide is about creating a Workflow in the Workflow Editor. For information on how to create a Workflow in a YAML configuration file, check out Workflow reference.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: It’s very simple to create your own Workflow with the Workflow Editor. You can create new Workflows based on any of the existing ones, or you can simply create an empty Workflow and add the Steps yourself.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: If, for example, you create a Workflow based on your primary one, it means that it will be created with the exact same Steps and input values as the primary Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the + sign on the top.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: In the dialog, give your Workflow a name.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: The name can be as long as you wish since longer titles get broken into multiple lines so that you can read the whole title conveniently.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: From the dropdown menu labeled Based on, select the Workflow you want to use as the basis for the new one.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Alternatively, choose the An empty workflow option to create an empty Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Add the Steps you need to your Workflow.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click the + symbol between two Steps to insert a Step at that position. Remove Steps you do not need by clicking on the Step and clicking the little trash bin symbol.

title: Creating a Workflow
body: Click Save changes in the top right corner.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can chain multiple Workflows and rearrange the order of Workflows in a chain in the Bitrise Workflow Editor. Take advantage of utility Workflows to reuse components in multiple different contexts.

title: Managing Workflows
body: You can chain multiple Workflows and rearrange the order of Workflows in a chain in the Bitrise Workflow Editor. Take advantage of utility Workflows to reuse components in multiple different contexts.

title: Managing Workflows
body: Offline Workflow Editor

title: Managing Workflows
body: Everything described here is also available in the offline Workflow Editor.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: You can set up multiple Workflows to run in succession. The order of these Workflows can be rearranged, new Workflows can be added to the chain and existing Workflows can be removed from it at any time.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click the ellipsis button to the right of the name of the Workflow.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: From the dropdown menu, select Chain Workflow.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Select a Workflow from the list and click either Add before or Add after.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: Chaining Workflows in YAML

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: In this example, we're chaining together three Workflows: test, deploy, and ci, using the before_run and after_run parameters.

title: Chaining Workflows together
body:
workflows:
 test:
 envs:
 - IS_TEST: "true"
 steps:
 # test Steps to run

 deploy:
 before_run:
 - test
 steps:
 # steps to deploy

 ci:
 before_run:
 - test
 after_run:
 - deploy

title: Chaining Workflows together
body: For more information on how to manage Workflows directly in the bitrise.yml file, check Workflow reference.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Once you have a chain, you can easily rearrange the order of Workflows in a drag-and-drop menu.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click the ellipsis labelled Manage Workflows.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: From the dropdown menu, select Reorder Workflow chain to bring up a drag-and-drop menu where you can rearrange the Workflows of the chain.

title: Rearranging chained Workflows
body: Click Save in the top right corner.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Bitrise supports a special type of Workflow called a utility Workflow. A utility Workflow's ID always starts with an underscore character: for example, _setup. They are usually used to perform tasks that are required either at the start or at the end of several different Workflows: for example, you can separate git cloning and activating your SSH key into a utility Workflow instead of adding those Steps to every Workflow of an app.

title: Utility Workflows
body: You can create a utility Workflow the exact same way as you create a regular one. To denote it as a utility Workflow, you just need to prefix the name with an underscore.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflows cannot run alone

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflows cannot be run as standalone Workflows. They need to be chained together with a normal Workflow, either before or after the Workflow: Chaining Workflows together.

title: Utility Workflows
body: Utility Workflow in YAML

title: Utility Workflows
body: In this example, we have two utility Workflows, called _setup and _send-notifications. They are chained together with two Workflows called test and ci using the before_run and after_run parameters.

title: Utility Workflows
body:
workflows:
 _send-notifications:
 steps:
 # send notifications

 _setup:
 steps:
 # setup Steps to run

 test:
 before_run:
 - _setup
 envs:
 - IS_TEST: "true"
 steps:
 # test Steps to run

 ci:
 before_run:
 - test
 after_run:
 - _send-notifications

title: Utility Workflows
body: For more information on how to manage Workflows directly in the bitrise.yml file, check Workflow reference.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: You can copy an existing Bitrise Workflow from any bitrise.yml file, including your local files.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: If you have a lot of apps, you might not want to spend time with setting up Workflows for each and every one of them separately, especially if there’s little difference between the Workflows you want to run for them. If so, the easiest thing to do is to simply copy an existing Workflow.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: YAML mode only

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Copying a Workflow to another app is only possible in YAML mode. You can create a new Workflow based on an existing one but only for the same app.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: You can copy a Workflow from any bitrise.yml file, including your local files. To copy an existing Workflow from one Bitrise app to another on our website:

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML from the navigation menu.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Select the Workflow you want and copy it.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Open the app you want to copy it to.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Go to the Workflow tab and then the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Copying Workflows from one app to another
body: Paste the Workflow under the workflows property.

title: Workflow recipes for Android apps
body: Workflow Recipes provide ready-made solutions for common Workflow tasks.

body: Here you can find Workflow recipes specifically for iOS apps. Some of these can be used for the iOS versions of cross-platform apps, too while some are specifically meant for native iOS apps.

title: (Android) Deploy to Visual Studio App Center
body: (Android) Deploy to Visual Studio App Center

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Visual Studio App Center.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Visual Studio App Center project where your app is registered.

title: Prerequisites
body: Adding the API token as a Secret to your Bitrise app with the name APPCENTER_API_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: If you want to deploy a release build, don't forget to set up code signing on Bitrise to build and sign the APK with your release key.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: set this to apk.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: If you build a release variant, add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: You can skip this if you plan to deploy an unsigned debug variant.

title: Instructions
body: Add the AppCenter iOS Deploy Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: API Token: $APPCENTER_API_TOKEN

title: Instructions
body: Owner name: for example, my-company.

title: Instructions
body: App name: For example, my-app. Use the App Center CLI to get the app name since it might not be the same as the one you can see on the Visual Studio App Center website.

title: Instructions
body: Check out other options in the Step documentation or in the Workflow Editor.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: release
 - build_type: apk
 - sign-apk@1: {}
 - appcenter-deploy-android@2:
 inputs:
 - owner_name: my-company
 - app_name: my-app
 - app_path: "$BITRISE_APK_PATH"
 - api_token: "$APPCENTER_API_TOKEN"

title: (Android) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution
body: (Android) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Firebase App Distribution. This example builds and deploys an APK, but the Workflow can be tweaked to distribute AAB instead.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Firebase project where your exact package name is registered. See the Firebase documentation for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Obtain a token from Firebase by running firebase login:ci locally. See the Firebase CLI docs for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Add this token as a Secret to your Bitrise app with the name FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: Get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input to the Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Prerequisites
body: If you want to deploy a release build, don't forget to set up code signing on Bitrise to build and sign the APK with your release key.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: Set this to apk.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: Use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: If you build a release variant, add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: You can skip this if you plan to deploy an unsigned debug variant.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Firebase App Distribution Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Firebase token: use the secret Env var previously defined: $FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Instructions
body: App path: this should point to the APK that the previous steps have built and signed. By default, it's located at $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/app-release-bitrise-signed.apk, but the exact file name might be different based on your project config.

title: Instructions
body: Firebase App ID: get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input to the Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Instructions
body: Optional: you can define test groups or individual testers in the Step inputs

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - variant: release
 - build_type: apk
- sign-apk@1: {}
- firebase-app-distribution@0:
 inputs:
 - firebase_token: $FIREBASE_TOKEN
 - app_path: $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/app-release-bitrise-signed.apk
 - app: your_app_id_from_firebase
 - testers: email@company.com # optional
 - groups: qa-team #optional

title: (Android) Deploy to Google Play (Internal, Alpha, Beta, Production)
body: (Android) Deploy to Google Play (Internal, Alpha, Beta, Production)

title: Description
body: Build an Android app and upload to Google Play to internal, alpha, beta or production track.

title: Prerequisites
body: An Android keystore file is uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Prerequisites
body: Google Play API Access is set up.

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Add the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step. Set the input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Path to the build.gradle file: The default value is $PROJECT_LOCATION/$MODULE/build.gradle and in most cases you don't have to change it.

title: Instructions
body: New versionName: for example, 1.0.1

title: Instructions
body: New versionCode: for example, 42.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Build Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Build type: Set this to aab.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: Use release, debug, or one of your custom variants if you have any.

title: Instructions
body: Module: for example $MODULE.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Sign Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Google Play Deploy Step and set the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: Service Account JSON key file path: $BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Instructions
body: Package name: for example, com.your.package.name.

title: Instructions
body: Track: Choose one of internal, alpha, beta, or production.

title: Instructions
body: Status: The status of a release. For more information, see the Google API reference. Recommended draft for production and completed for internal test builds.

title: Instructions
body: Check the other options in the Workflow Editor or in the Step documentation.

title: Instructions
body: Deploy to Google Play fails with Error 403

title: Instructions
body: You might experience that Deploy to Google Play Step fails with error:

title: Instructions
body: "error: Failed to perform edit insert call, error: googleapi: Error 403: The caller does not have permission, forbidden"

title: Instructions
body: For possible solutions, check out our Knowledge Base article.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- change-android-versioncode-and-versionname@1:
 inputs:
 - new_version_name: 1.0.1
 - new_version_code: '42'
 - build_gradle_path: "$PROJECT_LOCATION/$MODULE/build.gradle"
- android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: "$PROJECT_LOCATION"
 - module: "$MODULE"
 - build_type: aab
 - variant: release
- sign-apk@1: {}
- google-play-deploy@3:
 inputs:
 - service_account_json_key_path: "$BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL"
 - package_name: io.bitrise.sample.android
 - status: completed
 - track: internal

body: (Android) Example CI Workflow

title: Description
body: Example Workflow for commits on the main branch of an Android app. The Workflow contains:

title: Description
body: Running unit tests.

title: Description
body: Running UI tests on a virtual device.

title: Description

title: bitrise.yml
body:
---
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: android
workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@6: {}
 - cache-pull@2: {}
 - android-unit-test@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $PROJECT_LOCATION
 - variant: $VARIANT
 - android-build-for-ui-testing@0:
 inputs:
 - variant: $VARIANT
 - module: $MODULE
 - virtual-device-testing-for-android@1:
 inputs:
 - test_type: instrumentation
 - android-lint@0:
 inputs:
 - variant: "$VARIANT"
 - android-build@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: "$PROJECT_LOCATION"
 - module: "$MODULE"
 - variant: "$VARIANT"
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}
 - slack@3:
 inputs:
 - channel: "#build-notifications"
 - webhook_url: "$SLACK_WEBHOOK"
 - cache-push@2: {}
app:
 envs:
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 PROJECT_LOCATION: "."
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 MODULE: app
 - VARIANT: debug
 opts:
 is_expand: false
trigger_map:
- push_branch: main
 workflow: ci

title: (Android) Run instrumentation tests on virtual devices
body: (Android) Run instrumentation tests on virtual devices

title: Description
body: Run instrumentation (for example, Espresso) or robo/gameloop tests on virtual devices. Our device testing solution is based on Firebase Test Lab. You can find the resulting logs, videos and screenshots on Bitrise.

title: Instructions
body: Add an Android Build for UI Testing Step. Set the input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Project Location: Use the default $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR or $PROJECT_LOCATION. You can set a specific path but the automatically exposed Environment Variables are usually the best option.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: Use the $VARIANT Enviromment Variable, or specify a variant manually.

title: Instructions
body: Module: Specify one or leave it blank to run tests in all of the modules.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Virtual Device Testing for Android Step. Set the input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Test type: instrumentation (or robo or gameloop)

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Test devices (default: NexusLowRes,24,en,portrait).

title: Instructions
body: Add a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step that makes the test results available in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Instructions
body: Potential issues with running instrumentation tests on virtual devices

title: Instructions
body: You might encounter some unexpected issues while running instrumentation tests on virtual devices. You can find some examples and possible solutions in our Knowledge Base:

title: Instructions
body: Tips for flaky Android emulator tests

title: Instructions
body: Test failed with Virtual Device Testing for Android Step

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-build-for-ui-testing@0:
 inputs:
 - variant: $VARIANT
 - module: $MODULE
- virtual-device-testing-for-android@1:
 inputs:
 - test_type: instrumentation
- deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}

title: Turn on Gradle build profiling
body: Turn on Gradle build profiling

title: Description
body: Generate and store a performance report of every Gradle build to spot build speed issues or compare different builds.

title: Instructions
body: No matter what Android or Gradle Step you use in your Bitrise Workflow, there is an option to define additional command line arguments for Gradle. Add --profile to the relevant input variable to generate a performance report of the Gradle tasks. In the example below, we are adding the argument to the Android Unit Test Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Android Unit Test Step to your Workflow and set the necessary input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Project location: $PROJECT_LOCATION.

title: Instructions
body: Module: $MODULE.

title: Instructions
body: Variant: $VARIANT.

title: Instructions
body: Arguments: --profile2.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Script Step to the end of the Workflow to compress the report files and copy the ZIP file to the deploy directory:

title: Instructions
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# fail if any commands fails
set -e
# debug log
set -x

zip -r $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/gradle-profile.zip $PROJECT_LOCATION/build/reports/profile

title: Instructions
body: Gradle creates the HTML report in build/reports/profile/, so we need to take all files in that folder (HTML, CSS and JS files), compress them, and move the ZIP archive to $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. Files in this folder can be accessed on the build page’s Artifacts tab.

title: Instructions
body: Trigger a manual build of your app.

title: Instructions
body: Download and unarchive the gradle-profile.zip file, then open the HTML report in your browser.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Artifacts tab and check the various aspects of the build in the report:

title: Instructions
body: The Summary tab shows time spent on things other than task execution.

title: Instructions
body: The Task execution tab lists all tasks sorted by execution time.

title: Instructions
body: Cached tasks are marked as UP-TO-DATE. This helps to fine-tune the Bitrise Cache Steps by comparing the reports of multiple builds.

title: Instructions
body: For Gradle optimization ideas, check out this article by Google.

title: Instructions
body: If you only want to display task execution times only in the build log, you can use the build-time-tracker plugin.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- android-unit-test@1:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $PROJECT_LOCATION
 - module: $MODULE
 - arguments: "--profile"
 - variant: $VARIANT
- script@1:
 title: Collect Gradle profile report
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 zip -r $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/gradle-profile.zip $PROJECT_LOCATION/build/reports/profile
- deploy-to-bitrise-io@1: {}

body: (Android) Run tests using the emulator

title: Description
body: Run any kind of tests (unit, instrumentation) on a local emulator instance.

title: Instructions
body: Add an AVD Manager Step. To customize the emulator, see the Step configuration.

title: Instructions
body: Using the AVD Manager Step

title: Instructions
body: The AVD Manager starts in the background, which can take several minutes. Because of that, we recommend adding the AVD Manager Step at the beginning of your Workflow (before Activate SSH key (RSA private key) Step and the Git Clone Step) to speed up your builds.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Android Build for UI Testing Step, and configure the required inputs.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Wait for Android emulator Step.

title: Instructions
body: Add an Android Instrumented Test Step, and configure the required inputs.

title: Instructions
body: Add an Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step with the following inputs:

title: Instructions
body: The name of the test: Emulator tests.

title: Instructions
body: Test result base path: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/app/build/outputs/androidTest-results.

title: Instructions
body: You might want to adjust the path based on the module name(s) in your project.

title: Instructions
body: Test result search pattern: *.xml.

title: Instructions
body: Add a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step that makes the test results available in the Test Reports add-on.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- avd-manager@1: {}
- android-build-for-ui-testing@0:
 inputs:
 - module: "$ANDROID_TESTING_MODULE"
 - variant: "$ANDROID_V_DEBUG"
- wait-for-android-emulator@1:
- android-instrumented-test@0: {}
- custom-test-results-export@0:
 inputs:
 - search_pattern: "*.xml"
 - base_path: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR/app/build/outputs/androidTest-results
 - test_name: Emulator tests
- deploy-to-bitrise-io@2:

title: (iOS) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution
body: (iOS) Deploy to Firebase App Distribution

title: Description
body: Build and distribute your app to testers via Firebase App Distribution.

title: Prerequisites
body: An existing Firebase project where your exact bundle ID is registered. Follow the Firebase documentation for details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Obtain a token from Firebase by running firebase login:ci locally. See the Firebase CLI docs for more details.

title: Prerequisites
body: Add this token as a Secret to your Bitrise project with the name FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Prerequisites
body: Get your Firebase App ID from your project's General Settings page and pass this value as an input variable to the [BETA] Firebase App Distribution Step.

title: Prerequisites
body: You have code signing set up. See iOS code signing for more details.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step and set the required input variables, such as Scheme, Distribution method and the desired code signing method.

title: Instructions
body: Add the [BETA] Firebase App Distribution Step and set the following input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Firebase token: use the secret env var previously defined: $FIREBASE_TOKEN.

title: Instructions
body: Firebase App ID: see the Prerequisites section above for details.

title: Instructions
body: Optionally, you can define test groups or individual testers in the Step input variables.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- xcode-archive@6:
 inputs:
 - distribution_method: development
 - scheme: # your scheme goes here
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key
- firebase-app-distribution@0:
 inputs:
 - firebase_token: $FIREBASE_TOKEN
 - app: # your app ID from Firebase
 - testers: email@company.com # optional
 - groups: qa-team #optional

title: (iOS) Override the Apple service connection credentials using Step inputs
body: (iOS) Override the Apple service connection credentials using Step inputs

title: Description
body: You can override the Apple service connection credentials configured in the App Settings by setting the inputs under the App Store Connect connection override input group in the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step.

title: Description
body: This can be useful if your team uses multiple App Store accounts or if you manage multiple apps in a single Bitrise app and would like to use different Apple service connections based on your Workflow.

title: Prerequisites
body: Before starting, generate or get the following using App Store Connect:

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API private key.

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API key ID.

title: Prerequisites
body: App Store Connect API issuer ID.

title: Prerequisites
body: For more information, check out Creating App Store Connect API private keys.

title: Instructions
body: Upload your App Store Connect API private key file (.p8 file) to the Generic File Storage in the Code Signing tab.

title: Instructions
body: Add the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step (version 4.6.0 or newer) to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to api-key.

title: Instructions
body: Set the following Step inputs under the App Store Connect connection override input group:

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API private key: Local path or remote URL to the private key (.p8 file) for App Store Connect API. Set this input to the automatically generated Env Var connected to the App Store Connect API private key file (.p8 file) you uploaded to the Generic File Storage in step 1.

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API key ID: Private key ID used for App Store Connect authentication.

title: Instructions
body: App Store Connect API issuer ID: Private key issuer ID used for App Store Connect authentication.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- xcode-archive@4:
 inputs:
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key
 - api_key_path: "$BITRISEIO_APP_STORE_CONNECT_API_ID_URL"
 - api_key_id: "$APP_STORE_API_ID"
 - api_key_issuer_id: "$APP_STORE_API_ISSUER_ID"

title: (React Native) Expo: Build using Turtle CLI
body: (React Native) Expo: Build using Turtle CLI

title: Description
body: Publish an app to Expo's servers and build an iOS App Store .ipa and an Android .aab file from your Expo project using Turtle CLI.

title: Prerequisites
body: Generate an iOS Distribution Certificate and an App Store Provisioning Profile based on the Generating iOS code signing files guide.

title: Prerequisites
body: Generate an Android Keystore by following the Android code signing with Android Studio guide.

title: Prerequisites
body: Make sure you can Publish your Expo project locally.

title: Instructions
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Instructions
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Code Signing & Files tab.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the project's iOS Distribution Certificate and App Store Provisioning Profile are uploaded.

title: Instructions
body: If not, add them in the Add Provisioning Profile(s) and the Add a certificate (.p12 file) for code signing, respectively.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the project's Android Keystore file is uploaded.

title: Instructions
body: If not, drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Upload file (max. 5 MB) field of the ANDROID KEYSTORE FILE section.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Instructions
body: Create a Secret (IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM) with the ID of the iOS Development Team issued in the project's Certificate and Provisioning Profile.

title: Instructions
body: Store the Expo account's username and password used for publishing in EXPO_USERNAME and EXPO_PASSWORD Secrets.

title: Instructions
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML from the navigation menu.

title: Instructions
body: Copy paste envs from bitrise.yml below to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: Copy paste steps from bitrise.yml below to your Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: The built .ipa and .aab files are exposed via BITRISE_IPA_PATH and BITRISE_AAB_PATH Env Vars.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
turtle_build:
 envs:
 - KEYSTORE_PATH: /tmp/keystore.jks
 - KEYSTORE_ALIAS: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS
 - EXPO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD
 - EXPO_ANDROID_KEY_PASSWORD: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD
 - PROFILE_PATH: /tmp/profile.mobileprovision
 - CERTIFICATE_PATH: /tmp/certificate.p12
 - EXPO_IOS_DIST_P12_PASSWORD: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_PASSPHRASE
 # Define these in your secrets
 - IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM: $IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM
 - EXPO_USERNAME: $EXPO_USERNAME
 - EXPO_PASSWORD: $EXPO_PASSWORD
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Install dependencies
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 node --version
 fastlane --version

 npm install -g turtle-cli
 turtle --version

 npm install -g expo-cli
 expo --version
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download Android Keystore
 inputs:
 - destination: $KEYSTORE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download iOS Certificate
 inputs:
 - destination: $CERTIFICATE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISE_CERTIFICATE_URL
 - file-downloader@1:
 title: Download iOS Provisioning Profile
 inputs:
 - destination: $PROFILE_PATH
 - source: $BITRISE_PROVISION_URL
 - npm@1:
 title: Install project dependencies
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - set-java-version@1:
 title: Set Java version to Java 8
 inputs:
 - set_java_version: "8"
 - script@1:
 title: Run Expo publish
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 expo login -u $EXPO_USERNAME -p $EXPO_PASSWORD --non-interactive
 expo publish
 - script@1:
 title: Run Turtle build
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 set -ex

 turtle setup:android
 aab_path=$BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/expo-project.aab
 turtle build:android --type app-bundle --keystore-path $KEYSTORE_PATH --keystore-alias $KEYSTORE_ALIAS -o $aab_path
 envman add --key BITRISE_AAB_PATH --value $aab_path

 turtle setup:ios
 ipa_path=$BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR/expo-project.ipa
 turtle build:ios --team-id $IOS_DEVELOPMENT_TEAM --dist-p12-path $CERTIFICATE_PATH --provisioning-profile-path $PROFILE_PATH -o $ipa_path
 envman add --key BITRISE_IPA_PATH --value $ipa_path

Example Gitflow release branch Workflow
body: Example Gitflow release branch Workflow

title: Description
body: An example Workflow that creates a Gitflow release branch for a specific version. The version can be passed on as an Environment Variable for the Workflow.

title: Prerequisites
body: Make sure that Bitrise has write access to your repository by manually adding an SSH key with write permission on GitHub.

title: bitrise.yml
body:
# Run the workflow with $VERSION env set up to, for examaple, '2.4.3'
create-release-branch:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@6: {}
 - script@1:
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

 git checkout -b release-$VERSION
 git push origin release-$VERSION

title: Description
body: Start builds for different apps

title: Description
body: Using this method, you can only start builds for the same app. If you would like to start another build for a different app, you can use the Trigger Bitrise workflow Step.

title: Prerequisites
body: Make sure you have a valid Bitrise API key in your Secrets ($BITRISE_API_KEY). See Personal access tokens for more details.

title: Prerequisites
body: A Workflow or multiple Workflows you would like to run in parallel (for example, workflow-1 and workflow-2).

title: Instructions
body: Add a Bitrise Start Build Step. Set the following input variables:

title: Instructions
body: Workflows: The Workflow(s) to start. Insert only one Workflow per line.

title: Instructions
body: Bitrise Access Token: $BITRISE_API_KEY

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Add any Step you would like to run in parallel while the triggered Workflows are running in the parent Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Add a Bitrise Wait for Build Step. Set the Bitrise Access Token input variable: $BITRISE_API_KEY

title: bitrise.yml
body:
parent-workflow:
 steps:
 - build-router-start@0:
 inputs:
 - workflows: |-
 workflow-1
 workflow-2
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"
 - script@1:
 inputs:
 - content: echo "Doing something else..."
 - build-router-wait@0:
 inputs:
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"

title: Optimizing cache efficiency for pull request builds
body: Optimizing cache efficiency for pull request builds

title: Description
body: Bitrise caching is branch-based. You can optimize cache efficiency by keeping the cache up-to-date on a given branch.

title: Description
body: If a branch doesn't have a cache entry yet, the repository's default branch is used as a fallback to pull a cache entry. If a pull request targets the main branch, this fallback mechanism is used to pull the default branch's cache (as the pull request branch doesn't have any cache entry yet). This means that caching can still be efficient if the pull request destination is the default branch and the cache is up-to-date on the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that any Workflow that runs frequently on the default branch contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step. This will keep the cache up to date with content from successful builds. We recommend one of two approaches:

title: Instructions
body: Run the Workflow after every commit (for example, a merge) to the default branch, triggered by the push event on the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: Run the Workflow as a scheduled nightly build every day. This warms up the cache by pushing content based on the latest state of the default branch.

title: Instructions
body: (Optional) Set the Compress cache input variable to true. This can be useful if your cache folders are large and you are experiencing slow build times.

title: Instructions
body: Make sure that the Workflow which runs the pull requests contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step.

title: Instructions
body: This pulls the cache from successful builds on the default branch. We don't recommend pushing content into the cache for pull request builds for security and efficiency reasons. Even if the Workflow contains the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step, it's skipped by default for pull request builds.

title: bitrise.yml
body: Workflow running on the default branch:

title: bitrise.yml
body:
# Add steps that produce the cached content (e.g. dependecies, builds)

- cache-push@2: {}

title: bitrise.yml
body: Pull request Workflow:

title: bitrise.yml
body:
- cache-pull@2: {}

# Add steps that can utilise the restored cache content
