title: Steps
body: A Step is a block of script execution that encapsulates a build task on Bitrise: the code to perform that task, the inputs and parameters you can define for the task, and the outputs the task generates.

title: Steps
body: Steps are the heart of Bitrise. A Step is a build task: for example, the Git Clone Step clones your Git repository at the start of a build while the Google Play Deploy Step can deploy your finished app to the Play Store.

title: Steps
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Steps
body: Our Steps are defined in YAML format, and written in either bash or Go.

title: Steps
body: You can find a list of our Steps in:

title: Steps
body: The Integrations page.

title: Steps
body: The Bitrise StepLib.

title: Steps
body: The Workflow Editor.

title: Steps
body: You can also create and run any custom script you want as part of your Bitrise build using the Script Step. All you need to do is specify the script runner (the default is bash), add the script, and run a build. For more information on how to set up these custom scripts, check out Bitrise Script Step - Running (Bash, Python, NodeJS, Ruby, Swift, Kotlin).

title: Steps
body: For the purposes of your builds, Steps can be managed directly from the Workflow Editor. You can rearrange them, set their versions, add or remove Steps at any time.

title: Types of Steps
body: Bitrise has over 300 Steps in its Step Library (StepLib) which third-party companies or open-source teams can enrich with Steps based on their services/tools.

title: Types of Steps
body: There are three different types of Steps at Bitrise. You can identify each one based on their labels on our GUI:

title: Types of Steps
body: Official Bitrise Steps: These Steps are created and maintained by Bitrise. These Steps are labeled by a green badge and a "B".

title: Types of Steps
body: Verified Steps: These Steps are created and maintained by the community, but they are owned by a service or tool or an open-source team that guarantees secure, maintained, consistent, and high-quality performance for any Bitrise user. These Steps are labeled by a blue badge and a check mark. For more information about Verified Steps, check out our guide.

title: Types of Steps
body: Community Steps: These Steps can be created by anyone in the community. These Steps are not labeled and don't have a badge. If you would like to learn how to develop Steps and share them with the Bitrise community, check out Developing a new Step.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: Steps can be added or removed any time from your Workflows. You can add any Step to your Workflow - there are absolutely no restrictions. It’s possible to add a Step specific to, for example, iOS apps to a Workflow of an Android app.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: Steps can be added or removed any time from your Workflows. When adding a new app to Bitrise, the project scanner generates at least one Workflow with some default Steps but you don't have to use these at all: it's up to you what Steps you want to include.

title: Adding Steps to a Workflow
body: You can add any Step to your Workflow - there are absolutely no restrictions. Please note that this means that it’s possible to add a Step specific to, for example, iOS apps to a Workflow of an Android app. Always make sure you only add the relevant Steps to your Workflow!

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the + symbol between two Steps to insert a Step at that position.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Search for the Step you need.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Search filter

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Be aware of the filter to the right of the search field. By default, the filter is set to the platform type of your app. For example, if you want to add a Step to an iOS app, the the search will be filtered to iOS Steps. Click ALL to search among all Steps.

title: Adding Steps in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Step to add it to the Workflow.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Generally, we recommend using Steps that are part of the official Bitrise Step Library. But you can add Steps from other sources, if you want to: you can use either a Git URL or a local path.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: On the Bitrise website, the git:: special source is the easiest way to use a Step that is not in the Bitrise Step Library. Let’s see how.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML from the navigation menu.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Add the git URL of the Step you want to use.

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: In this example, we’re adding the Script Step from a git source:

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: - git::https://github.com/bitrise-io/steps-script.git@1.1.3:

title: Adding Steps from alternative sources
body: Click Save.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: You can remove a Step at any time. Be aware, however, that if you add it back at a later date, the Step inputs will be set to the default value - any custom configuration will be gone.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Disabling a Step

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: If you don't want a Step to run but want to keep the Step configuration intact, you can disable the Step: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the Step you want to remove.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click the trash bin icon on the right.

title: Removing a Step from a Workflow
body: Click Save.

title: Step versioning
body: Bitrise Step versions follow semantic versioning: a version number looks like MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. For example, version 3.2.1 is the first patch of the second minor version of the third major version.

title: Step versioning
body: Bitrise Step versions follow semantic versioning: a version number looks like MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH. For example, version 3.2.1 is the first patch of the second minor version of the third major version.

title: Step versioning
body: You can use any existing version of a Step in your Workflows, and different versions of the same Step in different Workflows.

title: Step versioning
body: We regularly update our Steps to make sure they are fully equipped for our users’ needs. However, you don’t have to use the latest version if you don’t want to: if an old version is stable and compatible with your build, feel free to continue using that, or roll back to it any time.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: On the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor, you can choose between locking a Step to either a major version or a minor version in any of your Workflows. This determines what version of the Step your Workflow will use.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Locking a Step to a version means that your Workflow is automatically updated to use the latest release of the Step’s selected version type, either major or minor, but it won’t get updated if a different major or minor version is released.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If a Step is locked to a major version, it is automatically updated if a new minor version or a new patch for that major version is released. If a new major version is released, it won’t be updated.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If a Step is locked to a minor version, it is automatically updated only if a new patch for that minor version is released. If a new minor or major version is released, it won’t be updated.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Version locking

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: The Example Step’s current version in the Workflow is 2.3.3. A new minor version comes out: 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If the Step is locked to major version 2.x.x, the Step is updated to 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: If the Step is locked to minor version 2.3.x, the Step is NOT updated to 2.4.0.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Now let’s say the Example Step gets a new major version: 3.0.0!

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: In that case, the Step will not be automatically updated either way. If you want to use the new version, you need to lock the Step to either major version 3.x.x or minor version 3.0.x. This way you can be sure that a new update will not break your builds.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: To lock a Step to a major or minor version:

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Select the Step.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Go to the Properties tab.

title: Locking a Step to a major or minor version
body: Open the Version updates dropdown menu, and select your version.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: You have the option of using a specific, static Step version. For example, version 3.2.2. This means that no matter what new versions are released for the Step, your Step version will not be updated in the Workflow.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: YAML mode only!

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Please note that you cannot set a specific Step version on the graphical UI: you can only lock the Step to either a major or minor version. Setting a specific Step version is only possible in YAML mode.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: To set a specific Step version, you need to add that version to the Step reference in your app’s configuration YAML file:

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Find the Workflow and the Step you need.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: Set the Step version as part of the Step reference.

title: Using a specific Step version
body: In this example, we're setting the Activate SSH key Step of the primary Workflow to version 4.0.3:

title: Using a specific Step version
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4.0.3:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Locking on to the latest release of a Step means that if a new version of the Step is released, the user’s Workflow is updated to use that. This includes automatic update to a new major version, potentially breaking the build. So be careful!

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: To make sure your Workflow will always use the latest available version of a given Step, all you have to do is remove any version information from the Step reference in the bitrise.yml file of your app:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML from the navigation menu.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Find the Workflow and the Step you need.

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: Make sure the Step has no version information:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body: In this example, we're setting the Activate SSH key Step of the primary Workflow to the latest version:

title: Using the latest available version of the Step
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key:

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are the way to configure the Steps for your build. Steps have required inputs that must have a valid value and optional inputs that provide more options to customize your build.

title: Step inputs
body: Step inputs are the way to configure the Steps for your build. Steps have required inputs that must have a valid value and optional inputs that provide more options to customize your build.

title: Step inputs
body: Click on a Step to bring up its input variables on the right of the currently selected Workflow. Required inputs are marked as such in the Workflow Editor. If required inputs do not have valid values, the Step will fail.

title: Step inputs
body: Modify a Step input by either:

title: Step inputs
body: Clicking into the input field.

title: Step inputs
body: Clicking the CHANGE option next to the input field.

title: Step inputs
body: You can also use Environment Variables (Env Vars) as Step inputs.

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can configure Steps in your Bitrise builds so that they don't run if the previous Step in the Workflow failed. This can help with avoiding wasting build time and credits.

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can skip certain Steps in your Bitrise build. There is no point in running, for example, a unit test Step if the previous Step failed to build your app.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Of course, there are examples when it’s better to run a Step even if the previous Step failed. For example, if the Cache:Pull Step fails, there is no reason not to run the next Step - in fact, if the next Step is one that installs dependencies then it’s a very bad idea to skip that Step if pulling the cache is unsuccessful.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Enabling a Step conditionally

title: Skipping Steps
body: You can also configure Steps to run only in certain conditions: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Skipping Steps
body: To set a given Step to be skipped if the previous Step failed:

title: Skipping Steps
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Skipping Steps
body: Select the Step you want to skip.

title: Skipping Steps
body: On the right, find and open the When to run section and toggle the Run if previous Step failed option.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can enable or disable a Step in any given Workflow, and you can also set conditions for Steps. You can do so, either on your own computer, with the Bitrise CLI or by using the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can enable or disable a Step in any given Workflow, and you can also set conditions for Steps. You can do it either on your own computer, with the Bitrise CLI or by using the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: We mostly use run_if expressions to do these things. Check out the examples for possible template expressions: Examples of run_if expressions.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: You can also view the examples on GitHub: Template expression examples.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: A run_if can be any valid Go template

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: A run_if can be any valid Go template, as long as it evaluates to true or false (or any of the String representation, for example True, t, yes or y are all considered to be true). If the template evaluates to true, the Step will run, otherwise it won’t.

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: An example run_if to check a custom Environment Variable:

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body:
run_if: |-
 	{{enveq "CUSTOM_ENV_VAR_KEY" "test value to test against"}}

title: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally
body: This run_if will skip the Step if the value of CUSTOM_ENV_VAR_KEY is not test value to test against.

title: Disabling a Step
body: If you do not want to remove a Step from your Workflow but you don’t want it to run, you can disable it, using a run_if expression.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Experimenting with Workflows

title: Disabling a Step
body: To experiment with different configurations for a Workflow, without removing or disabling Steps, we recommend cloning the Workflow. You can modify the cloned Workflow as much as you wish without changing anything in the original.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Workflow Editor

title: Disabling a Step
body: bitrise.yml

title: Disabling a Step
body: Open the Workflow you need.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Disabling a Step
body: In the Additional run conditions input, type false.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Conditionals

title: Disabling a Step
body: Any condition that evaluates to false works, too.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Add run_if: false to it.

title: Disabling a Step
body: Conditionals

title: Disabling a Step
body: Any condition that evaluates to false works, too.

title: Disabling a Step
body:
- script:
 run_if: false
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "This will never run, because of run_if:false"

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Running a Step only in a CI environment means your build will skip that particular Step for local builds. Like disabling Steps, you can do this with a run_if expression. Use this to debug builds locally.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Enabling CI mode locally

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: CI mode can be enabled on your own Mac/PC by setting the CI environment to true (for example, run export CI=true in your Bash Terminal), or by running bitrise run with the --ci flag: bitrise --ci run ....

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Open the Workflow you need.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Find the Step you need.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: In the Additional run conditions input, type .IsCI.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Find the Step you need.

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body: Add run_if: .IsCI to its properties:

title: Running a Step only in a CI environment
body:
- script:
 run_if: .IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "This will only ever run in a CI environment because run_if: IsCI"

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: It is possible to run a Step ONLY if the build failed before it got to that particular Step. In addition to run_if, you will need to use the is_always_run property as well.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Open the Workflow you need.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: In the Additional run conditions input, type .IsBuildFailed.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Make sure the Run even if previous Step(s) failed option is toggled on.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Open your app’s bitrise.yml file.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Find the Step that you want to disable.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Add run_if: .IsBuildFailed to it.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: Add is_always_run: true to it.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body: This enables the Step to run even if a previous Step failed.

title: Running a Step only if the build failed
body:
- script:
 is_always_run: true
 run_if: .IsBuildFailed
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "Build Failed!"

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Usually, when a Step fails during a build, the built itself fails, too. This isn't the case with every Step, of course: both the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps can fail without failing the build. You can also configure any other Step to ensure their failure doesn't fail the build.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: YAML mode only

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: You can't do this on the graphical UI of the Workflow Editor: you have to edit your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: On the left, select Configuration YAML from the navigation menu.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Find the Step you need.

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body: Add the is_skippable flag to it and set it to true:

title: Ignoring a failed Step without failing the build
body:
- script: 
 is_skippable: true 
 inputs: 
 - content: |- 
 # !/bin/bash 
 echo "Failing Step." 
 exit 1 
 # exit 1 would mark this step as Failed, but it won't break the Build 
 # because of the is_skippable: true flag / property

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Sometimes the conditions required to determine whether a Step should run or not are complex and multi-layered. If so, using a complex chain of Go templates in a run_if expression can be overwhelming, especially if you prefer other languages instead of Go.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: In such cases, we recommend using a workaround: add a Script Step in your Workflow, and write a script that evaluates to a certain value. Store that value in an Environment Variable, and then the Step with the conditional expression only needs to check that value.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Using a non-Go script for a run_if expression

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: In this example, we'll create a simple Bash script and store its value, then check whether it matches a preset value.

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: First, we add a Script Step, and in the script content, we define a value. Once the value is defined, we use envman to store it in an Environment Variable. In this particular case, we define a variable in Bash, and use that variable as the value for our Env Var:

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body:
workflows: 
 example: 
 steps: 
 - script@1:
 title: Do anything with Script step 
 inputs: 
 - content: |- 
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails 
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x
 # creating the variable and storing it as an Env Var 
 my_variable='This is the value we need!' 
 envman add --key OUR_CONDITION --value "$my_variable"

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: We then create a simple run_if expression for the Step for which we need a condition. In this case, our Step is the Save cache Step, and we'll check if the value of the OUR_CONDITION variable matches the value stored in the previous Bash variable:

title: Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
Setting up run_if conditions with Script Steps
body: Since the values match, the Save cache Step will run.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body: There are many different ways of using a run_if expression. The following Workflow contains examples for most of them, with commented explanations. The expressions are used with Script Steps that, when successfully running, print that the used expression was true.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body: All expressions are valid Go templates. To learn about Go templates, check out the documentation: Go template docs.

title: Examples of run_if expressions
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 #
 # Check if an Environment Variable's value is equal to a given string
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{getenv "TEST_KEY" | eq "test value"}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Use the enveq function to check if an Env Var's value is equal to a given string
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{enveq "TEST_KEY" "test value"}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 # Use envcontain to check if the value of an Env Var contains a given string. It works on the level of Pipelines, too
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{envcontain "TEST_KEY" "test value"}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if a given Env Var is NOT empty
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{getenv "TEST_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if two Env Vars have the same value
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: '{{getenv "TEST_KEY_1" | eq (getenv "TEST_KEY_2")}}'
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Use the available expression data properties
 # like IsCI (checks if the build runs in a CI environment) or IsBuildFailed (checks if the build has failed) directly
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{.IsCI}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You don't have to wrap the expression in {{...}} if it's a simple
 # oneliner
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: $.IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You can even remove the $ sign, it's optional in a simple
 # expression like this
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: .IsCI
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # If-Else condition, in this example the Step will run if the build runs in a CI environment
 - script:
 title: Run-If expression
 run_if: |-
 {{if .IsCI}}
 true
 {{else}}
 false
 {{end}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # You can use multiple conditions
 - script:
 title: CI and Not Failed
 run_if: |-
 {{.IsCI | and (not .IsBuildFailed)}}
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 #
 # Check if the build is a pull request or not
 - script:
 title: Only if NOT a pull request
 run_if: not .IsPR
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "RunIf expression was true"
 - script:
 title: Only if it was a Pull Request
 run_if: .IsPR
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "Pull Request ID: ${PULL_REQUEST_ID}"

title: Step bundles
body: Step bundles allow you to reuse Steps and sequences of Steps in any Workflow in a convenient way, without having to manually copy and paste Steps from a YAML file.

title: Step bundles
body: Step bundles allow you to group multiple steps into a single unit. With Step bundles, you can reuse Steps and sequences of Steps without manually copying and pasting from a YAML file.

title: Step bundles
body: Step bundles are configured with a root level entity called step_bundles. You can insert Step bundles into any Workflow. Unlike utility Workflows and Workflow chaining, Step Bundles can be placed anywhere in a Workflow.

title: Step bundles
body: When running a build, each Step within the bundle will run at the position the bundle is inserted.

title: Creating a Step bundle
body: You can only create Step bundles in a configuration YAML file. The bundle will be visible on the Workflow Editor but you can't create it on the graphical UI.

title: Creating a Step bundle
body: Open the configuration YAML of your project.

title: Creating a Step bundle
body: Add a step_bundles entity to the top level of the YAML file and give it a name. You will refer to the bundle by this name.

title: Creating a Step bundle
body:
format_version: 11
step_bundles:
 install_deps:

title: Creating a Step bundle
body: Add a steps property under your bundle and add the Steps you want to run. You can reference Steps here the same way as in a Workflow.

title: Creating a Step bundle
body: In this example, we add the restore-cache Step and an npm Step.

title: Creating a Step bundle
Creating a Step bundle
body: Add your Step bundle to an existing Workflow. The syntax works like this: bundle::<bundle-name>.

title: Creating a Step bundle
Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: In any Step bundle, a list of Environment Variables can be defined under the envs key. You can use these variables to predefine the inputs of Steps included in the bundle, or share common values among the Steps.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: The variables will be available among the Step bundle's included steps, but not outside of the Step bundle. For example, they can be used to preconfigure Step inputs within the Step bundle.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: In your configuration YAML file, add the envs property to your Step bundle.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body:
format_version: 11
step_bundles:
 install_deps:
 envs:

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: Under envs, add key-value pairs that will be used for Step inputs.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body:
format_version: 11
step_bundles:
 install_deps:
 envs: 
 - CACHE_KEY: "npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}"
 - NPM_COMMAND: install

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: Add the keys to the appropriate Step inputs.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body: In our example, we configured default inputs for the key input of the restore-cache Step and the command input of the npm Step.

title: Configuring default inputs and common values for Steps in a bundle
body:
format_version: 11
step_bundles:
 install_deps:
 envs: 
 - CACHE_KEY: "npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}"
 - NPM_COMMAND: install
 steps:
 - restore-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: $CACHE_KEY
 - npm@1: {}
 inputs: 
 - command: $NPM_COMMAND

title: Overriding Step bundle variables
body: You can override any Environment Variables defined in the Step bundle by reassigning them in the Step list of the Workflow:

title: Overriding Step bundle variables
body: In your configuration YAML file, find your Workflow and the Step bundle in its steps list.

title: Overriding Step bundle variables
body: Add an envs property where your Step bundle is referenced, and add a key-value pair to it.

title: Overriding Step bundle variables
body: In this example, we override the value of the CACHE_KEY variable. When the Workflow runs, the restore-cache Step will use the npm-cache value instead of npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}.

title: Overriding Step bundle variables
body:
format_version: 11
step_bundles:
 install_deps:
 envs: 
 - CACHE_KEY: "npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}"
 - NPM_COMMAND: install
 steps:
 - restore-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: $CACHE_KEY
 - npm@1: {}
 inputs: 
 - command: $NPM_COMMAND
workflows:
 ci:
 steps:
 - git-clone@8: {}
 - bundle::install_deps:
 envs:
 - CACHE_KEY: "npm-cache-"
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}

title: Step bundle outputs
body: Steps can generate output variables. When Steps are included in a Step bundle, their output variables are available to all Steps in the Workflow after the Step bundle.

title: Step bundle outputs
body: For example, if the Step bundle used in the Workflow uses the xcode-archive Step, the next Steps after the bundle will have access to the BITRISE_IPA_PATH output variable which is exposed by the Step.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: A Step timeout, defined in seconds, sets a maximum time a Step is allowed to run. If the Step exceeds that limit, the Workflow moves on to the next Step.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Ensure that your builds do not exceed the time limit by setting up Step timeout for Steps that might cause builds to hang.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: A Step timeout, defined in seconds, sets a maximum time a Step is allowed to run. If the Step exceeds that limit, the Workflow moves on to the next Step. This is useful if, for example, your builds hang for not immediately obvious reasons - you can set timeouts for the Step or Steps which are suspected to have caused the problem.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Find the Step in the bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: You can edit the file locally, or on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body: Add a timeout property before the other Step inputs and specify its value in seconds:

title: Setting a time limit for Steps
body:
- xcode-test@1.18.14:
 timeout: 120
 inputs:
 - project_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"
 - scheme: "$BITRISE_SCHEME"

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: You can detect and abort hanging Steps that do not produce any log output for a certain amount of time using the No Output Timeout function. You can use this function to automatically abort hung builds after a configurable timeout period to save credits and to enable Bitrise to gather data on hanging builds.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: You can use the No Output Timeout function in two ways:

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: Enable globally for all Steps.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: Enable for specific Steps only.

title: Detecting and aborting hanging Steps without output
body: The No Output Timeout function can be used alongside other timeout functionalities, such as the one described in the M1 Hanging builds issue guide or in Setting a time limit for Steps.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Bitrise 1.50.0 or newer is required

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: You must use Bitrise 1.50.0 or a newer version to use the No Output Timeout function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: To enable the No Output Timeout globally for all Steps:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Go to the Secrets tab.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Add a new secret Env Var: BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT and set its value to the number of seconds you want the build to wait for output logs before aborting.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: We recommend setting it to 600 seconds (10 minutes).

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Aborting a hanging build automatically

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Compared to setting a time limit for Steps, the No Output Timeout function only aborts a build no output log is generated for a set amount of time.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Any log output will reset the timeout. This can result in a Step running longer than the value you set in BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Click Save. You can check the Build log of your build to determine if the function is enabled.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: And that's it! From now on, whenever a Step does not produce an output log for the number of seconds you set in BITRISE_NO_OUTPUT_TIMEOUT , your build automatically aborts with the message: Abort via Bitrise CLI (no output timeout).

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: Disabling the No Output Timeout function for a specific Step

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: If you enabled the No Output Timeout function globally and want to disable it for specific Steps, you can add the no_output_timeout: 0 Step property just above the inputs: part of the chosen Step(s) in the bitrise.yml.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body: For example:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function globally for all Steps
body:
steps: 
 - virtual-device-testing-for-ios@1:
 no_output_timeout: 0
 inputs:
 - zip_path: "$BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH"

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Bitrise 1.50.0 or newer is required

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You must use Bitrise 1.50.0 or a newer version to use the No Output Timeout function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You can enable the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps by adding the no_output_timeout Step property below a Step in your bitrise.yml file.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: To do so with the Workflow Editor:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Search for the Step(s) where you would like to use the function.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Insert no_output_timeout: 12 Step property and value just above the inputs: part of the chosen Step(s) to automatically abort a build if the Step does not produce an output log for 12 seconds.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Setting the no_output_timeout Step property to 0

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: You can disable the No Output Timeout function for a Step by setting the no_output_timeout Step property to 0.

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: Let's look at an example where a Script Step will always be aborted automatically:

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body:
output_slows_down:
 steps:
 - script@1:
 title: Output is slower and slower
 no_output_timeout: 12
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 for i in {1..5}
 do
 DURATION=$((5*i))
 echo "🏃‍step output (sleeping ${DURATION}s)"
 sleep $DURATION
 done

title: Enabling the No Output Timeout function for specific Steps
body: And that's it! Now, if your Step hangs and does not produce a single output log for the number of seconds you specified in the no_output_timeout Step property, the build will be aborted automatically.

title: Pipelines
body: Pipelines allow you to define dependencies between your Workflows. This can reduce build time by running CI tasks in parallel whenever possible.

title: Pipelines
body: A Bitrise Pipeline is the top level of our CI/CD configuration. Pipelines can be used to organize the entire CI/CD process and to set up advanced configurations with multiple different tasks running parallel and/or sequentially.

title: Pipelines
body: A Pipeline allows you to configure dependencies between Workflows. Each Workflow starts executing when its parent Workflows are done. Workflows on the same level are executed in parallel:

title: Pipelines
body: In this example, B and C are executed, in parallel, once A is successful. D is executed once B and C are both successful.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: Configure a Bitrise Pipeline by adding Workflows and optionally, defining dependencies between the Workflows.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: Pipelines with stages

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: If you have an existing Pipeline configuration from before December 2024, you probably have stages in your Pipeline. We strongly recommend to stop using stages and instead focus on configuring dependencies between Workflows. These dependencies determine the order of execution in a Pipeline. This eliminates unnecessary waiting time in stages and allows you to create more flexible CI configurations.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: You can keep using Pipelines with stages but they will receive no new features in the future. You can have both types of Pipelines in the same configuration YAML file but you can't mix and match the two types: you can't have both stages and Workflow dependencies in the same Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: You can find the documentation for Pipelines with stages here: Pipelines with stages.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: You can define your Pipelines under a pipelines element in a configuration YAML file. You can use the following elements to set up a Pipeline:

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: A Pipeline name: the human readable identifier of the Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: The workflows element: this contains a list of the Workflows that are part of the Pipeline.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: The depends_on property: This is a property of the workflows element and accepts an array of Workflow names. It defines the dependencies between Workflows.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: For example, here's a simple Pipeline configuration:

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: In this Pipeline, we have four Workflows:

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: Workflow A runs first.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: Once Workflow A is finished, Workflows B and C start at the same time.

title: Configuring Pipelines
body: Workflow D starts only when both Workflows B and C are successfully finished.

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: Workflow Editor

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: Configuration YAML

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: Open the Workflow Editor and select Pipelines on the left. Click Create Pipeline.

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: To add your first Workflow, click Workflows.

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: You can keep adding Workflows this way. This method creates no dependencies between Workflows: they will all run at the same time.

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: To create Workflow dependencies, hover over the right end of a Workflow and click the plus sign:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: You can add multiple dependent Workflows to the same Workflow this way:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: The same Workflow can depend on two or more different Workflows: you can create a path by dragging from the plus sign to another Workflow already in the Pipeline:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: A bare minimum Pipeline configuration consists of a single Workflow:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body:
pipelines:
 example:
 workflows:
 A: {}

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: You can have multiple Workflows that all run in parallel:

title: Creating a Pipeline
Creating a Pipeline
body: To create Workflow dependencies like the example above, you need to use the depends_on property:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body:
pipelines:
 example:
 workflows:
 A: {}
 B:
 depends_on:
 - A
 C:
 depends_on:
 - A
 D:
 depends_on:
 - B
 - C

title: Creating a Pipeline
body: If a Workflow depends on multiple Workflows, both YAML array syntaxes can be used:

title: Creating a Pipeline
body:
# Option 1
D:
 depends_on:
 - B
 - C
# Option 2
D:
 depends_on: [A, B]

title: Configuration restrictions
body: A Pipeline can have a maximum of 50 Workflows. Each must be an existing Workflow under the root level workflows element.

title: Configuration restrictions
body: Utility Workflows can't be added to a Pipeline. If you want to use utility Workflows, include them as part of a regular Workflow.

title: Configuration restrictions
body: Each Workflow can be added to the same Pipeline only once. You can't include the same Workflow in multiple different parts of a Pipeline.

title: Configuration restrictions
body: Any Workflow defined in the dependency list must be part of the same Pipeline.

title: Configuration restrictions
body: The dependency graph resulting from your configuration can't contain a circle or loop. Such an error will builds from starting.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Use run_if expressions to control Workflow execution: you can set conditions under which a Workflow should or should not run.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Workflow Editor

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Configuration YAML

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Open your Pipeline.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Hover over the Workflow you need and click the gear icon to open the Edit Workflow dialog.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Select Pipeline Conditions.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: In the Additional running conditions input, add a valid Go template.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: The input accepts three helper functions:

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: getenv: Accesses an Environment Variable's value.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: enveq: Compares an Environment Variable to a given value.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: envcontain: Checks whether an Environment Variable contains a given string.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: Close the Edit Workflow dialog, and click Save changes.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: In Pipelines, the run_if property needs an expression field that contains a Go template:

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body:
pipelines:
 example:
 workflows:
 A: {}
 B:
 run_if:
 expression: {{ enveq "EXAMPLE_KEY" "example value" }}
 depends_on: [A]

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: The expression field accepts three helper functions:

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: getenv: Accesses an Environment Variable's value.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: enveq: Compares an Environment Variable to a given value.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: envcontain: Checks whether an Environment Variable contains a given string.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: The Bitrise CLI evaluates the expression during runtime: a Workflow only runs if its run_if expression evaluates to true. A Workflow that is skipped because of a run_if expression is counted as a successful Workflow so its dependent Workflows will run.

title: Conditional Workflow execution in a Pipeline
body: In this example, B will only run if the EXAMPLE_KEY Environment Variable has the value example value.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: You can mark a Workflow to make sure it runs even if a Workflow it depends on failed.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Transitive dependency

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Even if a Workflow is configured to always run, its dependent Workflows might not run. If one or more of its parent Workflows failed, the Workflow in question will still run but its dependent Workflows might not.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: For example, let's say we have Workflow C that depends on Workflow B. Workflow B depends on Workflow A. Of the three Workflows, only B is set to always run:

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: If A fails, B will run but regardless of its result, C won't run because by depending on B, it also depends on A.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: C only runs if both A and B are successful.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Workflow Editor

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Configuration YAML

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Open your Pipeline.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Hover over the Workflow you need and click the gear icon to open the Edit Workflow dialog.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Select Pipeline Conditions.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Set the Always run input to Workflow.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: This setting means the Workflow will run even if one or more of its parent Workflows fail. However, its dependent Workflows might not run!

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: Use the should_always_run property. It requires a string to specify the scope of the configuration. It has two available values:

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: none: If a parent Workflow fails, the Workflow will not run. This is the default value.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: workflow: If a parent Workflow fails, the Workflow will run anyway.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body:
pipelines:
 example:
 workflows:
 A: {}
 B:
 depends_on: [ A ]
 should_always_run: workflow
 C:
 depends_on: [ B ]
 D:
 depends_on: [ C ]
 should_always_run: workflow

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: In this example:

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: If A fails, B still runs.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: If either A or B fails, C won't run.

title: Always executing a Workflow in a Pipeline
body: If C won't run or runs but fails, D will still run.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: You can configure the Pipeline to immediately terminate when any given Workflow fails. By default, the Pipeline won't terminate

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Workflow Editor

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Configuration YAML

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Open your Pipeline.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Hover over the Workflow you need and click the gear icon to open the Edit Workflow dialog.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Select Pipeline Conditions.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Toggle the Abort Pipeline on failure input on.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: If the Workflow in question fails, the Pipeline will immediately stop running.

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: Add the abort_on_fail field set to true to the selected Workflows:

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body:
pipelines:
 example:
 workflows:
 A: {}
 B:
 abort_on_fail: true

title: Aborting the Pipeline on Workflow failure
body: In this example, the Pipeline stops running if Workflow B fails: Workflow A will be aborted and no subsequent Workflows will run.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: To share files between Workflows in a Pipeline, you can use the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step and the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step. The Step downloads Pipeline intermediate files to a local folder.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: To configure file sharing:

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Workflow Editor

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Configuration YAML

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the Workflow that generates the file(s) you need.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: In the Pipeline Intermediate File Sharing input group, find the Files to share input and add the files as a newline-separated list of colon-separated items using the following structure: <file_or_directory_path>:<environment_variable_key>.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: You can use another Environment Variable as a filepath: for an iOS project, $BITRISE_IPA_PATH:BITRISE_IPA_PATH is a valid way to share a generated IPA with other Workflows.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Add the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step to any Workflow that needs the generated files.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Use the Artifact source input to specify a set of Workflows from which you need files.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: You can use wildcards in the input. In the example above, we’re pulling all artifacts from all Workflows which have a name starting with workflow.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: When the Step finishes, your files and directories specified via the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step should be available.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the Workflow that generates the file(s) you need.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Add the files to the pipeline_intermediate_files input as a newline-separated list of colon-separated items using the following structure: <file_or_directory_path>:<environment_variable_key>.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: You can use another Environment Variable as a filepath: for an iOS project, $BITRISE_IPA_PATH:BITRISE_IPA_PATH is a valid way to share a generated IPA with other Workflows.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body:
steps:
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io: {
 inputs: 
 - pipeline_intermediate_files: "$BITRISE_IPA_PATH:BITRISE_IPA_PATH"

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Add the Pull Pipeline intermediate files Step to any Workflow that needs the generated files:

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body:
steps:
 - pull-intermediate-files: {}

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: Use the artifact_sources input to specify a set of Workflows from which you need files:

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body:
steps:
 - pull-intermediate-files@1:
 inputs:
 - artifact_sources: workflow.*

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: You can use wildcards in the input. In the example above, we’re pulling all artifacts from all Workflows which have a name starting with workflow.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: When the Step finishes, your files and directories specified via the Deploy to Bitrise.io - Apps, Logs, Artifacts Step should be available.

title: Sharing files between Workflows in a Pipeline
body: For more information and details, check out the Step repository.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: You can reuse any environment variable from a Workflow and reuse it in subsequent Workflows using the Share Pipeline variables Step.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Optional Workflows using run_if conditions

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: You can easily combine the Share Pipeline variables Step with run_if expressions to create Pipelines with optional Workflows. For more information, check out Setting up run_if conditions for optional Workflows using Pipelines.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: To do so:

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Add the Share Pipeline variables Step to the Workflow.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Optionally, you can define additional run conditions in the Additional run conditions input. The Step will only run if the conditions you specify here are true.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Add the Env Var(s) you would like to use in subsequent Workflows in the Variables to share between Pipeline Workflows input.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Using environment variable keys

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: You can define Env Vars using a {key}={value} syntax. For example, MY_ENV_KEY=value, or INSTALL_PAGE_URL=$BITRISE_PUBLIC_PAGE_URL.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: If you want to use the default environment variable keys, you can use a shorthand syntax. For example, EXISTING_ENV_KEY.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Workflows
body: Sharing Env Vars using this Step does not override existing Env Vars defined in the app.

title: Pipeline builds
body: Bitrise Pipeline builds can be triggered the same way as Workflow builds, they can send status reports, and all their artifacts are available on the Artifacts page. You can use Pipeline builds to upload installable artifact's to Release Management.

title: Pipeline builds
body: You can run Pipeline builds the same way you would run builds of standalone Workflows:

title: Pipeline builds
body: You can start Pipeline builds manually.

title: Pipeline builds
body: Schedule Pipeline builds.

title: Pipeline builds
body: Trigger Pipeline builds automatically. For now, Pipeline triggers must be configured in YAML, however: YAML syntax for build triggers.

title: Pipeline builds
body: Pipeline builds are capable of sending build status reports: a Pipeline build will send a status report of the Pipeline itself and of any Steps that export test results: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider.

title: Pipeline builds
body: All artifacts of a Pipeline build are available on the Artifacts page: Build artifacts online.

title: Pipeline builds
body: You can use Pipeline builds to upload installable artifacts to Release Management, in order to distribute your mobile app to testers and release the app in an online store. All you need is a Workflow that generates an installable APK, AAB or IPA file: Uploading installable artifacts.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Frequently asked questions about the Pipeline feature on Bitrise.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Can I use Pipelines if I store my bitrise.yml file in my own repository?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes, absolutely. It makes no difference to Pipelines.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: How can I set the stack for my Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: In the current version, you can set the default stack for your app, or you can set Workflow-specific stacks, just like with standalone builds.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: How can I use Environment Variables with a Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: You can keep using project-level and Workflow-level Environment Variables.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Can I rerun a failed Pipeline?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes. Go to the Pipeline details page, and click the Rerun button. From there you have the option to rerun failed and subsequent Workflows or to rerun the entire Pipeline.

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Does the Rolling Builds feature work on Pipelines?

title: Pipeline Management FAQ
body: Yes! You don’t have to worry about wasting credits with builds that are no longer necessary because of new commits or pull requests.

title: Pipelines with stages
body: Pipelines with stages are the older way of configuring Pipelines. We recommend switching to the new way where you can define Workflow dependencies to create more flexible configurations, and you no longer have to waste time waiting for a stage to finish.

title: Pipelines with stages
body: However, you can keep using Pipelines with stages. Such Pipelines have three main building blocks:

title: Pipelines with stages
body: Steps: Blocks of script execution, each defining a single task in a CI/CD process.

title: Pipelines with stages
body: Workflows: Collections of Steps. When a build of an app is running, the Steps will be executed in the order that is defined in the Workflow.

title: Pipelines with stages
body: Stages: Collections of Workflows. A Stage can contain multiple Workflows which all run in parallel in the same Stage. If all Workflows are successful in a Stage, the Pipeline moves on to the next Stage. If any of the Workflows fail, the Pipeline ends without running the other Stages unless you configure a given Stage to always run.

title: Configuring a Pipeline with stages
body: Configuring a Pipeline that contains stages is only possible by directly editing the bitrise.yml file. You can create and modify Workflows in the graphical Workflow Editor but you need to define Pipelines and Stages in YAML format.

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
body: The bitrise.yml file contains the full configuration of your Pipelines. As with all bitrise.yml files, first you need to define the format version and the project type.

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
body:
---
format_version: '8'
default_step_lib_source: 
project_type: android

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
body: This is a bare minimum bitrise.yml configuration. To define your Pipelines, you will need to use the pipelines attribute.

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
Defining Pipelines with stages
body: In this example, we have a Pipeline called pipeline-successful, with three Stages that will run consecutively. This means that if stage-successful-1 finishes successfully, stage-successful-2 starts. If any of the Stages fail, the subsequent Stage will not start: instead, the Pipeline will be aborted and marked as failed.

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
body: Each Stage has to be defined separately under the stages attribute. Defining a Stage means specifying the Workflows that are part of the Stage.

title: Defining Pipelines with stages
Defining Pipelines with stages
body: In this example, the Stages run the test-1, build-1, build-2, deploy-1, and deploy-2 Workflows.

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
body: By default, if a Stage fails - because one of its Workflows failed -, any other subsequent Stages of the Pipeline will not run. However, you can configure your Pipeline to run certain Stages unless the Pipeline is aborted.

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
body: To do so, you just need to set the should_always_run attribute of the Stage to true:

title: Configuring a Stage to always run
Configuring a Stage to always run
body: In the example above, the Stage called stage-always-run-successful-1 will always run, regardless of the status of previous Stages. The only way these Stages will not run is if the Pipeline build is aborted by the user.

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
body: By default, if a Workflow in a particular Stage fails, the other Workflows in the same Stage aren’t automatically aborted: these Workflows will run but the next Stage won’t start. However, you can change this behavior to immediately and automatically abort all other Workflows in the same Stage.

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
body: To do so, you need to set the abort_on_fail attribute to true:

title: Aborting the Workflows of a failed Stage
Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: You can reuse any environment variable from a Workflow and reuse it in subsequent Workflows using the Share Pipeline variables Step.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Optional Workflows using run_if conditions

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: You can easily combine the Share Pipeline variables Step with run_if expressions to create Pipelines with optional Workflows. For more information, check out Setting up run_if conditions for optional Workflows using Pipelines.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: To do so:

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Add the Share Pipeline variables Step to the Workflow.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Optionally, you can define additional run conditions in the Additional run conditions input. The Step will only run if the conditions you specify here are true.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Add the Env Var(s) you would like to use in subsequent Workflows in the Variables to share between Pipeline Workflows input.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Using environment variable keys

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: You can define Env Vars using a {key}={value} syntax. For example, MY_ENV_KEY=value, or INSTALL_PAGE_URL=$BITRISE_PUBLIC_PAGE_URL.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: If you want to use the default environment variable keys, you can use a shorthand syntax. For example, EXISTING_ENV_KEY.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: Sharing Env Vars using this Step does not override existing Env Vars defined in the app.

title: Sharing Env Vars between Pipeline Stages
body: That's it! You can now use the Env Var in any subsequent Stage!

title: Currently supported use cases for the iOS platform
body: We have prepared some Pipeline recipes based on common iOS use cases. These contain some of the most frequent tasks our users need to run.

title: (iOS) Run tests in parallel on multiple simulators
body: (iOS) Run tests in parallel on multiple simulators

title: Description
body: This example uses the sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test iOS Open Source sample app, which has some example Unit and UI tests and uses Test Plans to group the tests.

title: Description
body: The example Pipeline config showcases how to run all the test cases of the project on different iOS simulators.

title: Description
body: run_tests_on_simulators Pipeline runs two Stages sequentially:

title: Description
body: build_tests stage that runs the build_tests Workflow. This Workflow git clones the sample project and runs the xcode-build-for-test Step to build the target and associated tests. The built test bundle is transferred to the next Stage (run_tests_on_simulators) via the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step.

title: Description
body: The build test bundle is compressed

title: Description
body: xcode-build-for-test Step compresses the built test bundle and moves the generated zip to the $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. That directory’s content is deployed to the Workflow artifacts by default via the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step.

title: Description
body: Artifact file size limitation

title: Description
body: There is no limitation on the number of files deployed to Artifacts per build. There is a limitation, however, on the file size which is 2GB per file.

title: Description
body: run_tests_on_simulators Stage runs three Workflows in parallel: run_tests_iPad, run_tests_iPhone, and run_tests_iPod. Both of these Workflows use the new xcode-test-without-building Step, which executes the tests based on the previous stage built test bundle. The pre-built test bundle is pulled by the _pull_test_bundle utility Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: To test the configuration in a new Bitrise example project, do the following:

title: Instructions
body: Visit the Create New App page to create a new App.

title: Instructions
body: When prompted to select a git repository, choose Other/Manual and paste the sample project repository URL (https://github.com/bitrise-io/sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test) in the Git repository (clone) URL field.

title: Instructions
body: Confirm that this is a public repository in the resulting pop-up.

title: Instructions
body: Select the master branch to scan.

title: Instructions
body: Wait for the project scanner to complete.

title: Instructions
body: Select any of the offered Distribution methods (for example development, it does not really matter as now we are focusing on testing).

title: Instructions
body: Confirm the offered stack, skip choosing the app icon and the webhook registration and kick off the first build.

title: Instructions
body: Open the new Bitrise project’s Workflow Editor.

title: Instructions
body: Go to the bitrise.yml tab and replace the existing bitrise.yml with the contents of the example bitrise.yml file.

title: Instructions
body: Click the Start/Schedule a Build button, and select the run_tests_on_simulators option in the “Workflow, Pipeline” dropdown menu at the bottom of the popup.

title: bitrise.yml
body: GitHub link: https://github.com/bitrise-io/workflow-recipes/blob/main/recipes/ios-run-tests-in-parallel-on-multiple-simulators.md#bitriseyml

title: (iOS) Run test groups in parallel
body: (iOS) Run test groups in parallel

title: Description
body: This example uses the sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test iOS Open Source sample app, which has some example Unit and UI tests and uses Test Plans to group the tests.

title: Description
body: XCode test plans

title: Description
body: Xcode Test Plans provide a way to run a collection of tests with different test configurations. raywenderlich.com has a great tutorial on how to get started with Xcode Test Plans.

title: Description
body: The example Pipeline config showcases how to run different test groups in parallel.

title: Description
body: run_tests_groups Pipeline runs two Stages sequentially:

title: Description
body: build_tests Stage that runs the build_tests Workflow. This Workflow git clones the sample project and runs the xcode-build-for-test Step to build the target and associated tests. The built test bundle is transferred to the next Stage (run_tests_groups) via the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step.

title: Description
body: run_tests_groups Stage runs two Workflows in parallel: run_ui_tests and run_unit_tests. Both of these Workflows use the new xcode-test-without-building Step, which executes the tests based on the previous Stage built test bundle. The pre-built test bundle is pulled by the _pull_test_bundle utility Workflow.

title: Instructions
body: Visit the Create New App page to create a new App.

title: Instructions
body: When prompted to select a git repository, choose Other/Manual and paste the sample project repository URL (https://github.com/bitrise-io/sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test) in the Git repository (clone) URL field.

title: Instructions
body: Confirm that this is a public repository in the resulting pop-up.

title: (iOS) Merging test results and deploying to the Test Reports add-on
body: (iOS) Merging test results and deploying to the Test Reports add-on

title: Description
body: Test Reports add-on is tied to Bitrise builds. To make all the test reports generated in different builds appear on a single page in the add-on, the reports must be merged and deployed in an additional build.

title: Description
body: This example uses the sample-swift-project-with-parallel-ui-test iOS Open Source sample app and extends the ‘Run iOS test groups in parallel’ example Pipeline config with merging and deploying test results.

title: Description
body: run_ui_tests and run_unit_tests Workflows are extended with a deploy-to-bitrise-io Step to make the generated test results available for the next Stage.

title: Description
body: run_tests_groups Pipeline is extended with a new Stage: deploy_test_results. This Stage runs the deploy_test_results Workflow:

title: Description
body: artifact-pull Step downloads all the zipped test results previously generated by Stage: run_tests_groups.

title: Description
body: script Step unzips each test result into a new test run directory within the Test Report add-on deploy dir and creates the related test-info.json file.

title: Description
body: deploy-to-bitrise-io Step deploys the merged test results.

title: Currently supported use cases for the Android platform
body: We have prepared some Pipeline recipes based on common Android use cases. These contain some of the most frequent tasks our users need to run. The examples include entire Workflows that can be copied and pasted for the most part.

title: (Android) Run UI tests in parallel on multiple devices or shards
body: (Android) Run UI tests in parallel on multiple devices or shards

title: Description
body: Running the UI (instrumentation) tests of a single module in parallel Workflows utilizing pipelines. You can run the tests in parallel by shards or by devices.

title: Description
body: The Pipeline contains two Stages that are run serially:

title: Description
body: build_for_ui_testing: This Stage executes a Workflow — also named build_for_ui_testing — that runs the android-build-for-ui-testing Step to build APKs for use in testing, and runs the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step to save those APKs for use in the later Stages. Performing this Stage separately from the actual testing allows for each test Stage to use these pre-built APKs rather than having to rebuild them for each test Stage.

title: Description
body: run_ui_tests_on_devices: This Stage executes three UI test Workflows in parallel — ui_test_on_phone, ui_test_on_tablet, ui_test_on_foldable — which use the android-instrumented-test Step to run the UI tests on the APKs built in the previous Workflow on each specific device type.

title: (Android) Running unit and UI tests in parallel

title: Description
body: Run unit tests and UI tests in parallel utilizing Pipelines.

title: Description
body: This Pipeline contains one Stage — stage_unit_and_ui_test — that executes two Workflows in parallel:

title: Description
body: unit_tests: This Workflow simply runs the unit tests of the given module and variant using the android-unit-test Step.

title: Description
body: ui_tests: This Workflow builds the given module and variant using the android-build-for-ui-testing Step, spins up an emulator using the avd-manager Step, waits for the emulator to boot using the wait-for-android-emulator Step, and runs the UI tests using the android-instrumented-test Step.

title: Developing your own Bitrise Step
body: You can develop your own Bitrise Steps and your own project scanner, and submit them to Bitrise so that other users can use them, too.

title: Developing your own Bitrise Step
body: Contributing to Bitrise is easy: develop an open source integration, submit it and you’re done! In this section, we’ll be focusing on technical contributions: creating a new Step and creating your very own project scanner.

title: Creating your own Step
body: Bitrise offers well over 200 Steps to our users. We maintain many of them ourselves but our users’ community does an outstanding job of contributing to our Step Library (StepLib). Anyone can submit a Step - if approved, it will become part of the official Bitrise StepLib and available to all Bitrise users! Check out how to create your own Step and share it with the world: Creating your own Step.

title: Creating your own scanner
body: Our project scanner automatically detects the project type whenever you add a new app on Bitrise. In this context, type means the platform or framework used to create the app, for example, Android, iOS, React Native or Flutter. Based on the results, we automatically create a configuration, with at least one default Workflow that contains the most frequently used Steps for the detected type.

title: Creating your own scanner
body: Our scanner might not detect your app, for a couple of reasons: either something is missing from your repository (such as a config.xml file in the case of an Ionic app, for example), or we simply don’t have a scanner for your type yet. If it’s the latter, you can configure your app manually, or you can create your own scanner, with its own project configuration: Creating your own Bitrise project scanner.

title: Developing a new Step
body: To develop a Bitrise Step and get it integrated in our Step library, you need to write a code, create the description, and submit everything for review.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Duplicate Steps

title: Developing a new Step
body: Before deciding to develop a new Step, please make sure that there’s no already existing Step that performs the same function.

title: Developing a new Step
body: You can search for Steps on our Integrations page or in the Step Library on GitHub.

title: Developing a new Step
body: A Step is a build task: for example, the Git Clone Step clones your Git repository at the start of a build while the Google Play Deploy Step can deploy your finished app to the Play Store.

title: Developing a new Step
body: A Step contains the code that performs the build task. You can configure the inputs and parameters that define the task, and view and reuse the outputs a Step generates. Reusing the output means that another Step can use it as the value of one of its inputs.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Our Steps are written in Go or Bash. Steps are contained in their own Git repositories: that includes the code and the step.yml file that defines the configuration of the Step. If you wish to make the Step available to other users, the step.yml file needs to be included in the bitrise-steplib repository so that other users can find the Step on our website, in the Workflow Editor.

title: Developing a new Step
body: Sharing Steps

title: Developing a new Step
body: Sharing your custom Steps is optional: a Step with a use case that is specific to a single user will not be much help to others. As you can run a Step from your own machine or from any Git repository, your custom Steps do not have to be part of the Bitrise Step Library.

title: Developing a new Step
body: For more info on sharing Steps with other users, check out the Sharing Steps guide.

title: Developing a new Step
body: For detailed information on how Steps work, see the following guides:

title: Developing a new Step
body: Steps in YAML

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step inputs

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step outputs

title: Developing a new Step
body: Step properties

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Before creating a new Step, you will need to install the Bitrise CLI, set it up, and make sure the Step plugin is updated to the latest version.

title: Before you start developing a new Step
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Before you start developing a new Step
