body: Add a meta entry under the Workflow itself:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack:

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: Add the stack ID.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body: You can find the stack IDs on the top of each stack report page.

title: Setting Workflow-specific stacks in the bitrise.yml
body:
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta:      
 bitrise.io:       
 stack: osx-xcode-13.1.x

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can also define the machine type you want to use for your build in the bitrise.yml of your app. Machine type refers to the hardware resources used in your build; for example, an Elite machine has more CPU cores and available RAM than a Standard machine.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: To set the machine type in the bitrise.yml file, you need to use the machine_type_id attribute in a meta entry:

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Available machine IDs

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: You can find the available machine type IDs here: Build machine types.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Find the workflows property and find the name of the Workflow you need within.

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body: Add a meta entry:

title: Setting the machine type in the bitrise.yml file
body:
# setting an 8-core Gen2 machine for an Xcode stack as the default machine type of the app:
meta:
 bitrise.io:
 machine_type_id: g2.8core
# setting a 12-core Gen2 machine as a Workflow-specific machine type
workflows:
 deploy: 
 meta: 
 bitrise.io: 
 machine_type_id: g2.12core

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise offers multiple build machines with different specifications and credit costs. You can choose between them based on your needs.

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise offers multiple build machines with different specifications and credit costs. You can choose between them based on your needs.

title: Build machine types
body: You can track how much time you spent building your apps on each machine type with Insights: Utilization metrics.

title: Build machine types
body: Machine availability by subscription plan

title: Build machine types
body: Not all machines are available on all subscription plans. Visit the pricing page to find out which machines are available on your plan!

title: Build machine types
body: Bitrise build machine types

title: Selective builds
body: The Selective builds setting provides change detection for your builds. Enabling it allows you to only trigger a build of an app if certain files or folders have been modified.

title: Selective builds
body: Using build triggers instead

title: Selective builds
body: This is a legacy feature.

title: Selective builds
body: Instead of using this feature, you can now configure build triggers to only trigger builds when certain files or folders have changed: to do so, create a new trigger for push or pull request events, and choose the Files changed trigger condition. We strongly recommend using this option instead of Selective builds.

title: Selective builds
body: The Selective builds setting provides change detection for your builds. Enabling it allows you to only trigger a build of an app if certain files or folders have been modified.

title: Selective builds
body: You may want to use this setting if:

title: Selective builds
body: You have a monorepo; that is, you build multiple apps from a single repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Multiple apps share common files in your repository.

title: Selective builds
body: Selective Builds with non-Github projects

title: Selective builds
body: The current version of our Selective Builds feature only works with GitHub projects. If your repository is hosted by another Git hosting service, the option will not be available.

title: Selective builds
body: Using the Selective builds feature

title: Selective builds
body: Let's say you want to make sure that a commit to your app's repository triggers a Bitrise build only if the mycode.go file on the develop branch is modified in the commit.

title: Selective builds
body: In this example, you have a branch called develop.

title: Selective builds
body: You have a trigger that starts a build every time a code push happens on the develop branch.

title: Selective builds
body: In the selective builds feature, you specified the mycode.go file in the input field.

title: Selective builds
body: If you make a commit on the develop branch that modifies the mycode.go file, Bitrise will trigger a build. If your commit doesn't modify the file in any way, Bitrise will not trigger a build.

title: Selective builds
body: To configure selective builds:

title: Selective builds
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Selective builds
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Selective builds
body: Make sure the appropriate service credential user is set on the Integrations page.

title: Selective builds
body: This user must have admin right for the GitHub repository of the project.

title: Selective builds
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Selective builds
body: Find the Selective builds section and toggle it on.

title: Selective builds
body: Click Add path .

title: Selective builds
body: Can't find the button?

title: Selective builds
body: If you can't find the button - like in the screenshot above -, it is because of two possible reasons:

title: Selective builds
body: The app's repository isn't hosted on GitHub.

title: Selective builds
body: The service credential user isn't set correctly or doesn't have admin rights to the repo.

title: Selective builds
body: In the pop-up window, set the paths you need.

title: Selective builds
body: You can add one path at a time.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: You do not need to set an exact file name or file path for the Selective builds feature: you can set patterns. Using regular expressions is not supported but the pattern may contain certain metacharacters:

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *: Matches all files.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: a*: Matches all files beginning with a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *a: Matches all files ending with a.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: *a*: Matches all files that have a in them (including at the beginning or end).

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: **: Matches directories recursively.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: ?: Matches any one character.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: \: Escapes the next metacharacter.

title: Using patterns in the file name or file path
body: [set]: Matches any one character in set.

title: Rolling builds
body: With the rolling builds feature, you can configure Bitrise to automatically abort on-hold builds or already running builds if another build is triggered on the same branch.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can cancel running builds or builds on hold with the Rolling Builds feature. The previous builds of your project can be automatically aborted once a new one is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Please note that manual and scheduled builds are also cancelled if you start a new build with the Rolling builds option enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: When is a build aborted?

title: Rolling builds
body: If you trigger a build on a branch where a build is already running, the running build is aborted only if it runs the same Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: For example, if you trigger a build on the main branch of your repository with the deploy Workflow, it will NOT cancel a build running on the same main branch with the primary Workflow.

title: Rolling builds
body: You can also set which types of triggered builds you wish to abort. Let’s see how!

title: Rolling builds
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Rolling builds
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Rolling builds
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Rolling builds
body: Find the Rolling builds section.

title: Rolling builds
body: Select the type(s) of builds you wish to abort when a new build is started.

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabling the options will do the following:

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabled for Pull Requests: will cancel all previous builds still on-hold for Pull Requests and all related Pushes. Running builds will not be canceled unless Running builds are aborted is also enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: Enabled for Pushes: will cancel all previous builds still on-hold for Pushes to the same branch. Running builds will not be canceled unless Running builds are aborted is also enabled.

title: Rolling builds
body: Running builds are aborted: will also auto-cancel running builds in addition to on-hold ones.

title: Rolling builds
body: All done! From now on, you don’t have to wait for a triggered build to finish if you do not need it!

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Bitrise's built-in email notification system sends emails about builds to every user who is assigned to work on an application. They are sent when a build is finished and they can be configured for both successful and failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Notifications are updates about your activity on Bitrise. Usually, they concern the state of your builds but you can receive notifications about a lot of different things.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Our built-in email notification system sends emails about builds to every user who is assigned to work on an application. They are sent when a build is finished and they can be configured for both successful and failed builds.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Watching the app

title: Configuring email notifications
body: To receive automatic email messages, you need to be watching the app. If you turn off watching, you won’t receive the automated emails.

title: Configuring email notifications
body: Email notifications are automatically set up for all applications when first creating them but you can modify these notification settings at any time: Changing your email notification settings

title: Configuring email notifications
body: The alternative solution is to send emails via a dedicated Step. This allows for far more customization regarding the notifications: Sending emails with a Step

title: Watching a project
body: Watching a Bitrise project means getting email notifications for that project. Turning off watching the project means you won't get automatic notifications.

title: Watching a project
body: To enable watching:

title: Watching a project
body: Open Bitrise CI.

title: Watching a project
body: From the project list on the right, select your project.

title: Watching a project
body: On the left, toggle Watching.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Email notifications are automatically set up for all projects when first creating them. There are three possible settings for both successful builds and failed builds:

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Always. This is the default setting for failed builds.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Never.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Send email when build status changes on the same branch. This is the default setting for successful builds. This means that if build #1 and build #2 both succeeded, you will not get a notification about build #2. However, if build #3 fails and then build #4 succeeds again, you will be notified.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: You can change your email notification settings at any time - you can even completely disable them.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: On the left, select Notifications.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Scroll down to email notifications.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: Select the settings you need for both successful and failed builds from the appropriate dropdown menu.

title: Changing your email notification settings
body: For example, if you want to disable receiving notifications, set both options to Never.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The Send Email with Mailgun Step can send emails to any email address with customized updates, in either HTML or plain text format. You can use environment variables to send information, as well as attach files to the emails.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: To use the Step, you need:

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun account.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: A Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Your Mailgun domain name.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Make sure the Step runs in every build!

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: If you use the Send Email with Mailgun Step in your workflow, make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed! This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, you will not receive emails if your builds fail.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun API key.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_API_KEY. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable that holds your Mailgun domain.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: We recommend naming the key $MAILGUN_DOMAIN. This is the default value of the Step’s relevant input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Add the Send Email with Mailgun Step to the end of your workflow.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Find the Send To emails input of the Step. Click on the input and then click Select secret variable.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Create a new Secret Environment Variable that contains the list of the email addresses.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can choose any key you want. The addresses should be separated by a comma.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Set the email subject, and the two potential email messages: one for a successful build, one for a failed build.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: You can insert environment variables to any of the inputs (the subject and the messages). In the email, the values of the variables will be displayed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: The default messages will send the name of the app, the number of the build and whether the build succeeded or failed.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Attach files, if necessary: the File attachments input accepts a file path or an environment variable as input.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Multiple files can be attached: separate their paths with commas.

title: Sending emails with a Step
body: Run a build - and check your emails!

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: You can integrate Slack to your app on Bitrise by adding the "Send a Slack message" Step to your app's Workflow.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: You can send Slack messages during a Bitrise build to individual users, groups or channels with the Send a Slack message Step. Customize the messages, include attachments, and link buttons that will take the users to the build page.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: To use the Step to send messages:

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Set up the workspace Slack integration and get the integration ID.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: The Step needs the integration ID.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Add the integration ID as a Secret.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Add the Send a Slack message Step to your Workflow.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Make sure that it is always set to run even if the previous Step failed!

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: This is the default setting of the Step. If you change it, messages won’t be sent if the build fails.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Find the Slack integration ID input and add the Secret containing the integration ID.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Customize your Slack message with the relevant inputs of the Step.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: There are several options, including but not limited to:

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Setting the target channel, group or username: this can be a name or an encoded ID.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: The text of the message to send.

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: The bot’s username for the message

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: The message’s color

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: File attachment

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Link buttons attached to the message

title: Sending Slack messages in a build
body: Check out all the inputs in the Workflow Editor to see all the ways in which you can customize your Slack messages.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If you want to push back any commits to your own Git repo from Bitrise while running your build, you can set up your Git credentials on build machines.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: The default Git username and user email address on our stacks are the following:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body:
git config --global user.email "please-set-your-email@bitrise.io"
git config --global user.name "J. Doe (https://devcenter.bitrise.io/builds/setting-your-git-credentials-on-build-machines/)"

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: If you want to push back (git push) any commits to your own repo from Bitrise while running your build, you have to set your own username and the email address. There are three ways to achieve this:

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use a custom Script Step to set your credentials with the git config command.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can set your Git credentials as Env Vars.

title: Setting your Git credentials on build machines
body: You can use the Set Git Credentials Step.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Git has various basic Environmental Variables similar to Bitrise Env Vars. If you would like to reduce the amount of Steps in your Workflow, you can set up Env Vars in Bitrise utilizing specific Git Environmental Variables:

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Open the Workflow Editor.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Go to the Env Vars tab.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: Create the following Env Vars:

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_AUTHOR_NAME: This is the human-readable name of the “author”.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_AUTHOR_EMAIL: This is the email address of the "author".

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_COMMITTER_NAME: This is the human-readable name of the “committer”.

title: Setting your Git credentials using Env Vars
body: GIT_COMMITTER_EMAIL: This is the email address of the "committer".

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: Add a Set Git Credentials Step as the very first step in your workflow. The Step has to come first before you’d git commit. This way you can make sure any changes you make to the current build will be attached to a commit associated with your username and email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: In the Git Username field, set the value to your own user name.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: In the Git Email Address field, set the value to your own email address.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: Start a build.

title: Setting your Git credentials using the Set Git Credentials Step
body: If all went well, you should see the changes in your repository in your Git provider. The new username and email address will be visible for all future commits you push from your builds to your Git provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: You need to authenticate Bitrise and specify a Service credential user in the App settings page of your app to push back build status reports to your Git provider.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Bitrise can send build status reports to your Git provider (GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket). This helps developers make informed decisions quickly and eliminates the need to switch between platforms.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: We send a status report for each build, even if the same commit triggers multiple builds. You can customize the report using variables to make it more descriptive and convey specific information.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: You can set up status reports on the project level or the level of Workflows or Pipelines.

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: Pipeline reports

title: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider
body: If the triggered entity is a Pipeline, it will report its build status but the individual Workflows within the Pipeline won't report separate statuses. Other than the Pipeline status report, Bitrise also reports test result statuses for Steps that are exporting a test result.

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: There are two ways to set up Git status reports on Bitrise:

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: By using the GitHub App integration. It automatically sends status reports without any additional configuration, other than optionally customizing your reports.

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: Via the service credential user. If you use OAuth authentication for repository access, this is how you can send status reports. The service credential user must have their Bitrise account connected to the Git provider account and must have access to the Git repository. The following permissions are required:

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: GitHub: Write

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: Bitbucket: Write

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: GitLab: Developer.

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: You can test the service credential user's connection at any time: Checking the service credential user.

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: Allowlist the Bitrise website IP addresses

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: If you use some form of self-hosted solution for storing your code, you might need to allowlist the static IP addresses of the Bitrise website and its background workers. This allows you to use such features as storing the bitrise.yml file in your own repository, or receiving build status updates from Bitrise: IP address ranges for Bitrise backend workers.

title: Setting up build status reporting
body: You can send both project level and Workflow or Pipeline level reports with both methods.

title: Branch protection rules
body: When updating your build status report settings, you might need to change your branch protection rules at your Git provider.

title: Branch protection rules
body: If you use Workflow/Pipeline level status reports or use the target-id dynamic variable, you will have a different status check for every Workflow or Pipeline that was run. This means you might need more than one branch protection rule IF all checks are mandatory for all your pull requests.

title: Custom status reports
body: You can create custom Git status reports: You can tailor the commit status message to your team's preferences and requirements. You can give your report a name that allows you to immediately identify it on the Git provider site. You can use dynamic variables in the status report's name, like the title of your project or the name of the Workflow.

title: Custom status reports
body: The default status report name is ci/bitrise/<project_slug>/<event_type>. For legacy GitHub Checks reports, the default name is Bitrise.

title: Custom status reports
body: You can set up custom reports on two levels:

title: Custom status reports
body: Project level reports apply to all Workflows and Pipelines within a project. This provides a consistent format for the status of any build in the same project.

title: Custom status reports
body: On the level of individual Workflows or Pipelines. These custom reports will take precedence over the general project-level status report. This is useful when you want to provide more specific information about a particular build stage or to differentiate between different types of builds.

title: Custom status reports
body: Character limit and accepted characters

title: Custom status reports
body: Keep your status message concise. The limit is 100 characters, and BitBucket allows only 40 characters.

title: Custom status reports
body: The following characters are supported: , . / ( ) : - _ (space) (a-z) (A-Z) (0-9) < > [ ] |

title: Project level status reports
body: To create a custom status report on a project level, add the status_report_name property under app in your configuration YAML file. It can have static values:

title: Project level status reports
body:
app:
 status_report_name: 'Bitrise build'

title: Project level status reports
body: Or you can use dynamic values:

title: Project level status reports
body:
app:
 status_report_name: 'PR check for <project_title>'

title: Project level status reports
body: You can also combine multiple dynamic values:

title: Project level status reports
body:
app:
 status_report_name: 'Executing <target_id> for <project_title>'

title: Project level status reports
body: We recommend using target_id: it's the name of the Workflow or Pipeline that the build uses. With this variable, Git commit statuses from different Workflows/Pipelines on the same commit don't override each other.

title: Project level status reports
body: Find the available variables here: Table 1, “.

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: To create a custom status report on the Workflow level, add the status_report_name property under the name of the Workflow in the configuration YAML file:

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body:
workflows:
 build-ios:
 status_report_name:

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: Similarly, to create one on the Pipeline level, add the property under the name of the Pipeline:

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body:
pipeline:
 deploy-pipeline:
 status_report_name:

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: You can also combine multiple dynamic values:

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body:
pipeline:
 deploy-pipeline:
 status_report_name: 'Executing <target_id> for <project_title>'

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: We recommend using target_id: it's the name of the Workflow or Pipeline that the build uses. With this variable, Git commit statuses from different Workflows/Pipelines on the same commit don't override each other.

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: Find the available variables here: Table 1, “.

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: We recommend using target_id: it's the name of the Workflow or Pipeline that the build uses. With this variable, Git commit statuses from different Workflows/Pipelines on the same commit don't override each other.

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: Branch protection rules

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: When switching from project-based status reports to Workflow level status reports, you might need to update branch protection rules.

title: Workflow/Pipeline level status reports
body: You can also set Workflow-level status reports in the Workflow Editor: open the Workflow, and go to its Properties tab, then find the Git status name input.

title: Dynamic variables
body: You can use the following dynamic variables in your status reports:

title: Dynamic variables
body: Dynamic variables for status reports

title: Troubleshooting build status reporting
body: If your builds do not send status reports to your Git hosting provider - GitHub, GitLab or Bitbucket -, you will need to do a little investigating to find out what causes the problem. Let’s take a look at the potential issues!

title: Checking the service credential user
body: The service credential user of the app on bitrise.io must have connected their Bitrise account to their Git hosting account and must have access to the repository of the app on that Git account.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: You can check the service credential user and test their Git connection.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Go to your app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Find the Service credential user section.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Current user

title: Checking the service credential user
body: In the figure, the current active user is the service credential user. If the service credential user is a different user, this looks a little different, including the button's text.

title: Checking the service credential user
body: Click the Test <Git provider> connection button to test the user's Git connection.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure that you granted Bitrise access to your Workspace or team. It might be that you did not grant Bitrise access or denied access to the GitHub Workspace or Bitbucket team that owns the repository.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Make sure the URL repository is up to date:

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: On the left, select General.

title: Checking repository permissions and repository URL
body: Find the repository URL and make sure it's correct.

title: Starting builds
body: You can start builds on Bitrise in multiple ways: manually, by scheduling, setting up triggers, or by using the API.

title: Starting builds
body: Pipelines

title: Starting builds
body: This section of the documentation deals with starting standalone Bitrise builds. For starting a Pipelines, check out Running a Pipeline.

title: Starting builds
body: You can start builds on Bitrise in multiple ways:

title: Starting builds
body: With the API: Triggering and aborting builds

title: Starting builds
body: You can also configure Bitrise to skip certain commits or Git Tags, preventing these from triggering builds.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can start builds manually by selecting the app you need from your Dashboard and clicking the Start/Schedule build button.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build manually on Bitrise takes literally two clicks - if you leave everything on the default settings. If you do not wish to do that, or at least want to be sure what the default settings are, read on!

title: Starting builds manually
body: To start a build using the basic configuration options:

title: Starting builds manually
body: On the Bitrise CI page of your app, find the Start build button and click the button with the clock icon next to it.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Enter the branch you want to run into the Source branch input field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can choose between typing the name or selecting it from a dropdown menu. Click Select branch to bring up the dropdown menu.

title: Starting builds manually
body: You can only set one branch. If a pull request to your repository is made from a forked branch, type the name of that branch to run a build of the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Pull request build

title: Starting builds manually
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Optionally, enter a build message in the Message field.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Please note that entering the Git commit message of a specific commit doesn't trigger a build of that commit!

title: Starting builds manually
body: From the Target menu, select a Workflow or Pipeline.

title: Starting builds manually
body: If you don't select one, Bitrise will choose a Workflow or Pipeline based on your app's trigger setup.

title: Starting builds manually
body: Scheduling a build

title: Starting builds manually
body: The Schedule this build option allows you to configure builds to be triggered at specific times. Read more: Scheduling builds.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: You can manually start a build by running a single Workflow from the Workflow Editor.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: To do so:

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Open your app on Bitrise and click the Workflows button to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: On the Workflows tab, use the WORKFLOW drop-down menu to select the Workflow you would like to run.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Click Run Workflow.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Specify the branch that you want to build in the Branch field.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: Click Run Workflow to start the build.

title: Running Workflows from the Workflow Editor
body: And that's it! As soon as you click the Run Workflow button, your build will be kicked off, and the build's page will open in a new tab.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You can select a source type in the Source dropdown menu. In addition to the default Branch option, you can also select:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: In addition to different sources, you can also add:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Build triggers
body: You can configure automatic build triggers on Bitrise by specifying a trigger event and a Workflow. You can trigger builds from code pushes, pull requests or Git tags.

title: Build triggers
body: Existing trigger configurations

title: Build triggers
body: This page details information about target-based build triggers, defined within a Workflow or a Pipeline. We recommend this approach for all new users as it offers a more granular and flexible build trigger system.

title: Build triggers
body: Existing configurations might use legacy, project-based triggers. Read more about them: Legacy project-based triggers.

title: Build triggers
body: Use build triggers to start one or more Bitrise builds automatically. A trigger's definition contains a code event and one or more conditions that the event must match in order to trigger a build.

title: Build triggers
body: You can define triggers within a Workflow or a Pipeline. They allow a single code event to trigger multiple different Workflows or Pipelines so you can run all the relevant parts of your CI process together based on the scope of code change, without bundling everything into a single Workflow or Pipeline. Each build will run independently and deliver individual results.

title: Build triggers
body: For the detailed syntax of triggers and the exact trigger conditions, see YAML syntax for build triggers.

title: Code events
body: You can use three types of code events to trigger builds:

title: Code events
body: Code push: Trigger a build automatically whenever you push code using commits that match your trigger conditions. For example, a commit to the specified branch of the project's repository triggers a build.

title: Code events
body: Pull request: Trigger a build automatically whenever a pull request matches your trigger conditions. For example, you can specify source and/or destination branches where any pull request will trigger a build.

title: Code events
body: Initial PR event

title: Code events
body: A pull request only triggers a build once, at its initial event. In most cases, that initial event is the creation of the pull request. For example, converting a PR to a draft PR will never trigger another build. To trigger builds for updates to a pull request, configure code push triggers for the new commits.

title: Code events
body: Git Tag: Trigger a build automatically whenever a commit with a specific tag triggers a build.

title: Conditions
body: A trigger condition is a filter for code events: instead of triggering a build on every pull request, you can configure triggers for pull requests targeting a specific branch.

title: Conditions
body: Different Git providers support different conditions. For the full table, see Supported trigger conditions.

title: Conditions
body: Trigger conditions can be combined within a single trigger: for example, you can set up a pull request trigger that only triggers a build if the PR targets a specific branch AND contains a specific label.

title: Creating build triggers
body: You create build triggers directly in a Workflow or Pipeline. Such triggers allow a single code event to trigger multiple Workflows or Pipelines. You can create triggers via the UI or in the configuration YAML file.

title: Creating build triggers
body: To create triggers:

title: Creating build triggers
body: Workflow Editor

title: Creating build triggers
body: Configuration YAML

title: Creating build triggers
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Select a Workflow.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Select the Triggers tab on the Workflow's page.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Select the trigger type and click the Add trigger button.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Configure your trigger in the dialog.

title: Creating build triggers
body: When done, click Add trigger.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Open your configuration YAML file.

title: Creating build triggers
body: Find the Workflow.

title: Creating build triggers
body: In the Workflow, add a triggers property.

title: Creating build triggers
body:
my-workflow:
 triggers:

title: Creating build triggers
body: Create your triggers. You can find the exact syntax for the different trigger types here: YAML syntax for build triggers.

title: Creating build triggers
body: For example, this trigger starts a build with the Workflow

title: Creating build triggers
body:
my-workflow:
triggers:
 push:
 - commit_message: your_message

title: Creating build triggers
body: Save the configuration.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: You can temporarily disable any build trigger. A disabled trigger doesn't trigger builds but retains all configuration information. You can reactivate a disabled trigger at any time.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: To disable a build trigger:

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Workflow Editor

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Configuration YAML

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Open the Workflow Editor on Bitrise.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Select a Workflow or Pipeline.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: On the Workflow page, select the Triggers tab.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Find the trigger you need and click the vertical ellipsis next to its name.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Select Disable trigger.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Open your configuration YAML file.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Find the Workflow or Pipeline and its triggers property.

title: Disabling a trigger
body: Add enabled: false to the trigger you want to disable.

title: Disabling a trigger
body:
triggers:
 push:
 - branch: main
 enabled: false

title: Supported trigger conditions
body: Not all trigger conditions are available for all Git providers. As a general rule, all our trigger conditions are available for the cloud service of the three most frequently used Git providers: GitHub, GitLab, and Bitbucket. For other providers, or self-hosted Git repositories, check out the detailed table for both push triggers and pull request triggers.

title: Supported trigger conditions
body: Supported trigger conditions for code push triggers

title: Supported trigger conditions
body: Supported trigger conditions for pull request triggers

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: GitHub and GitLab offers a feature called draft pull request (or merge request in the case of GitLab): when you create a pull request (PR), you can choose to create a pull request that is ready for review or a draft pull request. Draft pull requests cannot be merged, and code owners are not automatically requested to review draft pull requests.

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: Git provider limitations

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: This feature is only supported for GitHub and GitLab repositories.

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: By default, opening a draft PR triggers builds. You can disable this at any time.

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: If opening a draft PR triggers a build, submitting it for review (converting it to "full" PR, in other words) will not trigger another. You can check out the exact code events that trigger builds depending on the draft PR trigger settings: Build trigger behavior for draft PRs.

title: Triggering builds from draft PRs
body: Each separate trigger has its own toggle: you can configure your app so that certain triggers start a build from draft PRs while other triggers don't.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Skipping Steps if a build is triggered by a draft PR

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: This guide tells you how to disable triggering builds from a draft PR altogether. You can, however, also skip certain Steps in a build that is triggered by a draft pull request. You just need to use a run_if condition and the GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT Environment Variable: for more information, see Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Workflow Editor

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: bitrise.yml

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Open your Workflow and select the Triggers tab.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: If you have a Pipeline, you can only disable the setting in the configuration YAML file.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Find the trigger you need and click the vertical ellipsis next to its name.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Select Edit trigger from the menu.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Uncheck the Include draft pull requests option and click Apply changes.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Open your configuration YAML file.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Find the triggers element in all Workflows or Pipelines you want to modify.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body: Add draft_enabled: false to the pull request triggers you need.

title: Disabling builds from a draft PR
body:
workflows:
 primary:
 triggers: 
 pull_request:
 - draft_enabled: false

title: Build trigger behavior for draft PRs
body: The table shows whether a build is triggered when a specific action is performed regarding draft PRs, depending on the draft PR trigger settings. For example, converting a draft PR to a PR doesn't trigger a build if the draft PR trigger is enabled but it does trigger a build when it's disabled.

title: Build trigger behavior for draft PRs
body: Trigger behavior

title: Trigger variables
body: A number of Environment Variables related to build triggers are available during an automatically triggered build. These variables can give detailed context about build triggers and pull request attributes. Use these trigger variables to:

title: Trigger variables
body: Use pull request data, such as comments, labels, and changed files, to automate complex workflows and decision-making processes.

title: Trigger variables
body: Understand who and how your builds are triggered and use that to better debug your workflows

title: Trigger variables
body: Implement precise build conditions to reduce unnecessary runs, saving time and resources.

title: Trigger variables
body: You can find all trigger variables and their definition in our reference table: Table 2, “.

title: Trigger variables
body: Trigger variables are only available if the requirements are met. For example, the BITRISE_GIT_PULL_REQUEST_COMMENT variable is only available if the build is triggered by a PR comment; in other words, the build trigger has a pr_comment condition. You can find the exact conditions in Table 2, “.

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: Here are some example use cases for trigger variables. These are merely suggestions: you can experiment with variables to find what suits your needs best.

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: Reporting back to the PR comment

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: BITRISE_GIT_PULL_REQUEST_COMMENT_ID: Use the pull request comment ID to post a status update directly to the original comment on the pull request. This can include details such as success, failure, logs, or any other relevant information.

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: Conditional test execution

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: BITRISE_GIT_CHANGED_FILES : Identify modified parts of the codebase and based on these changes, trigger specific test suites, such as running frontend tests for UI changes and backend tests for API modifications.

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: Deploying to different environments based on commit messages or labels

title: Use cases for trigger variables
body: Use BITRISE_GIT_COMMIT_MESSAGES and BITRISE_GIT_PULL_REQUEST_LABELS to determine the deployment environment. For instance, if a commit message includes "[staging]" or a label "ready-for-staging" is present, deploy the code to the staging environment.

title: YAML syntax for build triggers
body: The configuration YAML files contain the definitions for build triggers. You can configure them directly in YAML without having to use the online Workflow Editor.

title: YAML syntax for build triggers
body: Existing trigger configurations

title: YAML syntax for build triggers
body: This page details information about target-based build triggers, defined within a Workflow or a Pipeline. We recommend this approach for all new users as it offers a more granular and flexible build trigger system.

title: YAML syntax for build triggers
body: Existing configurations might use legacy, project-based triggers. Read more about them: Legacy project-based triggers.

title: YAML syntax for build triggers
body: The configuration YAML files contain the definitions for build triggers. You can configure them directly in YAML without having to use the online Workflow Editor.

title: Trigger syntax
body: Triggers must be included in a triggers element within a Workflow or Pipeline. A valid trigger in the triggers element includes the type of the trigger and at least one trigger condition.

title: Trigger syntax
body: For example, the below trigger launches a build when code is pushed to the release branch.

title: Trigger syntax
body:
workflows:
 pipeline-tests:
 triggers:
 push:
 - branch: "release"

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: We parse all triggers in a configuration YAML and start builds with all matching triggers. This means the order of the triggers doesn't matter.

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: For example, if you have two Workflows with push triggers with the same branch condition, both will be triggered when a commit is pushed to that branch. In the configuration below, both triggers will launch a build if a commit is pushed to the release branch:

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: The pipeline-tests Workflow specifies the release branch.

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: The pipeline-build Workflow uses a wildcard so any commit triggers a build with it.

title: Multiple matching triggers
body:
workflows:
 pipeline-tests:
 triggers:
 push:
 - branch: "release"
 [...]
 pipeline-build:
 triggers:
 push: 
 - branch: "*"

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body: If you define multiple trigger conditions, all of them must match to trigger a build. In the example below, a build will be triggered if:

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body: A commit is pushed to the release branch.

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body: Certain files have changed in the commit.

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body:
workflows:
 pipeline-builds:
 triggers:
 push:
 - branch: release
 changed_files:
 - path/to/library-a/**

title: Wildcards and regex
body: We support wildcards (*) for simple text matching within all types of triggers. Wildcards are a good choice when you don't need the advanced pattern matching capabilities of regular expressions. For example, a trigger based on commit messages starting with fix can be achieved using a wildcard.

title: Wildcards and regex
body: Wildcards are useful to match specific, fixed values appearing in the input. We recommend using regexes are needed when multiple alternative values, negation, capturing specific groups of characters or specific character types (for example, numbers only) are needed.

title: Wildcards and regex
body: To use regular expressions for a trigger condition, you need to add regex: to its value:

title: Wildcards and regex
body:
workflows: 
 deploy:
 triggers:
 tag:
 - name:
 regex: '^\d\.\d\.\d$'
 pull_request:
 - comment: "[workflow: deploy]"
 commit_message:
 regex: '.*\[workflow: deploy\].*'

title: Trigger components
body: Components for all trigger types

title: Trigger components
body: Components for code push triggers

title: Trigger components
body: Components for pull request triggers

title: Trigger components
body: Components for tag triggers

title: Legacy project-based triggers
body: Legacy or project-based triggers are defined on the project level: that is, the top level of your configuration YAML file. The trigger defines which Workflow or Pipeline should run when a given code event happens. A single code event can only trigger a single build.

title: Legacy project-based triggers
body: Legacy triggers

title: Legacy project-based triggers
body: This page is about legacy triggers that are defined on a project level. For new users, we strongly recommend using the target-based build triggers which are defined on the level of Workflows and Pipelines as they allow more flexibility in designing your triggers: Build triggers.

title: Legacy project-based triggers
body: Legacy or project-based triggers are defined on the project level: that is, the top level of your configuration YAML file. The trigger defines which Workflow or Pipeline should run when a given code event happens. A single code event can only trigger a single build.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Project-based triggers are defined on the project level: that is, the top level of your configuration YAML file. The trigger defines which Workflow or Pipeline should run when a given code event happens. A single code event can only trigger a single build.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Project-based triggers are defined on the project level: that is, the top level of your configuration YAML file. The trigger defines which Workflow or Pipeline should run when a given code event happens. A single code event can only trigger a single build.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Workflow Editor

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Configuration YAML

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Select a Workflow.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Select the trigger type and click the Add trigger button.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: For example, if you want to set up a trigger for pull request events, select the Pull Request tab.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Click the Add trigger button.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Configure your trigger in the dialog.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: When setting multiple conditions, all conditions must be fulfilled for a build to start. You can use regular expressions for any of the condition types.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: You can find the full list of supported trigger conditions here: Supported trigger conditions

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: When done, click Add trigger.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Open your configuration YAML file.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: In the Workflow, find the trigger_map property and set up your trigger under it. You need:

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: A type property to define the type of the code event.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: A trigger condition. For example, commit_message.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: The Workflow or Pipeline you want to trigger.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body:
trigger_map:
- type: push
 commit_message: your_message
 workflow: my-workflow

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: You can find the exact syntax for the different trigger types here: YAML syntax for build triggers.

title: Creating project-based triggers
body: Save the configuration.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: To disable a project-based build trigger:

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Workflow Editor

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Configuration YAML

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Open the Workflow Editor on Bitrise.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: On the left, select Triggers.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Select the appropriate tab, depending on the trigger you want to deactivate.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Set the trigger to Inactive.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Open your configuration YAML file.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Find the trigger_map property and the trigger you want to disable.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body: Add enabled: false to it.

title: Disabling a project-based trigger
body:
trigger_map:
- type: push
 push_branch: main
 workflow: primary
 enabled: false

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: A project-based trigger has three main elements in its YAML syntax:

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: The type of the trigger: push, pull_request, or tag.

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: The trigger condition. For example, the source branch of a pull request.

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: The Workflow or Pipeline to be triggered.

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: One trigger means one build: a single project-based trigger can only trigger a single Workflow or Pipeline. You can chain Workflows together run several Workflows in succession from a single trigger.

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body: Below is a single trigger that triggers a build with the primary Workflow when a pull request is opened from any branch.

title: Project-based trigger syntax
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_source_branch: "*" 
 type: pull_request 
 workflow: primary

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: For project-based triggers, the first trigger with matching conditions triggers a build. This means the order of the triggers is important:

title: Multiple matching triggers
body:
trigger_map:
- type: push
 push_branch: main
 workflow: primary
- type: push
 commit_message: deploy
 workflow: deploy

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: The first trigger triggers the primary Workflow if code is pushed to the main branch of the app's repository.

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: The second trigger triggers the deploy Workflow if a commit with the commit message deploy is pushed to any branch of the repository.

title: Multiple matching triggers
body: What happens when a commit is pushed to the main branch with the commit message deploy? The commit matches all conditions of the first trigger so the primary Workflow is triggered. In this scenario, the deploy Workflow is NOT triggered, even though the commit matches all conditions of that trigger, too.

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body: If you define multiple trigger conditions in a single project-based trigger then all conditions have to match in order to trigger a build. For example:

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body:
trigger_map:
- pull_request_target_branch: "main"
 pull_request_source_branch: "develop"
 type: pull_request
 workflow: primary

title: Multiple trigger conditions
body: This will only select the primary workflow if the pull request’s source branch is develop AND the target branch is main.

title: Project-based trigger components
body: The components listed on this page are valid for legacy, project-based triggers.

title: Project-based trigger components
body: Components for all trigger types

title: Project-based trigger components
body: Components for code push triggers

title: Project-based trigger components
body: Components for pull request triggers

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: You can trigger Bitrise builds from your Slack workspace by configuring Slash Commands in your Slack apps. Each Bitrise app needs its own Slash Command.

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: Register the Bitrise webhook URL to your Slack app's Slash Command: Adding a Slack webhook.

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: Slack app reinstall

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: Creating a new Slash Command might require a reinstall of your Slack app.

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: Use the command by adding at least the two required parameters to it: workflow and branch.

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: /build-myapp workflow: run_tests|branch: main

title: Triggering builds by Slack commands
body: You can set a number of different parameters in the command call, including a commit hash, and any Environment Variables that you want to pass on to the build. For more information on the available parameters, check out Available parameters for your Slack command.

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: To trigger builds via Slack, you need to amend your Slash Command with parameters in a key:value|key:value format.

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: You must specify at least one parameter:

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: b or branch. For example, branch: main

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: w or workflow. For example, workflow: run_tests

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: Without specifying either branch or Workflow in your command, the command will fail.

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: The optional parameters allow further configuration of your build:

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: t or tag. For example, branch: main|tag: v1.0

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: c or commit. For example, workflow: run_tests|commit: eee55509f16e7715bdb43308bb55e8736da4e21e

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: m or message. For example, branch: main|message: ship it!!

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: You can also send environment variables that will be available in your Workflow with the format: env[KEY1]:value1|ENV[KEY2]:value2

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: Slack command with all parameters included

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: The example includes all parameters, required and optional. It builds a specific commit and passes two Environment Variables to the build:

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: $DEVICE_NAME with the value of iPhone 6S.

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
body: $DEVICE_UDID with the value of 82667b4079914d4aabed9c216620da5dedab630a

title: Available parameters for your Slack command
