title: Scheduling builds
body: You can schedule your builds to run automatically at a specific time of the week.

title: Scheduling builds
body: You can schedule your builds to run automatically at a specific time of the week so that you can check your logs when it’s most convenient for you.

title: Scheduling builds
body: When scheduling a build, you can define custom Environment Variables. You can also set advanced filters for Git Tags and for Git commit hash.

title: Scheduling builds
body: If you have one or more regularly scheduled builds, you can:

title: Scheduling builds
body: Edit their configuration.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Trigger them manually at any time.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Temporarily disable them.

title: Scheduling builds
body: Permanently delete them.

title: Scheduling a build
body: How to schedule a build with the basic configuration options on Bitrise:

title: Scheduling a build
body: On the Bitrise CI page of your app, find the Start build button and click the button with the clock icon next to it.

title: Scheduling a build
body: In the Schedule build dialog, set up the scheduling cadence: you can choose between Basic and Cron settings.

title: Scheduling a build
body: In the Basic settings, you need to set a start date, a start time in 24-hour time format, and select a timezone.

title: Scheduling a build
body: In the Cron settings, you can set a cron schedule expression. The dialog will parse your expression and display the configured time in a human-readable format.

title: Scheduling a build
body: If you chose Basic, enable or disable repetition with the Repetition toggle. If you enable repetition, configure the frequency, from minutes to years.

title: Scheduling a build
body: The build will be triggered with the configured frequency, always at the same time, determined by the scheduling cadence. For example, you can configure your builds to run on Monday and Thursday every week.

title: Scheduling a build
body: When ready, click Next to proceed to the build configuration.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Select between Basic and Advanced configuration.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Basic configuration offers three options:

title: Scheduling a build
body: A branch name. This is a required field.

title: Scheduling a build
body: A message in the Message field. This is not related to Git commit messages at all. It's just a place to provide some optional information about your build.

title: Scheduling a build
body: A Workflow or a Pipeline. You can select a specific one or use the Based on trigger map option to select one using the the trigger map in the app's bitrise.yml configuration file.

title: Scheduling a build
body: Pull request branch

title: Scheduling a build
body: Starting a build of a pull request’s branch is NOT the same as a pull request build. The manually started build of a pull request branch will only build the state of the code on that branch. An automatically triggered pull request build, however, builds the state of the code as it will look like once you merged the pull request.

title: Scheduling a build
body: For advanced configuration options, see the Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds section.

title: Scheduling a build
body: When done, click Schedule build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If you choose Advanced in the Build configuration window, you have all the options available with Basic, and a few more:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You can select a source type in the Source dropdown menu. In addition to the default Branch option, you can also select:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tag: Builds a particular branch or commit that is tagged with the Tag you enter. If you set this, you can't set a commit hash.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Git Tags and commit hashes are conflicting options

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: You cannot specify both a Git Tag and a commit hash. When you set one, the other one will disappear. This ensures you cannot enter conflicting input values.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit Hash: Copy a specific commit’s hash here to build that particular commit. This option can even send a build status update to your git hosting service. If you set this, you can't set a Git Tag.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Commit hash takes precedence over the Branch option

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: If the Branch option specifies a branch where the commit hash you chose doesn't exist, Bitrise will find the branch that does have the given commit and run a build with that branch.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: In addition to different sources, you can also add:

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Custom Environment Variables: Create a custom Environment Variable that is used in the build. See Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build.

title: Advanced configuration options for starting/scheduling builds
body: Generated cURL command: Based on the options you set in the Build configuration window, we provide an automatically generated cURL command. This can be copied and pasted, and you can run it on any platform that has cURL installed.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: To change the configuration of a regularly scheduled build:

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds page of your app.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Find the Scheduled builds section and open it to view your scheduled builds.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Click the vertical ellipsis to open the context menu.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Select Edit configuration.

title: Editing a scheduled build
body: Make the changes you want and click Save.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: To immediately trigger a scheduled build:

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Go to the Builds page of your app.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Find the Scheduled builds section and open it to view your scheduled builds.

title: Triggering a scheduled build manually
body: Click Trigger now.

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: To temporarily pause a regularly scheduled build:

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds page of your app.

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: Find the Scheduled builds section and open it to view your scheduled builds.

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: Click the vertical ellipsis to open the context menu.

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: Select Pause schedule.

title: Pausing a scheduled build
body: The build will not run until you enable it again.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: To permanently delete a regularly scheduled build:

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Go to the Builds page of your app.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Find the Scheduled builds section and open it to view your scheduled builds.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Click the vertical ellipsis to open the context menu.

title: Deleting a scheduled build
body: Select Delete and then click Delete again when prompted for confirmation.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: You have the option of requiring manual approval for Bitrise builds started by pull requests if the app contains exposed Secrets. This option cannot be deactivated for public apps.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Not all pull requests need to be built. After all, for most projects, anyone can create a fork of the repository and submit a pull request. However, if an app on Bitrise is set up with Secrets that are exposed for pull request builds, for example, then you probably don’t want just anyone to be able to access those secrets.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: That is why you have the option to require approval for a pull request build before it can start. This feature works somewhat differently for public and private apps:

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Private apps: by default, pull requests submitted from a fork require approval. The setting can be changed. If your secrets are NOT exposed to PRs, the build will run without asking for approval.

title: Approving pull request builds
body: Public apps: pull requests submitted from a fork require approval by default and it cannot be changed. Public apps CANNOT opt out of this feature.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: To enable or disable manual approval, you need to be an Admin or an Owner on the application’s team. The application MUST be private: public apps cannot opt out of this feature!

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Scroll down to Manual build approval.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Please note that you can only change this setting for private apps! For public apps, this is always enabled.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: Toggle the switch to enable or disable it.

title: Enabling manual approval for private apps
body: By default, it is set to disabled.

title: Approving the PR build
body: Approving the PR build

title: Approving the PR build
body: Please note that approving a PR build means approving it on Bitrise. Approving a pull request on GitHub, for example, isn't sufficient to start a build on Bitrise: an owner has to approve the build on Bitrise itself.

title: Approving the PR build
body: If a pull request is submitted from a fork, you will be notified that a PR build is waiting for approval:

title: Approving the PR build
body: A notification email will be sent with the name of the app, as well as links to the repository itself and to the app’s Builds page on Bitrise.

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Git provider, the status of the CI check will show Pending - Waiting for approval

title: Approving the PR build
body: On the Builds page of the app, a confirmation box will be displayed.

title: Approving the PR build
body: To approve and run the build, click the Approve and Run Build button. Clicking Review opens the pull request on the website of your Git provider.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: You can start multiple parallel builds by using the Bitrise Start for Build and the Bitrise Wait for Build Steps.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Using Build Pipelines to start parallel builds with a single trigger

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If you have a credit-based account and you are planning on running multiple tasks parallel with a single trigger, we recommend using Build Pipelines. For more information, check out Build Pipelines.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If you have more than one concurrency or you have a credit-based account, you can run more than one build simultaneously. And since we want to make life as easy for you as possible, these builds can be started automatically, with a single trigger. Let’s go through how it works!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: In the example, we have three Workflows of a single app set up to run at the same time. Let’s call these Workflows Trigger, Building and Testing. The workflow called Trigger will be triggered by a pull request, and then the workflow will trigger Building and Testing which will run simultaneously.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: All workflows run on separate, clean Virtual Machines. They can also run on different types of stacks: to choose the stack for any Workflow, go to the Workflow Editor of the app and select the Stack tab.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: If any of the builds fail, the build will be considered a failed build. If the build is triggered by a webhook, Bitrise will send a summarized build result to your Git provider. If any of the parallel builds fail, a failed status will be reported.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: No reports for "child" builds

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Bitrise will send a Git status report only for the original "parent" build, the one that triggered all the other builds. The "child" builds will not send back status reports to your Git provider!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: For example, if build A triggers builds B and C, a status report will be sent once A is finished. There will be no separate status reports for builds B and C, however.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: What you need:

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Personal Access Token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: A Secret Environment Variable storing the token.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Start Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Bitrise Wait for Build Step.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Bitrise Start Build Step on the CI

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Since the Bitrise Build Start Step heavily relies on the parameters of the currently running build (for example, the app slug, build slug and the build number) to call the API, you cannot use the Bitrise Build Start Step locally.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: bitrise.yml example

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: You can edit your bitrise.yml file on the bitrise.yml tab of the Workflow Editor, or you can edit the file locally. The example below focuses on the Bitrise UI, but if you prefer to use YAML format, check out our example!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Personal Access Token for your user.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Go to Profile Settings and select the Security option on the left side. Click the Generate new button.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Copying the token

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Make sure the copy the token once it's generated: you won't be able to see it again!

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Create a Secret Environment Variable on the Secrets tab of the app’s Workflow Editor and add the token as its value.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Feel free to use any key you wish for the secret. We recommend something simple like $ACCESS_TOKEN.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Start Build Step to the Trigger Workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Note that the Bitrise Start Build Step will set an Environment Variable to all builds it starts: $SOURCE_BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER. Each build triggered by the Step will have their own build numbers but the source build number will be the same for all of them.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Find the Workflows input of the Step, and add Building and Testing to it.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the Bitrise Wait for Build Step as the last Step of the Trigger Workflow.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Checking build statuses

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: The Step checks statuses of the builds defined in the Step. The builds are defined in the Build slugs input: the slugs are the output of the Bitrise Start Build Step. As long as the builds defined by the slugs are running, the Step will hold the build it is running in. The build will fail if any of the builds included in the Step fail.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: Add the secret env storing your personal access token to the Bitrise Access Token input of the Step: click the Select secret variable button and choose the key you created.

title: Starting parallel builds with a single trigger
body: And you are done! Once you trigger the Trigger workflow, the Bitrise Start Build Step of the Workflow will trigger two more builds running simultaneously. If those two builds are successful, the Bitrise Wait for Build Step lets the first build finish. A single status report is sent to the git hosting provider, regardless whether the build is successful or not.

title: bitrise.yml example
body:
Trigger:
 steps:
 - build-router-start@0:
 inputs:
 - workflows: |-
 Building
 Testing
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"
 - build-router-wait@0:
 inputs:
 - access_token: "$BITRISE_API_KEY"

title: Skipping a given commit or pull request
body: Depending on your settings, every code change in your repository can trigger Bitrise builds. However, if you need to, you can skip a specific commit or pull request.

title: Skipping a given commit or pull request
body: Depending on your settings, every code change in your repository can trigger Bitrise builds. However, if you need to, you can skip a specific commit or pull request. Skipping means, in this context, that a code change will NOT trigger a build on Bitrise, even if the triggers are set up to do so.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: To make sure a specific commit does not trigger a build, include either [skip ci] or [ci skip] in the commit message:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: This is not important, please [skip ci]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Or:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body:
I just changed the README 

[ci skip]

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Only the head/last commit message is checked!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you push more than one commit, only the last (head) commit’s message will be checked for the skip ci pattern!

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: If you do want to start a build after all, you have two choices:

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Rebase the commit (change the commit message).

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Push another commit.

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Pushing an empty commit

title: Preventing a commit from triggering a build
body: Git allows to create and push empty commits. If you want to build a skipped build you can do git commit --allow-empty -m "I decided to run this" on the related branch and push the commit.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Pull requests are treated as (virtual) commits themselves, where the commit message is the title + description of the pull request. It is not the commit messages of the individual commits that make up the pull request.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: To skip a pull request include the [skip ci] pattern in the pull request’s title or its description.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Individual commit messages are not checked

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Putting the [skip ci] pattern in the commit message of individual commits that make up the pull request will not work: the pull request will trigger a build if the appropriate trigger is set up.

title: Preventing a pull request from triggering a build
body: Once you decide to not to skip the pull request, you can simply remove the [skip ci] pattern from the pull request’s title or description. This should automatically trigger a new build with the latest commit, and all future commits of the pull request will be built too (unless you add a [skip ci] pattern again).

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: When you use the draft PR function of GitHub, Bitrise inserts an Environment Variable called GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT into the build Environment Variable list. If this Env Var is available in your build Env Var list, its value is always set to true.

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: You can use the GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT Env Var in your build as part of a conditional: for example, you can skip certain Steps in builds that are triggered by draft PRs:

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body:
workflow1:
 steps:
 - script:
 run_if: '{{enveq "GITHUB_PR_IS_DRAFT" ""}}' 
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/usr/bin/env bash
 # fail if any commands fails
 set -e
 # debug log
 set -x

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: In this example, the run_if condition means that the Step will only run if the build is NOT triggered by a draft PR.

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: Yo recommend that you insert below run_if command to each Step in your Workflow to skip the Steps.

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: Starting a new build after a draft PR

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: Clicking the Ready for review button on GitHub only triggers a new build on Bitrise if builds from draft pull requests are disabled.

title: Skipping Steps triggered by a draft PR
body: If draft pull requests are enabled to trigger builds and a specific draft pull request already triggered a build, submitting it for review won't trigger a new build. Any previous builds will also contain the draft PR related Env Vars. In this case, we recommend you manually start a brand new build from the website or trigger the CI with a new commit.

title: Managing build files
body: Using the Deploy to bitrise.io Step, you can deploy files generated during a build to bitrise.io. You can also upload code signing files. You can view uploaded files on the Apps & Artifacts tab of the build page.

title: Managing build files
body: Managing files on Bitrise allows you to upload files to use in your builds. You are required to upload files for the purposes of code signing. Builds also produce files as outputs.

title: Managing build files
body: You can:

title: Managing build files
body: Upload files to the Generic File storage.

title: Managing build files
body: Use uploaded files in your builds.

title: Managing build files
body: Use encrypted files in your builds.

title: Managing build files
body: Using the Deploy to bitrise.io Step, you can deploy files generated during a build to bitrise.io. You can view these files on the Artifacts tab of the build page.

title: Managing build files
body: In addition, you can check out a build's generated installable artifacts (installable binaries, either IPA or APK/AAB) files on the Artifacts page of an app. The page shows all generated binaries from past builds and you can view the details of each file, including a QR code and a link to the public install page, both of which allow users to install the app on their devices.

title: Managing build files
body: You can also upload both Android and iOS code signing files. Read more about Android code signing and iOS code signing in our detailed guides.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: If your build requires any files to make it work, you can upload them in the Code Signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: If your build requires any files to make it work, you can upload them to Bitrise on the App settings page. It accepts any file type, all you need to do is provide a unique ID and upload the file.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Once a file is uploaded, it is stored as an Environment Variable (Env Var). You can use this Env Var to access the file and use it in your builds. The file can also be:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Downloaded by anyone who has either admin or owner role on the app’s team on Bitrise. You can prevent this: Protecting your uploaded files

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Exposed to pull request builds.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: File restrictions

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: There are certain restrictions on upload size and number of files:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: You can't upload a file bigger than 5 MB.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: You can only store a total of 5 different files at the same time. If you want to upload more, you need to delete one of the files in the storage.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: To upload a file:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: On the left, select Files.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Click Add file.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: In the dialog box, enter a unique ID in the File Storage ID input field.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: The unique ID will be part of the generated download URL that Bitrise stores as an Environment Variable.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Upload the file. You have two options:

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Click anywhere in the Select a file to upload section and select the file from your computer.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Drag and drop a file into the Select a file to upload section.

title: Uploading files for your builds
body: Remember that the file size cannot exceed 5 MB.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Once you uploaded a file to Bitrise, you can set your uploaded files to Protected mode. This means that no one can download or reveal the file from your account but your builds can still use them. Bitrise will handle the Environment Variable attached to your uploaded files as a Secret.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: On the left, select Files.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Click the horizontal ellipsis button next to the name of the file, and select Make protected.

title: Protecting your uploaded files
body: Click Make it protected in the dialog box.

title: Using files in your builds
body: To use a file in your builds, you can download it using a Step like File Downloader in your Workflow, or you can use the file's automatically generated Env Var as a Step input.

title: Using files in your builds
body: There are multiple ways to use files in your Bitrise builds.

title: Using files in your builds
body: Most Steps that generate files store the filepath in an output Environment Variable (Env Var). Subsequent Steps in the same Workflow can re-use that Env Var to access the file.

title: Using files in your builds
body: You can upload a file to the Generic File Storage and use the automatically generated Env Var as a Step input value in Steps that accept URLs as an input.

title: Using files in your builds
body: You can upload a file to the Generic File Storage and use one of our Steps (for example, the File Downloader Step) to download the file for the build. This works with Steps that require local file paths and as such do not support URLs directly as the input value.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: One of the ways to access a file in your build is by using the File Downloader Step. This Step is useful when you need to use a file in a Step input that only accepts local paths as a value.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: The Step downloads the file in a location you specify, and then every subsequent Step can access the file in that location.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Workflow Editor

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: bitrise.yml

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Open the Workflow Editor.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Add the File Downloader Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the Download source url input, add the location where the file can be found.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Finding the download URL for an uploaded file

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: If you uploaded the file to Bitrise, you can find its download URL in the Files section of the App settings page.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the Download destination path input, specify the path where you want to download the file. It should be a path relative to the root of the repository.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Using an Env Var as the input value

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: You can store the filepath in an App Env Var instead of specifying it directly for the input. That way you can refer to the file through the Env Var in other Steps, you won’t have to specify the path every time.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: For example, if you store the path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var, you can use it as the path for the input, and also use it to access the file in every subsequent Step.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Click Save changes in the top right corner.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Open the app's bitrise.yml file.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Add the file-downloader Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body:
workflows:
 download:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key: {}
 - git-clone: {}
 - file-downloader:
 inputs:

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the source input, add the location where the file can be found.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body:
workflows:
 download:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key: {}
 - git-clone: {}
 - file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: "$BITRISEIO_BITRISE_TEST_URL"

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: In the destination input, specify the path where you want to download the file. It should be a path relative to the root of the repository.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: Using an Env Var as the input value

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: You can store the filepath in an App Env Var instead of specifying it directly for the input. That way you can refer to the file through the Env Var in other Steps, you won’t have to specify the path every time.

title: Downloading a file using the File Downloader Step
body: For example, if you store the path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var, you can use it as the path for the input, and also use it to access the file in every subsequent Step.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: If you don't want to use the File Downloader Step to download and access an uploaded file in your build, you can use your own custom Script Step as well. All you need to do is to get the download URL and then download the file by specifying a full download path that exists on the build machine.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Workflow Editor

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: bitrise.yml

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Add a Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Find the Script content input of the Step.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Add a script to download the file and store the destination path in an Env Var.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Uploading the file to Bitrise

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: If you upload the file to Bitrise, you can use the file's download URL in your script.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: In the example below, the download URL is stored in the BITRISE_IO_MY_FILE_ID_URL Env Var. We're using envman to store the destination path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var. Subsequent Steps can use this Env Var to access the file.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex

# specify local download path
export file_local_path=download/path/to/my/file

# download the file
wget -O "$file_local_path" "$BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_ID_URL"
echo "file downloaded to: $file_local_path"

# OPTIONALLY: export the file's local path, to be able to use it in subsequent steps as an input value
envman add --key BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH --value "$file_local_path"

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Alternatively, for example, you can set the location as an App Env Var and simply download it to that path instead of defining the path inside the Script Step.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Open the bitrise.yml file of your app.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Add a script Step to your Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 script:
 inputs:
 - content:

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: In the content input, add a script to download the file and store the destination path in an Env Var.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: In the example below, the download URL is stored in the BITRISE_IO_MY_FILE_ID_URL Env Var. We're using envman to store the destination path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var. Subsequent Steps can use this Env Var to access the file.

 echo "file downloaded to: $file_local_path"

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Alternatively, for example, you can set the location as an App Env Var and simply download it to that path instead of defining the path inside the Script Step.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body: Optionally, export the file's local path so you can use it in subsequent Steps in the same Workflow.

title: Downloading a file using a custom Script Step
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content:
 #!/bin/bash
 set -ex

 # specify local download path
 export file_local_path=download/path/to/my/file

 # download the file
 wget -O "$file_local_path" "$BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_ID_URL"
 echo "file downloaded to: $file_local_path"

 # export the file path for subsequent steps
 envman add --key BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH --value "$file_local_path"

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: You can use encrypted files on Bitrise, easily. After encrypting the file on your computer, upload it to the Generic File Storage and use the Decrypt file Step or your own custom decrypting solution to decrypt it when you need it.

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: You can use encrypted files on Bitrise, easily and securely. All you need to do is encrypt the file on your computer, upload it to the Generic File Storage and use the Decrypt file Step or your own custom decrypting solution to decrypt it when you need it.

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: GPG encryption

title: Using encrypted files in your builds
body: Please note that the Decrypt file Step only decrypts files encrypted with GPG. If you use other encryption software, you will not be able to decrypt files using the Step. You can, of course, set up your own decryption solution in a Script Step.

title: Encrypting your files
body: In this example, we’ll use the pwgen password generator tool and GPG as the encryption software to encrypt a file.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Open a Terminal/Command Line.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Create a 32 character passphrase for encryption.

title: Encrypting your files
body: Keep the passphrase

title: Encrypting your files
body: You will need this passphrase to decrypt the file on Bitrise.

title: Encrypting your files
body: pwgen -s 32 1

title: Encrypting your files
body: Encrypt your file. In this example, the file is called my_secret_file.

title: Encrypting your files
body: gpg -c my_secret_file

title: Encrypting your files
body: Optionally, you can encrypt your file(s) in a non-interactive way.

title: Encrypting your files
body: gpg --batch --passphrase <passphrase> -c my_secret_file

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: After you successfully encrypted a file, you need to upload it to Bitrise and you need to be able to decrypt it during the build. In this procedure, we'll use the Decrypt file Step to decrypt the file.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: GPG encryption

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Please note that the Decrypt file Step only decrypts files encrypted with GPG. If you use other encryption software, you will not be able to decrypt files using the Step. You can, of course, set up your own decryption solution in a Script Step.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Go to the Secrets tab, and add your decryption passphrase as a Secret.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Upload the file to Bitrise

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Copy the Environment Variable (Env Var) under the name of the uploaded file. This Env Var stores the download URL for the file.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Go to the Workflows tab.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Open the Workflow Editor.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Add the Decrypt file Step to your Workflow.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Paste the Env Var of the file to the Encrypted file path input.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: In the Output file path input, specify the path where you want to place the decrypted file. Subsequent Steps will be able to access the file at this path.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: Using an Env Var as the input value

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: You can store the filepath in an App Env Var instead of specifying it directly for the input. That way you can refer to the file through the Env Var in other Steps, you won’t have to specify the path every time.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: For example, if you store the path in the BITRISEIO_MY_FILE_LOCAL_PATH Env Var, you can use it as the path for the input, and also use it to access the file in every subsequent Step.

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body: A bitrise.yml example for decrypting files

title: Decrypting and downloading your files during a build
body:
---
format_version: '11'
default_step_lib_source: https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-steplib.git
project_type: macos
workflows:
 secret:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4: {}
 - git-clone@6: {}
 - decrypt-file@0:
 inputs:
 - encrypted_file_path: "./secret.txt.gpg"
 - output_file_path: "./secret/"
 - decrypt_passphrase: "$PASSWORD_FOR_ENCRYPT"
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@2: {}

title: Build artifacts online
body: A build on Bitrise can and often does produce artifacts: for example, test reports, images, executable binaries. If you select a build of your app, on the Artifacts tab, you can check out the artifacts which have been generated during the build.

title: Build artifacts online
body: Build artifacts are any files generated during a Bitrise build: test results, screenshots, executable binaries, and so on. You can view build artifacts at two places:

title: Build artifacts online
body: On the Artifacts tab of the build's page. Here you can view all artifacts.

title: Build artifacts online
body: The Artifacts page on the main page of the app. Here you can only see the installable binaries.

title: Build artifacts online
body: There is no limitation on the number of files deployed to the Artifacts tab per build. There is a limitation, however, on the file size which is 2GB per file.

title: Build artifacts online
body: Artifact retention for 365 days

title: Build artifacts online
body: Artifacts older than 365 days are permanently deleted.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: On the Installable artifacts page, you can:

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: View the installable binaries of past builds.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: Download the installable artifacts.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: Check the details page of these artifacts. This can include a public install page.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: To get to the page, log in to Bitrise, select the Workspace that owns the app, and open Bitrise CI. Select your app and you can see Artifacts on the left.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: You can filter your installable artifacts using several different filters:

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: Platform of your binary (iOS or Android).

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: The timeframe of the build that generated it.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: The Workflow the build ran on.

title: The Installable artifacts page
body: The branch of the repository that was built.

title: Artifact details
body: You can check the details of any installable artifact (a binary, either an IPA or an APK/AAB file) generated by a Bitrise build. The details can potentially include:

title: Artifact details
body: The exact filename.

title: Artifact details
body: The version of the binary.

title: Artifact details
body: Metadata such as time of creation and file size.

title: Artifact details
body: A QR code for installation.

title: Artifact details
body: A link to the public install page if it is enabled.

title: Artifact details
body: To get to the details page, open the Artifacts page and select your file from the Installable artifacts list.

title: Artifact details
body: On the details page itself, the most important thing you can do is install the app on a mobile device. This is particularly useful for testing purposes. You have two options:

title: Artifact details
body: A QR code: scan it to install the binary.

title: Artifact details
body: A link to the public install page.

title: Artifact details
body: Note that if you're trying to install an iOS app on a device, the device must be registered for the app on the Apple Developer Portal. You can see the available devices in the Who can install this app? section.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Artifacts are deployed into the Artifacts section in your build’s page with the help of the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. It deploys all the files which have been generated during the build and stores them in the $BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR directory.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: To deploy the artifacts, insert the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step AFTER the Step(s) that generate the artifacts or even better if the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step is at the very end of your Workflow.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Put the Step in the right place

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in the right place. If you insert the Step before other Steps that generate files during the build, then Deploy to Bitrise.io will have nothing to deploy.

title: Deploying files into artifacts
body: Note that the content of any sub-directories found in the deploy directory will not be displayed in the Artifacts section of your build. You can, however, compress your artifacts into a zip file if you modify the default false value to true in the Compress the artifacts into one file field in the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. This will compress the whole directory along with its sub-directories and deploy to Artifacts.

title: Modifying the target directory path
body: You can modify the target directory path to another one but make sure you reference the same directory paths in other Steps of your Workflow to ensure that the generated files get collected to the same directory.

title: Viewing artifacts if your build has failed
body: With the Run if previous Step failed toggle enabled, you can access your build artifacts - only those that have been successfully generated - even if your build has failed. For example, you can detect bugs in your failed build by looking into the generated test report files.

title: Who can access build artifacts?
body: The artifacts at Artifacts are accessible for everyone who is the owner, admin, developer, tester/QA of the app. Besides these roles, if you keep the default config of the Enable public page for the App feature, then anyone who receives the URL, will be able to access your app and its artifacts.

title: Environment Variables
body: An Environment Variable (Env Var) is a key-value pair that holds data that you can use in your builds by inserting them into Step inputs.

title: Environment Variables
body: An Environment Variable (Env Var) is a key-value pair that holds data that you can use in your builds by inserting them into Step inputs. For example, working directory of an app's repository is often stored in an Env Var so you don't have to specify the path for every Step input that needs it.

title: Environment Variables
body: You can configure Env Vars for an entire app or for specific Workflows. App level Env Vars are available for every Workflow of the app; Workflow level Env Vars are only available for the given Workflow.

title: Environment Variables
body: Size limit of the Env Var list

title: Environment Variables
body: By default, the Env Var list size is 120 KB. You can easily increase the list size using a Script Step as described in this Knowledge Base article.

title: Environment Variables
body: Secrets are a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs.

title: Environment Variables
body: Protect confidential information

title: Environment Variables
body: Unlike Secrets, Env Vars are fully exposed in builds triggered by pull requests so you should not add any sensitive information to Env Vars.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: Users can declare Environment Variables on three different levels:

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: App level.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: Workflow level.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: Step level.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: In addition to the user-declared Env Vars, there are Env Vars automatically exposed by either the Bitrise CLI or bitrise.io. These are always available in any build. You can find the list of these here: Available Environment Variables

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: App level Env Vars are available to every build of a given app. Whenever you create a new Workflow, for example, it immediately and automatically has access to every single app level Env Var.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: A Workflow level Env Var is only available to the specific Workflow it was defined in. If your primary Workflow has an Env Var with the key TEST_ENV, your deploy Workflow won't be able to access that Env Var.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: Chaining Workflows together

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: If you chain Workflows together, using the after_run parameter, and define an Env Var in one of the Workflows, all subsequent Workflows in the chain will be able to access that Env Var.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: A Step level Env Var is defined within a particular Step of a build. Such an Env Var is not available to other Workflows, or to the preceding Steps in the same Workflow. Subsequent Steps, however, can access it. Step outputs are also exposed as Environment Variables.

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: You can set Environment Variables, regardless of level, in both the Workflow Editor, in your app's bitrise.yml file, or during a build with a custom Script using the envman tool:

title: Scope of Environment Variables
body: Environment Variables have a given processing order based on their level: Availability order of Environment Variables

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Environment Variables (Env Var) are available after the Env Var is processed.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: There are Env Vars exposed by the Bitrise CLI. These are available from the start: for example, BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR and BITRISE_TRIGGERED_WORKFLOW_ID.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: All other Env Vars are processed and made available as the build progresses.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: The processing order is the following:

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Env Vars exposed by the Bitrise CLI.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Secrets: they are processed before a Workflow starts.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: One-off Environment Variables specified for the build through our API.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: App Environment Variables.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Workflow Environment Variables: when the processing of the specified Workflow starts, the Env Vars specified for that Workflow are made available.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: If the Workflow has Workflows chained before or after it, the Environment Variables of the chained workflows are processed and made available right before the first Step of the Workflow would run.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Step inputs: they are exposed for each Step, right before the Step would start.

title: Availability order of Environment Variables
body: Step outputs: they are exposed by the specific Step, so those are available for subsequent Steps after the Step finishes.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Every Env Var value is a string

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: The value of an Environment Variable or Secret can only be a string. Even if you set a number (for example, 7), it will be passed on as a string.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Using the $ character

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: You can use the $ character in the value of an Env Var or Secret (for example, in a password) but in that case always leave the Replace variables in inputs option unchecked. If you replace the variable's key with its value in inputs, the Bitrise CLI will treat the value as another Env Var because of the $ character.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: To set a new Environment Variable (Env Var):

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: On the left, select Env Vars from the navigation menu.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Choose the level of the Env Var:

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Scroll down to the App Environment Variables section to set an app level Env Var.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Scroll down to one of the Workflow Environment Variables sections to set an Env Var for that specific Workflow.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Click the Add new button in your chosen section.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Add a key and a value.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: Click Save changes in the top right corner.

title: Setting an Env Var in the Workflow Editor
body: That's it. Your new Env Var is saved and ready to be used.

title: Replacing variables in inputs
body: Replacing variables in inputs ensures that the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build instead of the key. For details, check Replacing variables in inputs.

title: Replacing variables in inputs
body: Toggling on this option ensures that instead of the key of the Env Var, the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build. Normally, this is not necessary.

title: Replacing variables in inputs
body: Please note that if you add a new Environment Variable directly in the bitrise.yml file and do NOT set the is_expand property, the default value will be true. We recommend explicitly setting is_expand in this case:

title: Replacing variables in inputs
body:
envs:
 - opts:
 is_expand: false
 KEY: VALUE

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: When scheduling a new build or starting a new build manually, you have the option to set up custom Environment Variables (Env Var). These variables are only available for the build you started or scheduled.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Don't use the same key as an App Env Var

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: App Environment Variables have precedence over custom Environment Variables! This means that if you define a custom Env Var with the same key as an App Env Var, the build will use the value of the App Env Var.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: On the Bitrise CI page of your app, find the Start build button and click the button with the clock icon next to it.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: In the Build configuration pop-up window, select the Advanced tab.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Find the Custom Environment Variables section.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Enter a key and a value.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Replacing variables in inputs ensures that the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build instead of the key. For details, check Replacing variables in inputs.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Press the + Add Environment Variable button.

title: Setting a custom Env Var when starting a build
body: Finish starting or scheduling the build.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Many Step inputs accept Environment Variables (Env Var) and Secrets as input values.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Sensitive inputs

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Input fields marked as SENSITIVE only accept Secrets as their input. Generally, we do not recommend changing the value of these inputs.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: To use an Env Var or a Secret as a Step input value:

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Select Env Vars from the navigation menu on the left.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Select a Step from the Workflow. For example, the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Choose a Step input. For example, the Clone destination (local) directory path input of the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Next to the name of the input, click Insert variable.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Find the Env Var in the list, and select it.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: You can search for the Env Var by typing its key (or a part of it) into the Filter by key search field.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: Env Vars generated by Steps

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: The interactive list of Env Vars will show the Env Vars that are generated by previous Steps of the Workflow. For example, if you want to insert an Env Var into one of the inputs of the third Step in the Workflow, you can choose from the Env Vars generated by the first and second Steps.

title: Using an Env Var in a Step input
body: That's it. The next time you run a build of that Workflow, the Step input will use the value of the inserted Env Var as the Step input value.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Environment Variables (Env Var) normally contain a simple string value. However, it is possible to set up an Env Var that includes other Env Vars as values.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Secrets as variable values

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: The methods described here also apply to Secrets. You can also embed a Secret within an Env Var.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: You can, at any time, use another Environment Variable in the value of an Env Var - embedding the Env Var, so to speak. For example, let's say we want to set the value of the $BITRISE_AUTH Env Var to $PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN which is another Env Var.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: To do this, you need to make sure that the key of $BITRISE_AUTH is replaced with its value so that its the embedded Env Var that is passed on to the Workflows and Steps.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: On the left, select Env Vars from the navigation menu.

title: Using Env Vars in the value of an Env Var
body: Under the key of the Env Var you need, toggle the Replace variables in inputs? toggle to active.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: You can set Env Vars during a build by defining them in a Step, typically a Script Step. To accomplish this, you can use the envman tool.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: New Env Vars take effect from the next Step

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: Any Environment Variable you create with the envman tool takes effect only from the subsequent Step in the Workflow. In other words, you can't use a newly created Environment Variable in the same Step in which it was created.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: Here is a simple example where we're using envman to add a new Env Var with the key MY_RELEASE_NOTE:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --value "This is the release note"

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: You can call envman in any Step, including a Script Step, or even in your own script (stored in your repository) if you call it from a bitrise build.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: You can specify the value as the --value parameter, or by using pipe:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: echo 'hi' | envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: You can also read the value from a file:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --valuefile ./some/file/path

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: Once the Env Var is exposed, you can use it like any other Env Var. You can use these exposed Env Vars in the inputs of other Steps as well.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: Here is an example where we’re exposing the release note Env Var and then using it in another Script Step and in a Send a Slack message Step:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body:
workflows:
 example:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 envman add --key MY_RELEASE_NOTE --value "This is the release note"
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "My Release Note: $MY_RELEASE_NOTE"
 - slack:
 inputs:
 - channel: ...
 - webhook_url: ...
 - message: "Release Note: $MY_RELEASE_NOTE"

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: If you want to expose the value of an Env Var to be accessible through the key of another Env Var, you can do so.

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: For example, to expose the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER under the key MY_BUILD_NUMBER:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: envman add --key MY_BUILD_NUMBER --value "${BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER}"

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: After this, subsequent Steps can get the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER from the MY_BUILD_NUMBER Env Var. If you change the value of BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER after this, the value of MY_BUILD_NUMBER won’t be modified, it will still hold the original value!

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: If you need to know if a custom Env Var has been defined, you can easily check it, and even overwrite its value:

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body:
#!/bin/bash
set -ex
if [ ! -z "$API_PROJECT_SCHEME" ] ; then
 envman add --key PROJECT_SCHEME --value "$API_PROJECT_SCHEME"
fi

title: Setting and managing Env Vars during a build
body: This script checks whether the API_PROJECT_SCHEME Env Var is defined, and if it is, its value will be assigned to the PROJECT_SCHEME Environment Variable, overwriting the original value of PROJECT_SCHEME.

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: You can set Env Vars directly in the YAML configuration file for your app. You can set both app level and Workflow level Env Vars in your app's config file.

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: In this example, we have a configuration with an app-level Env Var called TEST_KEY:

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body:
app: 
 envs: 
 - opts: 
 is_expand: false 
 TEST_KEY: test value

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: Replacing variables in inputs

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: Replacing variables in inputs ensures that the value of the Env Var will be passed to the build instead of the key. For details, check Replacing variables in inputs.

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: In this example, the deploy-alpha Workflow defines an Env Var called ENV_TYPE, and then runs another Workflow that can use that Env Var:

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body:
workflows:

 deploy-alpha:
 envs:
 - ENV_TYPE: alpha
 after_run:
 - _deploy

 _deploy:
 steps:
 - script:
 inputs:
 - content: |
 #!/bin/bash
 echo "ENV_TYPE: $ENV_TYPE"

title: Setting Env Vars in the configuration YAML
body: If you run the deploy-alpha Workflow, that will set the ENV_TYPE Env Var to alpha, then it will run the deploy Workflow, which can use that Env Var. In this example, it will simply print its value (the printed text will be: ENV_TYPE: alpha).

title: Secrets
body: Secrets are a specific type of Environment Variable: they aren't shown in the bitrise.yml and their value is not exposed in the build logs.

title: Secrets
body: Secrets are a specific type of Environment Variable: they hide their information in an encrypted format and their value is not exposed in the build logs. They aren't shown in the bitrise.yml configuration either. You can store confidential information, such as passwords or API keys as Secrets.

title: Secrets
body: Just like Environment Variables, Secrets can be used as the value of a Step input: Using an Env Var in a Step input

title: Setting a Secret
body: Every Env Var value is a string

title: Setting a Secret
body: The value of an Environment Variable or Secret can only be a string. Even if you set a number (for example, 7), it will be passed on as a string.

title: Setting a Secret
body: You can create a Secret either on the Secrets page in the Workflow Editor or when modifying Step inputs.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Secrets page

title: Setting a Secret

title: Setting a Secret
body: Add a key and a value.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Using the $ character

title: Setting a Secret
body: You can use the $ character in the value of an Env Var or Secret (for example, in a password) but in that case always leave the Replace variables in inputs option unchecked. If you replace the variable's key with its value in inputs, the Bitrise CLI will treat the value as another Env Var because of the $ character.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Optionally, you can replace the key of your Secret with its value in inputs: check the Replace variables in inputs option.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Optionally, you can expose your Secret to pull requests by selecting the option.

title: Setting a Secret
body: In most cases, we strongly recommend not to expose Secrets.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click Save.

body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.
