body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Select a Workflow and find the Step you want to configure.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Find the sensitive input you wish to modify.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click the $ sign and then click Create in the dialog.

title: Setting a Secret
body: In the Create variable dialog, specify a key and a value for your new Secret.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Optionally, you can replace the key of your Secret with its value in inputs by checking the option.

title: Setting a Secret
body: Click the Add new button.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Once you’ve added a new secret Env Var in the Secrets tab, you come back to it any time, modify its content or make it protected from curious eyes!

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: On the left, select Secrets.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Modify its content as needed.

title: Editing an existing Secret
body: Click Save.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Normally, you can show and hide the value of a Secret by clicking the eye icon. This feature is useful if you have a long list of secret env vars in Secrets and you wish to check the value of only one Secret while leaving the other values hidden. If a value is hidden, it’s represented with the crossed out eye icon.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: However, you can hide the value of a Secret permanently by making it protected. If you do so, no one, including yourself, will be able to change or even view the value again.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: A Secret's protection can't be undone

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Making a Secret protected is irreversible. If you ever need to change the value, you will have to delete the Secret and create a new one.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: On the left, select Secrets.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: Check Protected.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: The dialog will warn that the process is irreversible. Click Save and protect.

title: Protecting the value of a Secret
body: That's it. You can no longer view the value of the Secret.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: By default, pull requests do not have access to the values of Secrets. This means that if a pull request opened from a fork of a repository triggers a build, that build can't use the app's Secrets.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: If you need to grant pull request builds access to a particular Secret, you can expose that Secret to pull requests. However, even when exposed, its value won't be visible in the logs: it will be displayed as [REDACTED].

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Protected Secrets can't be exposed

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Once a Secret has been made protected, you can't expose it to pull request builds.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Public apps

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: If your app is a public app, you can't expose the app's Secrets to pull requests builds.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: On the left, select Secrets.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Click Edit next to the value of your Secret.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Toggle the Expose for Pull Requests? toggle.

title: Exposing a Secret to pull requests
body: Once the Secret is exposed, pull request builds can access it.

title: Managing Secrets across multiple apps
body: By default, all Secrets are handled on the app level. You can reuse Secret keys across multiple Bitrise apps, even if their corresponding values are different for each app.

title: Managing Secrets across multiple apps
body: However, it is possible to set up a Secret that holds the same value for all your apps, and manage that Secret from one location. For example, if all your apps need access to the same API, it makes sense to store the Secret containing the API key in a central location. If the API key ever changes, you only need to change it in that single location and the change applies to all your Bitrise apps.

title: Managing Secrets across multiple apps
body: There are two ways to achieve this:

title: Managing Secrets across multiple apps
body: Managing your Secrets from a Workspace. This is only available on Enterprise plans.

title: Managing Secrets across multiple apps
body: Managing secrets from a central location such as a vault or database and pulling it with a Step.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: On Enterprise plans, you can store Secrets on a Workspace level. This means that the same Secret is accessible to all apps owned by that Workspace. This means increased security: only Workspace Owners and Managers can access these Secrets.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Downgrading

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: If you downgrade from an Enterprise plan, Workspace Secrets will be converted to app level Secrets.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: When passing Secrets to your build, app level Secrets take precedence over Workspace level Secrets in the availability order. This also means that if you have two Secrets with the same key, the app level Secret will be used during the build.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: To add a new secret:

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: On the Bitrise main page, select Settings on the navigation menu on the left. It takes you to the Workspace settings page.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: On the Workspace settings page, select Shared resources.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Click the Add new button.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Add a key and a value.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Configure the usage details of the Secret:

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Replace variables in inputs: This passes the value of the Secret as a string to the build. Use this for embedded Secrets or Environment Variables: when the value of your Secret is the key of another Secret or Environment Variable. For most use cases, you don't need this checked.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Expose for pull requests: Exposing a Secret to a PR means that the Secret is available to use in pull request builds. Depending on your repository's privacy settings, this is a potential security risk!

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: Protected: The value cannot be changed or viewed again. This setting is irreversible once saved.

title: Managing Secrets on a Workspace level
body: When you're ready, click Done.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Setting up Secrets in a central location requires two things:

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: A central vault or database - such as HashiCorp or Doppler - to store the Secrets. It must be accessible via a CLI.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: A Script Step to access the central vault/database, pull the Secret and set it to sensitive on Bitrise.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: To create a new Secret and store it in a central location during a build:

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Add the Secrets as a key-value pair to your vault or database where you want to store them.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Add a Script Step to ALL Workflows where you want to use the Secrets.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Add the necessary commands to access your vault and pull the Secrets. The exact commands depend on the service you’re using.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Use the envman tool to mark the Secrets as sensitive. The envman tool has the following syntax:

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: envman add --key KEY --value value --sensitive .

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Make sure the Step doesn’t display the value of the Secret in the build log. To do so, remove set -x from the Step’s content.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Secret redaction

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Please note that if you have Secret redaction turned off, your Secrets will not be redacted and thus their value can still be visible in logs.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Storing your Secrets in a HashiCorp Vault

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Let’s say you have a HashiCorp Vault instance called secret/hello. You have two Secrets in this vault instance: foo with the value world and foo2 with the value world2. To use these Secrets in a Bitrise build, you need to:

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Export them from the Vault instance.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: Iterate over them and mark both of them as sensitive.

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body: You can use this Script to achieve both:

title: Managing Secrets from a central vault or database
body:
# Exporting the Secrets
vault kv get --format=json secret/hello | jq -r '.data.data | to_entries[] | [.key, .value] | @tsv' | 
# Iterating over the Secrets and marking them as sensitive
while IFS=$'\t' read -r key value; do
 envman add --key "$key" --value "$value" --sensitive
done

title: Redacting Secrets
body: The Bitrise CLI automatically redacts your Secret Env Vars and prints [REDACTED] with newlines after the key so that the Secret Env Vars are NOT VISIBLE in the build log. This applies to both private and public apps.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: You can turn this off at any time though if you need to have your Secrets visible in logs.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: This is a potential security risk. We strongly recommend not to turn off Secret redaction.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: On the left, select Secrets.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Click Add new to register the BITRISE_SECRET_FILTERING secret Environment Variable with false value.

title: Redacting Secrets
body: Click Save changes in the top right corner.

title: Build statuses
body: On the Builds page, you can track the current status of all your builds. There are six different build statuses: on hold, starting, running, aborted, failed, and success.

title: Build statuses
body: On the Builds page of a project, you can track the current status of all your builds. There are six different build statuses:

title: Build statuses
body: On hold: There are more builds started than what your current plan allows. In most cases, this is only relevant for legacy, concurrency-based plans: it means you don't have enough concurrency to start another build.

title: Build statuses
body: Time limit

title: Build statuses
body: All builds on hold are aborted after 30 days to ensure no build gets permanently stuck.

title: Build statuses
body: Starting: When a build is triggered, Bitrise creates a virtual machine to run it. If computing resources aren’t immediately available, the build is placed in a queue. Once a worker is available, the worker assigned to create the virtual machine is processing the build request.

title: Build statuses
body: Running: Once a virtual machine is ready to go, the build starts running. This means that Bitrise is executing all the Steps defined in your Workflow.

title: Build statuses
body: Aborted: A build can be aborted manually by the user, or automatically either by the Rolling builds feature or because your build time has run out.

title: Build statuses
body: Aborted with success

title: Build statuses
body: There is a specific status called Aborted with success: this means the build has been aborted by the API but it is reported as a success to your git hosting provider.

title: Build statuses
body: Use the abort_with_success parameter with a Bitrise API call to abort a build but still count it as a successful one.

title: Build statuses
body: Failed: In most cases, a build fails if any of the Steps fails. There are exceptions, such as the caching Steps, and you can mark Steps as skippable which means even if they fail, the build will keep running.

title: Build statuses
body: Success: If Bitrise successfully executes all Steps that aren’t marked as skippable, the build is marked as successful.

title: Build statuses
body: You can always check your build status on the Builds page of the project, and you can send status reports: Reporting the build status to your Git hosting provider

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you need a tool that isn't preinstalled on the build machines and you can’t find a Step for it, you can always install and use them with scripts or Script Steps.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you need a tool that isn't preinstalled on the build machines and you can’t find a Step for it, you can always install and use them with custom scripts. You can add a Script Step to your Workflow, and either write your script there, or run a script from your repository. Passwordless sudo is enabled in all of our build virtual machines, so you can freely use sudo if you need it.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Once you have a working script, you can also transform it into a Step and optionally share it with others (through our StepLib). Read more: Developing a new Step

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Add a Script Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Insert your script into the Script content input field.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can run a script from your repository using this Step: you just need to add the right command with the script's path, relative to the repository root.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Installing cmake on macOS

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Install cmake with a Script Step on macOS with the following brew command:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Brew install

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can also use the Brew install Step to install cmake and many other tools.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Installing cmake on Linux

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Install cmake with a Script Step on Linux with the following apt-get command:

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Use the -y flag for apt-get

title: Installing tools during a build
body: If you don’t add the -y (yes) flag to the apt-get command, apt-get will present a prompt which you have to accept or deny manually. This is not a problem on your own Linux machine but in a CI environment you can’t provide manual input for apt-get. To prevent this issue, and to auto accept the prompt, just use the -y flag, as shown in the example.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Run npm command

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can also use the Run npm command Step to install cmake and many other tools.

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Installing iOS 13 runtime on Xcode 14 stacks

title: Installing tools during a build
body: Install iOS 13 runtime on Xcode 14 stacks with a Script Step.

title: Installing tools during a build
Installing tools during a build
body: Available simulator runtimes on macOS stacks

title: Installing tools during a build
body: You can install other runtimes using a similar syntax, but keep in mind, some runtimes are already preinstalled on our stacks. If you are interested in the list of preinstalled tools, such as simulator runtimes on our stacks, you can find every available stack’s System Report on GitHub.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Instead of installing a dependency or tool using a dependency installer Step or a Script Step, you can also use the deps option in your configuration YAML file. If you declare deps for a specific Step, the Bitrise CLI will check if that tool is installed, and will install it for you, if required.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: If the selected tool or dependency is already available, the Bitrise CLI will not install it.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Select Configuration YAML on the left.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Find the Step you need: you will declare the dependencies for that Step.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Add deps below the Step title:

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Declare the package manager name and the package name.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:
 brew:
 - name: cmake
 apt_get:
 - name: cmake

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: Declaring the binary name

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body: If you want to declare a dependency which might be available from another source (not through the package manager), then you might also want to declare the related binary name. If the package does not match the binary name, you can declare it with bin_name. An example is AWS CLI, where the package name in both package managers is awscli, but the binary itself is aws.

title: Installing tools by declaring deps in the bitrise.yml file
body:
workflows:
 test:
 steps:
 - script:
 deps:
 brew:
 - name: awscli
 bin_name: aws

title: Finding a specific build
body: If your project has multiple builds, you can search for a specific one on the main page of the app by using a variety of options, like build number or commit message.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Build retention for 200 days

title: Finding a specific build
body: On the Builds page of your app, we only show builds from the last 200 days. The same limit applies if you are searching for specific builds on the page. This limitation also applies to most API calls: the GET/apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint and related endpoints can only return builds from the last 200 days.

title: Finding a specific build
body: However, there are two methods to get a build that is older than 200 days:

title: Finding a specific build
body: If you know the exact build URL, you can access the build.

title: Finding a specific build
body: You can use the GET/apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds API endpoint: Listing the archived builds of an app.

title: Finding a specific build
body: If your project has multiple builds on bitrise.io , you can search for a specific one by using a variety of options. To do so:

title: Finding a specific build
body: Open an project on Bitrise.

title: Finding a specific build
body: On the Builds page of the project, you can find the filter options and the search field above the list of builds. You have several options:

title: Finding a specific build
body: In the search field, enter either a build number or a commit message to find the build.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the status filter dropdown menu to find builds with a specific status.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the branch filter dropdown menu to find builds that ran on a specific branch.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the Workflows dropdown menu to find builds that ran with specific Workflows.

title: Finding a specific build
body: Choose a filter from the triggers dropdown menu to find builds that were triggered by one of our trigger options: pushes, pull requests, or tags.

title: Build numbering and app versioning
body: All Bitrise builds have a build number. The first build of your app is, by default, number 1, and the build number gets incremented with each build. You can also change your build number manually.

title: Build numbering and app versioning
body: All Bitrise builds have a build number. The first build of your app is, by default, number 1, and the build number gets incremented with each build. You can get a build’s Bitrise build number on the website, as well as via the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable. This variable can be used in any Step or script where you need the Bitrise build number for any reason.

title: Build numbering and app versioning
body: You can also take care of your app’s versioning automatically, using Bitrise. We have two Steps to do it for you: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: In order for Bitrise to be able to use the machine user to access your repository, you must add the same SSH key to the machine user and the app on Bitrise.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: Negative build numbers

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: The build number must be either 0 or a positive integer. Negative numbers are not accepted. You can, however, set any number you have already used.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: On the left, select Builds.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: Scroll down to Next build number.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: This number is automatically incremented whenever you run a build but you can set it manually.

title: Adding the SSH key to the machine user
body: To modify the number, click Edit.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Track the version of your app in its Git repository by modifying the file containing the essential information about the app (for example, the Info.plist file for iOS apps and either the build.gradle file or the AndroidManifest.xml file for Android apps).

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Bitrise has two steps to do this for you. These two Steps can insert the Bitrise build number or some other specified number into their respective files:

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Change Android versionCode and versionName for Android apps.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Set Xcode Project Build Number for iOS apps.

title: Setting up app versioning automatically on Bitrise
body: Both Steps accept either numbers (integers and/or numeric strings) or environment variables in their relevant inputs. By default, both use the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable as their default value for the build number.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: For an Android app, the setting is used as an internal version number, to determine if a build of the app is more recent than another build. The versionName setting is a string used as the version number shown to users.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: For in-depth information about Android versioning, please check out the Android developer guide on the subject.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Version information in the manifest file

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: In this guide, we’re setting the version information in the build.gradle file. This is the recommended method: you can also set it directly in the AndroidManifest.xml file but be aware that any version info set in the manifest file before the build will be overwritten by the build.gradle file’s settings during the build.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: To configure Android versioning:

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step to your Workflow.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Set the the path to your build.gradle file in the Path to the build.gradle file input.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add a value in the New versionCode input.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: The default value is the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable.

title: Setting the versionCode and the versionName of an Android app
body: Add a value in the New versionName input.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: For an iOS app, the value of the CFBundleVersion key (“Bundle version” in Xcode) is the build number of the app while the value of the CFBundleShortVersionString key (“Bundle versions string, short” in Xcode) is the version number of the app.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: For in-depth information about iOS versioning, including the functions of the CFBundleVersion and the CFBundleShortVersionString keys, please check out this Apple technical note; you can also look up the summary of most important keys.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Setting up iOS versioning for apps using Xcode 13+

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: To set up iOS versioning on Bitrise using Xcode 13+, update the following in Xcode:

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Set the Generate Info.plist File to No, under PROJECT and TARGETS on the Build Settings tab.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Make sure you have all the necessary keys defined in the Info.plist file.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Add the Set Xcode Project Build Number Step to your Workflow.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Set the file path to the Info.plist file in the Project path, scheme and Target input.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Add a value in the Build Number input. This sets the CFBundleVersion key to the specified value in the Info.plist file. The default value is the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Value.

title: Setting the CFBundleVersion and CFBundleShortVersionString of an iOS app
body: Optionally, add a value in the Version Number input. This will set the CFBundleShortVersionString key to the specified value in the Info.plist file. This input is not required.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: You can also offset your App’s build version numbers if you handled version tracking in a different way before for the same app: all you need to do is setting the value which should be added to the build number. The value can be either a fixed integer value or an Environment Variable.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: To offset your version number by your Bitrise build number every time a build is triggered, use the $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Environment Variable:

title: Offsetting the build version
body: For Android apps, find the versionCode Offset input of the Change Android versionCode and versionName Step and set $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER as its value. The value of the variable will be added to the value specified in the versionCode input.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: For iOS apps, find the Build Number Offset input of the Set Xcode Project Build Number Step and set $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER as its value. The value of the variable will be added to the value specified in the Build Number input.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Offsetting an Android app's version

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Let’s say you have an app and you are about to run its fifth build on Bitrise. You wish to offset the Build Number by 6 as the app had six builds before starting to use Bitrise. The following configuration is used:

title: Offsetting the build version
body:
- Version Code: $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER
- Version Code Offset: 6
- Version Name: 1.0.5

title: Offsetting the build version
body: The value of $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER (which equals 5 in our example) will be added to the Version Code Offset value. As such, android:versionName value will be set to 1.0.5 (11), indicating it’s the 11th build of the 1.0.5 version of your app.

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Offsetting an iOS app's version

title: Offsetting the build version
body: Let’s say you have an app and you are about to run its fifth build on Bitrise. You wish to offset the Build Number by 6 as the app had six builds before starting to use Bitrise. The following configuration is used:

title: Offsetting the build version
body:
- Build Number: $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER
- Build Number Offset: 6
- Version Number: 1.1

title: Offsetting the build version
body: The value of $BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER (which equals 5 in our example) will be added to the Build Number Offset value. As such, CFBundleShortVersionString will be set to 1.1 (11), indicating it’s the 11th build of the 1.1 version of your app.

title: Build logs
body: On Bitrise, build logs are easily accessible: they can be viewed on the website in their entirety or they can be downloaded to view them on your own device.

title: Build logs
body: Build logs allow users to analyze their builds and find out what went wrong - and what went right! On Bitrise, build logs are easily accessible: they can be viewed on the website in their entirety or they can be downloaded to view them on your own device.

title: Build logs
body: Build retention for 200 days

title: Build logs
body: On the Builds page of your app, we only show builds from the last 200 days. The same limit applies if you are searching for specific builds on the page. This limitation also applies to most API calls: the GET/apps/{app-slug}/builds endpoint and related endpoints can only return builds from the last 200 days.

title: Build logs
body: However, there are two methods to get a build that is older than 200 days:

title: Build logs
body: If you know the exact build URL, you can access the build.

title: Build logs
body: You can use the GET/apps/{app-slug}/archived-builds API endpoint: Listing the archived builds of an app.

title: Finding a build log
body: When you run a build, a build log is generated automatically. Every build has its own log, with its own unique build log URL. The build log URL contains the build slug: a hexadecimal identifier for a specific build.

title: Finding a build log
body: Assisting Bitrise Support

title: Finding a build log
body: When Bitrise Support asks for your build logs, the best thing to do is send the build URL.

title: Finding a build log
body: Open the Bitrise CI page and select your project from the project list.

title: Finding a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Finding a build log
body: Make sure you have the Log tab selected.

title: Finding a build log
body: On the Log tab, you can see the Steps of the Workflow and their status. By default, all failed Steps are expanded.

title: Finding a build log
body: Expand any Step's info by clicking the downward arrow on the right to the Step. This will show the relevant part of the build log.

title: The build log page
body: The build log page shows all Steps that were part of the build, and their status. By default, failed Steps are expanded, with the error message highlighted for convenient troubleshooting. Expanding a Step also allows you to see:

title: The build log page
body: The start time of the Step's run.

title: The build log page
body: The Step ID. This is how the bitrise.yml configuration file identifies the Step. For more information, see Step reference/ID format.

title: The build log page
body: The current version of the Step. Underneath the version number, you can check the release notes for the Step. If the build didn't run with the latest version of the Step, you can also click Update to open the Workflow Editor and update the Step to a different version.

title: The build log page
body: Under Step resources, you can check out the Step's documentation on our Integrations page, as well as its source code and issue tracker on GitHub.

title: The build log page
body: To view a build log's contents in full, in a single file, download the log.

title: Following a build log live
body: You can check the log of a build live - that is, while the build is running. What’s more, you can even follow the log as the build is happening. That means that as the build progresses, the log will automatically scroll to the new sections as they appear.

title: Following a build log live
body: To do so:

title: Following a build log live
body: Start a build.

title: Following a build log live
body: Go to the build’s page.

title: Following a build log live
body: Scroll down to the log.

title: Following a build log live
body: Click Follow.

title: Following a build log live
body: To stop following, you just need to manually navigate anywhere within the log. You can restart following any time.

title: Downloading a build log
body: If you need to send your build logs to people who do not have access to the app on Bitrise, or you want to store your logs in your own archives, you can simply download the log file from Bitrise.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Log security

title: Downloading a build log
body: Please note that your build log can contain sensitive information! Make sure to check its contents before downloading the log file and sending it out to anyone. We recommend using Secrets to make sure nothing sensitive appears in build logs.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Open the Bitrise CI page and select your project from the project list.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Downloading a build log
body: Open the Logs dropdown menu and click the Download logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: If necessary, you can delete the logs of any build on Bitrise. It can be handy if, for example, you do not want new team members to see potentially sensitive information that is displayed in previous logs.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Not all team members are authorized to delete logs: only those with either Admin or Owner role in the team can do it.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Deletion is final

title: Deleting a build log
body: Be aware that you cannot undo deleting a log. Once you delete it, there is no way to recover the log file.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Open the Bitrise CI page and select your project from the project list.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Deleting a build log
body: Open the Logs dropdown menu and click the Delete Logs button.

title: Deleting a build log
body: In the pop-up window, click Delete logs.

title: Remote access
body: Remote access allows users to connect to their build’s virtual machines via SSH or a screenshare app, which you can access from your build's Build details page.

title: Remote access
body: Remote access allows users to connect to their build’s virtual machines via SSH or a screenshare app. A failed build can be rebuilt with remote access enabled to make troubleshooting a lot easier - for example, if the build logs don’t provide enough information about the error.

title: Remote access
body: You can rebuild both standalone builds and pipeline builds with remote access.

title: Remote access
body: Authorization

title: Remote access
body: Users who have the Testers/QA roles on the app CANNOT use remote access.

title: Remote access
body: There are two ways to use remote access on our build machines:

title: Remote access
body: SSH: this is available for both Linux/Docker based and MacOS machines.

title: Remote access
body: Screenshare: this is only available for MacOS machines. It uses the VNC system.

title: Remote access
body: With either method, you can access the build machine remotely during the build and for 10 minutes after the build is finished. If you would like to extend the availability of remote access, you can do so by adding a simple custom Script Step after the failed Step. Check out Extending the availability of remote access for more information.

title: Remote access
body: Build time

title: Remote access
body: When using remote access, 10 minutes will be added to your overall build time.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with SSH, you will need a command line interface and the correct command and password:

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: On the main page of the app, find the build you want to re-run with remote access and click it.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: On the Rebuild button, click the downward arrow to open the dropdown menu.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: Select Rebuild with remote access. This starts a new build that you can access remotely.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: In the SSH section, find the Command and run it in a command line interface.

title: Remote access with SSH
body: And done! You should be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: To access a Bitrise build machine with a screenshare app, you will need the correct username, password, and address, as well as a VNC screenshare app:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: macOS only

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Remote access with screenshare is only available for Workflows that run on a macOS-based stack. If the Workflow's stack (or in absence of Workflow-specific stacks, the app's default stack) is a Linux-based one, you won't see the screenshare instructions at all.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open the app on Bitrise.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: On the main page of the app, find the build you want to re-run with remote access and click it.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: On the Rebuild button, click the downward arrow to open the dropdown menu.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Select Rebuild with remote access. This starts a new build that you can access remotely.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Under the Screenshare option, find the required information:

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Address

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Username

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Password

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Open a VNC screenshare application.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: The simplest option is using the default Screen Sharing application on macOS.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: Fill out the required fields with the information from under the Screenshare option.

title: Remote access with screenshare
body: And done! You should now be able to access the virtual machine where your build is running.

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: Once you successfully logged in to the Bitrise virtual machine that ran your build, you can dive into the files themselves to see what’s happening in real time. After Bitrise finished cloning your app on to the VM, you can always access it at the following location:

title: Finding your files on the VM
body: /Users/Vagrant/git

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Remote access is available while the build is running and for 10 minutes after the build is finished. If this is not enough, there’s a simple workaround to make sure remote access is available for a longer time.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a Script Step after the Step that causes the build to fail.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Toggle the Run if previous Step failed option on to ensure the Script Step always runs.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: Add a command to let the build “sleep” for a time specified in seconds:

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: sleep 5400

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: This example lets the build run for 90 minutes. It should be no more than your build time limit, of course.

title: Extending the availability of remote access
body: That’s it. While the build is still running, you can look around on the virtual machine for the possible issues that caused it to fail.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your build fails on Bitrise, we often recommend to try and run it locally. To debug: use a full clean git clone, and run the build on your machine with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your build fails on Bitrise, we often recommend to try and run it locally, on your machine. To do this, do the following:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Do a full clean git clone of your project’s online repository.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run the build on your machine with the Bitrise CLI.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: This helps to eliminate, among other things, a very common issue: that uncommitted or gitignored files are in your working directory but they haven’t been committed into your git repository online and therefore they are not available when Bitrise clones the repository for running the build. Other possible issues include:

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Code signing files are present on your local machine but not uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: A difference in the version of the tool(s) used for the build.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Open your Terminal / Command Line interface on your machine.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type in: cd /tmp

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Clone your repository with: git clone REPOURL ./quick-repo-test --branch BRANCH-YOU-WANT-TO-TEST:

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: git clone https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise.git ./quick-repo-test --branch master

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Type cd ./quick-repo-test.

title: Testing with a full clean git clone
body: Run the commands you want to test, to build your project, or to open the project file from this directory.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: After doing a full clean git clone, run a build locally, using the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Install the Bitrise CLI.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Download your app’s bitrise.yml file from bitrise.io.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: Run the build with: bitrise run <workflow-name> (for example, bitrise run primary).

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: This should help reproducing the issues in most cases, and allows you to attempt to debug them on your own machine.

title: Testing with the Bitrise CLI
body: If the build succeeds under these conditions but still fails on Bitrise, contact our support!

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Android projects

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If you still can’t reproduce the issue locally, you might also want to delete the $HOME/.gradle (hidden) directory, to clear your Gradle caches. (Quick Terminal / Command Line command: rm -rf $HOME/.gradle).

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Run docker from a clean git clone

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: If your project uses the Android/Linux environment, you can download and use the exact same environment as the one your build is running in on bitrise.io.

title: Debugging your build on your own machine
body: Ideally, you should first do a clean git clone and run docker from there, so that files which are in your .gitignore won’t affect the build, and the build can run the the same way as on bitrise.io.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: The Bitrise GitHub app provides an extended version of the classic status checks Bitrise sends back to GitHub.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: GitHub App integration

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: If you use the Bitrise GitHub App to connect a Bitrise Workspace to a GitHub account or organization, you don't need to do anything described in this section: GitHub Checks will automatically work for you to provide status updates.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: You can, however, continue to use the OAuth connection for your apps and use GitHub Checks with our GitHub App.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: The Bitrise GitHub App provides, among other things, an extended version of the classic build status checks that Bitrise sends back to GitHub. This extended version includes a Bitrise build summary and a check status. You can view the checks if you click the Details link of a pull request on GitHub. It unfolds the detailed build summary and build status our GitHub app attaches to your pull request on the Checks tab of GitHub.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: There can be three different check statuses:

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: Success.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: Failed.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: Action required (in the case of manual pull request approval).

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: To start using the Bitrise app to send status checks, you need to perform two separate actions:

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: Install the Bitrise app: This is only necessary for GitHub.com users. GitHub Enterprise Server users who already set up the integration can proceed to enable the status checks with the app.

title: GitHub Checks with the Bitrise GitHub App
body: Enable the Bitrise app: Turn on the feature on the Bitrise website and run a first build to be able to select the Bitrise app in your branch protection rules.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: To use Bitrise Checks as a GitHub.com user, you need to install it as a GitHub app.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: If the workspace that owns the Bitrise project has the Bitrise GitHub App connected and granted access to the Bitrise project's repository, you can skip the procedure described here and start using GitHub Checks.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: GitHub.com users only

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: If you are a GitHub Enterprise Server user, you don't need to do this procedure. To enable GitHub Checks, you need to:

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Install the GitHub Enterprise Server integration.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Enable GitHub Checks on Bitrise.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: On the left, select Integrations from the menu options.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Click the link under the toggle. Don’t toggle the switch just yet, since you first need to install the Bitrise app.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: This link will take you to GitHub's Bitrise installation page.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Select the user or GitHub Organization you want to add the Bitrise app to.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Select an option to install the GitHub app to:

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: All repositories: Applies to all current and future repositories.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Only select repositories: Select the repositories that you need.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: With this, you authorize Bitrise to act on your behalf; for example, to check which repos you have access to, and use GitHub Checks to display check results.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: Click Install and authorize.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: In the GitHub prompt, provide your GitHub password.

title: Installing the Bitrise GitHub app for GitHub Checks
body: If all goes well, you land on the Bitrise page of GitHub. You should see a blue note at the top-left corner of the page that Bitrise has been successfully installed on your GitHub account.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Once the Bitrise app is installed on GitHub, you need to enable GitHub Checks on the project settings page on Bitrise.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Enabling GitHub Checks is limited

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Please note that only workspace owners and project admins can enable this toggle on the Project settings page of the project.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: On the left, select Integrations and then go to the Git provider tab.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Scroll down and toggle on the GitHub Checks switch.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Can't toggle the switch?

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: If you can't toggle the switch, check out Can't enable GitHub Checks.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: Trigger a build. You can do so either automatically or manually. If you trigger a build manually, provide a specific commit hash to build.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: This build is necessary to perform the first Bitrise check. Once there is a finished check, you can select Bitrise Checks in your branch protection rules.

title: Enabling GitHub Checks on Bitrise
body: And you’re done! Now any pull request you open to your project on GitHub will be validated with Bitrise Checks and a build will get automatically started on Bitrise (if the pull request trigger is properly set on Bitrise).

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: There are two main reasons why you might not be able to toggle the switch to enable GitHub Checks:

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: You cannot toggle the switch unless you install the Bitrise GitHub app FIRST. Once it’s done, you can go ahead and toggle the switch to the right to enable it.

title: Can't enable GitHub Checks
body: If you have renamed or moved the GitHub repository of an app which has already been added to Bitrise and you have installed Bitrise Checks on it. The repository’s GitHub URL has obviously changed. GitHub Checks switch can only work if the URL on Github and on Bitrise fully match (no redirect URL is allowed). So in this case, you have to manually update the Repository URL of your app.

title: Switching to the Bitrise GitHub app from previous CI checks
body: If you have been already using status checks on pull requests prior to merging, it must have been the ci/bitrise/... check system. To be able to use the Bitrise GitHub app, you have to manually switch from ci/bitrise/... to Bitrise to access those detailed checks. Let’s see how!

title: Switching to the Bitrise GitHub app from previous CI checks
body: Go to the Settings tab of your repository.

title: Switching to the Bitrise GitHub app from previous CI checks
body: Click Branches on the side menu. Under Require status checks to pass before merging, you can see ci/bitrise/... as the selected checks system.

title: Switching to the Bitrise GitHub app from previous CI checks
body: Select Bitrise instead of ci/bitrise/....

title: Switching to the Bitrise GitHub app from previous CI checks
body: Merge a pull request.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: To disable GitHub Checks for your project:

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: if you toggle the ENABLE GITHUB CHECKS switch to the left on the Settings page of the project.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: Select Integrations on the left and then go to the Git provider tab.

title: Disabling GitHub Checks
body: Under GitHub Checks, disable the GitHub Checks toggle.

title: GitHub Checks test summary
body: If your app’s repository contains any UI or unit tests, you can run those tests by using the appropriate testing Steps in your Workflow, and if you add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step, your test results will be displayed in our Test Reports page and you can also see them on GitHub Checks, too.

title: GitHub Checks test summary
body: For example, if you have an Android app, you can use the Virtual Unit Testing for Android Step to be able to see all your test results on GitHub Checks.

title: Step by Step error report
body: If a CI build runs, GitHub Checks' test summary displays the Steps' successful and failed tests in separate tabs on the left sidebar. If you click on a Step, a more detailed report summary comes up where a number of tests are listed with actionable error report. The build summary is available on the Bitrise tab.

title: Step by Step error report
body: Please note that GitHub Checks' test summary can only print detailed information of the following Steps:

title: Step by Step error report
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Step by Step error report
body: Android Unit Test

title: Step by Step error report
body: iOS Device Testing

title: Step by Step error report
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android

title: Step by Step error report
body: Flutter Test

title: Step by Step error report
body: You can export test results generated by any other Step to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in two ways:

title: Step by Step error report
body: We strongly recommend using our Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step: this Step locates the test results based on your inputs.

title: Step by Step error report
body: You can configure your own custom Script Step that creates and exports the necessary files.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: If your build has some failed tests, here is how to access them in GitHub Checks:

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: Click the Bitrise Checks dropdown.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: Click on a Step and view the error report of the specific Step.

title: Checking the test results of a failed Step
body: You can click on other Steps from here or the build summary. The View more details on Bitrise Checks link takes you to the build page on Bitrise.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Role requirement

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: To re-run a build using GitHub Checks, your GitHub account must connected to Bitrise, and you need to have at least Developer role in your app's team. If these conditions are not met, re-run checks will fail without an error.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: For a complete list of user roles and role cheatsheets, check User roles on app teams.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: If you would like to re-run a build using GitHub Checks:

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Open the pull request on GitHub where you would like to re-run checks.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Open the Checks tab.

title: Re-running a build using GitHub checks
body: Click Re-run all checks.

title: Checking build details
body: You can find additional details about a specific build by accessing the build's Details & Add-ons tab.

title: Checking build details
body: You can find additional details about a specific build by accessing the build's Details & Add-ons tab. The details include when the build was triggered, when it started and finished, its infrastructure details (such as the agent version or the hostname), its parameters and even the exact command that was used to launch it.

title: Checking build details
body: To check the details:

title: Checking build details
body: Open the Bitrise CI page and select your project from the project list.

title: Checking build details
body: Select the build you want to check out.

title: Checking build details
body: Select the Details & Add-ons tab.

title: Checking build details
body: Add-ons

title: Checking build details
body: In this tab next to the build details, you can see and access all available Add-ons. Accessing your Add-ons from here is the same as if you would open them from your app's Add-ons tab.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: View dynamically generated rich HTML content (for example, code coverage reports or performance reports) directly on the Bitrise UI: no need to download the report and use a separate tool to view it.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: If you generate some form of rich HTML content (for example, code coverage reports or performance reports) during your Bitrise build, you do not have to download and view the report in a separate tool: you can view the content directly on the Bitrise UI. You don't have to embed everything in the HTML file either: Bitrise will parse all images, CSS files and Javascript files to display the full content as intended.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: To view an HTML report on Bitrise:

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Generate your HTML report during a build.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Create a subfolder of the BITRISE_HTML_REPORT_DIR directory with a descriptive name. The name of the folder will be the title of your report on the UI.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: BITRISE_HTML_REPORT_DIR is an Environment Variable pointing to the directory where Bitrise is looking for the HTML reports.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Make sure your generated report is deployed to your subfolder.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Multiple reports

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: You can generate multiple reports in multiple subfolders. Each report must have an index.html file.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Run a build.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Once the build is finished, go to the build's page and select the Artifacts tab. You can find your report under the HTML reports section.

title: Viewing HTML reports
body: Seven day limit

title: Viewing HTML reports

title: Build Annotations
body: Build Annotations allow you to add relevant build information directly on the Bitrise build details page, simplifying the process of accessing crucial data during build progression and debugging.

title: Build Annotations
body: Build Annotations allow you to add relevant build information directly on the Bitrise build details page, simplifying the process of accessing crucial data during build progression and debugging.

title: Build Annotations
body: The annotations are generated using Markdown styling. Some use cases include:

title: Build Annotations
body: Detailed test results for custom tools.

title: Build Annotations
body: Emphasizing warnings or error messages.

title: Build Annotations
body: Security and vulnerability scan reports.

title: Build Annotations
body: Static analysis reports.

title: Build Annotations
body: Links to deployed artifacts.

title: Annotating a build
body: To use annotations:

title: Annotating a build
body: Add a Step capable of running custom commands.

title: Annotating a build
body: For example, Script or fastlane.

title: Annotating a build
body: Add a command to install the Bitrise Annotations plugin:

title: Annotating a build
body: bitrise plugin install https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-plugins-annotations.git

title: Annotating a build
body: Use the annotate command of the plugin to create your annotations.

title: Annotating a build
body: The command works in the following format: bitrise :annotations annotate [markdown] [flags]. This is a basic Markdown annotation in the default style:

title: Annotating a build
body: bitrise :annotations annotate "**My Annotation**"

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body: Build annotations are a snippet of Markdown. The basic style of the snippet is determined by the --style flag of the annotation command. The possible values are:

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body: default:

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body: warning:

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body: error:

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body: The annotations accept Markdown syntax. In addition to simple formatting, it also supports code blocks, using the ~ character or four-space indentation:

title: Styling and formatting your annotations
body:
bitrise :annotations annotate "
~~~
This is a codeblock
~~~ 
"

bitrise :annotations annotate "
 This is also a codeblock
"

title: Dependencies and caching
body: Bitrise offers several dedicated Steps to make sure you can install your dependencies regardless of project type. You can cache dependencies and other build files using both key-based and branch-based caching.

title: Dependencies and caching
body: Handling platform and application dependencies is a vital part of development. On Bitrise, we offer several dedicated Steps to make sure you can install your dependencies regardless of project type.

title: Dependencies and caching
body: Dependencies, and just about any other build files, can be cached, too. Bitrise offers two types of build caching and several dedicated Steps to make caching as convenient as possible.

title: iOS dependencies
body: Install iOS dependencies via our official Xcode Steps which offer built-in dependency management, or use our Steps for the most commonly used third-party dependency managers: iOS dependencies

title: iOS dependencies
body: Use the official Xcode Steps to handle Swift Package Manager dependencies without having to worry about configuring anything outside Xcode: Managing dependencies with SPM.

title: iOS dependencies
body: If you use CocoaPods, and have your Podfile configured, you can use our Run CocoaPods install Step to install your pods: Managing dependencies with CocoaPods.

title: iOS dependencies
body: If you use Carthage in your project, you can use our Carthage Step to install your dependencies: Managing dependencies with Carthage.

title: Android dependencies
body: Our official Android Steps run your Gradle tasks for you in a CI environment. As such, if your dependencies are appropriately configured within your project, they will handle installing them for you: Android dependencies.

title: Flutter dependencies
body: For Flutter, our Flutter Build Step can handle both packages and plugins so you don't need to add any additional Step to install your dependencies: Flutter dependencies.

title: React Native dependencies
body: For React Native, you can install npm packages via either npm or Yarn, as we have official Steps for both package managers. You can also install your native dependencies separately: React Native dependencies

title: Caching
body: Bitrise offers two types of caching: key-based caching and branch-based caching. Generally, we recommend key-based caching as it's faster and more flexible but both methods are fully supported with dedicated Steps.

title: Caching
body: Our caching solutions allow you to cache just about any build file you want. You can cache all of your dependencies with barely any configuration as several Steps can automatically collect and cache dependency content. For other build files, the main caching Steps are fully configurable to fit your needs.

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching relies on using key-value pairs to identify cache archives. The keys can be dynamically generated so you can ensure, for example, that the archive is only updated if certain files change. You have full control over assigning keys to your cache archives: Key-based caching.

title: Branch-based caching
body: Branch-based caching works by saving a cache archive for each branch of your repository on which you run builds. You can configure exactly what files and folders should be cached: Branch-based caching.

title: Caching dependencies
body: For key-based caching, we have dedicated Steps for all the most frequently used dependency managers. For branch-based caching, each and every Step handling dependencies is capable of collecting cache content.

title: Remote build cache
body: The Bitrise build cache is a custom, hosted implementation of the caching solutions of certain build systems. You can use the remote cache both locally and in the Bitrise CI environment: in this way your builds will work consistently regardless of the environment and you can save a significant amount of build time.

title: Remote build cache
body: Bitrise supports remote build caching for two build systems:

title: Remote build cache
body: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle.

title: Remote build cache
body: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel.

title: iOS dependencies
body: You can manage iOS dependencies either via SPM or by a third-party package manager such as CocoaPods or Carthage.

title: iOS dependencies
body: There are two main ways to handle dependencies for iOS apps:

title: iOS dependencies
body: Using the Swift Package Manager which is built into Xcode.

title: iOS dependencies
body: Using a third-party dependency manager, such as Carthage or CocoaPods.

title: iOS dependencies
body: Bitrise allows you to use either method.

title: Managing dependencies with SPM
body: On Bitrise, every Xcode Step can handle Swift package dependencies without any extra configuration. You can install and cache SPM packages easily.

title: Managing dependencies with SPM
body: Swift packages are reusable components of Swift, Objective-C, Objective-C++, C, or C++ code that developers can use in their projects. Xcode uses the built-in Swift Package Manager (SPM) to support creating and publishing Swift packages and managing package dependencies.

title: Managing dependencies with SPM
body: On Bitrise, every Xcode Step can handle Swift package dependencies without any extra configuration. For example, if you wish to build an iOS app to deploy it to the App Store, the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step will handle installing Swift dependencies to your app.

title: Installing Swift packages
body: You can easily install Swift packages for your iOS apps during a Bitrise build:

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Make sure you have correctly configured your Swift packages in Xcode.

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Add one of our official Xcode Steps to your Workflow. The available Steps are:

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Xcode Archive & Export for iOS

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Xcode Build for testing

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Xcode Build for Simulator

title: Installing Swift packages
body: Any of these Steps can handle the Swift package dependencies.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: There are two ways to cache Swift packages in a build, depending on whether you use key-based caching or branch-based caching.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Key-based caching

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Key-based caching is only available for credit-based accounts!

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Key-based caching

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Branch-based caching

title: Caching Swift packages
body: With key-based caching, you only need the Restore SPM cache and the Save SPM cache Steps to cache your Swift packages. These Steps require no configuration as they automatically set up the cache keys needed for your dependencies.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Setting specific cache paths

title: Caching Swift packages
body: You don't have to use the default cache paths that the dedicated key-based caching Steps use. If you need to set a specific cache path, you can do so by configuring the Save Cache and the Restore Cache Steps: Using key-based caching in your builds.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Add the Restore SPM cache Step to your Workflow

title: Caching Swift packages
body: It should come before any Step that handles SPM packages in any way, such as Xcode Archive & Export for iOS.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Add the Save SPM cache Step to the end of your Workflow.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Branch-based caching relies on the built-in feature of all our Xcode Steps to collect Swift package cache content. The Xcode Archive & Export for iOS, Xcode Test for iOS, Xcode Build for testing for iOS, and the Xcode Build for Simulator Steps can all collect Swift package cache content.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Setting specific cache paths

title: Caching Swift packages
body: You don't have to use the default cache paths that the built-in caching options use. If you need to set a specific cache path, you can do so in the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps: Including files and folders in the build cache.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step to your Workflow.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: It should come before any Step that handles SPM packages in any way, such as Xcode Archive & Export for iOS. The Step requires no extra configuration if you use our Xcode Steps.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Enable Swift package caching in the Xcode Step(s) you use in your build: in the Caching input group, set the Enable collecting cache content input to swift_packages.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step to the end of your Workflow.

title: Caching Swift packages
body: The Step requires no extra configuration if you use our Xcode Steps.

title: Managing dependencies with CocoaPods
body: With the Run CocoaPods install Step, you can easily install CocoaPods dependencies on Bitrise. You just need a Podfile and the Step. Bitrise also offers dedicated Steps to cache your pods.

title: Managing dependencies with CocoaPods
body: CocoaPods is a dependency manager for Swift and Objective-C Cocoa projects. An iOS app with CocoaPods dependencies needs to have a Podfile with a number of pods listed in it: these pods are installed during the process of building the app.

title: Managing dependencies with CocoaPods
body: You can, of course, easily install CocoaPods dependencies during a Bitrise build. You just need our dedicated Step: Run CocoaPods Install. The Step can run both pod install and pod update commands.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: To install your dependencies with CocoaPods:

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: Workflow Editor

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: bitrise.yml

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: If you need a specific version of CocoaPods, make sure you define it either in the Gemfile or the Podfile.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: The Step first looks for the cocoapods gem in the Gemfile. If there's no cocoapods gem, the Step uses the CocoaPods version defined in the Podfile. If the version is not defined there either, the preinstalled system version will be used which you can check in the system reports.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: Make sure that the Xcode Step building your app uses your .xcworkspace file: the Project path input of the Step should point to the path of .xcworkspace.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: Add the Run CocoaPods Install Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: It should come after any Step that pulls from the build cache. If you don't have any caching Steps, add the Step right after the Git Clone Step.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: In the CocoaPods command input, select the command you wish to run.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: install: Installs the version specified in the Podfile for each pod.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: update: Installs the latest version for each pod listed in the Podfile.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: Optionally, you can specify a path to your Podfile in the Podfile path input.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: This is not mandatory: if you leave the input empty, the Step performs a recursive search in the root directory of your app, and uses the first Podfile it finds.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: If you need a specific version of CocoaPods, make sure you define it either in the Gemfile or the Podfile.

title: Installing CocoaPods dependencies
body: Make sure that the Xcode Step building your app uses your .xcworkspace file: the project_path input of the Step should point to the path of .xcworkspace.

title: Managing dependencies with Carthage

title: Managing dependencies with Carthage
body: Carthage is a dependency manager for iOS and macOS. It's a decentralized dependency manager that doesn't alter your Xcode project in any way. You can use it on Bitrise, too, to handle dependencies for your iOS apps.

title: Android dependencies
body: If you have your Android dependencies defined in your build.gradle file, the dedicated Android Steps on Bitrise can handle installing and even caching them.

title: Android dependencies
body: The Gradle build system handles dependencies for Android apps. If you have your dependencies defined in your build.gradle file, the dedicated Android Steps on Bitrise can handle installing and even caching them.

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Building an Android app with Gradle dependencies is straighforward on Bitrise. When you first add the app, our project scanner determines that it's an Android app by locating the build.gradle file. Our official Android Steps can handle installing dependencies during the build process, and can build different modules and variants easily.

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: To make sure all your dependencies will be installed during the build:

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Define dependencies in your Android project.

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Use one of our Android Steps to build your app. The following Steps can install dependencies and build the app:

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Android Build

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Android Build for UI Testing

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Gradle Runner

title: Installing dependencies for Android apps
body: Each of these Steps run a Gradle task the same way you would run it on your own device. They can build specific modules and install the relevant dependencies for those modules in the process.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: Our build machines come with all the most commonly used Android tools pre-installed. However, if you need additional components of the Android SDK installed, we have a dedicated Step that handles the job for you.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: This Step requires you to have the Gradle Wrapper in your project, as it looks for the `gradlew file. It runs the gradlew dependencies --stacktrace command to list and install the missing dependencies.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: To install missing Android SDK components in a Bitrise build:

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: Define the Android SDK components you need in the top level build.gradle file of your project.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: Make sure you have a gradlew file in your project's repository.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: On Bitrise, add the Install missing Android SDK components Step to your Workflow. It should be before any Step that requires Android SDK components.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: In the gradlew file path input, set the path to your gradlew file, relative to the root of the repository.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: If you use the Native Development Kit in your project, set the required version in the NDK version input.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: If you don't use NDK, leave the input empty.

title: Installing missing Android SDK components
body: In the Additional options for the gradlew dependencies command input, you can set flags in addition to the default command call.

title: Caching Gradle dependencies
body: Setting specific cache paths

title: Caching Gradle dependencies
body: You don't have to use the default cache paths that the dedicated key-based caching Steps use. If you need to set a specific cache path, you can do so by configuring the Save Cache and the Restore Cache Steps: Using key-based caching in your builds.
