title: Caching Gradle dependencies
body: It should come before any Step that handles dependencies in any way, such as Android Build.

title: Caching Gradle dependencies

title: Caching Gradle dependencies

title: Caching Gradle dependencies

title: Caching Gradle dependencies
body: You don't have to use the default cache paths that the built-in caching options use. If you need to set a specific cache path, you can do so in the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull and the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Steps: Including files and folders in the build cache.

title: Flutter dependencies
body: Using the official Bitrise Steps, you can easily install and cache Flutter dependencies, including Dart packages and plugin packages.

title: Flutter dependencies
body: Flutter supports using shared packages as app dependencies. The packages you can use in your app can be divided into two broad types:

title: Flutter dependencies
body: Dart packages use only Dart code and can contain dependencies, apps, resources, or tests.

title: Flutter dependencies
body: Plugins are a special type of package, containing both native Android or iOS code, as well as Dart code. They make platform functionality available to your Flutter apps.

title: Flutter dependencies
body: Bitrise Steps can handle both types, and we have efficient caching solutions for all Flutter dependencies.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Our Flutter Build Step can build both the iOS and Android apps of a Flutter project. The Step runs the flutter pub get command to install all dependencies found in your project's pubspec.yaml file, including plugin packages. As such, it's really simple to add dependencies to a Flutter app on Bitrise.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Package interdependencies

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: If your app's dependencies include plugin packages that require access to platform-specific APIs, you need to add the appropriate dependency declarations to the platform-specific build files. For example, you might need to declare a Gradle dependency in the pubspec.yaml file and in your project's build.gradle file as well.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: For more information, check out the official Flutter documentation: Handling package interdependencies.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Workflow Editor

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: bitrise.yml

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Add dependencies to your Flutter project's pubspec.yaml file.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: On Bitrise, add the Flutter Install Step to your Workflow to install the Flutter SDK.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Add the Flutter Build Step to your Workflow.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: The Step can build both the iOS and Android apps of a Flutter project. If your app's repository contains the necessary build files, it will download and install all required dependencies.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: Add dependencies to your Flutter project's pubspec.yaml file.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body: On Bitrise, add the flutter-install Step to your Workflow to install the Flutter SDK.

title: Installing dependencies for Flutter apps
body:
your-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - flutter-installer:
 inputs:
 - is_update: false

title: React Native dependencies
body: You can use both npm and Yarn to install Javascript package dependencies for React Native app on Bitrise. Bitrise also offers dedicated Steps to cache these dependencies.

title: React Native dependencies
body: npm and Yarn are both package managers for Node.js. They can manage the dependencies of a project, or globally installed Javascript tools. For mobile development, they are frequently used as package managers for React Native projects. If you have a React Native app on Bitrise, you can use our dedicated npm or Yarn Steps to install and cache your dependencies.

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching on Bitrise works by associating cache archives with a key. A Workflow can restore a cache archive by referring to the key; the build files can be saved into the cache archive that the key indicates.

title: Key-based caching
body: Key-based caching works by associating cache archives with a key. A Workflow can restore a cache archive by referring to the key; at the end of the Workflow, the build files can be saved into the cache archive that the key indicates. This overwrites the cache archive.

title: Key-based caching
body: Cache keys can contain variables and other dynamic elements that are replaced at runtime. Users can set up caching that periodically creates new cache archives and automatically discard the old archives.

title: Key-based caching
body: A new cache archive is valid for seven days after creation. If the archive is updated, the timer restarts. If an archive is not updated for seven days, it is automatically discarded.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Key-based caching requires defining a key that identifies a cache archive. A key can be static or dynamically generated, and you can use templates in your keys. There are dedicated key-based caching Steps for dependency managers that require no configuration.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Key-based caching requires two Steps that must be used together:

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Save Cache: saves the build files into a cache archive, identified by a key.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Restore Cache: restores build files into a cache archive, identified by a key.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Dedicated key-based caching Steps

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: You can use dedicated key-based caching Steps, such as the Save NPM Cache, to cache npm or yarn dependencies.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: For a full list of dedicated key-based caching Steps, check out Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers.

title: Using key-based caching in your builds
body: Both Steps access cache archives via key strings. These keys need to be specified as the values of the Cache keys Step input; each key identifies a separate cache archive.

title: Cache retention and eviction policy
body: Your cache entries are retained for seven days since the last use. If they're not used in your workflows for a continuous period of seven days, they will be automatically removed.

title: Cache retention and eviction policy
body: If you run out of your cache storage allowance, the Least Recently Used (LRU) cache entries on your app will be replaced with any new ones produced. LRU is a cache replacement algorithm that removes the least recently used data in order to make room for new data. This might mean that your cache hit rate could reduce if the replaced cache entries are needed by any Workflows. We recommend upgrading to a higher plan to get more storage so that you don't lose any cache entries that might be needed by your Workflows.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Add the Save Cache Step at the end of your Workflow.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: In the Cache key input, define a cache key. This key will be used to identify the cache archive.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: Key limitations

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: The maximum length of a cache key is 512 characters (longer keys get truncated). Commas (,) are not allowed in keys.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can use templates and functions to create dynamic keys that change depending on the build environment or other factors.

title: Creating a new cache archive
body: You can specify multiple keys; the Step will evaluate them in order and match the first one. Read more: Key matching for cache archives.

- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: |-
 npm-cache-{{ .OS }}

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Cache archives cannot be shared between builds running on Linux and Mac stacks

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: A cache archive saved on a Linux-based stack can only be restored in builds also running on Linux machines. Similarly, Mac builds can only restore caches previously saved in a Mac build. The Restore Cache Step fails with a "The specified key does not exist." error if the build tries to restore a cache archive saved on a different OS.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Cache archives can be shared among stacks with different versions of the same OS (for example, between different Xcode stacks).

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Add the Restore Cache Step at the start of your Workflow.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: In the Cache key input, type the key of the cache that you want to restore.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: You can use templates and functions to create dynamic keys that change depending on the build environment or other factors.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: You can specify multiple keys; the Step will evaluate them in order and select the first matching one. Read more: Key matching for cache archives.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Restoring a cache archive from one of two keys

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: In this example, we're restoring one of two keys:

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: First, we'll look for a cache archive with a key that includes the name of the current Workflow. For example, if the current Workflow's name is primary, the Step will look for an archive with the key npm-cache-primary.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
body: Second, we'll look for an archive with a key that includes the name of the current branch. For example, if the current branch's name is main, the Step will look for an archive with the key npm-cache-main.

title: Restoring an existing cache archive
Key-based caching templates and functions
body: Both key-based caching Steps support using template elements in their Step inputs. The Steps evaluate the key template at runtime and the final cache key to be used can change depending on the build environment or on certain files in the repository.

title: Available caching templates
body: Key-based caching templates

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: The key-based caching templates support the use of two different functions:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: checksum: This function computes the SHA-256 checksum of the contents of one or more files. This is useful for creating unique cache keys based on files that describe content to cache. Example 1, “.

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: getenv: This function returns the value of an Environment Variable (Env Var) or an empty string if the variable is not defined. Example 2, “

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Using the checksum function

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the checksum function to create a key that computes the checksum of the package-lock.json file:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}
 - paths: node_modules

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the checksum function to create a key that computes a checksum for any .gradle file and the gradle.properties file:

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }}
 - paths: AndroidApp

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Using the getenv function

title: Using functions in caching templates
body: Use the getenv function to create a key that contains the value of the BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER Env Var.

title: Using functions in caching templates
body:
- save-cache@1:
 inputs:
 - key: npm-cache-{{ getenv "BITRISE_BUILD_NUMBER" }}
 - paths: node_modules

title: Key matching for cache archives
body: It's possible to define more than one key in the Cache keys input of the key-based caching Steps. You can specify additional keys by listing one key per line. The list is in priority order, so the Step will first try to find a match for the first key you provided, and if there is no cache stored for the key, it will move on to find a match for the second key (and so on).

title: Key matching for cache archives
body:
inputs:
 key: |
 key-1
 key-2
 key-3

title: Key matching for cache archives
body: In addition to listing multiple keys, each key can be a prefix of a saved cache key and still get a matching cache archive. For example, the key my-cache- can match an existing archive saved with the key my-cache-a6a102ff. We recommend configuring the keys in a way that the first key is an exact match to a checksum key, and to use a more generic prefix key as a fallback:

title: Key matching for cache archives
body:
inputs:
 key: |
 npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }}
 npm-cache-

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: You might not want to update a cache archive every time you run a build. By skipping caching, you can:

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Avoid saving potentially incorrect build data in the cache.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Make the PR validation workflow faster.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Limit the amount of data stored and transferred.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If the cached content did not change during your build at all, the Save cache Step can automatically skip compressing and uploading the cache. To make this work, you need to make sure your cache archive has a unique cache key that changes whenever the contents of the cache change: in practice, this requires a dynamic key with a checksum and a file that describes the cached content. The checksum will be calculated based on the contents of the file; if the file remains unchanged, so does the checksum.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: We strongly recommend configuring the Step in a way to take advantage of this feature. Follow the steps below, or skip ahead to our YAML example.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Skipping the Save cache Step entirely

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If you don't wish to update the cache archive even if the content that would be cached has changed, you can either remove the Save cache Step from your Workflow or you can set conditions for the Step: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Open your Workflow and select the Save cache Step.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Set the Unique cache key input to true.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If the input is set to false, the Step can still skip uploading the cache but it will need to create the cache archive first to calculate its checksum. This takes time.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: In the Cache key input, create a key with a checksum for a file that describes the cached content.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: For example, npm-cache-{{ checksum "package-lock.json" }} is a dynamic key that remains unchanged as long as the package-lock.json file does not change.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: Add the same dynamic key to the Cache keys input of the Restore cache Step.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: If everything is configured correctly, if the keys in the two caching Steps match, the cache archive will not be updated.

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: YAML example for using a dynamic key with checksum

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body: In this example, the cache key calculates the sum for any .gradle file and the gradle.properties file. Both the Restore cache and the Save cache Step looks for the same cache key:

title: Using conditional caching with dynamic keys
body:
workflows: 
 caching: 
 steps: 
 - restore-cache@1: 
 inputs: 
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }} 
 - save-cache@1: 
 inputs: 
 - key: gradle-cache-{{ checksum "**/*.gradle*" "gradle.properties" }} 
 - is_key_unique: 'true'

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Bitrise's dedicated caching Steps store their archives in the same storage space as the Save cache and Restore cache Steps but unlike those two, they automatically set up the appropriate cache paths and cache keys and as such, they require no configuration.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Key-based caching is powerful and flexible: you can use the Save cache and Restore cache Steps with any app, regardless of platform or the type of data you want to cache. However, these Steps require careful configuration and it is possible to make mistakes. If you are looking for a simple solution to cache dependencies of the most frequently used dependency managers, we offer dedicated Steps that require no configuration whatsoever.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: The dedicated caching Steps store their archives in the same storage space as the Save cache and Restore cache Steps but unlike those two, they automatically set up the appropriate cache paths and cache keys.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: The following dedicated Steps are available:

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save NPM Cache and Restore NPM Cache: Caching npm and Yarn dependencies.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Gradle Cache and Restore Gradle Cache: Caching Gradle dependencies.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Carthage Cache and Restore Carthage Cache: Caching Carthage dependencies.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: Save Dart Cache and Restore Dart Cache: Caching dependencies for Flutter apps.

title: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers
body: To use these Steps, simply add the Restore version to the start of your Workflow and the Save version to the end of your Workflow. No other configuration is needed.

title: Branch-based caching
body: In branch-based (legacy) caching, every branch of your repository on which you run a build will have its own cache archive. You can only use a cache archive on the same stack it was generated on. The cache is stored as a single archive file: if the content of the cached paths changes in any way, the entire file gets updated.

title: Branch-based caching
body: Build cache expiry

title: Branch-based caching
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Branch-based caching
body: The default branch cache is used as fallback

title: Branch-based caching
body: If a branch does not yet have a cache saved, the default branch’s cache will be used. Caching is not available for pull request builds of public Bitrise apps.

title: Branch-based caching
body: Every folder and file specified in the Cache paths input of the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change the value of this input: you only need to add anything here if you want to cache files generated by a Step that doesn’t have its own caching function. A few examples of Steps with their own caching function:

body: To find out how access the cache during builds, check out Using branch-based caching in your builds.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The legacy, branch-based build cache feature is split into two parts:

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Build Cache API.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Steps.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Build Cache API is a simple API. It makes sure that you have the required access rights to the resource (the build cache archive), and provides secure - time-limited and expiring - download and upload URLs. It does not process the files.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The Steps are responsible for executing the logic of comparing caches and creating the cache archives. This means that you can write your own Steps and implement your own comparison and compression logic. The only requirement is that the Step has to use the Build Cache API to get download and upload URLs. There’s no restriction on the cache file format or on its content.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: Archive size limit

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The size of a single cache archive cannot exceed 15 GB.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: Read more about developing your own Step in our dedicated guide: Developing a new Step.

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: The cache might not be available

title: Technical notes on branch-based caching
body: It’s always a good idea to write your code in a way that your builds won’t fail if the cache can’t be accessed. Also keep in mind that the cache is downloaded over the internet. Storing a resource or dependency in Bitrise build cache might help if you have reliability issues with the usual download location but it doesn't necessarily save you time.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can use two dedicated Bitrise Steps for caching: Bitrise.io Cache Pull to tap into the cache and use the contents of it in your build, and Bitrise.io Cache Push to store information from your build in the cache.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Branch-based caching vs key-based caching

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: This guide is is about legacy, branch-based caching. For key-based caching, check out our in-depth guide: Key-based caching.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can read about our dedicated key-based caching Steps here: Dedicated caching Steps for dependency managers.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: The basics of using the cache in your builds are simple and it can work out of the box, depending on your Workflows: you just have to use the two dedicated Steps.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step right before you need the cache.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: For example, in the case of an iOS app, you can insert the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step between the Git Clone Repository and the dependency installer Steps (such as the Run CocoaPods install or the Carthage Steps). You should not put the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step BEFORE the Git Clone Repository Step.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Build cache expiry

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: The build cache, related to a specific branch, expires after seven days which means it is automatically deleted - but only if there’s no new build on that branch in the meantime. This means that if you do builds on a specific branch more frequently than a week, the cache won’t get deleted. If you don’t start a build on that specific branch for more than seven days, then the related cache will be deleted, and and your next build will run like the first.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Add the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step as the last Step of the Workflow.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: For simple use cases, that’s it, that’s all you have to do. These Steps work out of the box alongside Steps with their own caching function. But if you wish to learn more and create your own caching configuration, read on!

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: Pull request builds

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: By default, if you run a build that is triggered by a pull request, the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step won’t work: in this case, a pull request build can only read the build cache but can’t update it!

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: We strongly recommend that you do not change this! From a security perspective, the best practice is to never allow pull request builds to alter anything that can affect other Bitrise builds.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: If you absolutely must change it, you need to use a run_if expression in the app’s bitrise.yml file. Read more about run_if expressions: Enabling or disabling a Step conditionally.

title: Using branch-based caching in your builds
body: You can find example build cache configurations/guides at our build-cache discuss page.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: As mentioned before, every file and folder specified in the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step’s Cache paths input gets cached, unless the Step is configured to ignore certain folders and files. In most cases, you don’t have to change this input. If you use Steps that have their own in-built caching function, you don’t have to worry about specifying files and folders unless you have a specific use case.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To check whether a Step has a caching function, take a look at their inputs. If there’s no input to turn caching on and off, the Step in question doesn’t have its own caching function.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: To include files from Steps that do not have their own caching function:

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Find the Cache paths input.

title: Including files and folders in the build cache
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to include in the cache. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can also tell the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step to specifically ignore certain content. Ignoring means one of two things:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder isn’t checked for changes: if the specified path is included in the previous cache archive, it will be included in the new one with the same content as before.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: A file or folder is completely excluded: in other words, it isn’t uploaded to the cache at all, regardless of its changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can choose either option for any of your files or folders.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: To ignore certain files or folders:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: In your Workflow, open the Bitrise.io Cache:Push Step.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Find the Ignore Paths from change check input.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Add the path or paths for files and folders that you want to ignore. You can use either an absolute path, or a path relative to the root of your repository.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to completely exclude a given path from the cache archive, prefix the path with !. For example, !my/path/.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: If you want to exclude a given path from change checking, just add the path without any prefix. If a path is located inside an ignored cache path item and the path is NOT prefixed with an !, the path will be included in the cache archive, but it will not be checked for changes. For example, if you add my/path/ to the input, the path directory will be included in the archive but it will not be checked for changes.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, of course, specify certain patterns in the paths, too. For example:

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a path element with *: a/*/b: this will match a/x/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Replacing a part of the path with **: a/**/b will match a/x/y/z/b

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring an entire directory with /. For example, /my/full/path/ ignores everything in the path folder.

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: Ignoring paths

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can’t ignore a path which results in an invalid cache item. For example, if you specify a/path/to/cache path to be cached, you can’t ignore a/path/to, as that would ignore every file and wouldn’t check for changes, hence no fingerprint could be generated for a/path/to/cache. This won’t fail the Step: you’ll simply receive the following warning: No path to cache, skip caching...

title: Ignoring files and dependencies
body: You can, however, ignore paths inside a cache path. For example, if your path is a/path/to/cache, you can ignore a/path/to/cache/.ignore-me, unless that’s the only file inside a/path/to/cache.

title: Downloading or deleting the build cache
body: You can download and delete build caches for every branch which generated a cache. You can check the size of the caches and the last time a given cache was used.

title: Downloading or deleting the build cache
body: If you only want to delete the cache which is related to a single branch, you should also delete the default branch’s cache too! This is because if a build runs on a branch which doesn’t have a cache, the Bitrise.io Cache:Pull Step will get the cache of the default branch.

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache
body: The Bitrise Build Cache is a fully managed caching solution that reduces CI build durations for applications built with Gradle and Bazel build systems. It specifically caches build and test outputs to minimize how much work is done in subsequent builds.

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache
body: The Bitrise Build Cache is a fully managed caching solution that reduces CI build durations for applications built with Gradle and Bazel build systems. It specifically caches build and test outputs to minimize how much work is done in subsequent builds, making it more efficient in environments with frequent updates. Compatible with any CI tool, it accelerates the build cycle without requiring you to manage a caching infrastructure.

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache
body: Invocations

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache
body: Invocation is a key concept in remote caching, one that we use often in the guides. An invocation is a single Gradle or Bazel command execution. This means running a specific gradle or bazel command to achieve a particular goal.

title: Remote build caching with the Bitrise Build Cache
body: Invocations are only counted when the Remote Build Cache is enabled and used.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: The Bitrise remote build cache allows you to utilize the Gradle build cache for both local and CI builds. The solution caches Gradle task outputs on a remote server. When you run a build, Gradle will not execute tasks whose output is available in the remote cache and download the cache entry instead.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Try it for free

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: We offer a 30-day free trial at no cost; you don't even need to provide payment information. The trial starts automatically when you set up the Bitrise Build Cache.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Click here to get started with the Bitrise Build Cache. If you don't have a Bitrise account, you will be prompted to create one first before proceeding to set up the Build Cache.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: The Gradle build cache helps you save time by reusing outputs produced by other builds. The Bitrise Build Cache allows you to utilize it for CI builds both on Bitrise and other CI environments.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Gradle builds are a series of tasks with inputs and outputs. Bitrise caches task outputs on a performant remote server. When you start a Gradle build, Gradle will skip executing tasks whose output is available in the remote cache and will instead download and reuse the cache entry.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Dependency caching vs build caching

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Build caching and dependency caching are separate concepts. The best practice is to use both to minimize build times. Read more: Caching Gradle dependencies.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: Use key-based dependency caching

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle
body: We recommend that you do not use the legacy dependency caching Steps in combination with remote build caching. Instead, combine build cache only with key-based dependency caching. This is to prevent unintended consequences that can happen when the legacy dependency cache carries build settings over between builds.

body: In the Bitrise CI environment, you only need our official Step to use the Bitrise Build Cache for your Gradle builds.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle in non-Bitrise CI environments

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Environment

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Make sure to run the script in the same environment as the Gradle command(s) you want to speed up. For example, if you use multiple Docker containers throughout the build, make sure that the Bitrise Build Cache CLI runs in the same Docker container as the Gradle command.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Gradle in non-Bitrise CI environments
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euxo pipefail

# download Bitrise Build Cache CLI
curl -sSfL 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-build-cache-cli/main/install/installer.sh' | sh -s -- -b /tmp/bin -d

# run the CLI to enable Bitrise build cache for Gradle
/tmp/bin/bitrise-build-cache enable-for gradle

title: Gradle execution reason diagnostic builds
body: You can run Gradle diagnostic builds on Bitrise to find out the reasons behind Gradle task execution events. This helps reducing cache misses for remote caching.

title: Gradle execution reason diagnostic builds
body: Cache hit ratio is a measurement of how many content requests a cache is able to fill successfully, compared to how many requests it receives. Getting a high amount of cache misses slows down your build as it doesn't take full advantage of caching.

title: Gradle execution reason diagnostic builds
body: When running Gradle tasks, a change in task inputs usually lead to a cache miss. Gradle's execution reasons can help understand why the change in inputs happened, and to debug the problem.

title: Gradle execution reason diagnostic builds
body: You can keep on reading to understand the details of how Gradle tasks and their caching works.

title: Gradle execution reason diagnostic builds
body: To learn how to set up diagnostic builds on Bitrise, skip ahead to Diagnostic builds.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: In the Gradle build system, the basic unit of action is a task. A task could be compiling classes, running unit tests, or creating a JAR. Each task has its own inputs, such as files or environmental variables, and outputs.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Tasks usually generate their output in a specific build directory which is configurable for each module. The contents of this directory can be often reused between builds on the same machine. As such, Gradle saves time by executing only the tasks that can't be reused. For other tasks, the output from the build directory is reused and the task gets the UP-TO-DATE label. This process is what Gradle calls an incremental build.

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Incremental build vs incremental task execution

title: Gradle tasks and caching
body: Incremental builds are not the same as incremental task execution! You can read about incremental tasks in Gradle's official docs.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: When running Gradle in a CI environment, all tasks are either executed or retrieved from cache because the build directory is empty. After execution, Gradle saves metadata about the task inputs in the project cache directory. Gradle uses this metadata to be able to perfom incremental builds.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: For example, in the case of a compile task, Gradle saves the checksum of the source files and only re-compiles files that have changed, based on the checksums. For more information on how Gradle checks task inputs, read Gradle’s docs on task inputs and outputs.

title: Gradle tasks in a CI environment
body: If metadata is not available, Gradle will execute all tasks.

title: Caching tasks
body: If the metadata indicates that a task has to be executed, and the Bitrise build cache is enabled, the task inputs and certain Gradle properties such as the version are hashed into the cache key. If either the remote or local cache has a match for the cache key, the task does not have to be fully executed: its execution result is loaded from the cache and gets the FROM-CACHE outcome label.

title: Caching tasks
body: If there is no match for the cache key in the remote or local cache (a cache miss), the task is fully executed and its outputs are stored in the cache.

title: Caching tasks
body: When a task doesn't have the UP-TO-DATE label, the reasons for this are recorded and displayed in the task's row in the invocation details on Bitrise. Some of the possible reasons are as follows:

title: Caching tasks
body: If the metadata is missing, No history available is displayed.

title: Caching tasks
body: If the outputs are missing, Output... has been removed is displayed.

title: Caching tasks
body: Tasks without the UP-DO-DATE label can still be cached if their inputs were cached at least once previously.

title: Diagnostic builds
body: To understand what changes contribute to a task’s execution, you’ll need the Gradle metadata and the build outputs from a previous build. Restoring them on a CI environment simulates a local incremental build, showing the changes between builds that contribute to cache misses.

title: Diagnostic builds
body: These builds are called diagnostic builds on Bitrise.

title: Diagnostic builds
body: Debugging purposes only

title: Diagnostic builds
body: Diagnostic builds heavily use key-based caching and have increased build time. Their purpose is debugging and they shouldn't be a part of your daily workflows!

title: Diagnostic builds
body: The archive limit for key-based cache is 15 Gb. If your app’s outputs exceed that, you can run two separate builds with the same principle, using your own artifact storage solution.

title: Gradle configuration cache
body: Gradle configuration cache reduces build times by caching the result of a Gradle project's configuration phase and reusing it in subsequent builds. For details, read Gradle's official documentation. The Bitrise Build Cache supports this feature for Gradle 8.6 and later versions.

title: Gradle configuration cache
body: Gradle configuration cache reduces build times by caching the result of a Gradle project's configuration phase and reusing it in subsequent builds. For details, read Gradle's official documentation. The Bitrise Build Cache supports this feature for Gradle 8.6 and later versions.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: To set up the configuration cache:

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Make sure you have a subscription or a trial for the Bitrise Build Cache.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Run a build locally with the --configuration-cache flag.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: This ensures that your Gradle project supports configuration caching. To enable configuration caching in the Gradle settings, refer to Gradle's official guide.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Generate a Bitrise personal access token and add it as a Secret with the BITRISE_BUILD_CACHE_AUTH_TOKEN key.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Token consistency

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: For the configuration cache to function correctly, the authentication token used by the Gradle plugins must remain consistent across builds.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Generate a Gradle encryption key:

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: openssl rand -base64 16

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Save the key as a Secret named GRADLE_ENCRYPTION_KEY in your Bitrise project.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: This ensures that the encrypted value of the configuration cache remains the same across different builds. Using a fixed encryption key is supported from Gradle version 8.6 or later. Bitrise doesn't support Gradle configuration cache for earlier Gradle versions.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Set your Bitrise workspace slug as an Environment Variable named BITRISE_BUILD_CACHE_WORKSPACE_ID.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Add the Build Cache for Gradle Step to your Workflow.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: The Step must be of version 2.7.7 or later. Any subsequent updates to the Step will cause a one-off invalidation of the configuration cache. If this happens, do a rebuild to fix the issue.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Add the Restore Gradle configuration cache and the Restore Gradle Cache Steps before your Gradle invocation in the Workflow.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: The Steps retrieve cached configuration data and enable the configuration cache to access artifacts it references.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Configuration cache directory

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: The Restore Gradle configuration cache Step saves data in the ./.gradle/configuration-cache directory. You can override this by changing the Configuration cache directory input.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: For example, if you use Android Build to build your Gradle project, these two Steps must come before it in the Workflow.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Add the Save Gradle configuration cache and the Save Gradle Cache Steps after your Gradle invocation in the Workflow.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: The Steps save the configuration data to the cache and save artifacts referenced by the configuration cache.

title: Setting up the configuration cache
body: Enable the Save transforms input of the Save Gradle Cache Step. You need Step version 1.4.1 or later.

title: Saving the Gradle configuration cache log
body: Gradle's build logs might contain information about why it didn't reuse the configuration cache. You can save the log to the Artifacts page of your build:

title: Saving the Gradle configuration cache log
body: Enable the --info log level in Gradle.

title: Saving the Gradle configuration cache log
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow.

title: Saving the Gradle configuration cache log
body: Set the Deploy directory or file path input to what Gradle outputs as the file path.

title: Saving the Gradle configuration cache log
body: You can check the deployed file on the Artifacts page: open Bitrise CI, select your project and then the build, and select the Artifacts tab.

title: Troubleshooting the configuration cache
body: If your build doesn't reuse the configuration cache, you can check a number of potential problems.

title: General troubleshooting
body: Make sure to add the Save/Restore Gradle cache Steps to utilize dependency caching. Gradle configuration cache references artifacts that must be present.

title: General troubleshooting
body: It may take multiple runs before the configuration cache is fully applied and reused.

title: General troubleshooting
body: Check the Gradle logs to find out why Gradle didn't reuse the configuration cache. You can save the gradle configuration cache log to your build artifacts.

title: General troubleshooting
body: Updates to the Build Cache for Gradle Step will cause a one-off invalidation of the configuration cache. Just run another build to fix the problem.

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: Your build could fail with the following error:

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: org.gradle.internal.operations.BuildOperationInvocationException: Failed to instrument class io/bitrise/gradle/cache/BitriseBuildCache in ClassLoaderScopeIdentifier.Id{coreAndPlugins:init-file:/root/.gradle/init.d/bitrise-build-cache.init.gradle.kts(export)}

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: To fix this issue:

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: In the Save Gradle cache Step, set the Save transforms input to true.

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: Version requirement

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: The input is only available from version 1.4.1 or later.

title: Failed to instrument class error
body: Force a save by running a build without the Restore Gradle cache Step.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel
body: To successfully use remote caching for Bazel, you need a bitrise.bazelrc file that contains the necessary configurations to enable the remote build cache for your Bazel project. You can use the remote cache for builds running on Bitrise or in other CI environments.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel
body: Try it for free

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel
body: We offer a 30-day free trial at no cost; you don't even need to provide payment information. The trial starts automatically when you set up the Bitrise Build Cache.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel
body: Click here to get started with the Bitrise Build Cache. If you don't have a Bitrise account, you will be prompted to create one first before proceeding to set up the Build Cache.

title: Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel
body: To successfully use the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel, you need a bitrise.bazelrc file that contains the necessary configurations to enable the cache for your Bazel project. You can use the Bitrise Build Cache for builds running on Bitrise or in other CI environments.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: You can use the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel on the Bitrise CI by adding our dedicated Step to your Workflow. The Step activates the Bitrise Build Cache. After it executes, Bazel builds will automatically read from the build cache and push new entries if it's enabled.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: Workflow Editor

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: bitrise.yml

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: Add the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel Step to your Workflow.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: The Step requires no configuration.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: Open the bitrise.yml file and add the activate-build-cache-for-bazel Step to your Workflow.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: The Step requires no configuration.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body:
your-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - activate-build-cache-for-bazel:

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in the Bitrise CI environment
body: During your first build, outputs will be saved to cache. We recommend running a couple of builds to ensure the cache is warmed up.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: The Bitrise Build Cache does not require using the Bitrise CI. You can use other CI/CD services and still take advantage of remote caching to improve your Bazel build times.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: To do so, you need to configure your CI environment to download the Bitrise Build Cache CLI during the build and then run the CLI to enable the Bitrise Build Cache.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Generate a Personal Access Token on Bitrise: Creating a personal access token.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Copy the value of the token, as you will need it during the process.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Find your Workspace ID: open the Workspace settings page and select General settings on the left navigation menu. You can find and copy the slug from there.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Set the following Environment Variables in your CI configuration:

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: BITRISE_BUILD_CACHE_AUTH_TOKEN: The value should be your Personal Access Token.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: BITRISE_BUILD_CACHE_WORKSPACE_ID: The value should be the Bitrise Workspace slug.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Add the following script to your CI configuration before the step you want to speed up:

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Environment

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body: Make sure to run the script in the same environment as the Bazel command you want to speed up. For example, if you use multiple Docker containers throughout the build, make sure that the Bitrise Build Cache CLI runs in the same Docker container as the Bazel command.

title: Configuring the Bitrise Build Cache for Bazel in non-Bitrise CI environments
body:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
set -euxo pipefail

# download Bitrise Build Cache CLI
curl -sSfL 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-build-cache-cli/main/install/installer.sh' | sh -s -- -b /tmp/bin -d

# run the CLI to enable Bitrise build cache for Bazel
/tmp/bin/bitrise-build-cache enable-for bazel

title: Code signing
body: During a Bitrise build, you can digitally sign your app regardless of platform. Bitrise has dedicated Steps for both Android and iOS code signing procedures.

title: Code signing
body: Code signing is the process of digitally signing your app, as a means of guaranteeing that the code has not been altered since signing. It provides security for deployment, and identifies the author.

title: Code signing
body: To deploy mobile apps to an online store, such as Google Play or the App Store, code signing is absolutely crucial. On Bitrise, we tried to make it as easy and convenient as possible.

title: iOS code signing
body: Every iOS app, native or cross-platform, needs code signing. At the minimum, two files are required:

title: iOS code signing
body: A provisioning profile.

title: iOS code signing
body: A signing certificate.

title: iOS code signing
body: These files are part of Apple's process and can be obtained only with an Apple Developer account. On Bitrise, we help you manage these assets:

title: iOS code signing
body: The Steps that support automatic code signing asset management, automatically download provisioning profiles and fix common issues through an already set up API key or Apple ID connection.

title: iOS code signing
body: For manual code signing asset management, you have to manually upload the code signing certificate and provisioning profile to Bitrise and add the Certificate and Profile Installer Step along with a build Step.

title: Android code signing
body: Android code signing can be handled via our dedicated Step, via Android Studio, or in your Gradle configuration.

title: Android code signing
body: To sign an Android app, you will need a keystore file which requires a Google Play Developer account, and Google Play API access.

title: Android code signing
body: Before you distribute your Android app through Google Play Store, your APK or AAB file must be digitally signed. You can use the dedicated Bitrise Step or perform code signing with a Gradle configuration.

title: Android code signing
body: Before you distribute your app through Google Play Store, your APK file must be digitally signed.

title: Android code signing
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio or manually in your Gradle configuration. You can also use the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow Editor to have your APK signed automatically.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: You can upload multiple Android keystore files to Bitrise and use the one your app needs. This makes the Android code signing process much easier.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: To be able to digitally sign your Android apps, and distribute them on the Google Play Store, you need a keystore file. You can store the keystore file in any accessible location and our Steps can use them but the easiest, most convenient way is to upload them directly to Bitrise.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: To do so:

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Multiple files

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: You can upload multiple keystore files to Bitrise. If you do, make sure your Steps use the right one, as they will have different URLs.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: On the left, select Code signing and go to the Android tab.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Click the Add keystore file button.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: In the dialog box, you can either drag-and-drop your keystore file to the Select an Android keystore file field, or click the field to browse your files.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: A keystore URL automatically gets generated once you upload the keystore file. Bitrise assigns an Environment Variable (BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL) to the download URL (which is a time-limited, read-only download URL) of the file as the value. No need to download it manually as the Android Sign Step downloads it automatically.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Fill out the displayed three input fields with your Android keystore credentials:

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Keystore password

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Keystore alias

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Private key password

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: You can set the passwords and the alias when creating the key: Generate an upload key and keystore.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Click Continue. The next page will show the new Environment Variables that will be available to your builds once you finish the file upload process:

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PRIVATE_KEY_PASSWORD

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Each time you upload an additional keystore file after the first, the new file's respective Env Vars will have a number at the end. For example, $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS_1, $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS_2.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Review your keystore data to make sure you've uploaded the correct file.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Optionally, you can set up a custom ID for the keystore file: in the Custom keystore ID field, add the ID you want to use to identify your keystore file.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: The ID will replace the unique part of the keystore-related Env Vars: for example, if you set the ID to My_Best_App, the URL will be $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL_MY_BEST_APP.

title: Uploading Android keystore files to Bitrise
body: Click Add file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file on the Code signing tab of the Workflow Editor.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can create a signed APK using the Android Sign Step in your Bitrise Workflow. This Step is configured to run if you have already uploaded your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: The Android Sign Step is not required if signing is configured in your project’s build.gradle file. If so, running the Android Build Step (or the Gradle Runner Step) signs the output (APK or AAB) automatically. Nevertheless, we recommend that you use the Android Sign Step to sign your project in an easy and secure way.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: jarsign and apksigner

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: APKs can be signed with either jarsigner or apksigner. For APKs, if you wish to use apksigner to sign your project, then in the Android Sign Step you have to first set the Enables apksigner input to true and leave the APK Signature Scheme input on automatic. This way apksigner checks your APK’s minimum and target SDK versions and chooses the required schemes. It signs your project with V1 scheme if your minimum supported version is low and it also signs with other schemes for newer systems.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Please note that AAB files can only be signed with jarsigner. The Step uses jarsigner if it detects a file ending with .aab

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Upload your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Add the Android Sign Step to your Workflow after the Step that builds your APK or AAB file.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Bitrise uses the above Environment Variables and sets them as inputs into the respective fields of the Android Sign Step. Once the Step runs, it produces either a signed APK or an AAB. The signed APK or AAB is used in deploy Steps, for example, the Google Play Deploy Step or the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step. The latter deploys the APK/AAB on the Artifacts tab. You can also use Release Management to deploy your app once you built an installable artifact.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: Downloading your keystore file

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: You can download your keystore file to the project directory using the File Downloader Step:

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body:
- file-downloader:
 inputs:
 - source: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL
 - destination: "$HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks" #native android#

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: If a Step requires the keystore file, make sure to include that Step AFTER the File Downloader Step.

title: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step
body: After this Step, my_keystore.jks will be available at $HOME/keystores/my_keystore.jks.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio before running a Bitrise build. You will need a keystore file, a key alias and a key password.

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: You can specify the code signing configuration for your project in Android Studio. You will need a keystore file, a key alias and a key password - have these ready before you start the procedure!

title: Android code signing with Android Studio
body: Open Android Studio.

body: Once you filled out the signing information, the signingConfigs block will be created in your module’s build.gradle file. On Bitrise, you just need to build the app, either with the Android Build or the Gradle Runner Step.

body: You can manually specify the code signing configuration in your Gradle configuration so that your app gets signed during the build process on Bitrise.

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: keyAlias

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: keyPassword

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: Attach the signing config to a build type.

title: Android code signing in Gradle

title: Android code signing in Gradle
body: For more information, check out how to configure Gradle to sign your app.

Android code signing in Gradle

title: Android code signing in Gradle

title: Android code signing in Gradle

Android code signing in Gradle

Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: You can define the location of the keystore file of an Android app in your build.gradle file. If the keystore file itself is missing from the location, you can use one of our file downloading Steps to download the keystore file from Bitrise and put it in the defined location.

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: A keystore file is required for Android code signing. You can define the location of the keystore file of an Android app in your build.gradle file: Android code signing in Gradle. You can upload your keystore file to Bitrise and use the File Downloader Step to download the keystore file from Bitrise and put it in the location defined in the build.gradle file.

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: The Android Sign Step

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: If you use the Android Sign Step to sign your app, you don't need to download the keystore file. The Step will find the file: Android code signing using the Android Sign Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: Add the File Downloader Step to your Workflow. The Step should be added BEFORE any Step that requires the keystore file, such as Gradle Runner.

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: Fill out the following two input fields:

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: Download source url: Set the generated keystore URL you get when you upload your file to Bitrise).

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: Download destination path: Set the location of the keystore file as a relative path. This path should be the same as the keystore path already defined in your build.gradle file (for example, $HOME/keystores/project_release.keystore).

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: Add the Gradle Runner Step right after your file downloading Step.

title: Downloading a keystore file from Bitrise during a build
body: With that said, if you have successfully added the Steps to download your keystore file to the same location that you specified in your build.gradle file, you do not need the Android Sign Step in your workflow. Our Gradle Runner Step will sign and assemble your project.

title: iOS code signing
body: To install your iOS app on a new device or to distribute your app to App Store, you will need to provide code signing files. The code signing of iOS projects requires signing certificates issued by Apple and provisioning profile file(s) matching your project.

title: iOS code signing
body: To install your iOS app on a new device or to distribute your app to App Store, you will need to provide code signing files. The code signing of iOS projects requires:

title: iOS code signing
body: Signing certificates issued by Apple.

title: iOS code signing
body: Provisioning profile file(s) matching your project (team ID, bundle ID, and so on).

title: iOS code signing
body: Setting up iOS code signing on Bitrise

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Automatic code signing means automatically managing the provisioning profiles that are available on your Apple Developer Portal account. If you set up some form of authentication to your Apple account, Bitrise can download and install the provisioning profile for your app during the build process.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: On Bitrise, we're aiming to make iOS code signing as simple as possible for you. As such, we've done our best to automate a lot of the process. Several of our Steps have a built-in option for automatic code signing management to make configuration a lot more streamlined.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Automatic code signing in this context means automatically managing the provisioning profiles that are available on your Apple Developer Portal account. If you set up some form of authentication to your Apple account, Bitrise can download and install the provisioning profile for your app during the build process.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: To use this feature, you need to:

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Upload the code signing certificates to Bitrise.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Connect your Apple Developer Portal account to Bitrise either via Apple ID or via the App Store Connect API.

title: iOS code signing with automatic provisioning
body: Use one of the Steps that support automatically managing code signing assets.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: All iOS code signing methods require you to export and upload your iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Generating code signing files

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: If you don't have the necessary code signing files ready, you can generate new files: Generating iOS code signing files

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: To upload the certificates to Bitrise, first you need to export the files in the .p12 file format. Once you successfully exported the files, you need to upload them to Bitrise. You have two options:

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Via an API call.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Uploading it manually. This guide focuses on this option.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Upload the distribution AND the development signing certificates

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: We strongly recommend uploading BOTH the development and distribution signing certificates for your project. If you don't have an uploaded development signing certificate, Steps with automatic provisioning options will generate one on the fly every time you start a build. This can eventually lead to reaching the maximum number of certificates, blocking you from starting new builds.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: To export your certificates and upload them to Bitrise in the Workflow Editor:

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Make sure you have your .p12 certificates exported and ready.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: On the left, select the Code signing menu option.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Click Add .p12 file to add a certificate.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: In the dialog box, either drag and drop the file into the Select a code signing certificate section, or click the same section and select the file you want to upload.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Certificate password

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: If your certificate is protected by a password, you need to set the password here, too.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: When done, click Continue.

title: Uploading iOS code signing certificates to Bitrise
body: Check the summary and if everything is okay, click Add certificate.

title: Apple services authentication for automatic provisioning
body: To take advantage of the Bitrise Steps that offer built-in, automated iOS code signing options, you need to set up Apple service authentication. For these Steps, you have two options.

title: Apple services authentication for automatic provisioning
body: Apple services authentication options for iOS code signing

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: There are two ways to handle automatic provisioning on Bitrise:

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Using the official Xcode Steps that can both manage code signing files and build your app.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Table 1, “ describes the use cases for the two methods. To be able to configure the necessary Steps, check out either:

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Don't use the Certificate and profile installer Step

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: If you use automatic provisioning, you never need to use the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Configuring the Steps for automatic provisioning
body: Steps with automatic provisioning options

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: You can use any of the Xcode Steps with built-in automatic management of code signing assets.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Set up connection to Apple services.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: You can choose between API key authentication or Apple ID authentication. We generally recommend API key authentication.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Add any of the following Steps to your Workflow, depending on what you need:

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Xcode Archive and Export for iOS: Builds your Xcode app and exports an IPA of the type you choose.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Export iOS and tvOS Xcode Archive: Exports an IPA from an already existing archive.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Xcode build for testing for iOS: Builds your Xcode app with the build-for-testing action.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service authentication type you set up.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: For example, if you chose API key authentication, choose the api-key option.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: YAML example for setting code signing method

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: In this example, the Xcode Archive and Export for iOS Step is set to use API key authentication.

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body:
- xcode-archive@4: 
 inputs: 
 - automatic_code_signing: api-key

title: Using the Xcode Steps
body: In most cases, the default values for all other inputs are sufficient if you set up your Apple connection correctly.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Use our dedicated Step for automatically managing code signing assets if you do not use one of the Xcode Steps to build your iOS app, or if you have a cross-platform app.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Add the Manage iOS Code Signing Step after any dependency installer Step in your Workflow, such as Run CocoaPods install or Carthage.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: Set the Apple service connection method input to the Apple service connection you want to use.

title: Using the Manage iOS Code Signing Step
body: You can choose between API key authentication or Apple ID authentication.

title: Creating a signed IPA for Xcode projects
body: We strongly recommend uploading BOTH the development and distribution signing certificates for your project. If you don't have an uploaded development signing certificate, Steps with automatic provisioning options will generate one on the fly every time you start a build. This can eventually lead to reaching the maximum number of certificates, blocking you from starting new builds.
