title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for the iOS code signing of Ionic and Cordova apps as well.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Naturally, Bitrise supports iOS applications built with either Ionic or Cordova. However, the code signing process is slightly different compared to a native Xcode project.

title: iOS code signing for Ionic and Cordova projects
body: Bitrise supports both manual and automatic provisioning for Ionic and Cordova apps as well - and once again, the processes are somewhat different.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Generate the native Xcode project locally from your Ionic or Cordova project by calling cordova platform add ios or ionic cordova platform add ios.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Upload the files to bitrise.io: open the Project settings page and select Code signing on the left. Upload a certificate and a provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Make sure you have the Certificate and profile installer Step in your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow. It must come after the Certificate and profile installer Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs for the Step. Please note that both the Code Signing Identity and the Provisioning Profile are required inputs for iOS apps even though they are not marked as such.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Build configuration: you can set it to either debug or release.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Code Sign Identity: enter a Developer or a Distribution identity.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Provisioning Profile: enter the appropriate provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Packaging Type: this controls what type of build is generated by Xcode. Set the type of code signing you need.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova archive or the Ionic archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Platform input needs to be set to: device.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: This Step must come after the Generate cordova build configuration Step in the Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with manual code signing asset management
body: Run your build!

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Make sure your .p12 signing certificates are uploaded to bitrise.io.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova prepare or the Ionic prepare Step to your Workflow. These Steps call the platform rm and platform add commands.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Manage iOS Code Signing Step to your Workflow. If you have both the Certificate and Profile Installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Step will export:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The project’s development team.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed codesign identity’s name.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The installed provisioning profile.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: One code signing Step only

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: If you have both the Certificate and profile installer and the Manage iOS Code Signing Steps in your Workflow, your build might encounter unexpected issues.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Select the Apple service connection method (based on the Apple service you have set up in Bitrise) and the Distribution method.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Generate cordova build configuration Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Configure the Step to use the code signing settings exported by the Manage iOS Code Signing Step:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Development distribution example:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body:
- generate-cordova-build-configuration:
 inputs:
 - development_team: $BITRISE_DEVELOPER_TEAM 
 - package_type: development 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: debug

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Production distribution example:

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body:
- generate-cordova-build-configuration:
 inputs:
 - development_team: $BITRISE_DEVELOPER_TEAM 
 - package_type: app-store 
 - code_sign_identity: iPhone Developer
 - configuration: release

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Add the Cordova Archive or the Ionic Archive Step to your Workflow.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Platform input needs to be set to: device.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: The Build command configuration input must match the Build configuration input of the Generate cordova build configuration Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Set the Should remove platforms as prepare step? to false. This is crucial: it ensures the Step will not remove and re-add the platform of the native projects generated in the Cordova prepare or the Ionic prepare Step.

title: Ionic/Cordova code signing with automatic code signing asset management
body: Run your build!

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: You can set your code signing files to Protected mode: this means they cannot be downloaded from your bitrise.io account. Your builds will be able to use these protected files but no one will be able to reveal them and there is no way to overwrite them: you can only delete the files and upload new ones instead.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: You can set your code signing files to Protected mode: this means they cannot be downloaded from your bitrise.io account. Your builds will be able to use these protected files but no one will be able to reveal them and there is no way to overwrite them: you can only delete the files and upload new ones instead.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: On the left, select Code signing from the menu.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Locate the file you wish to make protected and open the dropdown menu by clicking the ellipsis button on the right.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Select the Make protected option.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: A dialog box will warn you that this change is irreversible once you confirm it. You do not need to separately save your changes.

title: Protecting your code signing files
body: Once you are done, your only option in the file’s dropdown menu will be Delete.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: You can generate iOS code signing files either with Xcode or on the Apple Developer Portal.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: You’ll need two kinds of files to sign your app: certificates and provisioning profiles.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: The certificates - development or distribution - are the guarantee that you, the named developer, built this code, that you are a member of the developer program, and that Apple have issued you with a certificate to do so.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: To get a certificate, you need to generate a Certificate Signing Request with Keychain Access and send it to Apple. This will create a public/private key pair for you if you don’t have one already. Apple will then verify the information, and create a certificate for you.

title: Generating iOS code signing files
body: Provisioning is the process of preparing and configuring an app to launch on devices and to use app services. Development provisioning profiles holds the device identifiers (UUID) that is eligible to run your app. Distribution provisioning profiles can include App Store profiles that allow you to distribute your app to the App Store. Ad-hoc profiles are good for distributing to your testers.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: First you have to add your Apple ID to Accounts preferences in Xcode. If you are already done with this, you can skip to Selecting your Apple ID.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Click on the + on the lower left corner and select Add Apple ID…

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear. Add your Apple ID and your password, then select Sign in. If you don’t have an account you can create your Apple ID by selecting Create Apple ID.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team from the right side bar, then click on View Details….

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear where you will see your code signing identities and the provisioning profiles.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: Under the signing identities locate the iOS Development and iOS Distribution profiles. If you have not created them you will see a Create button next to them. Simply select it and Xcode will issue and download your code signing identities for you.

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: When to click Reset next to Code Signing Identities

title: Generating a code signing certificate with Xcode
body: If you already have Code Signing Identities issued, you will see a Reset button next to them. You can issue new certificates with it, that Xcode will generate and download, however note that this will invalidate your previous certificate, so only do this if you’ve lost those files or if you know what you are doing!

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Open your Keychain Access app on macOS.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select Keychain Access > Certificate Assistant > Request a Certificate From a Certificate Authority…

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Fill in the User’s Email Address and the Common Name and select Saved to Disk.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Click on Continue and save the generated certSigningRequest file locally.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Go to https://developer.apple.com and log in to your account.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select Certificates, IDs & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Go to Certificates and click on the + button on the top right corner.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Select iOS App Development and click Continue.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: On the next page you see the instructions for creating the certSigningRequest file. Click Continue.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Upload the created certSigningRequest to the form and click Continue. It will generate your code signing certificate for you.

title: Generating a code signing certificate manually
body: Download the certificate and double click to install it. Once installed it will be added to your Keychain Access app.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Xcode will automatically generate an App ID for your project, that matches your unique bundle ID for your project. An App ID is used to identify one or more of your apps. It can be an explicit App ID that only matches one unique bundle identifier or a wildcard App ID that can match multiple ones.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Xcode will also create a Team Provisioning Profile for your project automatically, so you can start deploying to your device automatically.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: If you hit any issues you should make sure that the device is eligible, for example if the device doesn’t match the deployment target you will get an error. Also make sure that your app is connected to the correct Team.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: To generate a provisioning profile using Xcode:

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select your project file from Xcode’s project navigator.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Go to the Signing section and under the Team select your correct team.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Build your project in Xcode.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: To download a provisioning profile from Xcode:

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team, then select Download Manual Profiles.

title: Generating a provisioning profile with Xcode
body: Go to ~/Library/MobileDevice/Provisioning Profiles/ and your profiles should be there.

title: Generating a provisioning profile manually
body: To generate a provisioning profile manually, you need a working Apple Developer account, and you need to set up an App ID for your project.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: If you haven’t already created an App ID for your project, go to https://developer.apple.com and log in.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Select Certificates, Identifiers & Profiles from the left sidebar.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Navigate to Identifiers > App IDs.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: In the App ID Description add a recognizable name for your App ID.

title: Setting up an App ID
body: Select Explicit App ID and add your bundle identifier to the field.

title: Setting up an App ID

title: Exporting iOS code signing files manually

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Start Xcode.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select Xcode > Preferences from the navigation bar.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: At the top of the window select Accounts.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select your Apple ID and your team from the right side bar, then click on View Details....

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: A dialog will appear where you will see your code signing identities and the provisioning profiles.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Select the certificates and choose Export from the pop-up menu.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Enter a filename in the Save As dialog. You can set a password and a verification to store it securely, but it’s not necessary.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates with Xcode
body: Xcode will export the requested certificate in .p12 format.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Start Keychain Access.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: On the top left sidebar select login and on the bottom left select My Certificates.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: This will list all your installed certificates and the associated private key.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Select the one that you would like to export and choose Export from the pop-up menu.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Enter a filename in the Save As dialog. You can set a password and a verification to store it securely, but it’s not necessary.

title: Exporting iOS code signing certificates manually
body: Keychain Access will export the requested certificate in .p12 format.

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode

title: Exporting iOS provisioning profiles with Xcode

title: Troubleshooting iOS code signing
body: iOS code signing can be complicated, with several potential issues. We've collected some of the most common issues and their potential solutions.

title: Troubleshooting iOS code signing
body: iOS code signing can be complicated, with several potential issues. We've collected some of the most common issues and their potential solutions. Let’s look into what you can do to make sure code signing works!

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: Every Bitrise build uses a clean virtual machine with no leftover files and configuration from previous builds. While you most likely have all the necessary code signing files (certificates and provisioning profiles) available on your local machine this is not the case with our virtual machines. They do not contain any code signing files relevant to your project, that is why you have to make sure:

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You choose the right code signing asset management option to upload the provisioning profiles to Bitrise. From here our Steps will download the files to the virtual machine at runtime.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You upload the necessary signing certificates to the Code Signing tab.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: You have connected your Bitrise account to the Apple Developer portal. (This step is not needed if you use the Certificate and Profile Installer Step.) to Apple Developer portal.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: If you suspect an error is related to code signing, there is almost certainly a problem with one of these three. When trying to build an iOS app on Bitrise, we strongly recommend generating an .ipa file of the app locally, on your own machine first. If that fails, the build will certainly fail on Bitrise, too.

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: Verbose logs

title: Code signing and clean virtual machines
body: If you are getting any issues, make sure you enable the Verbose log input in your code signing asset management or building Step to get more information on the nature of the issue.

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Our iOS code signing Steps manage your provisioning profiles for you: they download the profiles from the Apple Developer portal and install them for you. Here’s what you can do if these Steps fail:

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Before trying to use this Step, generate an .ipa file locally - with the same export method you want to use on Bitrise - to ensure that the profiles are uploaded to the Apple Developer portal.

title: iOS code signing Steps fail
body: Make sure that your Bitrise account is connected to the Apple Developer portal and that you have at least an Admin role in your Apple Developer team.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: The maximum number of provisioning profiles and .p12 certificates you can upload to the Code Signing tab on Bitrise is 30. If you’ve already reached this limit and wish to use even more, then here are a few tips on how to use even more provisioning profiles:

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: Use a Step with automatic provisioning, such as Xcode Archive and Export for iOS, Export iOS and tvOS Xcode Archive, Xcode build for testing for iOS , or Manage iOS Code Signing. These Steps only require the code signing identities (certificates with .p12 extension) to be uploaded to Bitrise. You can download the provisioning profiles from the Apple Developer portal on-the-fly during the build if you have connected your Apple Developer account to Bitrise.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: You can create a .zip file containing the required certificates/profiles. In this case, you don’t need to upload any certificates/profiles on Bitrise. During the build you can download the .zip file and update the certificate/profile related inputs of the Certificate and Profile Installer Step to match the path to the certificate/profile on the build machine. Note that the Certificate and Profile Installer Step supports local paths and URLs for certificates and profiles.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: You can host the profiles and certificates yourself, and only add an URL that is pointing to a given certificate/profile to the workflow.

title: File count limit on provisioning profiles
body: Also note that multiple URLs can be specified for both the certificate and profile inputs. Make sure you separate them with a pipe (|) character.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: To install iOS apps on a given device, you have to either:

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Export an IPA file with the development export method, with the device’s UDID registered in the provisioning profile used for the export.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Export an IPA file with the ad-hoc export method and install the app via the public install page generated by the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: If you can't install an app on a given device:

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Check that the device UDID is included in the app’s provisioning profile.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: If you use manual provisioning, check the provisioning profile you uploaded to Bitrise.

title: Could not install the app on a device
body: Check the logs to see if the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step used the provisioning profile with the device’s UDID in it.

title: Testing
body: Bitrise has a number of dedicated Steps to help you with running your tests, and you can use custom Script Steps if you do not find what you need in our Step Library.

title: Testing
body: Testing your app is a major part of the continuous integration process. Bitrise has a number of dedicated Steps to help you with running your tests, and you can use custom Script Steps if you do not find what you need in our Step Library.

title: Testing
body: Check out our testing Steps for iOS, Android, and multiplatform apps: from Xcode tests through Flutter tests to Android Lint, you can review and test your app on Bitrise, regardless of the frameworks and tools you use.

title: iOS testing
body: Run UI and unit tests with Xcode using our Xcode Test for iOS Step. With this Step, you don't need code signing and you can easily export your test results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: iOS testing
body: Build an iOS app for testing with the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step. The Step uses the build-for-testing action of xcodebuild to build your test targets and exports the resulting bundle. You can use this bundle, for example, to perform device testing with Firebase.

title: iOS testing
body: Build an iOS app for a simulator with the Xcode Build for Simulator Step. The Step builds an .app file that you can install on an iOS simulator. This requires no code signing, and as such it is a simple way to provide a testable app for your testers.

title: iOS testing
body: You can easily run multiple tests in parallel with Pipelines: Currently supported use cases for the iOS platform.

title: Android testing
body: Run unit tests for Android apps with our Android Unit Test Step. You can configure the Step to run tests on certain modules and variants, and you can pass additional arguments to the Gradle task running the tests. The Step can also export the test results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Android testing
body: Run instrumented tests using the Android Build for UI Testing and the Android Instrumented Test Steps. The Steps generate and export an APK and a test APK and then run your instrumented tests using adb.

title: Android testing
body: You can easily run multiple tests in parallel with Pipelines: Currently supported use cases for the Android platform.

title: Flutter testing
body: Run unit and UI tests for Flutter apps with the Flutter Test Step. The Step simply runs the flutter test command on your app: you can configure it to run only specific tests or to run all tests it can find. You can also export the results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Flutter testing
body: Perform static code analysis with the Dart analyzer: our Flutter Analyze Step runs the flutter analyze command with the required fail severity and the additional parameters you wish to append to it.

title: React Native testing
body: Run unit and UI tests for React Native apps by either npm test or yarn test. The Steps run the tests script in the scripts object of your package.

title: React Native testing
body: Perform end-to-end testing with Detox, a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Bitrise offers a convenient device testing solution with Firebase Test Labs. You don't need your own Firebase account, nor do you need any complex configuration: you just need to build your iOS and Android apps for testing and then run the dedicated device testing Steps that runs your tests and can export them to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: The solution also works for multiplatform apps, such as Flutter and React Native apps.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for iOS: Build a test bundle from your .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file and run device tests on real devices on Firebase.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for Android: Build an APK and then run robo-, instrumented-, and gameloop tests with the device testing Step.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for multiplatform apps: Learn how to configure your multiplatform apps for device tests with Firebase.

title: Test Reports
body: The Test Reports add-on offers a convenient way to view and analyze all your test results. You can break down the results by test cases, or by the state of the test results. You can view screenshots and other test artifacts within the add-on.

title: Test Reports
body: Set up the Test Reports add-on for your apps by using the supported testing Steps and the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step.

title: Test Reports
body: Export test results from any testing Step either by using a custom Script Step or the dedicated Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step.

title: Testing iOS apps
body: Run UI and unit tests with Xcode using our Xcode Test for iOS Step. With this Step, you don't need code signing and you can easily export your test results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Testing iOS apps
body: Build an iOS app for testing with the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step. The Step uses the build-for-testing action of xcodebuild to build your test targets and exports the resulting bundle. You can use this bundle, for example, to perform device testing with Firebase.

title: Testing iOS apps
body: Build an iOS app for a simulator with the Xcode Build for Simulator Step. The Step builds an .app file that you can install on an iOS simulator. This requires no code signing, and as such it is a simple way to provide a testable app for your testers.

title: Testing iOS apps
body: You can easily run multiple tests in parallel with Pipelines: Currently supported use cases for the iOS platform.

In most cases, you don't need to change this input: when adding a new app, the project scanner automatically finds the relevant file and stores its location in the Environment Variable that is the default value of the input.

body: Headless mode

title: Running unit and UI tests for iOS apps
body: From Xcode 9 onwards, tests are run in headless mode by default: this means that the simulator will run in the background only. To change it, go to the Step’s Debug input group and set the Run the simulator in headless mode input’s value to no. However, with this option, tests will take more time.

title: Running unit and UI tests for iOS apps
body:
- xcode-test:
 inputs:
 - headless_mode: 'no'

title: Running unit and UI tests for iOS apps
body: The xcpretty output tool does not support parallel tests. If parallel tests are enabled in your project, go to the Step’s xcodebuild log formatting input group and set the Log formatter input’s value to xcodebuild or xcbeautify.

title: Running unit and UI tests for iOS apps
body:
- xcode-test:
 inputs:
 - log_formatter: xcbeautify

title: Rerunning failed tests (Not available in Xcode 13)
body: The Should retry test on failure? (Not available in Xcode 13+) input in the Test repetition section of the Xcode Test for iOS Step allows you to automatically rerun ALL your tests, not just the failed ones. If you set this input to yes, the Step will run xcodebuild one more time in the case of test failure.

title: Rerunning failed tests (Not available in Xcode 13)
body: From Xcode 13 and above, the feature is not available anymore. Use the Test Repetitions Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input with the retry_on_failure option selected. This allows you to rerun only the failed test/s instead of running all your tests. You can find this test repetition feature with our Xcode Test for iOS Step from version 3.0.0 and above.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Xcode’s test repetition modes are available with the Xcode Test for iOS Step on stacks running Xcode 13 and above on Bitrise. With test repetitions, you can run any type of tests multiple times in various ways such as retry on failure, until failure and until max repetitions.

title: Test Repetitions
body: The Xcode Test for iOS Step’s Test Repetitions Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input offers the following options:

title: Test Repetitions
body: none: The tests won’t repeat.

title: Test Repetitions
body: until_failure: Repeats a test until the test fails or until the maximum repetition. The default number of test runs is three.

title: Test Repetitions
body: retry_on_failure: Failed tests run until they succeed or until the repetition number you specify. The default number of test repetitions is three.

title: Test Repetitions
body: up_until_maximum_repetitions: Reruns all tests until maximum test repetition is reached regardless of the test outcomes.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Please note that these options are only available from Xcode Test for iOS version 3.0.0 and above.

title: Test Repetitions
body: With the Maximum Test Repetitions (Available in Xcode 13+) input you can specify the maximum number of test repetitions. Please note that you have to add a greater number than one if the Test Repetition Mode (Available in Xcode 13+) input is set to other than none.

title: Test Repetitions
body: Enable the Relaunch Tests for Each Repetition (Available in Xcode 13+) input to launch tests in a completely new process for each repetition.

title: Building an iOS app for testing
body: You can build an iOS app specifically for testing: our dedicated Step builds your app and its associated tests and also exports an .xctestrun file. Once built, you can upload the app to a third-party testing service or install it on a simulator or a physical device. You can also use this Step to set up virtual device testing with Firebase.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: You can build an iOS app for an iOS or tvOS simulator platform.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: To do this, you'll need the Xcode Build for Simulator Step. The Step creates an .app file which you can install on any macOS device or send to, for example, testers. This requires no code signing at all, so it is an easy way to create a distributable version of your iOS app.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step also creates an .xctestrun file which you can use to run tests. Both the .app file and the .xctestrun file can be accessed by subsequent Steps referring to their output variable, and they can be downloaded as a build artifact.

 steps:
 - generate-cordova-build-configuration@0: {}
 - xcode-build-for-test@2: {}
 - xcode-test@4: {}
 - xcode-build-for-simulator@0.12:
 inputs:
 - scheme: $BITRISE_SCHEME
 - destination: generic/platform=iOS Simulator
 - configuration: debug
 - xcconfig_content: |-
 CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=YES 
 COMPILER_INDEX_STORE_ENABLE = NO
 - project_path: $BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Enhanced Xcode reporting allows you to immediately view your Xcode test results in a rich HTML format. It will show both successful and failed test cases, as well as any videos and screenshots generated by the test.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Enhanced Xcode reporting allows you to immediately view your Xcode test results in a rich HTML format. It will show both successful and failed test cases, as well as any videos and screenshots generated by the test.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: To use it, your build needs to do two things:

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Run your Xcode tests and place the .xcresult file in the correct location. The Xcode Test for iOS and the Xcode Test for Building Steps do this by default and require no further configuration. You can also use other Steps, for example, fastlane, but you need to specify where Xcode should place the .xcresult file.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Run the Generate Xcode HTML report Step: it takes the .xcresult file and generates the report. If you use the Xcode Test for iOS Step to run your tests, this Step requires no configuration. When using other Steps, you have to manually set the location of your .xcresult file.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: We strongly recommend using the official Xcode Test for iOS Step to run your tests: this Step generates an .xcresult file and the Generate Xcode HTML report Step finds it without any additional configuration.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: To view the rich test results:

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Workflow Editor

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Add a Step that runs your Xcode tests to your Workflow.

body: We recommend using the Xcode Test for iOS Step

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Using our Xcode Test for iOS Step (as well as the Xcode Test without building Step) means you don't need any additional configuration to export your results.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: You can use other Steps to run your tests and then view the rich results afterwards. In that case, you have to make sure that the Step generates an .xcresult file and point the Generate Xcode HTML report Step to its location. For example, you can use the fastlane Step or your own Script Step.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: For more information on configuring the Step to run your Xcode tests, see Running unit and UI tests for iOS apps.

body: It should, of course, come after the Step that runs your tests.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: Make sure the Xcresult file paths input points to the location of your .xcresult files.

title: Viewing Xcode test results in rich HTML format
body: You can add multiple .xcresult files to this input, either by specifying one or more directories or by specifying filepaths, separated by a newline (/n). Each file will have its own report.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: You can register a test device easily by opening Safari on your iOS device and accessing the Test devices page from your Profile. With other browsers, you can manually register one using the Register device manually button.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: You have multiple options to register test devices on bitrise.io:

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: Open Safari on your iOS device and access the Test devices tab from your Profile settings page.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: Manually register a device from the Test devices tab from your Profile settings page.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: After registering your device on Bitrise, make sure to register it on the Apple Developer Portal as well. We recommend using the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step which can:

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: Register all available test devices of the app.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: Register a selection of test devices, defined in a text file that contains a list of their UDIDs.

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: Apple Developer Portal device limit

title: Registering test devices for iOS apps
body: There is a limit on registrable devices on the Apple Developer Portal, so make sure to check the list of available test devices of an app before you use the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step to register devices!

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: The most comfortable way to register your iOS test device on bitrise.io is to open bitrise.io with Safari. This way we can open your device’s Settings and create a temporary profile to get your Unique Device Identifier (UDID). This way you don’t have to look for it and manually copy/paste it.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Clear the cache

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: When trying to install an app from the public install page, you should clear the cache: click the link appearing in the If you synced your settings from your old device, you need to clear the cache and register your new device line. The link redirects to the Profile settings page where you can follow the procedure described below.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Read more about installing an app from the public install page in our Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io guide.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Open Safari in non-incognito mode on your iOS device and log into bitrise.io.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Go to your Profile.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Account Settings.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Test devices on the left.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Register this device.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: In the pop-up window, Tap Allow so that bitrise.io can show your configuration profile.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Install when the Install Profile dialog appears.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Enter your devices’s passcode.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Install on the Install Profile again. Now you can see your UDID and your iOS device name in the Register device dialog.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Tap Register device.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: Register this test device to the Apple Developer Portal with the correct provisioning profile added to your device or use our Auto Provisioning step with enabling profile generation.

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: If you go back to Test devices, you can see the registered device:

title: Register an iOS device using Safari
body: You can delete the registered device any time if you click on the Remove button.

title: Register a test device manually
body: On bitrise.io, open the account selector menu on the top right and select Profile settings.

title: Register a test device manually
body: On the menu on the left side, select Test devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Click on Register device manually.

title: Register a test device manually
body: In the Register device dialog, fill out the Title field and the Identifier field with your device’s UDID.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Click Register Devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: You can get your UDID if you plug your device into a computer, and open iTunes. Under Summary, you should see a Serial Number. If you click on it, it will reveal your device’s UDID which you can paste into the Identifier field on our Test Devices.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Register this test device to the Apple Developer Portal with the correct provisioning profile added to your device or use our Auto Provisioning Step with enabling profile generation.

title: Register a test device manually
body: Now you can see your registered test device under the Registered test devices section.

title: Register a test device manually
body: You can remove this registered device any time if you click the orange x icon.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: For any Bitrise app, you can check out the registered test devices available on the App Settings page. This will show an aggregated list of all registered test devices associated with users who have access to your app, regardless of their role. You can use any of those devices to run tests of your app.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: You can also download the list of registered devices as a .json file.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Open your project on Bitrise with a user that has the Admin role on the project.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: On the main page of the project, click on the Project settings button.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: On the menu on the left side, select Test devices.

title: Checking the available test devices for an app
body: Optionally, you can download the entire list as a .json file: click the Download as json button.

title: Registering devices on the Apple Developer Portal with the Xcode Archive Step
body: The Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step allows you to automatically register your test devices on the Apple Developer Portal. By default, the Step registers all test devices that you registered to your Bitrise account but you can configure it to only register a specific selection of devices.

title: Registering devices on the Apple Developer Portal with the Xcode Archive Step
body: Apple Developer Portal limit

title: Registering devices on the Apple Developer Portal with the Xcode Archive Step
body: Please note that the Apple Developer Portal has a limit for devices registered for testing purposes, typically set at 100 devices per account. Devices registered with the Xcode Archive & Export for iOS Step count towards this limit and you can only remove registered devices once a year.

title: Registering all devices on the Apple Developer Portal

title: Testing Android apps
body: Run unit tests, instrumented tests, and device tests for Android apps, using Bitrise's dedicated Android Steps. You can view your results in one location in the Test reports add-on.

title: Testing Android apps
body: Run unit tests for Android apps with our Android Unit Test Step. You can configure the Step to run tests on certain modules and variants, and you can pass additional arguments to the Gradle task running the tests. The Step can also export the test results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Testing Android apps
body: Run instrumented tests using the Android Build for UI Testing and the Android Instrumented Test Steps. The Steps generate and export an APK and a test APK and then run your instrumented tests using adb.

title: Testing Android apps
body: You can easily run multiple tests in parallel with Pipelines: Currently supported use cases for the Android platform.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: You can perform unit tests using the Android Unit Test Step, and view the results in the Test Reports Add-on.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Unit tests are useful if you want to verify individual code blocks, catch bugs or prevent crashes as early as possible. On Bitrise, you can run Android unit tests easily with the Android Unit Test Step. The Step finds and runs all unit tests included in the specified module and variant of your Android project.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The Step can also export the results directly to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Running multiple tests in parallel

title: Running Android unit tests
body: You can run multiple unit tests in parallel, for different devices or shards, by using the Pipelines feature: Currently supported use cases for the Android platform.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: To run your unit tests:

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running Android unit tests
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Make sure you included unit tests in your Android project.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Add the Android Unit Test Step to your Workflow.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Make sure the Project Location input points to the root directory of your Android project.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The root directory is the directory where your build.gradle file exists. If you configured your Android project automatically when adding it as an app on Bitrise, you don't have to change the default value.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: In the Module and Variant inputs, set the module and the variant you want to test. Leave the inputs blank to test all modules and/or variants.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: You can check the available modules and variants of your project in the Project window in Android Studio.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: In the Options input group, you can pass additional Gradle arguments to the build task in the Additional Gradle Arguments input.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: If you have custom output directories configured for the test results of the tests in your project, configure the Step to look for the test results in the correct location when exporting them:

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The Local unit test HTML result directory pattern input sets the directory for HTML test results.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The Local unit test XML result directory pattern input sets the directory for XML test results.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Both directories are zipped and exported to BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. This ensures that your test results can be viewed, for example, in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: If you don't have custom output directories configured, you do not need to change these inputs: the default values will work.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow to be able to view your test results in the Test reports add-on.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Make sure you included unit tests in your Android project.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Add the android-unit-test Step to your Workflow.

title: Running Android unit tests
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-unit-test:
 inputs:

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Make sure the project_location input points to the root directory of your Android project.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The root directory is the directory where your build.gradle file exists. If you configured your Android project automatically when adding it as an app on Bitrise, you don't have to change the default value.

title: Running Android unit tests
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-unit-test:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running Android unit tests
body: In the module and variant inputs, set the module and the variant you want to test. If you don't set these inputs, the Step will test all modules and/or variants.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: You can check the available modules and variants of your project in the Project window in Android Studio.

title: Running Android unit tests
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-unit-test:
 inputs:
 - module: app
 - variant: debug
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running Android unit tests
body: In the arguments input, you can pass additional Gradle arguments to the build task.

title: Running Android unit tests
body:

 - git-clone: {}
 - android-unit-test:
 inputs:
 - module: app
 - variant: debug
 - arguments: --task
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running Android unit tests
body: If you have custom output directories configured for the test results of the tests in your project, configure the Step to look for the test results in the correct location when exporting them:

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The report_path_pattern input sets the directory for HTML test results.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: The result_path_pattern input sets the directory for XML test results.

title: Running Android unit tests
body:

 - android-unit-test:

 - module: app

 - arguments: --task
 - report_path_pattern: '*build/reports/tests'
 - result_path_pattern: '*build/test-results'
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running Android unit tests
body: Both directories are zipped and exported to BITRISE_DEPLOY_DIR. This ensures that your test results can be viewed, for example, in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Running Android unit tests
body: If you don't have custom output directories configured, you do not need to change these inputs: the default values will work.

 - result_path_pattern: '*build/test-results'

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Instrumented tests run on Android devices, whether physical or emulated. On Bitrise, you can run instrumented tests using the adb tool.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Instrumented tests run on Android devices, whether physical or emulated. On Bitrise, you can run instrumented tests using the adb tool. To run your instrumented tests, you need two Steps in your Workflow:

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: The Android Build for UI testing Step builds both an APK and a test APK. For example, MyappDebug.apk and MyAppDebugAndroidTest.apk. The Step stores the path to these APKs in two output Environment Variables: BITRISE_APK_PATH and BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH. You can use these Env Vars to access the APKs in subsequent Steps in the same Workflow.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: The Android Instrumented Test Step runs the instrumented tests using the APKs built in the previous Step.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: To run instrumented tests for Android:

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Add the Android Build for UI testing Step to your Workflow.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Make sure the Project location input points to the root directory of your Android app.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Set the module and the variant you want to build in the Module and the Variant input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: You can check the available modules and variants of your project in the Project window in Android Studio.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: In the Options input group, you can set the location for the generated APK files in the APK location pattern input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: The input takes a file pattern as a value. The default value is */build/outputs/apk/*.apk.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Optionally, you can pass additional Gradle arguments to the build task in the Additional Gradle Arguments input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Add the Android Instrumented Test Step to the Workflow, at some point after the Android Build for UI testing Step.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Make sure that the Main APK path and the Test APK path inputs point to the correct location.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: By default, the values of the two inputs are the BITRISE_APK_PATH and the BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH Environment Variables, respectively. These variables are exported by the Android Build for UI testing Step. As such, in the vast majority of cases, you don't have to modify the value of these inputs.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: In the Test runner class input, specify the test runner you wish to use.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: The default runner is the AndroidJUnitRunner class.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Optionally, you can pass additional options to the test runner with the Additional testing options input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: With this input, you issue commands to the activity manager tool of the adb shell. For more information about the commands you can issue, see the official documentation for adb.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Add the android-build-for-ui-testing Step to your Workflow.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Make sure the project_location input points to the root directory of your Android app.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Set the module and the variant you want to build in the module and the variant input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: You can check the available modules and variants of your project in the Project window in Android Studio.

 - git-clone: {}
 - android-build-for-ui-testing:
 inputs:
 - module: app
 - variant: debug
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io: {}

 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Make sure that the main_apk_path and the test_apk_path inputs point to the correct location.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: By default, the values of the two inputs are the BITRISE_APK_PATH and the BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH Environment Variables, respectively. These variables are exported by the android-build-for-ui-testing Step. As such, in the vast majority of cases, you don't have to set the value of these inputs.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body:

 - git-clone: {}

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body:
steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-build-for-ui-testing:
 inputs:
 - arguments: flag

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: Optionally, you can pass additional options to the test runner with the additional_testing_options input.

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body: With this input, you issue commands to the activity manager tool of the adb shell. For more information about the commands you can issue, see the official documentation for adb. For example, the value KEY1 true KEY2 false will be passed to adb as adb shell am instrument -e "KEY1" "true" "KEY2" "false" [...].

title: Running instrumented tests for Android apps
body:
steps:

 - additional_testing_options: KEY1 true KEY2 false
 - main_apk_path: $BITRISE_APK_PATH
 - test_apk_path: $BITRISE_TEST_APK_PATH
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io: {}

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: On Bitrise, you can run lint checks with our dedicated Step called Android Lint. It runs the same lint function that is built into Android Studio. To perform lint checks, you don't need to write test cases or execute your app.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: Android Studio provides a code scanning tool called lint that can help you identify and correct problems with the structural quality of your code. When using Android Studio, configured lint checks run automatically when building your app. Lint checks don't require test cases.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: On Bitrise, you can run lint checks with our dedicated Step called Android Lint. To do so:

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: Add the Android Lint Step to your Android app's Workflow.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: It should come before any Step that builds your app (for example, Android Build), if you have such a Step in your Workflow.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: Make sure the Project Location input points to the root directory of your Android project, where the top level build.gradle file is located.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: In the Module and Variant inputs, specify the module and variant of the app you want to check.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: If you are unsure about the exact names of modules and variants in your project, you can check them in the Project view in Android Studio.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: In the Options input group, the Report location pattern input allows you to specify where the lint report should be found once the Step has run.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: The input accepts asterisks as a wildcard. You can set the input to return the results either as html or xml.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: In the Options input group, the Additional Gradle Arguments input allows you to pass arguments to the Gradle task.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: In the bitrise.yml file, add the android-lint Step to your Android app's Workflow.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: It should come before any Step that builds your app (for example, Android Build), if you have such a Step in your Workflow.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-lint:

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: Make sure the project_location input points to the root directory of your Android project, where the top level build.gradle or build.gradle.kts file is located.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-lint:
 inputs:
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: In the module and variant inputs, specify the module and variant of the app you want to check.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: If you are unsure about the exact names of modules and variants in your project, you can check them in the Project view in Android Studio.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-lint:
 inputs:
 - module: module
 - variant: variant
 - project_location: $BITRISE_SOURCE_DIR

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: The report_path_pattern input allows you to specify where the lint report should be found once the Step has run.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: The input accepts asterisks as a wildcard. You can set the input to return the results either as html or xml.

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body:
my-workflow:
 steps:
 - git-clone: {}
 - android-lint:
 inputs:
 - module: module
 - variant: variant
 - report_path_pattern: '*/build/reports/lint-results*.xml'

title: Running lint checks for your Android apps
body: The argument input allows you to pass arguments to the Gradle task.

title: Testing Flutter apps
body: Run unit and UI tests for Flutter apps with the Flutter Test Step. The Step simply runs the flutter test command on your app: you can configure it to run only specific tests or to run all tests it can find. You can also export the results to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Testing Flutter apps
body: Perform static code analysis with the Dart analyzer: our Flutter Analyze Step runs the flutter analyze command with the required fail severity and the additional parameters you wish to append to it.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: The Flutter Test Step allows you to run unit tests, widget tests, and integration (also referred to as end-to-end or UI testing) tests on your Flutter app on Bitrise. The Step runs the flutter test command and saves the json file that is generated by the command. You can then view the test results in the Test Reports add-on at any time.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Code coverage

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: The Flutter Test Step can also generate code coverage reports.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: To run tests using Flutter Test:

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Include tests in your Flutter project.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: For more information on how to write tests and include them in your Flutter project, check the official Flutter documentation: Testing Flutter apps.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Add the Flutter Install Step to your Workflow.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: This Step runs the initial setup of the Flutter SDK and installs any missing components.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Make sure that the Flutter Install Step installs the correct version of the Flutter SDK for your app: check the Flutter SDK Git repository version input.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: The input's default value is stable, which installs the latest stable version of the SDK. You can, however, set the value to either a specific version tag or a branch label:

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: You can find the available version tags here: Version tags.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: You can find the available branch labels here: Branch labels.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Installation bundle URL

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: You can also install the Flutter SDK from an installation bundle URL: you just need to specify the URL in the Flutter SDK installation bundle URL input. Please note that if you do so, the Flutter SDK Git repository version input will be ignored entirely!

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Add the Flutter Test Step to your Workflow. It should be after the Flutter Install Step.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: The Step runs the flutter test command with optional flags. It can also check code coverage.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: Make sure the Project Location input points to the root directory of your Flutter project.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: If the project scanner automatically detected it as a Flutter project when adding it as an app on Bitrise, you don't have to change the default value.

title: Running unit and UI tests on Flutter apps
body: If you configured the app manually, check that the location is correct. You can do so by going to the Env Vars tab on the Workflow Editor, and checking the BITRISE_FLUTTER_PROJECT_LOCATION Environment Variable.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: You can perform static analysis of your Flutter code with the Dart analyzer by using the Flutter Analyze Step on Bitrise. The Step runs the flutter analyze command that makes heavy use of type annotations that you put in your code to help track problems down.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: Set the Fail Severity input to the desired level.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: The input determines the minimum severity to fail the Step. Any issue with a severity at least as high as the specified fails the Step. It has three possible settings, from minimum to maximum severity:

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: info: When this setting is selected, info-, warning-, and error-level issues all fail the Step.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: warning: When this setting is selected, only warning- and error-level issues fail the Step.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: error: This is the default value. Only error-level issues fail the Step.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: Optionally, add additional flag to the flutter analyze command in the Additional Parameters input.

title: Running the Dart analyzer on Bitrise
body: For a list of available flags, run flutter help analyze. For example, you can use the --no-congratulate flag if you don't want to see any output if there are no errors, warnings, hints or lints.

title: Testing React Native apps
body: Run unit and UI tests for React Native apps by either npm test or yarn test. The Steps run the tests script in the scripts object of your package.

title: Testing React Native apps
body: Perform end-to-end testing with Detox, a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native.

title: Testing React Native apps
body: You can also use Bitrise's device testing solution, using Firebase Test Labs, to run device tests on both the iOS and Android apps of a React Native project: Running device tests with Firebase for multiplatform apps.

title: Running tests for React Native apps
body: You can run all kinds of tests for your React Native app on Bitrise: unit tests, integration tests, or component tests. You can use Jest, for example, to write all your tests and then run them during the build process with either npm or Yarn.

title: Running Detox tests on Bitrise
body: Detox is a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native. If you have a React Native app on Bitrise, you can run Detox tests.

title: Running Detox tests on Bitrise
body: Detox is a gray box end-to-end tests and automation library for mobile apps built with React Native. It supports both iOS and Android apps. If you have a React Native app on Bitrise, you can run Detox tests.

title: Before you start
body: Running Detox requires:

title: Before you start
body: A Mac with a macOS (El Capitan 10.11 or newer version).

title: Before you start
body: Xcode 8.3 or newer version with Xcode command line tools.

title: Before you start
body: A working React Native app.

title: Before you start
body: Install and set up Detox for your project. You will need to install Homebrew, Node.js and applesimutils, as well as the Detox command line tools. Add Detox to your project and then create and run Detox tests locally. If you have an Android app, go through this guide after the initial setup process.

title: Before you start
body: Once you are done, you can test your Detox-configured project on Bitrise.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Create a release device configuration either in the package.json file under the detox section, or in a separate Detox configuration file. For more information on setting up a Detox configuration, check out the documentation: Project setup.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Example:

title: Running a Detox test
Running a Detox test
body: On bitrise.io, go to your project and open the Workflow Editor.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Switch to the Workflow you want to use.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Add a Run npm command Step to your Workflow.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Install the Detox CLI and the React Native CLI using the npm command with arguments to run input:

title: Running a Detox test
body:
install -g detox-cli
install -g react-native-cli

title: Running a Detox test
body: Install a test runner.

title: Running a Detox test
body: For example, our sample app uses mocha, installed with the yarn Step. To install yarn dependencies, just set the The yarn command to run input’s value to install.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Add a Script Step to install the necessary utilities and then run Detox.

title: Running a Detox test
body:
#!/bin/bash
 
# applesimutils is a collection of utils for Apple simulators
brew tap wix/brew
brew install applesimutils
 
# we are building and testing a release device configuration
detox build --configuration ios.sim.release
detox test --configuration ios.sim.release --cleanup

title: Running a Detox test
body: You can, of course, put each of these commands in separate Script Steps, for the sake of modularity.

title: Running a Detox test
body: Run a build.

title: Running a Detox test
body: If the build fails, check out our example bitrise.yml file:

title: Running a Detox test
body:
---
workflows:
 primary:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key: {}
 - git-clone:
 inputs:
 - clone_depth: ''
 title: Git Clone Repo
 - yarn@0.0.8:
 inputs:
 - command: install
 - npm@1.0.1:
 inputs:
 - command: install -g detox-cli
 title: Install Detox CLI
 - script@1.1.5:
 inputs:
 - content: |-
 #!/bin/bash
 brew tap wix/brew
 brew install applesimutils
 
 detox build --configuration ios.sim.release
 detox test --configuration ios.sim.release --cleanup
 title: Detox - Build and Test Release App
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1.3.18: {}

title: Troubleshooting Detox tests
