title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Bitrise offers a convenient device testing solution with Firebase Test Labs. You don't need your own Firebase account: you just need to build your iOS and Android apps for testing and then run the dedicated device testing Steps that runs your tests and can export them to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Bitrise offers a convenient device testing solution with Firebase Test Labs. You don't need your own Firebase account, nor do you need any complex configuration: you just need to build your iOS and Android apps for testing and then run the dedicated device testing Steps that runs your tests and can export them to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: The solution also works for multiplatform projects, such as Flutter and React Native.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for iOS: Build a test bundle from your .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file and run device tests on real devices on Firebase.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for Android: Build an APK and then run robo-, instrumented-, and gameloop tests with the device testing Step.

title: Device testing with Firebase
body: Device testing for multiplatform apps: Learn how to configure your multiplatform apps for device tests with Firebase.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: With Bitrise’s iOS device testing solution, you can run iOS tests on physical devices without having to set up and register your own devices.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: With Bitrise’s iOS device testing solution, you can run UI tests for iOS apps on physical devices without having to set up and register your own devices: you just need to use our dedicated Steps and set the device type(s) on which you want to test your app. There are no limits to using the Step, other than your overall build time limit. It also works for iOS apps developed using other frameworks, such as Flutter or React Native.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: Our device testing solution is based on Firebase Test Lab: it uses real, production devices running in a Google data center to test your app. The devices are flashed with updated APIs and have customizable locale settings. You can find the resulting logs, videos and screenshots on Bitrise.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: For iOS apps, Firebase Test Lab runs XCTest tests. Find the list of the available devices here.

title: Device testing for iOS
body: Limitations

title: Device testing for iOS
body: You might be limited by your overall build time. Also note that a single build can contain only one iOS Device Testing Step, performing one type of test. This is because Bitrise sends the build slug to Firebase Test Lab. Sending the same build slug results in a Build already existserror.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: To run device tests for iOS apps with the Firebase Test Lab solution, you will need to add two Steps to your Workflow:

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Xcode Build for testing for iOS.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: iOS Device Testing.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Multiplatform apps

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The Step can run device tests for iOS apps built with other frameworks, such as Flutter or React Native. You just need to make sure the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step can access your app's .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step performs the xcodebuild command’s build-for-testing action: it builds the tests defined in your iOS app’s Xcode scheme. The Step exports a .zip file that contains your test directory (by default, it’s Debug-iphoneos) and the xctestrun file.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: To use this Step, you will need code signing files for the test app. You can choose between using automatic provisioning and manual provisioning.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The iOS Device Testing Step takes the path to this .zip file - exported as an Environment Variable - as input to run your tests and export the test results to Bitrise.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Automatic vs manual code signing asset management

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step can manage your code signing assets without you having to manually manage your provisioning profiles. This only requires you to select the relevant inputs in the Step (see below) and upload the right certificates to the Code Signing tab. This is the automatic code signing asset management method.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: If you decide to chose the manual code signing asset management, then add the Certificate and Profile Installer Step before the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step. The former will take care of the code signing asset management while the latter builds your project. Make sure the Automatic code signing method input of the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step is set to off.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The instructions below detail the steps of setting up automatic code signing asset management on Bitrise with the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Workflow Editor

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: bitrise.yml

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Add the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step to your Workflow.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Build for testing

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: This guide only mentions the most important inputs for setting up an app for device testing. For more information about the Step, see Xcode Build for testing for iOS.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: In the Scheme name input, set the Xcode Scheme you want to use. By default, the value of the input is the $BITRISE_SCHEME Environment Variable which is stored when your app is created.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: In the Build Configuration input, add the name of the Xcode build configuration you want to use.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: If no configuration is specified, the Xcode project's default build configuration will be used.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Set a destination option for xcodebuild in the Device destination specifier input of the Step.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The default value is generic/platform=ios: this means the tests can be run on any iOS device.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Set the Automatic code signing method input to the Apple service connection you want to use for code signing. The available options are:

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: off if you don’t do automatic code signing.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: api-key if you use API key authorization.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: apple-idif you use Apple ID authorization.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: Add the iOS Device Testing Step to the Workflow.The Step has to come after the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step.

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: API setting inputs

title: Running device tests with Firebase for iOS apps
body: The inputs related to the Test API (Test API's base URL and API token cannot be changed on the graphical UI. You should not attempt to modify their values.

title: Device testing for Android

body: With Bitrise’s Android virtual device testing solution, you can run UI tests on emulators without having to set up and register your own devices.

title: Device testing for Android
body: Limitations

title: Device testing for Android
body: The maximum duration for virtual device testing is 30 minutes.

title: Device testing for Android
body: A single build can contain only one Virtual Device Testing Step performing one type of test (instrumentation, robo or gameloop).

title: Device testing for Android
body: Our device testing solution is based on Firebase Test Lab. You can find the resulting logs, videos and screenshots on Bitrise.

title: Running tests
body: With Bitrise, you can choose from 3 different test types:

title: Running tests
body: If you want to read up on the difference between these test types, take a look at Firebase’s documentation.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: If your app needs specific user interaction for a successful robo test, you can use the Robo Directives input field to set those necessary inputs. For example, certain UI elements of the app are only accessible for robo testing if the required user inputs (username and email address) are populated for log in.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Click the Virtual Device Testing for Android Step in your workflow.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Click the Robo Test section.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Find the Robo directives input field and set your required user input directives.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: provide a comma-separated list of key-value pairs, where the key is the Android resource name of the target UI element, and the value is the text string. EditText fields are supported but not text fields in WebView UI elements. For example, you could use the following parameter for custom login:

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body:
username_resource,username,ENTER_TEXT
password_resource,password,ENTER_TEXT
loginbtn_resource,,SINGLE_CLICK

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: One directive per line, the parameters are separated with , character. For example: ResourceName,InputText,ActionType.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Based on the input you provide, you can successfully run a robo test (even on pages that are only accessible with a specific user input) and check the test results on the Test Reports page. The test results can be, for example:

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Screenshots.

body: Recorded video.

body: Logs.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Files.

title: Setting user input with Robo directives for successful robo tests
body: Here is a screenshot of a successful robo test, where the robo test got all the way through to My application by populating the email and password fields first with the pre-defined directives from the Robo directives.

title: Testing the iOS app
body: Add tests using the XCTest framework to the iOS app of the project.

title: Testing the iOS app
body: Build your app for testing with the Xcode Build for testing for iOS Step.

title: Testing the iOS app
body: Make sure that the Project path input of the Step points to the .xcodeproj or .xcworkspace file of your project. You can find these in the iOS folder. If you used automatic configuration to add your React Native app to Bitrise, you don't need to modify the default value of the input ($BITRISE_PROJECT_PATH.

title: Testing the Android app
body: You can run robo-, instrumentation- and gameloop tests using the Virtual Device Testing for Android Step. However, one instance of the Step can only run one type of test. If you need to run multiple test types, you need multiple instances of the Step.

title: Test Reports
body: You can run both UI tests and unit tests on Bitrise. You can view them in Test Reports, which you can access from the Add-ons section on the Build Details page.

title: Test Reports
body: Test Reports allows you to view all your test results in a convenient way.

title: Test Reports
body: Use our testing Steps, and all your test results will be deployed to the same directory. From there, Test Reports can process and display them in a way that’s easy to read and analyze.

title: Test reports overview
body: You can run both UI tests and unit tests on Bitrise and with Test Reports, you can view the results of the different test types on the same page.

title: Test reports overview
body: To be able to use Test Reports, you need to make sure your test results end up in the correct directory and in the correct format. From that directory, the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step exports the results to the add-on.

title: Test reports overview
body: There are three ways to make sure your test results end up in the correct location and in the appropriate format:

title: Test reports overview
body: Using our dedicated testing Steps that automatically export their results. With these Steps, all you need to do is put both the testing Step and the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to the Workflow and run the build.

title: Test reports overview
body: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step.

title: Test reports overview
body: Using a custom Script Step.

title: Test reports overview
body: Exporting the results from any testing Step

title: Test reports overview
body: Both the second and the third method allows you to export test results from any Step. Read the details in our Exporting to Test Reports from any Step guide.

title: Test reports overview
body: Test Reports can read and display test results that are in either of two formats:

title: Test reports overview
body: You can use Test Reports with five of our testing Steps by default. These Steps will run the tests defined in your repository and then store the output in an Environment Variable. The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will do the rest: it can read the results and send it to Test Reports. The Steps are:

title: Test reports overview
body: Xcode Test for iOS.

title: Test reports overview
body: Android Unit Test.

title: Test reports overview
body: iOS Device Testing.

title: Test reports overview
body: Virtual Device Testing for Android.

title: Test reports overview
body: Flutter Test.

title: Test reports overview
body: With these Steps, you don't have to worry about the format or the location of the test results. All you need to make sure is that you include the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step at the end of your Workflow.

title: Test reports overview
body: Testing guides

title: Test reports overview
body: Check out our testing guides to read more about how to use these Steps on Bitrise:

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Test Reports doesn’t require any sort of complicated configuration. All you need is to have tests in your repository, and two Steps in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Deploy to Bitrise.io version

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step must be of version 1.4.1 or newer - older versions of the Step do NOT support Test Reports. We recommend using version 1.5.0 or higher for the best experience.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Add tests to your app’s repository.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Add the appropriate testing Steps to your Workflow. For example, if you have an Android project, you can use the Android Unit Test Step to run Android unit tests.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Make sure you have the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: Run your build.

title: Configuring Test Reports
body: And that’s it! Once the build is finished, you will be able to view your test reports.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: You can export Test Reports from any Step using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step. Alternatively, you could configure your own Script Step to export the files.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Test Reports allows you to view all your test results in a convenient way. By default, five Steps support the Test Reports add-on:

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Xcode Test for iOS

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: Android Unit Test

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: To export the test results generated by any other Step to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step, you have two options:

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: We recommend using our Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step: this Step locates the test results based on your inputs. However, this Step cannot export screenshots or other images.

title: Exporting to Test Reports from any Step
body: You can configure your own custom Script Step that creates and exports the necessary files. If you need screenshots or other images, you need to export both the test results and the images in the same Script Step.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: You can use the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step to make sure your test results appear in the Test Reports add-on, even if you use Steps that don’t automatically export their results.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: With the correct configuration, the Step finds the test results in your app’s repository, and puts them in the export directory.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Screenshots and other images

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: The Step can only export test results, in either .xcresult or JUnit XML format. If your test results are in an .xcresult file, screenshots generated as part of the test are included and exported to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If you use the JUnit XML format, you need to export screenshots and other images using a Script Step: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports. In this case, the test results themselves must be exported using the same Script Step. You cannot export screenshots and test results in separate Steps!

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Go to your app’s page on bitrise.io.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Go to Workflows to open the Workflow Editor.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: From the WORKFLOW menu, select the Workflow you use to run your tests.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Add the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step AFTER the testing Step.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the The name of the test input, set the name of the test run. The test results will be under this name in the Test Reports add-on.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Path where custom test results reside input, set the path where your test results can be found.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: We recommend setting a folder here, though you can also set a specific filepath. The default value is the source directory of your app. Example patterns:

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If your app’s root directory is app: app/build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If your test results are within an app folder but app is not the root directory: ./app/build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Test result search pattern input, set a pattern that matches your test result file.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: This search pattern is used to search every file and folder of the path that was set in the Path where custom test results reside input.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: If there is more than one match, the Step will export the first match with a warning in the logs. If you set a specific filepath in the previous input, just set * here.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Example patterns:

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Matching all files within the base path: *

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Matching all files within a given directory of the base path: */build/test-results/testDemoDebugUnitTest/*

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: In the Step’s test result directory input, make sure the path is correct.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Do NOT modify this input’s value: this is the folder where the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will look for the test results to export them. It should be set to the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR Env Var.

title: Using the Export test results to the Test reports add-on Step
body: Make sure you have a Deploy to Bitrise.io Step in your Workflow.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: You can use your own scripts in a Script Step to export your test results. You just need to make sure that:

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: Your test results are in a JUnit XML format.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: You place the results in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR, which is an Environment Variable pointing to the correct path.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The results of each test run should be in its own sub-directory. You place a test-info.json file in each sub-directory to correspond to the test run.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The test-info.json file

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: The test-info.json file must have the name of the test run defined in it. Each test run should have its own test-info.json file. The value of test-name will appear as the name of the test run on the Test Reports page.

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: // Test Name ... { "test-name":"My first test" }

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: Here’s an example script to export your test results:

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body:
#!/bin/env bash
set -ex

# Creating a sub-directory for the test run within the BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR:

test_run_dir="$BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR/result_dir_1"
mkdir "$test_run_dir"

# Exporting the JUnit XML test report:

cp "MY/TEST/REPORT/XML/FILE/PATH.xml" "$test_run_dir/UnitTest.xml"

# Creating the test-info.json file with the name of the test run defined:

echo '{"test-name":"MY TEST RUN NAME"}' >> "$test_run_dir/test-info.json"

title: Using custom scripts to export test results
body: If all goes well, you should be able to see your test results on the Test Reports page.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step can only export test result files to the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step which supports two formats for results:

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The .xcresult file for iOS apps.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: A JUnit XML file for any app.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: If your tests produce an .xcresult file, screenshots generated during the test run are part of the test result. As such, they will be exported to the Test Reports add-on.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: If you use the JUnit XML format and want to export screenshots or other images, you cannot use the Export test results to Test Reports add-on Step.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: You need to use a custom script to export both the result and the screenshots. The script to export both must be in the same Script Step, and you must have a test-info.json file with the necessary information about the test runs: Using custom scripts to export test results.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: To export screenshots with the results, the script must place the images in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR folder.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Folder structure

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: The image files themselves must be in the $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR folder. They can't be nested in another folder within $BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR.

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Script to export an image

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body:
#!/bin/env bash
set -ex

# Creating a sub-directory for the test run within the BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR:

test_run_dir="$BITRISE_TEST_RESULT_DIR/result_dir_1"
mkdir "$test_run_dir"

# copying the image:

cp "MY/TEST/SCREENSHOTS/screenshot.png" "$test_run_dir/screenshot.png"

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: Associating images with test runs

title: Exporting screenshots and other images to Test Reports
body: You can associate an image with a specific test run by placing the image in the directory of that test run. In that case, the image will appear under all test suits of the given test run.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Codecov is the leading code coverage solution for CI/CD pipelines, delivering coverage metrics right into your workflow. It integrates directly with Bitrise to provide valuable insights on code quality in order to allow users to ship healthier code with less risk.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Codecov provides many features that make test coverage more available and actionable to speed up your development process and to deliver high-quality applications.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Some of these features include:

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Coverage changes overlaid with your source code, making it even easier to identify needed test areas.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Multi-language support so you can use Codecov right out of the box.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Summary of coverage information directly in your Workflow so that you can add and update tests quickly and effectively.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Status checks to block underperforming pull requests from being merged.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Seamless coverage report merging for Workflows that upload multiple reports across jobs.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
body: Custom coverage information based on groupings using Codecov Flags.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: In order to start using Codecov, you must be generating coverage reports with your preferred coverage tool (for example, Xcode or Gradle).

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Create an account on https://codecov.io.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Go to repository’s Settings tab on Codecov and copy the repository upload token.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Add the Codecov Step to your Workflow on Bitrise. Make sure you add the Step after the Steps that test and collect coverage.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Add the Codecov upload token as a secret variable, CODECOV_TOKEN, and set the Expose for Pull Requests option to true. Click Add new.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Click Save and start a new build to get coverage metrics.

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: Additional options

title: Integrating Codecov with Bitrise
body: The Codecov Step wraps around the Codecov bash uploader. You can add additional options in the Step listed in our arguments documentation.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: To view your coverage on Codecov, you can do the following:

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: View the URL supplied on the Codecov Step on Bitrise.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: Go to https://codecov.io and navigate directly to the applicable pull request or commit.

title: Viewing your coverage reports on Codecov
body: Click on the links provided by Codecov that are available on your code host’s status checks or pull request comment.

title: What's next?
body: Now that you have code coverage reports, you can take it to the next level with the following suggestions:

title: What's next?
body: Set non-blocking status checks to get your developers in the habit of thinking about code coverage.

title: What's next?
body: Start working towards code coverage by setting status checks to increase overall coverage on every pull request.

title: What's next?
body: Isolate your coverage reports for different types of tests or different parts of your system with Flags to measure what matters.

title: What's next?
body: Already using flags and don’t want to run your entire test suite with every Bitrise CI run? Try out Carryforward Flags to measure only what changes.

title: Measuring your code coverage with Codecov
Deploying
body: Deploy your apps to simulators, test devices, or app stores with the help of Bitrise. You can use our Steps or Ship, our dedicated deployment solution.

title: Deploying
body: Release Management

title: Deploying
body: This section is about deploying apps via Bitrise Steps. For a more granular and fully customisable app release process, we recommend using Release Management.

title: Deploying
body: Deploying an app on Bitrise means generating an installable binary and then either:

title: Deploying
body: Install it on test devices.

title: Deploying
body: Upload it to bitrise.io.

title: Deploying
body: Deploy it to a simulator.

title: Deploying
body: Upload it to online stores.

title: Deploying Android apps
body: Deploying Android apps means deploying an APK or AAB file to an online store. Any deployment solutions covered in these sections also cover apps developed with other frameworks, such as React Native or Flutter, that can produce APK or AAB files.

title: Deploying Android apps
body: Deploying Android apps generally requires a Google service account which you can upload to Bitrise.

title: Deploying iOS apps
body: Deploying Android apps means installing an IPA file on test devices or deploying an IPA file to an online store. Any deployment solutions covered in these sections also cover apps developed with other frameworks, such as React Native or Flutter, that can produce IPA files.

title: Deploying iOS apps
body: Deploying Android apps generally requires an Apple service connection on Bitrise.

title: Android deployment
body: Deploy Android apps to either bitrise.io, for testing, or to the Google Play Store, for release.

title: Android deployment
body: Deploy Android apps to either bitrise.io, for testing, or to the Google Play Store, for release. Learn about Google Play API, keystore files and APK flavors.

title: Android deployment
body: We also recommend checking out Release Management: it simplifies distributing your iOS and Android apps to testers or directly to app stores—all from one platform, from the CI you choose.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Bitrise or to Google Play by using our dedicated Steps and correctly configuring your project in Google Play Console.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: This guide describes how you can add your Android project to bitrise.io and deploy the APK or AAB built from your project to Google Play Store.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: You need a new service account created in the Google Play Console so that Bitrise can authenticate with Google Play Deploy during your build. The new service account has to be invited to Google Play Console as a user with the appropriate permission.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: To set up your project for the first time:

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: Register a Google Play Developer Account. If you already have a Google Play Developer account, and have already deployed your app to Google Play Store, skip to Setting up Google Play API access.

title: Deploying Android apps to Bitrise and Google Play
body: Go through Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Grant the Google Play API access to your project by creating a service account and granting the necessary user permissions to the service account.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Turn on the Google Play Developer API for your project: Enable the API.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Create a service account on Google Cloud Platform: Create service accounts.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Create a new JSON key for the service account: Create and delete service account keys.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Instant download

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: When you click Create at the end of the process, the service account JSON key is automatically downloaded. Make sure to save it as you cannot access or download it again!

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Invite your service account user on the Users & Permissions page in Google Play Console and grant the necessary permissions to be able to access and release apps on Google Play: Use a service account.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: Check out the Google Play Developer API guide if you need more information on the process.

title: Setting up Google Play API access
body: You have successfully prepared your Google Play Console project. A services credential account has been created which is authorized to manage your releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Connect your Google service account to Bitrise.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: In this section, we'll go through how to deploy your Android project to bitrise.io.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Deploying to bitrise.io means that the build artifacts generated during the build will be available for download once the build is finished. You can use this to test your Android app on your own test devices, for example.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: To deploy your app to bitrise.io:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Workflow Editor

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: bitrise.yml

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure your Workflow contains the Android Build Step to build your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, you can build your app with the Gradle Runner Step. This requires a bit more configuration from you but allows for more extensive customization.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Notifying other users

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can use the Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs of the Step to set up notifications about your deploy. Click the input names to reveal more information about how to configure them.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, set the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step to true so the Step enables the public install page for your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Run a build.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Open the bitrise.yml file of your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Make sure your Workflow contains the android-build Step to build your app.

workflows:
 example-workflow:

 - android-build@1:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, you can build your app with the gradle-runner Step. This requires a bit more configuration from you but allows for more extensive customization.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Set the module and/or variant input to tell the Step what to build.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io

body:
workflows:
 example-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build@1:

 - variant: debug
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io: {}

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Add the deploy-to-bitrise-io Step to your Workflow.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body:
workflows:
 example-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build@1:

 - variant: debug
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io: {}

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Notifying other users

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: You can use the notify_user_groups and the notify_email_list inputs of the Step to set up notifications about your deploy:

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: The notify_user_groups input allows you to send notifications based on the access roles granted to users. For example, you can set the input to notify everyone with an Admin and a Developer role. Set multiple roles separated by a comma: - notify_user_groups: admins, testers.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: The notify_email_list input only accepts Secrets, and the Secret should contain comma-separated lists of email addresses.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Optionally, set the Enable public page for the App? input of the Step to true so the Step enables the public install page for your app.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: Run a build.

title: Deploying an Android app to bitrise.io
body: The Deploy to Bitrise.io Step will deploy the app. You can share the generated binary with your team members using the build’s URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Deploying to Google Play requires a signed APK or AAB file and the Google Play Deploy Step.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Workflow Editor

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: bitrise.yml

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly and that you uploaded your service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Uploading the service account JSON key file

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: We recommend uploading the service account JSON key to Bitrise but it is not mandatory: you can store it elsewhere and provide a direct link to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open the App settings page, and select Code Signing.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: On the Android tab, find the uploaded service account JSON key and copy the secret Env Var under its name.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For example, BITRISEIO_SERVICE_ACCOUNT_JSON_KEY_URL.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your Workflow and add the Google Play Deploy Step to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Service Account JSON key file path input, paste the Environment Variable you copied.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Direct path to the service account JSON key file

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you don't want to upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise, you can also add a file path right in the Step’s input field where the file path can be local or remote too:

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For a remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For a local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Package name input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the Track input, add the track where you want to deploy your APK (for example, alpha/beta/rollout/production or any custom track you set).

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you're trying to deploy your app for the first time, make sure your Google Play configuration is set up correctly and that you uploaded your service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Uploading the service account JSON key file

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: We recommend uploading the service account JSON key to Bitrise but it is not mandatory: you can store it elsewhere and provide a direct link to it.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: Open your app's bitrise.yml file and add the google-play-deploy Step to it.

body: In the service_account_json_key_path input, you need to provide the path to the service account JSON key file.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you uploaded the file to Bitrise, you can find the Env Var storing its download URL in the Generic File Storage in the Workflow Editor.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: If you didn't upload your service account JSON key to Bitrise, you can set a direct path in the input. The file path can point to a local or a remote location.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For a remote JSON key file you can provide any download location as value, for example, https://URL/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: For a local JSON key file you can provide a file path url as value, for example, file://PATH/TO/key.json.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body: In the package input, add the package name of your app.

title: Deploying to Google Play
body:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Huawei AppGallery via a verified Bitrise Step called Deploy to Huawei App Gallery. The Step can be used to deploy any APK file that you build on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: You can deploy your Android apps to Huawei AppGallery via a verified Bitrise Step called Deploy to Huawei App Gallery. The Step can be used to deploy any APK file that you build on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: The Step will need:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: To successfully deploy your app to Huawei AppGallery, you need a Workflow that:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Builds and signs an APK or AAB file.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Includes the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step to deploy the app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: To configure deploying with the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step:

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Manually upload the first APK of the app to Huawei AppGallery using the website interface on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Create a team-level API client on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Open the Workflow Editor on Bitrise.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Go to the Workflow that you want to use for deploying the app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Add the Deploy to Huawei App Gallery Step after the Steps that build and sign your APK.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Open the Config input group.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Fill in the required inputs.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: File path: If you used a Step that automatically exports the BITRISE_APK_PATH Environment Variable after building your APK, leave this unchanged. The Android Build Step is such a Step, for example.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: File name: The unique name of the APK file. This name will be used when uploading to the AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: App ID: The identified can be found in the App information section on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Client ID: The API client ID generated on AppGallery Connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Key: The key generated with the API client on AppGallery connect.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Take a look at the following bitrise.yml file to see an example configuration that uses the Deploy to Huawei AppGallery Step to deploy an app.

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body:
workflows:
 deploy:
 steps:
 - activate-ssh-key@4:
 run_if: '{{getenv "SSH_RSA_PRIVATE_KEY" | ne ""}}'
 - git-clone@4: {}
 - cache-pull@2: {}
 - install-missing-android-tools@2:
 inputs:
 - gradlew_path: "$PROJECT_LOCATION/gradlew"
 - gradle-runner@1.9:
 inputs:
 - gradle_file: "$GRADLE_BUILD_FILE_PATH"
 - gradle_task: assembleRelease
 - gradlew_path: "$GRADLEW_PATH"
 - sign-apk@1.7: {}
 - deploy-to-bitrise-io@1: {}
 - cache-push@2: {}
 - appgallery-deploy@0:
 inputs:
 - huawei_client_id: 'XXX'
 - huawei_client_secret: "$CLIENT_SECRET"
 - huawei_app_id: 'YYY'

title: Deploying apps to Huawei AppGallery
body: Run a build! If all goes well, you should see your app on Huawei AppGallery.

title: Generate and deploy multiple flavor APKs in a single Workflow
body: You can generate, code sign and deploy multiple flavor (multi-flavor) APKs/AABs in one workflow using our Gradle Runner Step.

title: Generate and deploy multiple flavor APKs in a single Workflow
body: You can generate, code sign and deploy multiple flavor (multi-flavor) APKs/AABs in one Workflow using our Gradle Runner Step. Flavor means enhancing an app’s core code with features resulting in different versions of the same app (just to mention the most common examples: free/paid, demo/full). Check out the official Android Studio guide on build types, flavors and build variants for more info! In this tutorial, you will need to do some settings to Android Sign and Google Play Deploy Steps - so keep your eyes peeled!

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: To generate APK files for several different flavors:

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Insert Gradle Runner Step after the Android testing Steps. Android Build Step can only build one variant so if this Step is part of your Workflow, then we advise you to replace it with our Gradle Runner Step.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Config section of the Step.

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Specify assemble Gradle tasks by adding your build variants’ task names in the Gradle task to run Step input field - as many task names as many build variants you want to build in one workflow. Each task name must be exactly the same build variant name what you have listed in the Build Variant window of Android Studio! Make sure you separate them only with a space, no need for a comma ! In this image, you can see the order of the Steps for the deploy workflow and the Gradle Task to run Step input with two build variants:

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: assembleDemo and assembleFull (for APKs) or bundleDemo and bundleFull (for AABs)

title: Generating multi-flavor APKs
body: Gradle Runner generates a $BITRISE_APK_PATH_LIST / $BITRISE_AAB_PATH_LIST Environment Variable output that contains APKs/AABs built for ALL build variants defined above. We will need this output Environment Variable later.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Add one Android Sign Step AFTER the Gradle Runner Step if it’s missing from your Workflow.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Set the App file path input to $BITRISE_APK_PATH_LIST or $BITRISE_AAB_PATH_LIST depending on which app format you built in the previous Gradle Runner Step.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: This will make sure all APKs or AABs get code signed with the keystore file you uploaded to the Code Signing tab. The Step will export either the $BITRISE_SIGNED_APK_PATH_LIST or the $BITRISE_SIGNED_AAB_PATH_LIST Environment Variable output which contains the path of the signed app files for each build variant.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Make sure you set the following input fields in the Android Sign Step:

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore url

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore password

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Keystore alias

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Add the Google Play Deploy Step AFTER the Android Sign Step.

title: Signing and deploying multi-flavor APKs
body: Set the $BITRISE_SIGNED_APK_PATH or the $BITRISE_SIGNED_AAB_PATH Environment Variable in the APK or App Bundle file path Step input field so that the Google Play Deploy Step can release all your build variants to the app store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Creating an Android App Bundle with Bitrise is almost the same as generating an APK. You have to tweak a few Step inputs to compile an Android App Bundle (.aab) file from your code, then get the bundle signed and deployed to Google Play Store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Creating an Android App Bundle with Bitrise is almost the same as generating an APK. All you have to do is tweaking a few Step inputs to compile an Android App Bundle (.aab) file from your code, then get the bundle signed and deployed to Google Play Store.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Step versions supporting bundle creation

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: The following Steps must be of the indicated version or newer - older versions of the Steps do NOT support bundle creation.

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Android Build 0.10.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Gradle Runner 1.9.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Android Sign 1.3.0 or newer

title: Generating and deploying Android app bundles
body: Deploy to Google Play 1.6.0 or newer

title: Generating an Android App Bundle file
body: You can create an Android App Bundle with either the Gradle Runner Step or with the Android Build Step.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Workflow Editor

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: bitrise.yml

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Insert the Gradle Runner Step after the Android Unit Test and Android Lint Steps in your Workflow.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Click the Config section of Gradle Runner.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: In the Gradle task to run input field, set, for example, bundleRelease or bundleDebug to create a bundle of your project.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: APK and AAB in the same Workflow

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: If you wish to generate an Android App Bundle and an APK in one Workflow, you can specify an additional task in the Gradle task to run input field: set the input value to bundleRelease assembleRelease to generate release versions.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Open the bitrise.yml file of your app.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: Insert the gradle-runner Step after the android-unit-test and android-lint Steps in your Workflow.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: In the gradle_task input of gradle-runner, set, for example, bundleRelease or bundleDebug to create a bundle of your project.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: APK and AAB in the same Workflow

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: If you wish to generate an Android App Bundle and an APK in one Workflow, you can specify an additional task in the gradle_task input field: set the input value to bundleRelease assembleRelease to generate release versions.

title: Using the Gradle Runner Step
body: This way the Step will generate an Android App Bundle instead of an APK.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: You can generate an Android App Bundle for your Android app with our Android Build Step as well:

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Workflow Editor

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: bitrise.yml

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Log in to Bitrise and select Bitrise CI on the left, then select your project.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Click the Workflows button on the main page.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Add the Android Build Step after the Android Unit Test and Android Lint Steps in your Workflow.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Provide the root directory of your Android project in the Project Location input field.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Go to Build type and select aab as build type.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: APK and AAB in the same Workflow

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: If you wish to generate an APK and an Android App Bundle in one Workflow, add two Android Build Steps after each other and configure one to build an Android App Bundle and the other to build an APK.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Open the bitrise.yml file of your app.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Add the android-build Step after the android-unit-test and android-lint Steps in your Workflow.

title: Using the Android Build Step
Using the Android Build Step
body: Provide the root directory of your Android project in the project_location input field.

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: Set the value of the build-type input to aab.

title: Using the Android Build Step
Using the Android Build Step
body: APK and AAB in the same Workflow

title: Using the Android Build Step
body: If you wish to generate an APK and an Android App Bundle in one Workflow, add two android-build Steps after each other and configure one to build an Android App Bundle and the other to build an APK.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Signing an Android App Bundle file works the same way as signing an APK: the most convenient method is to upload your keystore files to Bitrise and use the Android Sign Step:

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Workflow Editor

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: bitrise.yml

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Upload your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Open your Workflow in the Workflow Editor, and add the Android Sign Step AFTER the build Step.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure that the Keystore password, Key alias and the Key password input fields are filled out.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Default input values

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: If you have uploaded your keystore file and filled out the required credentials, the Android Sign Step's Keystore url, Keystore password, Keystore alias, and the Private key password inputs will get populated automatically!

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure the App file path input field displays the same output env var as the output of the build Step you've been using.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: For example, Android Build exports either a $BITRISE_APK_PATH or a $BITRISE_AAB_PATH Env Var that points to the APK and/or AAB file the Step generated. By default, this input points at these Env Vars.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Further configuration options

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Check out all the available configuration options of the Android Sign Step in the Workflow Editor. You can:

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Enable or disable memory page alignment with the Page alignment input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Use apksigner instead of the default jarsigner with the Enables apksigner input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Enforce a specific Signature Scheme with the APK Signature Scheme input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Upload your keystore file to Bitrise.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: In your app's bitrise.yml file, add the sign-apk Step AFTER the build Step - for example, android-build - in your Workflow.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body:
sign-android-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build: {}
 - sign-apk@1:
 inputs:

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure that the keystore_url, keystore_password, and keystore_alias inputs point to the correct location.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body:
sign-android-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build: {}
 - sign-apk@:
 inputs:
 - keystore_url: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL"
 - keystore_password: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD"
 - keystore_alias: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS"

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Default input values

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: If you have uploaded your keystore file to Bitrise and filled out the required credentials, you do not have to set the inputs at all: the default values, defined in the Step's step.yml configuration file, will point to the keystore file and the necessary credentials.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Make sure the android_app input field displays the same output Env Var as the output of the build Step you've been using.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: For example, android-build exports either a $BITRISE_APK_PATH or a $BITRISE_AAB_PATH Env Var that points to the APK and/or AAB file the Step generated. By default, this input points at these Env Vars.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: The Step will look for a binary to sign at the locations provided in this input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body:
sign-android-workflow:
 steps:
 - android-build: {}
 - sign-apk@1:
 inputs:
 - keystore_url: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL"
 - keystore_password: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_PASSWORD"
 - keystore_alias: "$BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_ALIAS"
 - android_app: "$BITRISE_APK_PATH\\n$BITRISE_AAB_PATH"

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Further configuration options

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Check out all the available configuration options of the android-sign Step in its step.yml file. You can:

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Enable or disable memory page alignment with the page_align input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Use apksigner instead of the default jarsigner with the use_apk_signer input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: Enforce a specific Signature Scheme with the signer_scheme input.

title: Signing an Android App bundle
body: And you should be done! If you would like to read more about Android code signing, check out our guide.

title: Deploying your Android App Bundle to Google Play
body: Deploying an AAB file isn't significantly different from deploying an APK to Google Play.

title: Deploying your Android App Bundle to Google Play
body: If you want to check the bundle prior to app store distribution, you can add the Deploy to Bitrise.io Step after the Gradle Runner / Android Build Steps. It uploads the bundle into the Artifacts tab of your Build’s page.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Deploying to Google play publishes your app to Google's online store. When you do it for the first time, this requires a bit more work than simply deploying to bitrise.io. Once the necessary configurations are in place, it becomes very simple.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: When configuring Google Play deployment for the first time, you need to link your Google Play Developer account to an API project, set up API access, and upload the service account JSON key to Bitrise.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Upload the first AAB or APK manually to Google Play using the Google Play Console.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Link your Google Play Developer Console to an API project.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Set up API Access Clients using a service account: Please note when you create your service account on the Google Developer Console, you have to choose json as Key Type.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Grant the necessary rights to the service account with your Google Play Console. Go to Settings, then Users & permissions, then Invite new user. Due to the way the Google Play Publisher API works, you have to grant at least the following permissions to the service account:

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Access level: View app information.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Release management: Manage production releases, manage testing track releases.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Store presence: Edit store listing, pricing & distribution.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: As an optional step, you can add translations to your Store Listing: Translate & localize your app.

title: Setting up Google Play deployment for the first time
body: Connect your Google service account to Bitrise.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: With Bitrise's Export Universal APK Step you can export a universal APK from the App Bundle, sign it with a keystore (or debug keystore), and deploy the APK to your test device before releasing the app to the Google Play Store.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: You can test an Android app on a test device even if the generated artifact is an App Bundle (.aab). With the Export Universal APK Step you can export a universal APK from the App Bundle, sign it with a keystore (or debug keystore), and deploy the APK to your test device before releasing the app to the Google Play Store.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Configuring this Step is super simple:

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Workflow Editor

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: bitrise.yml

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Insert the Export Universal APK Step after the Android Build Step in your Workflow.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Make sure the Android App Bundle path input's value is the output variable (BITRISE_AAB_PATH) of the previous build Step.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Using a different build Step

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: If you don't use the Android Build Step to build an AAB file, make sure that the input points to the AAB output of the Step you used. You can use an Environment Variable, or a direct local path or URL.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Make sure the Keystore URL input points to your Android keystore file.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: We recommend uploading the file to Bitrise and using the default Env Var: $BITRISEIO_ANDROID_KEYSTORE_URL. You can, however, use a local path or a URL as input value here.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB
body: Provide your credentials in the Keystore alias and the Keystore password inputs.

title: Exporting a universal APK from an AAB

title: iOS deployment
body: To use Bitrise to deploy an iOS app to any platform, you will need code signing files and you'll have to archive your Xcode project and export a signed IPA file.

title: iOS deployment

title: iOS deployment
body: Our guides delve into the specifics of these two basic requirements and show how to use our Steps to deploy the app in the exact way you want to!

title: iOS deployment
body: We also recommend checking out Release Management: it simplifies distributing your iOS and Android apps to testers or directly to app stores—all from one platform, from the CI you choose.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: Deploy an app to Bitrise to be able to download the IPA file and install it on devices specified in the app’s Development type provisioning profile. This way, your internal testers can easily test the app.

This way, once the build runs, a public install page will be available with a long and random URL which can be shared with others who are not registered on Bitrise. This URL is sent to the users in an email. The Notify: User Roles and the Notify: Emails inputs determine which users get the email.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: You can also find the public install URL here. Click the expand-arrow icon next to the IPA file to reveal the details and to find the toggle for the public install page. Make sure that’s toggled on so you’re able to send the link to non-Bitrise users.

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: To install an app from the public install page, you must use a native Safari browser of the iOS device. You cannot click the installation link if you’re browsing from a third-party app. For more information, check out Installing an .ipa file on test devices from the Artifacts tab

title: Deploying an iOS app to Bitrise.io
body: And that’s it! The file can now be installed on all the devices included in the app’s provisioning profile. Remember: the installation link must be accessed from an iOS device’s Safari browser!

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: You can deploy your Bitrise app to App Store Connect either to invite testers on Testflight or to release your app on the App Store.

body: Invite testers on Testflight.

title: Deploying an iOS app to App Store Connect
body: On Bitrise, you can either simply just upload your binary to App Store Connect or you can also submit it for review.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: To deploy the app to App Store Connect, we have two Steps:

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Deploy to App Store Connect - Application Loader is simple: it simply pushes an .ipa or .pkg binary file to App Store Connect. With this Step, you cannot submit the app for review on the App Store, for example.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: With the Deploy to App Store Connect Step, you can:

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Submit your app to the App Store for review.

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: You can upload apps of three different platforms (iOS, OS X, AppleTVOS).

title: Deploy to App Store Connect Steps
body: Tell Bitrise whether you want to upload your screenshots and the app’s metadata along with the binary.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Keep in mind that every time you want to push an app to App Store Connect, it must have a unique build and version number: increment either or both before deploying.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: Make sure you have a working connection to your Apple Developer account.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect

body: Either the app’s Apple ID or its Bundle ID is a required input. One of the two must be provided.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: If you set the Submit for Review to true, the Step will wait for your submission to be processed on App Store Connect and then submit the given version of the app for review.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect
body: The default value of the Skip App Version Update input is No. Change it only if you incremented the app version number in another way.

title: Deploying the app to App Store Connect

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: You can build and deploy your iOS app to a simulator, to show it off in a browser, for example, or to use it in testing.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: You can build and deploy your iOS application to a simulator, to show it off in a browser, for example. On Bitrise, we have a dedicated Step to build for a simulator: the Xcode build for simulator Step runs the xcodebuild command with an iOS simulator destination and generates an .app file.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: The .app file can be run on any simulator. On Bitrise, we have a Step to upload your app to Appetize.io: the Appetize.io deploy Step. With this Step, you can deploy your app so you can run it in a browser.

title: Deploying an iOS app for simulators
body: To build the app for a simulator, you do not need code signing files!

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: You can build an iOS app for an iOS or tvOS simulator platform.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: To do this, you'll need the Xcode Build for Simulator Step. The Step creates an .app file which you can install on any macOS device or send to, for example, testers. This requires no code signing at all, so it is an easy way to create a distributable version of your iOS app.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The Step also creates an .xctestrun file which you can use to run tests. Both the .app file and the .xctestrun file can be accessed by subsequent Steps referring to their output variable, and they can be downloaded as a build artifact.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The input sets the -project or -workspace option of the xcodebuild command. In most cases, if your app has been automatically configured by the project scanner during the process of adding the app, the default value does not need to be changed.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: In the Scheme input, set the name of the Xcode scheme you want to use to build the app.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: The input sets the -scheme option of the xcodebuild command. The default value is an Environment Variable created when adding the app and performing the first-time configuration. If you need to use a different scheme, you can type its name here.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Build configuration

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: By default, the Step will use the build configuration specified in the scheme. However, you can override it and use a different build configuration: add the name of the desired build configuration to the Configuration name input. This input is optional and you only need it if you don't want to use the build configuration specified in the selected scheme.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: You can create new build configurations in your Xcode project at any time: Adding a build configuration file to your project.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: In the Device destination specifier input, select generic/platform=iOS Simulator

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Optionally, set the Build settings (xcconfig), allow code signing input to CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=YES. This allows code signing files to be installed during the build.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: In most cases, you don't need code signing for an app built for a simulator. It might be required for certain test cases or third-party dependencies. To set up code signing, see iOS code signing.

However, you can override it and use a different build configuration: add the name of the desired build configuration to the configuration input. This input is optional and you only need it if you don't want to use the build configuration specified in the selected scheme.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: Optionally, set the xcconfig_content input with the value CODE_SIGNING_ALLOWED=YES. This allows code signing files to be installed during the build.

title: Building an iOS app for a simulator
body: In most cases, you don't need code signing for an app built for a simulator. It might be required for certain test cases or third-party dependencies. To set up code signing, see iOS code signing.

primary:

 - xcode-test@4: {}
 - xcode-build-for-simulator@0.12:

 - destination: generic/platform=iOS Simulator
